HEADLINE: Judge Bars Tylenol PM As Lookalike

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Grabbing an advantage in a bruising market battle for combination pain-killers and sleeping pills, Bristol-Myers Squibb announced yesterday that a Federal judge had issued a temporary injunction barring sales of Johnson & Johnson's hot-selling Tylenol PM.
Bristol-Myers, which makes Excedrin PM, quoted Judge Arthur D. Spatt of United States District Court in Manhattan as saying that Johnson & Johnson's McNeil consumer products unit had "acted in bad faith." McNeil had named and packaged Tylenol PM in a manner that "would result in confusion" among aching consumers seeking Excedrin PM, Bristol-Myers quoted the judge as saying. 
 Lawyers for Johnson & Johnson asked the judge to lift the injunction yesterday, saying the action "essentially shuts down a "$60-million-a-year business."
 
A Hot Segment
 Analysts said that sales figure indicated that Tylenol PM was on the verge of overtaking Excedrin PM, less than a year after its nationwide introduction last May. They said the combination pain-killers and sleepinducers had become the hottest segment of the $2.5 billion market for analgesics, which relieve headaches and other pains.
Robert Kniffen, a Johnson & Johnson spokesman, said the Tylenol PM package "was never intended to confuse consumers by making them think that Tylenol was another product, not do we think this packaging had that effect."
Tylenol PM's blue-green box and Excedrin's royal blue box with a blue-green stripe both list the same two active ingredients: an analgesic, acetaminophen, and an antihistamine, diphenhydramine, which can induce drowsiness.
"The evidence is clear that McNeil's purpose was to trade on the Excedrin PM mark with full knowledge that the Tylenol PM mark would result in confusion," Judge Spatt wrote in his legal opinion, Bristol-Myers said. "McNeil did not innocently select its potentially confusing mark and trade dress."
In a written appeal to Judge Spatt yesterday, Johnson & Johnson said the order would "cause a serious financial loss to McNeil." It said the order would keep Tylenol PM off the market while its current inventory -- six to eight weeks' worth of sales -- was repackaged.
Gregory L. Diskent, a lawyer with Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler in New York, added that "stopping shipments on such short notice would, to a significant extent, shut down all of McNeil's businesses for some period of time." He said this was because Tylenol PM shipments were mixed with those of other Johnson & Johnson non-prescription consumer products.
A Bristol-Myers spokeswoman said that Judge Spatt had rejected Johnson & Johnson's request yesterday afternoon for an immediate lifting of the temporary injunction. Johnson & Johnson said it would try again next week.
Despite the competitive heat generated by the analgesic sleeping pills, they are relatively small items for Johnson & Johnson, which had $12.45 billion in sales last year, and for Bristol-Myers, with 1991 sales of $11.6 billion.
Analysts said such legal actions, and some pushing and shoving to be noticed by consumers, were common in the crowded analgesic market. "It's a very competitive, static market, and everybody's trying to have the hottest brand," said Barbara Ryan of Prudential Securities. "The recession has put everyone's over-the-counter business under pressure."
Neil Sweig, an analyst with Brenner Securities, said that 1991 sales of Tylenol analgesic products were about $750 million, or 31 percent of the American pain-relief market.
He said Bristol-Myers Squibb's analgesics, including Excedrin, Bufferin and Nuprin, had sales of about $450 million, including $65 million to $70 million for Excedrin PM. The other main competitors are American Home Products' Advil and other analgesics, with $400 million in sales, and the Sterling Winthrop unit of Eastman Kodak, with $300 million, mainly in Bayer aspirin.
Bristol-Myers stock closed at $78.625 yesterday, up 12.5 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Johnson & Johnson was down 25 cents, to $99.50.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 0.45 to End Week Up 34.22

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks finished lower in cautious but heavy trading yesterday, brought on by the expiration of equity options and of February major market index futures. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped to 3,280.19, down 0.45 point for the day. The average gained 34.22 for the week.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a strong 261.7 million shares, but it was down from the 270.7 million traded on Thursday. The Big Board composite index dropped 1.14 points, to 227.46. There were 971 losing issues and 727 gaining ones.
 
Broader Indexes Mixed
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.44 points, to 411.46, while the American Stock Exchange index ended virtually unchanged at 412.85, down a hundredth of a percentage point. 
 In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite dropped 2.48 points, to 629.75, while the Russell 2,000 index of small company stocks lost 0.49 point, to 210.40.
Analysts said investors remained focused on economically sensitive cyclical stocks that were likely to bounce back when an economic recovery gathers steam. The Dow transportation average, which includes such cyclical companies, had reached a new high on Thursday.
Don Hays, director of investment strategy at Wheat, First Securities Inc. in Richmond, said that on the surface the market barometers did not move as much for a "double witching" day. He noted that trading came in waves and the volume was heavy.
"But under the surface, money-supply numbers are up significantly and point to an economic recovery," Mr. Hays said. "Short-term interest rates are higher, and there is increasing concern that all interest rates are headed in the same direction.
"And if rates move higher, some of that C.D. money that flowed into the stock market and helped underpin its recent advances could head back out."
Mr. Hays noted that the broad market indexes, both on Thursday and yesterday, were much weaker than the Dow industrials, a narrow measure of stocks. He said he thought the market was preparing for a more pronounced correction.
"I expect that when the correction takes place, it will come in two waves, with 3,080 on the Dow the bottom support for the first, and 3,040 for the second," he said. "This will set the stage for a later rally in May."
Blue-chip issues opened lower, as investors lightened their positions after a 50.32-point gain for the Dow on Thursday. Analysts said the weak bond market and the rise in money-supply figures weighed on the market as it opened, dampening hopes of another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve.
 
Time Warner Higher
 Time Warner shares rose on the news on Thursday that N. J. Nicholas Jr. had resigned as co-chief executive and president and was replaced by the vice chairman, Gerald M. Levin. Traders said the moves were seen as positives for investors, since the changes address questions about Time Warner's future management raised by concern over the health of the company's chairman, Steven J. Ross. The stock was as high as 102 3/4 yesterday, before retreating to close at 99 3/4, up 1 7/8.
Morgan Stanley began its coverage of Perrigo Inc., a manufacturer of store brands for over-the-counter medication and personal-care products, with a "buy" recommendation. The stock rose 2 3/4, to 35 1/2.
 
Triton Off $3.125
 Shares of Triton Energy slipped after the flow rates of an oilfield partly owned by the company apparently disappointed investors. The stock fell 3 1/8, to 41 7/8, but analysts said investors might have been too hasty, since the measure of a field is not the flow but the size of the reserves.
After the announcement of a 5-for-4 stock split and a dividend rise, shares of A. G. Edwards & Sons, the St. Louis-based brokerage, rose 1 1/2, to 33.

HEADLINE: Few Gains Reported In 3-Way Trade Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The sixth major round of talks on a North American free-trade agreement ended today in Dallas with no breakthroughs on the most politically controversial differences among negotiators, further lengthening the odds against an agreement this year, Administration and Congressional officials said.
The biggest disputes among the United States, Canada and Mexico concern the energy, banking, automobile and textile industries. The details of the negotations are being closely guarded by the Bush Administration, which is worried about political fallout in an election year, particularly the reaction to any agreement that would open American markets to Mexico, where industrial wages are as low as one-twentieth that of wages in the United States.
 
Disappointment and Frustation
 The lack of significant compromises has produced frustration in all three Governments and mutual recriminations. A senior American trade official, for example, said that while President Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico both wanted a broad pact that would dissolve many barriers, "somehow that hasn't gotten across to the individual Mexican negotiators." 
 A free-trade agreement this year, "is entirely feasible, but it's going to take the Mexicans' realizing that it's a lot more significant for their economy than for ours," said the senior official, who insisted on anonymity.
A Mexican official who insisted on not being identified disputed any contention that his country's negotiators were quibbling, adding that progress had been made in Dallas.
And not all American trade officials are critical of the Mexican negotiators. Another senior official said today that descriptions of Mexican intransigence were "dead wrong."
Officials who have either seen the draft text or received classified briefings on it say the United States and Canada are arguing over how much of a car must be made in North America for the car to enter the United States free of duties. The existing free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada sets this figure at a minimum of 50 percent, and Canadian and Mexican officials want the figure to stay there in hopes of encouraging Japanese and other foreign auto makers to set up factories in their countries.
With the political spotlight on automobiles since President Bush's trip to Japan last month, the United States is insisting that a 60 percent minimum is needed.
As for Mexico, the United States wants it to open its market to American oil-drilling equipment and service companies, but Mexico has refused, citing a provision in its Constitution barring foreign participation in the extraction of natural resources. American negotiators say this provision does not extend to equipment and services used in drilling.
The United States also wants Mexico to open its banking and financial- services markets within 3 to 10 years, a period Mexico contends is too short to give its companies enough time to become competitive.
In textiles and glass, where domestic industries could suffer immediately, the United States is the one seeking a longer period of adjustment, possibly as much as 20 years.
 
Two Presidents to Meet
 President Bush and President Salinas will discuss trade, among other subjects, at a private breakfast on Thursday during a five-nation conference on narcotics in San Antonio, a White House official said.
Documents describing the United States negotiating positions, although already presented to Mexican and Canadian officials, have been classified as secret by the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills. That means only a few copies of the documents are available, in Congressional committee safes, and public discussion of their contents is illegal. Representative Marcy Kaptur, an Ohio Democrat who has been one of the leading opponents of the proposed agreement, said no one on her staff had read the draft text because no one had the necessary security clearance. And while Administration officials have held briefing sessions, "there's no opportunity for suggestions or changes," she said.
Kathleen A. Lydon, the spokeswoman for Mrs. Hills's office, said that members of Congress had been encouraged to seek security clearances for their staffs and that the secrecy was necessary. "You cannot negotiate in a fish bowl if you want a good agreement," she said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Gains While Gold Prices Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Israeli military clashes in southern Lebanon, economic problems in Germany and rising interest rates in the United States combined yesterday to bolster the dollar's value against leading foreign currencies.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery dropped $2, to $351.20 an ounce. A late bid at the Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $351.20 an ounce, down $1.90. 
 Analysts said battles on Thursday between the Israeli military and Palestinian forces in southern Lebanon raised anxiety among currency traders, causing some to buy dollars, which are generally considered a safe haven at times of turmoil.
"People are a little skittish that there may be some strike, whether they are either pre-emptive or defensive," said Curtis Perkins, currency trader for the Chemical Banking Corporation. "That's helping fuel the upside for the dollar."
Also helping the dollar were rising interest rates in the Treasury bond market and a growing money supply, said Ronald Holzer, chief currency dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
The Federal Reserve reported late Thursday that a widely watched measure of the nation's money supply, known as M-2, was growing at an annual rate of 5.5 percent. Economists say the growth, chiefly in cash in circulation and savings accounts, is a sign the economy will pick up momentum soon.
Germany's continuing troubles with reunification hurt the mark, analysts said. Labor talks between Germany's banks and workers are being closely watched because of a strike threat.
The dollar was quoted at 1.6590 German marks in late New York trading, up from 1.6450 late Thursday. In London, the dollar fetched 1.6495 German marks, up from 1.6470.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7470, from $1.7505 late Thursday. In late trading in New York, sterling was quoted at $1.7400, less expensive than $1.7520 late Thursday.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a close of 128.65 Japanese yen, from 128.60 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 128.70 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 128.95 yen, up from 128.60 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5020 Swiss francs, up from 1.4865; 5.6390 French francs, up from 5.5950; 1,243.75 Italian lire, up from 1,234.00, and 1.18675 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18365.

HEADLINE: Bashing Is Dangerous and Avoidable

BYLINE: By Richard Holbrooke; Richard Holbrooke, a managing director at Lehman Brothers, was Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific affairs in the Carter Administration.

 BODY:
In the last two months, U.S.-Japanese relations have declined more than at any time since the anti-American demonstrations in Tokyo in 1960. Yet nothing fundamental has changed between the two nations to precipitate this shift. It is the result of nothing more -- or less -- than a failure of leadership on both sides.
Each side has always had its protectionist politicians, businessmen and journalists who criticized the other nation, sometimes fairly, sometimes not. But never before have the leaders of the two nations allowed themselves to become part of the problem by crossing the fine line dividing constructive criticism from demagogy. 
 This is particularly inexcusable because George Bush and Kiichi Miyazawa are personal friends and are knowledgeable about each other's nations. Neither would have wanted this to happen -- yet their own actions and statements created the current mini-crisis.
How it happened and what should be done about it are questions that must be addressed immediately, not only by the two leaders but by everyone affected by the relationship. And that means practically everyone in both nations.
When President Bush unwisely changed the focus of his December trip from cooperation on the global agenda to dealing with his domestic problems, his implicit message was clear: Japan was responsible for America's current economic problems. Mr. Miyazawa's response was also surprising. As the most fluent English-speaking leader in Japanese history, with hundreds of American friends (and an American son-in-law), he surely understood that comments such as those about the American "work ethic" would echo blatantly anti-American comments that have been made by other senior Japanese officials.
The truth is, of course, that trade questions cannot be reduced to simple formulas. The U.S., as President Bush himself admitted during his Asian trip in December, is not always "pure" itself. The economic differences between the two nations have actually narrowed significantly in the very period of time in which the noise level has risen. In fact, the American trade deficit with Japan has decreased 27 percent in the last three years. Hundreds of other statistics that show the true complexity of the relationship have been similarly buried in the avalanche of recent publicity.
But while the Japanese have taken many steps on trade that once seemed unlikely or even impossible, they have failed utterly to explain themselves to the American public. Passive for years, the Japanese now respond with highly inflammatory comments (some of which are already being used in advertisements on American television for American-made products).
Everyone knows -- and has paid rhetorical lip service for years -- to the proposition that these two mightiest of economies (together amounting to 40 percent of the world's gross national product) have a responsibility to address the pressing world problems that during the cold war received insufficient attention.
But just when the cold war has finally end and the moment had arrived to put substantive flesh on those rhetorical bones, two weak leaders allowed domestic politics to turn them away from their original (and worthy) game plan and toward pandering to their own protectionist constituencies. In a word, political weakness drove President Bush and Prime Minister Miyazawa into positions with which neither man could possibly feel comfortable -- and from which they must extricate themselves.
Instead of postponing his trip to Washington, as he has just done, the pro-American Prime Minister should reschedule his visit to the pro-Japan President. Then both men, even in this political season, should tell the people of both nations the truth: while we have many problems to resolve, we have even more opportunities before us if we work together. If they continue to fail in their responsibilities as leaders of two great nations, both countries will descend into economic and trade wars, whose effects would be disastrous.
Surely, Mr. Bush and Mr. Miyazawa both know this. Why don't they say so, loudly and firmly?

HEADLINE: The Pros and Cons of Using a Discount Broker

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
It's not just people who pump their own gas or buy groceries in bulk who are willing to make extra efforts to save money. People with capital to invest in stocks and bonds like low prices, too.
More and more individual investors, twice the proportion of a decade ago, are flocking these days to discount brokers. The discounters, born in 1975 when the Federal Government banned price-fixed commissions, now offer an increasing array of sophisticated products and services. 
 Discounters are enjoying the return to the market of individual investors who have helped to propel the Dow Jones industrial average and other economic gauges to new peaks in recent months. "The public's back in -- big time," said Leslie C. Quick 3d, the president of the Quick & Reilly Group, one of the discount industry's Big Three. Institutions do not use discounters because they have the leverage to negotiate very low commissions with full-service brokers.
Discounters don't suit all individuals, either, certainly not the investor who wants somebody to supply ideas or to help decide whether it's time to sell the General Motors shares inherited from a favorite uncle. But for do-it-yourselfers who generate their own investment ideas and who need no hand-holding when the market gets rough, discounters make a great deal of sense. They now collect at least 10 percent of all commissions paid by individual investors.
Besides commissions that are typically 40 to 50 percent of those charged by the large full-service brokers, discounters have another feature that many find at least as valuable: no salesman will call.
Charles R. Schwab, the chairman of the company bearing his name, set a goal of making his operation "a safe haven for the personal investor, a place free from sales pressure and conflict of interest." Only the investor who has been pestered at an inopportune moment to buy a hot stock that subsequently loses value -- and then had the broker feign ignorance as to where this dud came from -- can fully appreciate this.
Unlike brokers at the full-service firms, who are paid a commission based on the number of shares bought and sold, not the profits customers make, discounters use only salaried personnel. This means you are dealing with an order-taker who never faces the common industry predicament that what is best for the broker -- often a generous extra commission for helping to unload stock the firm has itself acquired -- is rarely best for the client.
 
The Big Three
 Although there are a few dozen discounters, three have come to dominate the field. The biggest is Charles Schwab & Company, with headquarters in San Francisco. Schwab has 158 offices and about 45 percent of the business. It is rapidly staking out the up-market territory between the bare-bones discounters, some of them one-office operations, and the full-service brokers like Merrill Lynch.
The other large discounters are Fidelity Brokerage Services Inc., part of Fidelity Investments in Boston, and Quick & Reilly in New York. Fidelity Brokerage has 66 offices and about 30 percent of the business, and Quick & Reilly has 75 offices and about 12 percent of the market.
Quick & Reilly, which generally has the lowest rates of the national concerns, is "more conservative" than the others, and its clientele, with an average age around 50, is somewhat older and wealthier, Mr. Quick said.
 
Sales and Services
 All the discounters sell a wide variety of stocks, bonds, options and money-market and other mutual funds. None of them deal in commodities. Schwab and Fidelity offer sophisticated all-purpose accounts -- Schwab One and Fidelityplus -- which have $5,000 initial-deposit minimums and incorporate Visa debit (not credit) cards. These accounts collect proceeds from the sale of securities, pay interest, offer check writing and produce a consolidated monthly statement that includes a valuation of the portfolio. The Quick & Reilly version has no Visa card.
Heavy investment in technology, especially by Schwab, has made it progressively easier to get quotations and enter trades, using a personal computer and telephone lines. In fact, automated trading is confined mainly to discounters since full-service firms shun it as a threat.
The discounters now even offer investment research, albeit at extra cost. Schwab promotes the availability of the latest information on 5,000 companies from such sources as Reuters, Standard & Poor's and Media General. The first report is $9.50; subsequent reports are $12.50 each. The company also provides copies of Standard & Poor's well-known quarterly stock reports on nearly 4,000 companies at $3.50 each.
Customers of discounters are of all kinds, ranging from the three-transactions-a-year investor who lives on dividends to the in-and-out trader who is the biggest beneficiary of low commissions. Mr. Quick said that 20 percent of his concern's customers account for 70 percent of its business.
One drawback of using a discounter, some customers maintain, is that annual reports and other company information seem less likely to reach them than the customers of full-service brokers. All brokers are obliged to relay such communications when securities are held in the firm's name. While acknowledging the problem, Mr. Quick said that in many cases, it reflected penny-pinching on the part of corporate management, which may treat a discount brokers' customers as second-class citizens.
While brokers increasingly discourage the practice, it may be worth the time, trouble and possible expense to have shares registered in your name and then to have the certificates mailed to you, insuring that you get all company reports.
 
 
 
WINNING STRATEGIES FOR INVESTORS
 It's essential that the do-it-yourself investor learn some time-tested rules. Here's some advice from experts on and off Wall Street.
Buy shares in good-quality, growing companies, preferably ones that you know about firsthand.
Spread your money over a variety of securities, and diversify further by investing in numerous industries. Don't hesitate to gain diversity by investing in mutual funds.
Be patient. Invest for a minimum of several years. If you wish, use dollar-cost averaging. This means you buy the same dollar-amount of stock at regular intervals, a technique that means you buy more shares when prices are low and thus insure that your average cost over time will be less than the stock's average price.
Find your comfort zone when it comes to risk. One Wall Street adage divides people into those who want to eat well and those who want to sleep well. But it's possible to do both, at least sometimes.
Ignore 95 percent of the tips you get, and keep in mind that some of the other 5 percent may involve information that can get you into trouble with the law: inside information, for example.
Hold on to your winning stocks, and jettison the losers. Many investors sell their winners much too soon, and hang on to their losers much too long, reluctant to admit their error.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By George Johnson

 BODY:
SOMETHING TO DIE FOR, by James Webb. (Avon, $5.99.) For purely political reasons, a Secretary of Defense schemes with a battle-hungry admiral to convince the President and Congress that a good war is just what America needs. Written by a former Secretary of the Navy and author of "Fields of Fire," this novel "should push Mr. Webb onto anyone's list of first-class military-political writers," David Murray said in The Book Review last year.
LUCIUS D. CLAY: An American Life, by Jean Edward Smith. (Owl/Holt, $19.95.) As head of the military forces that occupied Germany after World War II, Gen. Lucius D. Clay used his extraordinary powers as benevolent despot to help shape the vanquished country into the economic power it is today. In fact, his biographer argues, had it not been for Clay, the United States might have let the Soviet Union take all of Germany. "Mr. Smith's biography is masterly," Stephen E. Ambrose said here in 1990. "Mr. Smith provides large sections of his interviews with Clay, mixing them with his own research and analysis quite successfully. . . . I recommend this book without reservation." 
 REQUIEM, by Shizuko Go. Translated by Geraldine Harcourt. (Kodansha, $6.95.) In a novel that has been called a Japanese "Diary of Anne Frank," a girl whose parents, brother and friends are killed in World War II finds herself left with nothing but her patriotism. " 'Requiem' is a difficult but moving stream-of-consciousness work about the futility of war and the immorality of indoctrinating the young with imperialistic ideals," Carol Ames said here in 1985. As part of its new series of fiction by Japanese women, Kodansha has also republished Geraldine Harcourt's translation of CHILD OF FORTUNE by Yuko Tsushima ($6.95), which tells the story of a divorced woman struggling against her society's pressures to conform.
PRESIDENT REAGAN: The Role of a Lifetime, by Lou Cannon. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.) To Lou Cannon, the reporter who covered Ronald Reagan's political career from the Sacramento Statehouse to the White House, he "may have been the one President in the history of the republic who saw his election as a chance to get some rest." This book, Mr. Cannon's third about the Reagan phenomenon, "is the best study of that enigmatic Presidency yet available," our reviewer, Herbert S. Parmet, said in 1991.
THE KNEELING BUS, by Beverly Coyle. (Penguin, $9.) In one of these connected stories about growing up in Florida in the 1950's, the family of a liberal Methodist minister is scandalized when grandmother joins the Seventh-Day Adventists. In 1990 our reviewer, Pamela Cytrynbaum, said reading the book "is like roaming through Disneyland as a child: you wander from image to image, discovery to discovery, and when you're finished you want to do it all over again."
NOTHING IF NOT CRITICAL: Selected Essays on Art and Artists, by Robert Hughes. (Penguin, $13.) When this book by Time magazine's art critic was published last year, our reviewer, Paula Weideger, called it "the brainy, witty and perceptive chronicle of the mad honeymoon that followed the marriage of art and financial speculation."
SHADOWS ON THE MIRROR, by Frances Fyfield. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) Sarah Fortune, a promiscuous London lawyer, is being pursued by two colleagues -- Malcolm, her corpulent ex-lover, and Charles, a handsome man with a violent streak. Last year our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, said Sarah and Malcolm are "the most endearing of lovers -- intelligent enough to be interesting, bruised enough to be sympathetic and unpredictable enough to be human."
DICKENS, by Peter Ackroyd. (Harper Perennial, $16.) At times this peculiar, 1,200-page biography of Charles Dickens "waddles along like a maudlin elephant that has attached itself to us against our will," James R. Kincaid said here last year. But he found virtue in the author's rare appreciation of how truly weird his subject was. "Mr. Ackroyd's great achievement is that he reinvests Dickens, that familiar figure of hearth and home, with an alien, slightly repellent mystery."
MAGIC HOUR, by Susan Isaacs. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.99.) A Long Island detective falls in love with the widow of a Hollywood producer who has been murdered at his home in the Hamptons. "Sailing through Susan Isaacs' new novel, 'Magic Hour,' is like polishing off an entire box of chocolate-covered chocolates," Helen Dudar said in The Book Review last year. "You know it can't be nourishing. But it is fun."
TALKING AT THE GATES: A Life of James Baldwin, by James Campbell. (Penguin, $10.) As a homosexual and a black, James Baldwin found life in the United States too much to bear. In this biography of the expatriate writer, James Campbell "has ably blended both scholarship and personal recollection," Michael E. Ross said here last year.
ANNE SEXTON: A Self-Portrait in Letters, edited by Linda Gray Sexton and Lois Ames. (Houghton Mifflin, $12.95.) When this collection of letters by the poet Anne Sexton was published in 1977, our reviewer, Margaret Atwood, said she was struck by "the sinuous, mercurial and engaging voice of . . . a flamboyant romantic, capable of extreme joy and extreme depression almost in the same minute." This edition includes a new foreword by Linda Gray Sexton, a daughter of the poet.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 59; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1955 words

HEADLINE: FOOD;
Sweet on Yams

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:
Everyone has a private dinner, at least everyone I know. A friend whose husband is out of town talks about her baked-potato supper as if it were a secret rendezvous. Another confesses to solitary evenings with Spam. On his bachelor evenings, one of my brothers looks forward to a meal of Frosted Flakes. Most private dinners are retro in origin and furtive in execution. In her book "Serve It Forth," M. F. K. Fisher calls such meals "secret eatings."
My mother's private dinner was a quart-size chocolate milkshake, and when she'd "had it with cooking," she served shakes to all of us. This happened perhaps five times in my entire life, but I remember each meal as an orgy, and I remember that she looked at once embarrassed and pleased. In the winter, her moments of despair or abandon, whichever it was, yielded hot chocolate and cinnamon toast. I adapted the menu during college: half a peck of popcorn, one tankard of instant hot chocolate. The meal endured for nearly a decade. 
 But now I bake yams. And so do a lot of people I know. They say it's because yams are so low in calories, high in carbohydrates and dense in beta carotenes, and because they pack such satisfying sweetness.
My own affair with yams began with their smell. That burnt sugary perfume reminds me of the pushcarts in Mexico City that hawk the toasted tubers. It takes me back to a New England fireplace where yams once roasted after a day of cross-country skiing. It reminds me of the smell that billows from Bob the Chef's restaurant in Boston, and from Sylvia's in Harlem. The smell is Thanksgiving, winter in Chinatown, a summer morning in a North Carolina market where I once sniffed sweet potato pie in the air. Every few months, on an evening when it's me and my yam, I waft among these places in the 40 minutes it takes to bake the sweet tuber, as the aroma slowly builds and detonates into one big blast of well-being in my kitchen.
Forgive the rhapsody. As Popeye would say, "I yam what I yam." And I am, by the way, not alone. In "Invisible Man," Ralph Ellison writes that the smell of Carolina yams roasting on a pushcart in Harlem, brought a "stab of swift nostalgia" that stopped him like a shot:
"At home we'd bake them in the hot coals of the fireplace, had carried them cold to school for lunch, munched them secretly, squeezing the sweet pulp from the soft peel as we hid from the teacher behind the largest book. . . . Yes, and we'd loved them candied, or baked in a cobbler, deep-fat fried in a pocket of dough, or roasted with pork and glazed with the well-browned fat; had chewed them raw -- yams and years ago."
What Americans call a yam is in fact a sweet potato, and the confusion is enduring and entrenched. The true yam, Dioscorea opposita, is a vining plant that probably originated in Asia, grows in the tropics and can reach a size of up to 600 pounds. On the Pacific island Ponape, writes Elizabeth Schneider in "Uncommon Fruits and Vegetables" yams are described as two-man, four-man and six-man yams, depending on how many it takes to lift them. It's tough to find even a two-hand yam in local groceries today.
According to "Seeds of Change," an exhibition at the Smithsonian that charts the interchange of Old and New World foods, Columbus may have started the confusion. On his famous journey of 1492, he was served sweet potatoes in the West Indies and wrote that they looked like yams and tasted like chestnuts. African slaves called them "nyam" or "nyami."
The sweet potato, or Ipomoea ba tatas, is a member of the morning-glory family that probably originated in Latin America. Today, Asia is a major producer, though the United States and Latin America are no weaklings in the international sweet-potato stakes. In "Why We Eat What We Eat," Raymond Sokolov writes that the International Potato Center in Lima, Peru, has identified more than 5,000 variations on the sweet potato.
The true yam has a neutral starchy flavor. The sweet potato, on the other hand, earns its name, even though the deeper its orange hue and the sweeter its taste, the greater the chance that it will be called a yam. In this country, the terms are interchangeable. So sacred is the tuber that the Trobriand Islanders in the South Pacific build ornate houses to display them. The Cubans reserve them for special occasions; in Japan they are used as a homeopathic fertility drug.
When Shakespeare was writing, the sweet potato, imported to England from Spain, was thought to be a potent aphrodisiac. "It was a luxury only to be enjoyed by the wealthy," according to "The History and Social Influence of the Potato" by Redcliffe Salaman. That reputation waned as sweet potatoes became a staple around the world. Yet the epicurean perversity to worship only the rare hasn't stripped the tuber of its mystique.
I have friends who now eat yams as they once ate an apple a day. They speak of yams as healthful, economical and convenient. But I suspect this is all just a way of rationalizing an evening alone with a yam.
I've edged toward going public with my private dinner. Even those who still think of yams as something baked with marshmallows have been converted. I began by slipping sweet-potato puree next to roast chicken and proceeded to scalloped versions, gratins and pan-fried cakes. Along the way I learned to buy medium-size yams that weigh about a third of a pound and are neither nicked or pocked; these tend to be sweeter and less woody than larger yams. It is best to store them in a cool place, but not the refrigerator.
The closest I've come to making yams the center of a meal was when I cooked them with risotto at a family reunion. And that may be as close as I ever get.
 
YAM SOUP WITH YOGURT
 
 6 medium yams, about 2 pounds, peeled, cut into 1-inch chunks
 1 red onion, peeled, coarsely chopped
 1 small clove garlic, peeled, finely chopped
 3 carrots, peeled, coarsely chopped
 1 rib celery, coarsely chopped
 1 bay leaf
 1 tablespoon fresh thyme leaves
1 1/2 quarts chicken broth, homemade or low-sodium canned
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper
 6 tablespoons plain low-fat yogurt
 6 sprigs flat-leaf parsley, stems removed, finely chopped.
1. Put the yams, onion, garlic, carrots, celery, bay leaf, thyme and chicken broth in a large pot. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Lower the heat and simmer until the yams are tender, about 30 minutes.
2. Puree the vegetables and broth in a blender until smooth. Pass the soup through a sieve. Continue to puree and strain until all of the vegetables and broth have been used. Season with salt and pepper.
3. Ladle the soup into bowls and garnish with dollops of yogurt and chopped parsley.
Yield: Four to six servings.
 
BAKED YAMS WITH RED ONIONS
 
 3 medium red onions, peeled, cut into paper-thin round slices
 3 medium yams, about 1 pound, cut into thin round slices
 2 cups apple cider
 2 teaspoons brown sugar
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground pepper
 1 tablespoon fresh thyme leaves
 1 tablespoon butter, cut into small pieces.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a 9-inch round or oval gratin dish, place the red onion and yam slices in alternate layers.
2. Put the apple cider, brown sugar, salt and pepper in a small saucepan and stir over medium heat until the sugar dissolves. Pour the hot cider over the onions and yams and sprinkle with the fresh thyme.
3. Distribute the pieces of butter over the top and cover the gratin dish with foil. Bake for 1 hour. Remove the foil and continue baking, basting often, until the onions and yams are tender, about 30 minutes.
Yield: Four to six servings.
 
RISOTTO WITH YAMS AND SAGE
(ADAPTED FROM THE UNION SQUARE CAFE, NEW YORK)
 
The broth:
 1 gallon chicken broth, homemade or low-sodium canned
 3 medium yams, about 1 pound total, peeled, cut in half
 1 carrot, peeled, cut into 1-inch pieces
 1 stalk celery, cut into 1-inch pieces
 
The garnish:
 1/2 teaspoon olive oil
 1 teaspoon water
 1/4 teaspoon kosher salt
 1/8 teaspoon cayenne pepper
 1 cup shaved almonds
 
The risotto:
 1 tablespoon unsalted butter
 1 white onion, minced
 3 cups Arborio rice
10 cups broth (see above)
 1/2 cup fresh minced sage leaves
 1 tablespoon minced fresh chives
 1 tablespoon grated Parmesan cheese
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper
 2 cups bitter greens, like mustard or dandelion, rinsed and shredded
 1 cup fresh mozzarella, cut into 1/4-inch dice.
1. Combine the chicken broth, yams, carrot and celery in a large pot and bring to a boil. Lower heat and simmer until reduced to 10 cups, about 30 minutes. With a slotted spoon remove 1 yam, cut it into 1/2-inch dice and set aside to use in preparing the rice. Remove the broth and remaining vegetables from the heat, puree in a blender and set aside to cool.
2. Meanwhile, make the garnish. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Combine the olive oil, water, salt and cayenne in a bowl. Add the almonds and toss to coat them. Spread the almonds on a baking sheet and bake until golden, about 15 minutes. Remove from the sheet and set aside. The recipe can be done ahead to this point for up to 3 days before serving; refrigerate the broth and the diced yam.
3. Forty minutes before serving, warm the yam broth over low heat and bring the reserved yam to room temperature if necessary. In a heavy pot, melt the butter over low heat. Add the onion, cover and cook until soft, about 5 minutes, stirring to avoid browning. Add the rice and stir well. Ladle in 1/2 cup of the broth and stir. Increase the heat to medium-high and for the next half hour continue ladling in the broth and stirring the rice to help it absorb the liquid and to prevent it from sticking. After 20 minutes, add the diced yam. When 1 cup of yam broth remains, the rice should be tender. If it is not, add simmering water and continue stirring until it is. Removefrom the heat immediately.
4. Vigorously stir in the remaining yam broth. This should make a very soupy porridge. Quickly stir in half the minced sage and chives and the Parmesan. Adjust seasoning with salt and pepper to taste. Stir in the greens and carefully stir in the mozzarella. Divide among bowls. Garnish with a sprinkling of the spiced almonds and the remaining fresh sage and chives and serve immediately.
Yield: Four large servings as a main course, or eight to ten as an appetizer.
 
YAM AND CELERY CUSTARD
 
 1 meaty ham hock, quartered
 1 bay leaf
 4 black peppercorns, crushed
 4 cups chicken broth, homemade or low-sodium canned
 2 medium yams, about 2/3 pound, peeled, coarsely chopped
 1 small onion, peeled, finely chopped
 1 small clove garlic, peeled, finely chopped
 2 carrots, peeled, coarsely chopped
 2 stalks celery, coarsely chopped
 1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves
 1 tablespoon butter
 2 eggs plus 2 egg yolks
 3/4 cup low-fat milk.
1. Put the ham hock, bay leaf and peppercorns in a small saucepan. Add the chicken broth and bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Lower the heat and simmer until reduced to 1 1/4 cups, about 45 minutes. Remove the ham hock and discard.
2. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Put the yams, onion, garlic, carrots, celery, thyme and 1/4 cup of the broth into a small baking dish or casserole. Cover with aluminum foil and bake until the vegetables are tender, about 45 minutes. Set aside to cool.
3. Grease a 9-inch round baking dish with the butter. In a blender, puree the vegetables with 1 cup of the broth until smooth. Add the eggs and milk. Pour the custard into the baking dish. Bake at 350 degrees until set, for 30 to 40 minutes.
Yield: Six servings.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: February 23, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2696 words

HEADLINE: Memo to the Democrats

BYLINE: By SIDNEY BLUMENTHAL AND JAMES CHACE; Sidney Blumenthal, a senior editor at The New Republic, is the author of "Pledging Allegiance: The Last Campaign of the Cold War." James Chace, the Luce Professor in Freedom of Inquiry and Expression at Bard College, is the author of "The Consequences of the Peace," to be published this spring.

 BODY:
George Bush's alpha and omega, the public opinion polls, are now signaling the most potentially important opening of the 1992 campaign: the foreign policy President is vulnerable on foreign policy. By late January, shortly after he limped back from Japan, polls showed that less than half of Americans approved of the way he was handling foreign policy -- the first time his approval rating had dropped below 50 percent in that vital category, the essence of his Presidential persona.
And yet the Democrats still don't seem to understand the political salience of confronting Bush on foreign issues. They either defer to his looming image as foreign policy wise man or render easy moral judgments about, say, his China policy. Both approaches play into the game plan of the Republicans, who will inevitably try to cast the Democratic nominee as weak and soft -- a "carping little liberal," as Bush has said -- incapable of a sustained and vigorous defense of the national interest. 
 The Democrats' opportunity to take the offensive on foreign policy is unparalleled since 1964. But for the Democratic candidate to defeat Bush and govern successfully, he must compellingly draw the connections between the Republican foreign policy and the insolvency that is sapping the country's strength. Suddenly, it is possible to depict George Bush as weak, an apostle of decline, while the Democratic nominee can present himself as the tribune of American strength and renewal. The Democrats, at last, have available to them potent themes -- progress versus paralysis, strength versus weakness. But their full political force can be brought to bear only by making the foreign policy case.
 
THE THEMES
The Democratic candidates must do more than claim the rhetoric of change. They must also display the substance that is the emblem of confidence and readiness. There are several central concepts that can provide the Democratic campaign -- and Presidency -- with a galvanizing sense of purpose.
The Democrats, to begin with, have neglected their own legacy, the legacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt, who forged a synthesis of idealism and realism and balanced the domestic and international agendas. Many of the candidates fatally assume that the path to success is to assign foreign policy to Bush (negative) and reserve domestic policy (positive) for themselves. With the end of the cold war, they seem relieved not to have to deal with foreign affairs.
But this is a staggering illusion. If they fail to redefine foreign policy, they will not only make themselves defenseless before Bush's attacks; without a new foreign policy, their hopes for the revival of domestic policy will be frustrated by continuing budget deficits. Quite simply, a new domestic agenda is impossible without a more realistic and less costly foreign one. While the candidates have put forward individual proposals, mostly for defense cuts, these in themselves do not constitute a foreign policy. What is missing at the beginning of a new era is the Rooseveltian imperative: the need for a new internationalism.
But the new internationalism must be based on the dictum of the great columnist Walter Lippmann. During World War II, while F.D.R. drafted plans for the postwar world, Lippmann laid down the cardinal principle of foreign policy: "Without the controlling principle that the nation must maintain its objectives and its power in equilibrium," he wrote, "its purposes within its means and its means equal to its purposes, its commitments related to its resources and its resources adequate to its commitments, it is impossible to think at all about foreign affairs." Insolvency, according to Lippmann, must eventually lead to nothing less than "disaster." It is this prospect that now faces Bush -- and the country.
During the cold war, our means expanded to meet expanded ends. Now our ends -- a crusade against "instability" and "uncertainty" -- are defined by the President so broadly and vaguely that they defy practical meaning. By the same token, the means to fight the cold war have not been remade to fit any new strategy. By failing to right an economy that has led the United States in less than a decade from being a creditor to a debtor nation that owes the world half a trillion dollars, Bush has violated the solvency principle. Through the peculiar combination of utopian rhetoric and myopic tactics that he substitutes for a foreign policy, the President is incapable of offering anything more than symbolic gestures to deal with the anarchic disorder that horrifies him.
Bush does not grasp the crisis into which he has plunged the country. But even if he did, his partisan commitments would make it virtually impossible for him to voice even a hint of understanding; for that would demand a searching critique of the past 12 years. Democrats should stress that Bush can no more break with the policy of insolvency than he can break from his party. The two have become one and the same. His Presidency, perforce, must lead to decline.
The Democrats should also hammer at the point that a second Bush term may well leave America ready to cede its place as the first economic power to Japan and soon thereafter to a united Europe led by Germany. On every major issue, the Democratic nominee should emphasize that the election will be a choice between decline and change, weakness and strength.
These are the themes. The next step is to translate them into concrete proposals that can emerge as campaign issues. We believe there are four central foreign policy issues that play into the Democrats' hands.
 
 
THE ISSUES
 NATO. The notion that Russia or the Commonwealth of Independent States is poised to send tank columns crashing through the Fulda Gap is patently absurd. Equally obvious is the fact that NATO has become obsolete. As an enormous, cold war military alliance, it is hardly configured to cope with the security needs of the new Europe. These include thwarting the rise of authoritarian regimes through military coups, intervening in civil wars and preventing existing boundaries from being altered by force. Still, the President stubbornly holds fast to the past, discouraging even a modest proposal by France and Germany to expand their joint military force to 50,000 troops from 4,200. Worse, by continuing to finance the anachronistic ends of the old order, Bush is deepening insolvency.
In his 1992 budget, President Bush calls for actual defense spending of more than $300 billion, and a five-year defense spending plan of $1.15 trillion (including the $50 billion in cuts outlined in his State of the Union address) -- numbers not adduced from any strategy but out of thin air. These projections are still loosely based on the now-phantom objectives of containing and deterring the defunct Soviet Union. Although the President has proposed withdrawing substantial numbers of troops from Europe, he plans to move them to the United States. This represents no savings at all; indeed, the costs of maintaining them at home may well be higher. At the very least, we will continue to allocate about half the defense budget -- some $150 billion -- to NATO's antiquarian defense of Europe.
Rather than clinging to a Western alliance that is directed at an invisible threat, the Democrats should propose a new European and Atlantic security organization that would include what remains of the former Soviet Union and the former Warsaw Pact countries, and insure that limited numbers of American troops remain on the continent with a purpose. The number of American troops could run as low as perhaps 50,000 -- the number is not a theological question -- but they would be there with a new mission. The central premise of the successor organization to NATO would be to assure Europeans that aggression by any country against its neighbor would be met with a united response.
Perhaps the most important element of the new alliance would be to compel the militaries of former Communist states to cooperate with their United States and European counterparts. Permanent participation in the multinational organization would lead inevitably to the democratic reform of the old military structures and mentalities, as occurred in the case of postwar Germany. The economic assimilation of eastern Europe into the West must be linked to military assimilation. Large-scale economic aid in the future would be contingent on military inclusion in the new security organization.
The establishment of a new Western alliance would be the rough analogue of the Marshall Plan and the founding of NATO -- the foundation for peace. It would also be the single greatest action in helping to bring our ends in line with our means. With savings of at least $150 billion (between $316 billion and $619 billion cumulatively for the rest of the decade, according to a Brookings Institution study), money would become available to support the numerous Democratic proposals to revitalize the nation, from health care to education to public works.
THE NUCLEAR THREAT. Our greatest military security threat today comes not from the weapons of the declared nuclear powers but from the proliferation of nuclear weapons to other countries -- North Korea, Iraq, Pakistan. Bush has rhetorically acknowledged the problem but has taken no effective steps to reduce the threat. He emphatically refuses to sign the comprehensive test-ban treaty, which is essential to induce the remaining nonnuclear countries to sign the nonproliferation treaty.
The Democrats should promise to sign the test-ban treaty, and further propose a suspension of economic aid to any nation that refuses to sign the nonproliferation treaty. The Democrats should point out that this policy would make it easier to isolate "crazy states" like Iraq from the start -- an alternative to Bush's early appeasement.
Having at last acknowledged the end of the cold war, and fitfully moving to reduce strategic nuclear warheads to perhaps as low as 4,700, Bush nonetheless has no strategic rationale for his numbers. The Democrats should argue for a policy of "minimum deterrence," which would mean reducing the long-range warheads on both sides to a minimum number, about 1,000 on each side and signing the test-ban treaty. Once again, the correct policy is also the less expensive policy, which allows Democrats to stand for growth and regeneration at home as well as strength and security abroad. In all this, Bush has again provided Democrats with a prime campaign issue, if only they would seize it.
BLOOD, SAND AND OIL. Bush will no doubt try to capitalize on the Persian Gulf war, which most Democrats opposed. So the Presidential candidates will have to concede that Bush achieved two of his aims: securing the Saudi frontier, thus thwarting Saddam's potential hegemony over the price of oil, and wresting Kuwait from Saddam. But they should stress how badly the President lost the peace. In retrospect, it appears that Bush went to war to make the Persian Gulf safe for feudalism. Not only was Saddam permitted to remain in power, he also was allowed to butcher Kurds and Shiites while our forces stood by.
The Arab-Israeli peace conference is one of the main means by which Bush is trying to justify the gulf war, as if the obligations incurred on all sides can yield a general conciliation. Certainly, it is praiseworthy to take up where Jimmy Carter's Camp David diplomacy left off. The conference may offer some promise of an agreement between Israel and the Palestinians on the West Bank for some form of autonomy and self-government. But it is hard to envision much else. In this respect, Bush risks American prestige on arranging a highly unlikely general peace that, should it fail, will arouse bitterness throughout the Middle East.
In any event, the Democratic candidates should stress that the gulf war belongs to the past, and they should emphasize where the war has left us strategically. In the world's most dangerously unstable region, the Administration has committed the United States as the guarantor of the balance of power. Hence, with no new world order in sight, the President seems on the verge of committing us to a longstanding and entangling involvement.
An alternative must include making a strong case for energy independence. Besides the obvious economic and environmental benefits, a renewed energy policy can be used to reduce the leverage the Persian Gulf states exercise over United States policy in the region. Once again, the Democratic candidates should expose Bush's posture of strength as a veneer for a deeper weakness. He is losing the future because he is bound to the past.
TRADE WARS. These days, most Americans feel more threatened by foreign trade than foreign military power. While ideologically committed to free trade, Bush has slid into a simplistic, unthinking version of "managed trade," extracting promises of foreign purchases in return for access to American markets. The Bush Administration's only other trade policy is to drive down the value of the dollar in an effort to make our goods cheaper. But a weak currency does not translate into a strong economy.
American voters consistently reject protectionist policies, sensibly recognizing that they sacrifice at least as many jobs as they save and that the reality of a global economy cannot be wished away. Thus, the Democrats should simply call for a "level playing field" and, once again, emphasize that it is the misguided Bush who is leading the country away from that goal.
The Democratic nominee should also strive to explain the cold war bargain that has landed us in this predicament. In the early cold war years, Washington actually granted allies, like Japan, special trade favors and access to our technology in return for allowing us to set up bases on their soil and provide for their security. In recent years, America has borne the exorbitant costs of maintaining a global military establishment in return for foreign capital to maintain the deficit that drains our ability to rejuvenate ourselves.
While the rest of the advanced economic powers engage in industrial strategies, Bush adheres to the myth of laissez faire. His ideological references to the strength of frontier individualism (a pose struck to fend off his right wing) obscure the actual insolvent bargain he has struck -- and his own reactive protectionism. Democrats should stress that as long as Bush clings to a foreign policy of insolvency, America can't hope to reverse the erosion of its technology, infrastructure and standard of living.
Clearly, the world needs new economic and financial institutions to replace or augment the trading system that was set up after World War II at Bretton Woods. There are no common rules for antitrust, dumping, subsidies or copyright of intellectual property, among other things. Without them, countries with coherent industrial strategies will always have an advantage. Free trade will not come about by ignoring these differences, nor by incantations of Ronald Reagan's rhetoric. Yet the ultimate practitioner of "voodoo economics" is none other than the one who gave it its fitting name.
GEORGE BUSH, unfortunately, is a man of the past. His reactive, patchwork approach in domestic policy is precisely mirrored in foreign policy. In both realms, Bush's ends are hollow, his means bankrupt. But his failure to conceive a solvent foreign policy is not due mainly to his reactive approach. By training and experience, Bush was admirably prepared to lead the United States in tactical, cold war maneuvering of the sort that has become obsolete. But his world view is now an anachronism. Further, he can hardly be expected to lead against the very policies of national paralysis he has promulgated for more than a decade. He has no choice but to take his place as the standard-bearer of decline.
The task of the Democratic Presidential candidate is to make clear just how costly it will be at home and abroad to continue with Bush's insolvent regime. In the triumphal aftermath of the cold war, George Bush is presiding over the dissolution of the American Century.

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
J. Carter Brown . . . and Beyond

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
When J. Carter Brown surprised almost everyone last month and announced his resignation as director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, he brought to a close a chapter in the evolution not only of his own institution but of all American museums. Such was the impact of his tenure that before Mr. Brown assumed his post in 1969, the image of an art museum was one thing, and today it is something else.
Although he was hardly alone in reshaping that image, his contribution was vital. The quiet gallery that he took over has become a strutting giant on the international stage, a purveyor of major traveling exhibitions and a center for the study of the visual arts. With its glamorous addition designed by the architect I. M. Pei that doubled the institution's physical size, and its wide array of educational and scholarly programs, the gallery is an exemplar of what museums aspired to become during the expansionist 1970's and 80's. And the brilliant and energetic Mr. Brown has come to epitomize the museum director. 
 Following upon the unsteady lead of his occasional rival, Thomas Hoving, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Mr. Brown successfully realized the aim of expanding the role of museums in public life. In his resignation letter, in which he cited family and other reasons for his decision, he stated that "it is time the gallery should have the opportunity of fresh leadership." With major museums from Brooklyn to Boston to Detroit facing hard times, perhaps the 57-year-old Mr. Brown is anticipating that the museum of the 90's will be a less lavish place than the one he helped to create, and that the person at its helm will have to be his opposite, a master of retrenchment.
Central to his vision has been the big exhibition. It is fitting, and perhaps not coincidental, that he chose to resign shortly after the close of the largest show that the gallery has ever presented, "Circa 1492: Art in the Age of Exploration," which brought together about 600 objects from Europe, Africa, Asia and the Americas. During the 1960's, when Mr. Brown was being groomed for the directorship by his predecessor, John Walker, the gallery had only one space devoted to temporary shows. Exhibitions tended to be modest, spartan affairs.
Since taking over, Mr. Brown has vastly broadened the offerings, staging temporary displays of the art of many cultures, not just the European and American art to which the gallery limits its own collection. He has proved to be a master at beguiling government and corporate officials into sponsoring mass-appeal shows. The $94 million, 450,000-square-foot East Building that Mr. Pei designed, which opened in 1978 millions of dollars over budget, may be the clearest expression of Mr. Brown's penchant for grand, theatrical statements.
Whether it was "Treasures of Tutankhamun" (1977) or "Treasure Houses of Britain" (1986) or the multicultural extravaganza that was "Circa 1492," Mr. Brown has embraced the blockbuster with an enthusiasm that has drawn criticism upon the gallery as it has also drawn large numbers of people to it. Annual attendance shot up from about one million visitors a year when he took over to a high of seven million.
Despite his roots (as a descendant of the family that founded Brown University) and his patrician manner, which have served him well at raising financial and political support in high places and at playing host at the gallery's glittering parties, Mr. Brown is at heart a populist. He conceives of the National Gallery as just that -- the nation's art museum, supported by taxpayers, and as such, a place that must be inclusive and accessible. This is one of Mr. Brown's greatest strengths. He has been an exceptionally eloquent advocate for the importance of art, and the gallery's popularity has proved his point.
The emphasis on special exhibitions has not come without costs. He has been criticized for putting too much stress on blockbusters and on shows that seem longer on style than on content, an attitude suggested by the unusual power that he has vested in the gallery's design department even over selecting and organizing exhibitions.
The criticism is not altogether fair. For every shallow exhibition like the one of Andrew Wyeth's "Helga" paintings in 1987, there have been many more substantive shows, both small and large. In recent years, the gallery has offered a string of displays focusing on single works of art, like Titian's "Flaying of Marsyas" and Bellini's "Feast of the Gods," that are models of their kind. It has organized major exhibitions of Veronese, Van Dyck, Matisse and Jasper Johns, to name a few, that are among the most stimulating and thoughtful shows to have been seen anywhere.
Mr. Brown has nonetheless thrown himself most enthusiastically and publicly into projects like "Treasure Houses of Britain," with its array of hundreds of decorative and other objects, and "Circa 1492." Whatever their intent, these gigantic displays flaunted the National Gallery's clout at extracting priceless loans from governments, institutions and private collectors around the world. In turn, the gallery has had to reciprocate by lending out its own treasures. Transporting valuable objects without compelling reasons has only heightened skepticism about the gallery's exhibition policies.
Mr. Brown has also stressed shows of private collections that can include remarkable and usually inaccessible works, but that have sometimes sacrificed scholarship to the stroking of collectors' egos. The gallery has hardly been alone in any of these practices, yet no American institution, except for the larger Metropolitan, has had a more ambitious and more high-profile exhibition program. The history of American museums during the last 20 years is replete with stories of Mr. Brown jousting, sometimes acrimoniously, with Mr. Hoving and Philippe de Montebello, Mr. Hoving's successor at the Metropolitan, over traveling shows like "Tutankhamun," "The Vatican Collections" and "Titian," and for the corporate support they require.
One often repeated story involves "The Splendor of Dresden" exhibition of 1978. Mr. Brown was incensed when he discovered that the Metropolitan had arranged to do the show. He had broached the idea with the State Department after learning that diplomatic relations between the United States and East Germany would soon be normalized. The department asked that he wait while negotiations between the countries were ironed out, and he complied, only to learn that the New York museum was pursuing the project. Mr. Brown called his friend David Rockefeller, whose name he had seen in a State Department cable mentioning the show, to referee a treaty with Mr. Hoving and the Metropolitan's chairman, C. Douglas Dillon. The result was a joint undertaking that began its American tour as the inaugural show at the National Gallery's East Building and concluded its tour at the Metropolitan.
The popular success of special exhibitions at those two institutions promoted a pattern for museums across the country through the 1970's and 80's. Blockbusters became one obvious way to fuel their budgets and build popular support for new buildings, acquisitions and programs -- which in turn had to be sustained by more blockbusters. What happened to overextended American businesses in the last few years happened to a number of museums. At a time when the economy is sagging and blockbusters have become riskier and more complicated, museums are scrambling to find ways to stay afloat and avoid crippling cutbacks.
As director, Mr. Brown has persuaded Congress to increase annual Federal spending on the gallery, from $3 million to $52 million. One obvious challenge for Mr. Brown's successor will be to sustain that level of support at a time of declining corporate help and widespread calls for slashing the Federal budget.
Another challenge involves the permanent collection. Mr. Brown is not best known for acquisitions, although he did strengthen the gallery's holdings in various ways. Some 20,000 works have come into the gallery's possession during Mr. Brown's tenure, among them Georges de la Tour's "Repentant Magdalene" and Jusepe de Ribera's "Martyrdom of Saint Bartholomew." The Old Master drawings department has been improved by recent acquisitions like those from the Ian Woodner collection. And Mr. Brown has overseen the creation of almost the entire 20th-century collection, which includes such postwar landmarks as Jackson Pollock's "Lavender Mist" and Barnett Newman's "Stations of the Cross."
A policy prohibiting the sale of works by the gallery has attracted various donors, like the Mark Rothko Foundation -- as that policy has also discouraged the gallery from acquiring objects by less established artists. And Mr. Brown has loudly touted the gallery's status as the nation's art museum to entice donors on patriotic grounds -- even if that sometimes has rankled with museums in the cities where those donors live.
Yet the astronomical prices for art in the 1980's rendered inadequate even the $56 million acquisitions fund that Mr. Brown worked hard to put together. And to see works of art that have been bought in recent years at museums like the Nelson-Atkins in Kansas City and the Kimbell in Fort Worth is to realize that ultimately he did not concentrate on this area with the energy he devoted to shows.
His sympathy for areas like 16th- and 17th-century Northern European paintings and his apparent lack of enthusiasm for German Expressionist paintings, of which the gallery has notably few examples, has skewed purchases. Publications devoted to the permanent collection have taken a back seat to exhibition catalogues. And although the curatorial and conservation staff he has assembled includes distinguished members, it does not challenge Mr. Brown's status as the gallery's star.
Now that the age of the imperial museum seems on the wane, the role for Mr. Brown's successor, as for American museum directors elsewhere in the 90's, looks increasingly to be as champion of the permanent resources rather than impresario of temporary spectacles.
This does not mean that museums will have to be less intriguing places. Their collections can be put to more creative uses in exhibitions like the ones that have been so successful at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the Museum of Modern Art in New York, and the gallery's own focused displays. Museums that have justified blockbusters by claiming they made converts to art will be called upon to prove it in lower-budget shows that promote closer and more thoughtful looking. The possibility is an increased respect for the permanent holdings.
Mr. Brown has been America's premier art impresario for two decades. It will not be easy to find a director who can shape the future of museums as potently as he has helped to shape their past.

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
From Bill Morrissey, Blue-Collar Angst With a Folk Touch

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
In the title song on Bill Morrissey's fourth album, "Inside," the narrator admits to his companion that their treadmill life certainly "ain't Hollywood." Singing in a quiet, gravelly voice against which Suzanne Vega's softer harmony rings like a mournful echo, Mr. Morrissey, a 40-year-old folk singer and songwriter from New England, describes the dreary existence of an unemployed worker who has recently given up drinking. He fixes dinner each night when his wife, a waitress, returns to their furnished room. Then they wait up to watch the late movie on a black-and-white television set.
Winding through the stark, matter-of-fact language is a solo violin played by Johnny Cunningham that evokes all the regrets and disappointments that cannot be stifled. Despite adversity, however, the relationship seems to be holding. "And you won't leave soon/ Because I know/ You're just like me/ With no place to go," the singer reminds her. "Call it love if you think you should/ There's no need to explain." 
 "Inside," like Mr. Morrissey's best songs, has a terseness, precision of detail and a tone of laconic understatement that relate his lyrics to the fiction of writers like Raymond Carver and Richard Ford. In the lineage of pop, Mr. Morrissey belongs to a modern acoustic folk tradition that goes back to Woody Guthrie and that includes not only the early Bob Dylan and John Prine but also Bruce Springsteen and Tom Waits in their more folkish, songs-of-the-common-man modes.
Mr. Morrissey, who grew up in Acton, Mass., and Hartford and attended Plymouth State College in New Hampshire, is no overnight sensation. He has performed for two decades on the New England coffeehouse circuit while drifting from job to job and town to town, punching factory time clocks and working on fishing boats, in gas stations and fast-food parlors.
Many of his songs are steeped in a mood of stiff-upper-lip, blue-collar angst. Their grayness is often augmented by stark images of the landscape of industrial New England in winter. The pervasive chill is frequently thawed by whisky and a playfully ironic sense of humor.
Mr. Morrissey released his first album, "Bill Morrissey" (Philo/Rounder 1105; CD and cassette), in 1984, and re-recorded its songs last year with improved sound, adding three new selections. Two albums, the austere "North" (Philo/Rounder 1106; all three formats), and the more rollicking "Standing Eight" (Philo/Rounder PH 1023; all three formats) followed. "Inside" (Philo/Rounder PH 1145; CD and cassette) is Mr. Morrissey's best-sounding record, largely because of Mr. Cunningham's expressive fiddle, which threads through five songs, pining dolefully on some numbers, dancing the jig on others.
The tight-lipped blue-collar realist is only one of several aspects of Mr. Morrissey's musical personality to be showcased favorably on the new album. Another side is a surreal trickster who suggests a milder mannered offshoot of the mid-1960's Bob Dylan. "Everybody Warned Me" is a gently phantasmagoric road song that recycles "look out kid," the same warning that punctuated Mr. Dylan's "Subterranean Homesick Blues." "Gambler's Blues" is crowded with allegorical figures named the Jack of Diamonds, Miss Downtown and St. Louis, a fellow who toots a broken horn. The title character of "Sister Jo" is a close spiritual relative of the threatening harpies who appear in such Dylan songs as "She Belongs to Me" and "Just Like Tom Thumb's Blues."
On "Inside" Mr. Morrissey also has a streak of the blues singer in him, most strongly in "Robert Johnson," a tribute to the seminal blues guitarist in which John Jennings's electric twangs echo Johnson's signature sound. But it is in the sober confessional monologues of characters like the narrator of "Inside" and "Off-White" that Mr. Morrissey's talent burns most intensely.
A bare-bones waltz, "Off-White" describes two people who have been burned but who are still anticipating a second marriage. This time, the narrator promises, "We'll hire us a band/ That won't play 'Proud Mary'/ No matter how late it gets." He adds: "Maybe you weren't my first/ The way I wasn't yours. But the last love is the sweetest of all."
Even better is "Man From Out of Town," the story of a drifter who settles down only to watch his home and possessions go up in flames on a rainy night. In the middle of the fire he imagines he hears the telephone ringing inside. The story works as both a vignette and a bleak parable of a rambler's inability to put down roots once he has left home. In one verse, the man compares a priest heeding Jesus's voice to his own response to the alluring sound of a train in the distance.
Not the least of Mr. Morrissey's contributions to modern folk music is the way his songs imprint an indelible vision of working-class New England onto the broader map of American pop literature. At their best and leanest -- conjuring up a landscape of church steeples, silver maples and wind-blasted seacoast streets -- Mr. Morrissey's songs have the force of poetry.

HEADLINE: FILM;
A Wannabe Who Got to Be

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:
Some 15 years ago, Griffin Dunne became a movie producer because he wasn't getting work as an actor. Now he's working as an actor in a play about a guy who wants to become a movie producer.
The play, "Search and Destroy" by Howard Korder, which opens Wednesday at Circle in the Square Uptown, concerns Martin Mirkheim, a ne'er-do-well with big dreams and a big tax bill, who is convinced that if he can buy the movie rights to an obscure book by a mysterious self-help guru his problems will be over. Needless to say, he suffers disillusionment at the hands of the guru, and is swept into a maelstrom involving cocaine-dealing and murder. The play, a black comedy by the author of "Boys' Life," is directed by David Chambers. 
 "It's about a guy who wants to do what I do for a living," Mr. Dunne said over a plate of pasta, heavy on the garlic. "He wants to validate himself by doing something creative. But he doesn't want to do the work."
For Mr. Dunne, a boyish-looking 36 years old, the work has been divided between acting and producing since he and two partners, Amy Robinson and Mark Metcalf, bought an option on the Ann Beattie novel "Chilly Scenes of Winter." "We had no idea how to make a movie," Mr. Dunne said, recalling that the three made cold calls to production managers, asking, "What do we do now?"
The movie, which was released as "Head Over Heels" in 1979, featured Mr. Dunne in a small role, which, he said, attracted some acting offers. Since then, he's appeared in several films, including Martin Scorsese's "After Hours," and "Once Around," which was produced by Double Play Productions, the company he formed with Ms. Robinson. On the horizon for Double Play is "The Foreigner," a play by Larry Shue, adapted by the novelist Don DeLillo, and a screen version of Scott Spencer's novel "Waking the Dead," in which Mr. Dunne will also star.
It all began serendipitously in the late 1970's, Mr. Dunne said, when he was an unemployed actor managing the popcorn concession at Radio City Music Hall. One day, he and Ms. Robinson and Mr. Metcalf drove to Cambridge, Mass., unannounced and uninvited, to persuade Ms. Beattie to sell them the rights to the film.
"We called from a corner and said, 'Can we come over?' " Mr. Dunne remembered. "Later, she said she gave us the rights because when we arrived, it was like three of her characters walking in the door."
