HEADLINE: Focus: California;
Pension Funds for One-Family Houses

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
THE recent decision by the California Public Employees Retirement System to invest $375 million in the construction of one-family houses within the state is being welcomed by builders here, who have been squeezed by a severe shortage of financing.
The first large-scale investment by a public pension fund in residential construction is being watched closely by builders across the country, who think it could spur similar moves by public pension funds in other states and open up a potentially huge source of new financing. 
 Officers of the California retirement system, known as Calpers, said in January that $75 million would be invested with each of three outside investment advisers to provide financing for home builders. Last week, it voted to give an additional $75 million each to two more advisers.
Although details are still being worked out, the advisers will most likely share ownership in new housing projects and help arrange financing packages that would also include bank loans as well as equity investments by the builders themselves.
Builders said the $375 million from Calpers, when combined with the bank financing, could pay for the construction of at least 5,000 homes in California. Because of the recession and the financing squeeze, the number of one-family housing starts in California, the nation's largest housing market, tumbled steadily and drastically from a high of 163,000 in 1989 to 74,000 last year.
Developers say they remain confident that the economy will right itself this year and that California, which has been hit hard by rising unemployment -- its unemployment rate was 8.1 percent in January, one point higher than the national rate -- will resume its course of steady growth
But builders have remained much more troubled by the lack of financing, a result of the failure of many savings and loan institutions and the tighter Federal regulation of banks and savings institutions.
The Calpers investment by itself will not solve the financing crisis, which has made it hard for most builders to get the acquisition, development and construction loans they need for their projects. Most estimates are that the total reduction in available financing amounts to billions of dollars a year within California and tens of billions nationwide.
Public pension funds, which provide retirement benefits for state and local government employees, have invested heavily in commercial real estate and in apartment buildings. But they have never shown much interest in one-family-home projects, in part because of the risks in buying land, improving it, winning all the necessary zoning approvals and then building and selling the homes.
But Calpers officials said they have come to believe that helping to finance new homes in California, especially homes affordable to first-time buyers, is a good investment.
The state's population, which rose 25 percent between 1980 and 1990, continues to grow rapidly -- it is estimated to have passed 30 million now -- and there is an acute shortage of affordable housing. In 1989, 54.6 percent of households in the state owned their own homes, compared with 64 percent nationwide.
Calpers, which has a reputation as an astute investor, believes it can earn as much as 22 percent on its investment. Last month, the pension fund awarded the right to invest the money to three real estate-oriented money-management firms: California Housing Advisors, a venture set up by Montgomery Securities of San Francisco; a unit of Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco, and the Prudential Realty Group, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Last week, it added Alex. Brown Kleinwort Benson of Sacramento and AMB Institutional Realty Advisors of San Francisco to the list.
Those firms will select which projects to back and will arrange financing for each.
Calpers directed that most of the financing go for construction of affordable homes, which builders take to mean houses within reach of first-time buyers. The statewide median price of a one-family home, $198,000, masks significant regional variations, with the low end ranging from under $100,000 in a few areas to more than $300,000 in Los Angeles and San Francisco.
"In looking at the current situation in the housing industry in the state, the consensus seemed to be that there's still good demand out there," said DeWitt Bowman, chief investment officer for Calpers. "The demographics are good and when affordable housing does come on the market, it sells well."
Some investment analysts said Calpers was partially motivated by growing political pressure to use some of its huge investment portfolio to help the state's faltering economy. The analysts said that pension funds in other states may not have the same motivation as Calpers to enter the residential building field, and indeed that pension funds may continue to find the risk of investing in the land acquisition and housing development too high.
STILL, a growing number of pension fund advisers think other funds will follow the lead of Calpers and begin investing in residential housing development projects, becoming major sources of financing along with banks and savings institutions.
"Investment in single-family product will become de rigeur for public pension funds in the 1990's," said a new report from Equitable Real Estate Investment Management of Atlanta.
"The concept that the largest pension fund in California and one of the largest in the country is investing specifically in California is very encouraging," said Robert Rivinius, chief executive of the California Building Industry Association. "Other pension funds will be watching it, and I know they will find the returns to be good and the investments to be safe."
Ultimately, Mr. Rivinius said, pension-fund financing could go a long way toward replacing the old financing from banks and savings institutions.
"We're into a new way of doing business," Mr. Rivinius said. "We've got a new ball game and this is a new ball."
James Z. Pugash, an executive vice president of California Housing Advisors, said he envisions arranging financing packages under which the builder would typically have to put up 10 percent of the total cost as equity. The money management firm, using capital from Calpers, would put up another 20 percent of the cost in equity. The remaining 70 percent would come from banks in the form of loans.
The bank lenders would be paid interest; any profits from the venture would be divided by the builder and the money manager under as-yet undefined terms. Ultimately, the bulk of the profits earned by the money manager would flow to Calpers.
Calpers officials and the money managers said they hope to work out the details and get the program running within a few months.
The new financing cannot come too soon for builders like Bob Ragle of Eagle Ridge Developments in Santa Rosa, Calif.
"Half of the banks I used to use don't exist anymore and the others are extremely cautious," said Mr. Ragle, who because of the financing squeeze is now able to build one new project a year instead of the two or three he used to do. "Any kind of financial help as far as getting subdivision improvements and housing starts going would be an improvement.
"What I'm looking forward to is an additional source of funds that will allow me to get back to a normal situation in my business."

HEADLINE: Apartment Sales: Mixed Signals

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
SUSAN WEST recently inherited an eight-room co-op in a prewar building in the Carnegie Hill section of Manhattan. On Jan. 1, she put the apartment up for sale for almost $875,000. She then received seven bids and in three weeks sold it for close to her asking price.
"We really wanted to sell it quickly, but I was surprised that it happened this fast," said Ms. West, a book editor. "I think it happened because it is a very good apartment, and I think it was priced right." 
 As New York's real estate recession enters its fourth year, Ms. West's story offers a glimmer of hope for co-op and condominium owners saddled with high-priced, hard-to-sell properties. Unfortunately, though, the plight of Howard Diller remains much more common. His eight-room co-op on Central Park West has been for sale for 18 months. His asking price has dropped from $1.4 million to $995,000. He has had only two offers, both in the mid-$700,000's, and rejected both.
"In the mid-80's, people were pleading, they would try to bribe me to sell them the apartment," said Mr. Diller, a lawyer. "We could have had $1.7 million to $1.85 million, easily. There was nothing available on Central Park West at the time. Then it was like a bomb exploded -- the recession, concern where the city was going."
These contrasting experiences of sellers are examples of the increasingly mixed state of the New York City co-op and condominium market. Though it has been ravaged by recession -- brokers estimate that co-op prices in Manhattan have declined by 20 to 40 percent since 1988 -- the market is also showing some spotty signs of recovery.
Foremost, perhaps, has been a spurt of sales prompted by auctions and deep, one-time-only price cuts or rebates. At the mammoth Lincoln Towers complex on the West Side, for example, 1990 prices were cut 15 to 20 percent last year, resulting in the sale of 112 apartments and the buildup of a waiting list of more than 300 prospective buyers. This prompted MacArthur Associates, sponsor of the conversion of the 3,837-unit complex, to order price increases of 6 percent this year, phased in at the rate of 2 percent a month through March.
"It's a question of apartments being reasonably priced," said Elizabeth F. Stribling, of Stribling & Associates, a Manhattan real estate brokerage. "People are looking at a lot of apartments, 50 or 60. They know where the values are."
The condominium market, spurred by foreign money, also appears to be staging a small comeback, although the recession has still stalled virtually all new construction. Ambrose-Mar Elia Company sold 312 units in 1991, against 180 in 1990. One of those properties last year was an entire floor at 200 East 65th Street for $4.8 million, the top price paid for a condominium unit all year. "We have been extremely busy," said Jean A. Luban, the vice president of the company's condominium-sales department.
TO be sure, many sellers, particularly those with small, run-of-the-mill co-ops and condominiums in marginal areas, are still finding it difficult, if not impossible, to attract buyers. Others, though, especially those with large or high-quality units, are managing to seal deals thanks to realistic pricing, attractive mortgage interest rates and a growing belief that the market, overall, has just about bottomed out.
A cautionary note: This isn't the first time that real estate brokers were saying that the worst was over for city's apartment market. At this time last year, many brokers announced that that sales had picked up and prices had bottomed out and they were predicting an upward swing during 1991. As spring gave way to summer, however, the market slipped back into lethargy as the recession took a tighter grip on the economy.
"The market may go down another 3 to 4 percentage points, and then it may not," said Richard J. Steinberg, a broker with the William B. May Company, a residential brokerage and management concern in Manhattan. "And people do not care if it is going to go down another 1 or 2 percent."
"It is almost like purchasing stock," he added. "To buy at the absolute bottom or sell at the pinnacle is next to impossible."
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, believes the drop in New York's apartment market is linked primarily to the city's job losses, particularly in the financial services industry. From November 1990 to November 1991, 167,000 jobs disappeared, and, the figure is close to a quarter million since the winter of 1988, when the recession started in New York City, long before it did in most of the rest of the nation.
"I haven't seen this kind of feeling about New York since 1975," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Rae D. Rosen, vice president and senior economist of the Federal Home Loan Bank in New York, said that the job losses and subsequent pessimism about the real estate market have been greater in the five boroughs than in most of the surrounding areas, with the possible exception of Long Island. "People are not convinced the market has hit bottom, and they are not convinced they are going to have a job," she said.
Assessing the impact of the recession on the apartment market is difficult because the selling prices of co-ops, which far outnumber condominiums, are not publicly reported. Several brokers have their own surveys and indexes for determining where the market is going. These reports, however, are, for the most part, only narrow snapshots, restricted in location, price range or sample size. And instead of closing prices, they often use asking prices that are adjusted for the double-digit drops that often occur during negotiations.
"It is hard to have a peg on this market," said Barbara S. Fox, president of the Fox Residential Group. "It is crazy."
In the largest survey, conducted by the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan brokerage, the average per-room sale price of 2,616 co-ops and condominiums in Manhattan dropped 3.4 percent in 1991, to $86,311, the lowest level since 1983. The average in 1990 was $89,349, a 17.3 percent decline from 1989's $108,040. The 1989 figure was an 8.2 percent drop from the high point: $118,040 in 1988.
"We are definitely seeing the start of a turnaround," said Barbara Corcoran, the firm's president, who cited a shorter listing time (26 weeks versus 30 weeks) and a smaller drop between asking and selling prices (20 percent, down from 23 percent) in 1991 as opposed to 1990.
Clark Halstead, the managing partner of the Halstead Property Company in Manhattan, said his offices have seen a rise in inquiries and closings in the last three months. "My expectation is that with the election-year politics, the easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve and the stock market rally, there is a growing consensus that we are looking at the end of the recession," he said. "This will get the fence-sitters into action.
A more dire situation, however, is presented in a smaller but broader survey (888 units in all five boroughs) compiled by the National Cooperative Bank. It showed that the cost of buying a co-op dropped by 18.4 percent, from $77,858 a room in 1990 to $63,552 a room last year. The survey was based on appraisals of properties financed in the past two years by the bank, as well as other comparable co-ops.
"You could possibly see a little more weakening, but not very much," said Grace Ann Huebscher, a senior vice president at the bank. "We are close to the bottom, but, in the case of increases, I don't think they are going to be significant."
Ms. Rosen offered another gloomy appraisal. "We think we are near the bottom," she said, "but we have not hit it yet, particularly if you are talking about the ubiquitous one-bedroom unit."
Not to mention the city's thousands of studios, one of which -- in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan -- Neil and Mary Ellen Raphan bought six years ago. They paid $80,000 for the 400-square-foot unit. Their mortgage payment plus maintenance is $1,250 a month. "I thought it was the right thing to do six years ago, because my monthly costs were lower than rent," said Mr. Raphan, an advertising art director. "Now, it is higher because of the escalation in maintenance."
When the Raphans tried selling two years ago, the only nibble was a bid for $56,000, which they accepted, only to see it fall through when the buyer could not get financing. "I'll go lower," Mr. Raphan said. "I don't need this in my head any more."
In the meantime, the Raphans, who have paid more than $1,000 for classified ads in their unsuccessful attempt to sell the studio, have bought a home in Livingston, N.J., and this month they began renting out their co-op for $895 a month. "Even that wasn't easy," Mr. Raphan said.
Dror D. Shnayer, the manager of a real estate portfolio held by a private investor, also turned his co-ops into rentals when five units under his supervision in a prewar building at 181 East 83d Street in Manhattan failed to sell -- even after prices were cut by 20 percent. The one-bedroom units were listed at $200,000 and now rent for $1,500 a month. The two-bedrooms were offered for $400,000 and rent for up to $3,500 a month.
"I'M not terribly optimistic -- I think there is a glut out there," Mr. Shnayer said. "If you bought a decent-to-better apartment, you will not get hurt in the long term, but if you bought in '87-'88 and not in a prewar building, I think you're in trouble. There is just too much out there, and you're competing with your neighbors."
Ms. Rosen noted that although rents have not fallen nearly as much as sale prices (6.3 percent citywide, according to the National Cooperative Bank), there is a greater availability of rental units.
"Another sign that the market has not hit bottom is that rents are more negotiable," she said. "And for owners, that means that even the option of renting is gone because you might get less than you are planning on."
By far the biggest declines in co-op values in 1991 were in Brooklyn and Queens, where the average room price, according to the National Cooperative Bank, fell 52 percent, to $23,623 from $48,822.
But the bank also found a steep drop in the city's most expensive neighborhood, the Upper East Side. Its study showed a 39.2 percent fall in the average price of a room there, from $155,047 in 1990 to $94,321 last year.
The safest area, financially, in 1991 was Lower Manhattan, where the bank's study showed that the value of units below 14th Street rose 18.6 percent, to an average of $56,823, mostly because of the strong demand for lofts in SoHo and TriBeCa. Co-op values also increased slightly, by 3.2 percent to $45,068, in mid-Manhattan, from 14th Street to 56th Street.
"Six years ago, you had a single uniform Manhattan real estate market that was like a juggernaut," said Peggy Brim, a broker with the William B. May Company. "Any property that people bought appreciated no matter what it was. Since then you have seen it fracture, and you have a number of different markets that are all behaving differently. The one thing that is true is that the best apartments in any category are selling."
Ms. Brim said that, space and location aside, the infamous apartment quirks and annoyances (lack of light, fifth-floor walk-ups, kitchenettes) that many New Yorkers paid for, sometimes eagerly, in the last decade were now major barriers to selling. It used to be, she said, that 10 to 15 percent of apartments were marginal and hard to sell. "In a tougher market," she said, "60 to 70 percent" fall into that category.
Ms. Huebscher also noted that co-ops in buildings with financial problems, high maintenance costs or low owner-occupancy rates may continue to suffer deep declines in prices, regardless of where they are. "The worst off are going to be those who have significant sponsor ownership, greater than 40 percent," she said. "You are going to get scrutiny not only by potential buyers but from share loan and blanket loan lenders."
Ellen Feldschreiber, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, added, though, that while getting a mortgage may be difficult in cases where the sponsor is delinquent in payments or is in foreclosure, financing for co-ops today may be easier than many buyers believe. "Most banks have adopted their own co-op board supplement to be attached to any loan application, and there usually isn't a problem if at least 50 percent of the units are sold and the sponsor is not in default or behind," she said.
That is not to say that banks have not tightened up on co-op lending. Some require that at least 70 percent of the units in a building be sold. Others charge an interest rate that is a percentage point higher than for a condominium.
CONDOMINIUMS, which made up only about 17 percent of the apartment units in the city in the late 1980's, are considered a more stable investment because financing is easier. They are also unusually attractive to foreigners, who often have trouble getting the approval of co-op boards and have difficulty finding comparable property in their own country for the same price. Moreover, foreigners, especially Europeans, have not been greatly effected by this country's economic problems and benefit from a devalued dollar.
According to Yale Robbins, a real estate analyst, condominium sale prices changed little from the end of 1990 to the end of 1991; the prevailing price is about $330 a square foot. "If anything, they are down slightly, but it is hard to read from the statistics," he said, noting wide month-to-month and building-to-building variations.
Meanwhile, condominium sales in Manhattan for the first six months of 1991 (1,320), the latest period for which figures are available, were down slightly over the same period in 1990 (1,578). By comparison, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, there were 5,182 sales in 1989, 7,209 in 1988 and 7,234 in 1987, the peak year.
"There has been a revival of overseas interest, Spanish, Italian, South American, Hong Kong, into the condominium market, particularly in the high end," said Alan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, a Manhattan brokerage and management firm.
Sales of condominiums, like those of co-ops, are also benefiting from auctions, such as the one scheduled for next Sunday at the Strand at 500 West 43d Street. There, 42 units that were offered for $125,000 (studios) to $390,000 (two bedrooms, two baths) in the summer of 1989 will be auctioned off with bids starting at $65,000 to $195,000.
"It is all very much tied to the economy," said Susan M. Wachter, an associate professor of finance at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, who has studied New York City's condominium market. "If interest rates stay down and the economy recovers in the second half of the year, then I do think there will be a bounce up next year."
"However," she added, "those are two major ifs."

HEADLINE: Casino Raises Fears of Compulsive Gambling

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
MARVIN STEINBERG said he found it ironic when a recent study commissioned by the state recommended a widespread expansion of gambling in Connecticut while also noting that the state had the highest rate of compulsive gamblers in the Northeast and perhaps in the country.
Like some other experts in the field, Mr. Steinberg, who is the founder and president of the Connecticut Council on Compulsive Gambling, said he saw a distinct correlation between the growing number of problem gamblers in the state and the variety of legalized gambling in Connecticut, which has more forms than any state except Nevada. 
 "There's no longitudinal data that proves legalized gambling creates more compulsive gamblers, but there's no doubt in my mind that as gambling proliferates, problems increase," said Mr. Steinberg, a clinical psychologist who is the assistant director of the Hamden Mental Service, an outpatient clinic. He started the compulsive gambling council in 1979. Unlike comparable organizations in Massachusetts and New Jersey, which receive state funds, the Connecticut council depends on private contributions. The opening last weekend of a gambling casino on the reservation of the Mashantucket Pequot Indians in Ledyard has heightened concerns about compulsive gambling among people like Mr. Steinberg and Chistopher Armentano, director of the Compulsive Gambling Treatment Program in Bridgeport. "It's definitely going to magnify the problem," Mr. Steinberg said. If the state allows the casino to add video slot machines, "the increase in the number of compulsive gamblers could change dramatically," Mr. Armentano said. The casino already is the only one east of the Mississippi permitted to have poker, he noted, "and we know that can be highly addictive."
Fifty video machines that can be used for 16 games have been installed at the Ledyard casino, but they cannot be used for gambling, since they are legally defined as slot machines, which are illegal in Connecticut. But the study commissioned by the state recommended that, to offset a loss of gambling revenue as a result of the new casino, Connecticut should install slot machines at six gambling locations in the state: three jai alai frontons, two theaters where viwers bet on televised horse races and the Plainfield dog track. In addition, the study proposed that the state consider building its own casino to compete with the one owned and operated by the Mashantucket Pequots, which, because it is on Indian land, is not subject to state taxes.
If slot machines, which account for approximately 60 per cent of the revenues at gaming establishments in Atlantic City and Nevada, are allowed in state-run casinos, under Federal law they also would be permitted at the Ledyard casino.
The state study, compiled by a Massachusetts research company that has done extensive work for gaming interests throughout the country, said that 6.3 per cent of the state's 2.5 million adults (about 160,000 people) have had a gambling problem. By contrast, the figure in Massachusetts is 4.4 per cent, while in both New York and New Jersey it is 4.2 per cent.
Neither Mr. Steinberg nor Mr. Armentano were surprised by those figures, they said. Noting that some state officials and legislators favor an expansion of legalized gambling as a way of offsetting declining state revenues, Mr. Armentano said, "Some people would like to wish these figures away rather than face up to them."
 
Fewer Therapists
 In a state where millions of dollars are gambled annually on state-run lottery and numbers games, at Off-Track Betting parlors and on jai alai and greyhound racing, Mr. Armentano is the only full-time employee dealing with the problem of compulsive gambling. Operating out of an office in the Greater Bridgeport Community Health Center, he counsels compulsive gamblers and refers them to Gamblers Anonymous, which has about a dozen chapters throughout the state.
"I certainly could use more help," said Mr. Armentano. He is assisted by two part-time therapists, he said, "but I lost two others last June because of the budget crisis." A few years ago, he said, the center had a director, two therapists and four other counselors.
"We had 40 active clients at the time my staff was cut," said Mr. Armentano, who also spends Tuesdays helping gamblers from an office in Hartford. "But now we're down to about 25. When their therapists leave, as happened last June, the people seeking help feel rejected, and many of them go back to gambling.
"I try to reach out to them. But I can only do so much. And there's also a whole large group of compulsive gamblers out there who've never showed up at our door. But even when they come in for help, a lot drop out and continue gambling. We try to help them to know themselves better and to make a complete commitment to abstinence. But it isn't easy."
Both Mr. Armentano and Mr. Steinberg say that not many people with gambling problems in the state are aware of the treatment center in Bridgeport.
Mr. Armentano's operation receives $200,000 a year from the state, "the same amount we've been getting every year since 1982," he said. "So when you take inflation into account, we're actually getting less and less each year."
 
Toll-Free Phone Line
 Fliers explaining the state's lottery games, which are available at all outlets where tickets are sold, provide phone numbers for the Bridgeport center and Gamblers Anonymous. But Mr. Steinberg noted: "It's in small print at the very end, and hardly anyone even sees it." Here we have the state spending millions of dollars encouraging people to gamble but refusing to spend anything to help people who develop problems from gambling."
The Ledyard casino, under an agreement with the Connecticut Council on Gambling, is paying for a new toll-free phone line that offers advice to state residents with gambling problems. The number is (800) 346-6238. (The last five digits correspond to the letters in "no bet.") In addition, the casino promised to give the council $16,000, the proceeds from a "play night" held at the casino on Feb. 13, two days before the official opening.
"They've been very cooperative," said Mr. Steinberg who helped train upper-echelon casino personnel to spot patrons with serious gambling problems. One of his talks has been made into a videotape that will be shown to all employees, said Bruce Einhorn, the vice president for casino operations.
But casino officials declined Mr. Steinberg's request that they display signs informing problem gamblers where they can seek help.
"We're sensitive to the issue, but we don't want to accentuate the negative," Mr. Einhorn said. "However, we will make some of Mr. Steinberg's literature available."
He added: "We realize that compulsive gambling is a problem. But we think that a very small portion of gamblers fit into that category."
 
'Unlimited Winnings'
 Dr. Rachel Volberg, an expert on compulsive gambling from Delmar, N.Y., who conducted part of the recent state survey, lauded casino officials for working with Mr. Steinberg. But she warned, "Any time you make gambling more accessible, you may have people getting in trouble."
Casinos can create problem gamblers, "because they offer fast action and unlimited winnings," Mr. Steinberg said. "Even when you talk high-stakes bingo, you can get more addictive gamblers."
Mr. Armentano said he knew cases in which gambling cost people their marriages, their jobs, their life savings and even their homes. One man who came for treatment "was still betting and had lost over $100,000," he said. "He told me he had $14,000 left, which was the amount he owed a bookie, but that he was thinking of gambling the money to try to recoup some of what he had lost. He never showed up again."
More sad stories of addictive gambling were recounted by Galen D., a spokesman for Gamblers Anonymous in Connecticut, who described himself as a former compulsive gambler. Like other members of Gamblers Anonymous, he said he would not divulge his last name when discussing the organization.
"We had a woman in our Hartford chapter who was the bookkeeper for her husband's business," he said. "She started out betting a dollar or two a day on the lottery and eventually was betting as much as $3,000 a day. One day she won $60,000, but she was so hooked that she ended up losing between $300,000 and $400,000 over a period of about four years, which almost cost her husband his business."
He added: "Quite often, you read or hear about people who commit crimes because of big personal debts. What those stories don't usually say is that many of those people have debts resulting from compulsive gambling."
 
'Created a Frankenstein'
 Galen D. said that when he joined Gamblers Anonymous 12 years ago, the Hartford chapter had 12 members. "Now we have between 35 and 40," he said.
State Representative Elizabeth Brown, Democrat of Waterbury, said she was working on a bill that, among other things, would provide more state funds to cope with compulsive gambling.
"We have created a Frankenstein," she said. "And we have to educate people about the problem of compulsive gambling."
While conceding that "gambling is here to stay in Connecticut," Mrs. Brown said, "I think it is bad public policy to try to balance budgets with money from gambling, especially when that gambling creates serious personal problems."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patrons betting on the Money Wheel at the new casino in Ledyard. A study says Connecticut has a high rate of compulsive gamblers.
(Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Pension Funds for One-Family Houses

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The recent decision by the California Public Employees Retirement System to invest $375 million in the construction of one-family houses within the state is being welcomed by builders here, who have been squeezed by a severe shortage of financing.
The first large-scale investment by a public pension fund in residential construction is being watched closely by builders across the country, who think it could spur similar moves by public pension funds in other states and open up a potentially huge source of new financing. 
 Officers of the California retirement system, known as Calpers, said in January that $75 million would be invested with each of three outside investment advisers to provide financing for home builders. Last week, it voted to give an additional $75 million each to two more advisers.
Although details are still being worked out, the advisers will most likely share ownership in new housing projects and help arrange financing packages that would also include bank loans as well as equity investments by the builders themselves.
Builders said the $375 million from Calpers, when combined with the bank financing, could pay for the construction of at least 5,000 homes in California. Because of the recession and the financing squeeze, the number of one-family housing starts in California, the nation's largest housing market, tumbled steadily and drastically from a high of 163,000 in 1989 to 74,000 last year.
Developers say they remain confident that the economy will right itself this year and that California, which has been hit hard by rising unemployment -- its unemployment rate was 8.1 percent in January, one point higher than the national rate -- will resume its course of steady growth
But builders have remained much more troubled by the lack of financing, a result of the failure of many savings and loan institutions and the tighter Federal regulation of banks and savings institutions.
The Calpers investment by itself will not solve the financing crisis, which has made it hard for most builders to get the acquisition, development and construction loans they need for their projects. Most estimates are that the total reduction in available financing amounts to billions of dollars a year within California and tens of billions nationwide.
Public pension funds, which provide retirement benefits for state and local government employees, have invested heavily in commercial real estate and in apartment buildings. But they have never shown much interest in one-family-home projects, in part because of the risks in buying land, improving it, winning all the necessary zoning approvals and then building and selling the homes.
But Calpers officials said they have come to believe that helping to finance new homes in California, especially homes affordable to first-time buyers, is a good investment.
The state's population, which rose 25 percent between 1980 and 1990, continues to grow rapidly -- it is estimated to have passed 30 million now -- and there is an acute shortage of affordable housing. In 1989, 54.6 percent of households in the state owned their own homes, compared with 64 percent nationwide.
Calpers, which has a reputation as an astute investor, believes it can earn as much as 22 percent on its investment. Last month, the pension fund awarded the right to invest the money to three real estate-oriented money-management firms: California Housing Advisors, a venture set up by Montgomery Securities of San Francisco; a unit of Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco, and the Prudential Realty Group, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Last week, it added Alex. Brown Kleinwort Benson of Sacramento and AMB Institutional Realty Advisors of San Francisco to the list.
Those firms will select which projects to back and will arrange financing for each.
Calpers directed that most of the financing go for construction of affordable homes, which builders take to mean houses within reach of first-time buyers. The statewide median price of a one-family home, $198,000, masks significant regional variations, with the low end ranging from under $100,000 in a few areas to more than $300,000 in Los Angeles and San Francisco.
"In looking at the current situation in the housing industry in the state, the consensus seemed to be that there's still good demand out there," said DeWitt Bowman, chief investment officer for Calpers. "The demographics are good and when affordable housing does come on the market, it sells well."
Some investment analysts said Calpers was partially motivated by growing political pressure to use some of its huge investment portfolio to help the state's faltering economy. The analysts said that pension funds in other states may not have the same motivation as Calpers to enter the residential building field, and indeed that pension funds may continue to find the risk of investing in the land acquisition and housing development too high.
Still, a growing number of pension fund advisors think other funds will follow the lead of Calpers and begin investing in residential housing development projects, becoming major sources of financing along with banks and savings institutions.
"Investment in single-family product will become de rigeur for public pension funds in the 1990's," said a new report from Equitable Real Estate Investment Management of Atlanta.
"The concept that the largest pension fund in California and one of the largest in the country is investing specifically in California is very encouraging," said Robert Rivinius, chief executive of the California Building Industry Association. "Other pension funds will be watching it, and I know they will find the returns to be good and the investments to be safe."
Ultimately, Mr. Rivinius said, pension-fund financing could go a long way toward replacing the old financing from banks and savings institutions.
"We're into a new way of doing business," Mr. Rivinius said. "We've got a new ball game and this is a new ball."
James Z. Pugash, an executive vice president of California Housing Advisors, said he envisions arranging financing packages under which the builder would typically have to put up 10 percent of the total cost as equity. The money management firm, using capital from Calpers, would put up another 20 percent of the cost in equity. The remaining 70 percent would come from banks in the form of loans.
The bank lenders would be paid interest; any profits from the venture would be divided by the builder and the money manager under as-yet undefined terms. Ultimately, the bulk of the profits earned by the money manager would flow to Calpers.
Calpers officials and the money managers said they hope to work out the details and get the program running within a few months.
The new financing cannot come too soon for builders like Bob Ragle of Eagle Ridge Developments in Santa Rosa, Calif.
"Half of the banks I used to use don't exist anymore and the others are extremely cautious," said Mr. Ragle, who because of the financing squeeze is now able to build one new project a year instead of the two or three he used to do. "Any kind of financial help as far as getting subdivision improvements and housing starts going would be an improvement.
"What I'm looking forward to is an additional source of funds that will allow me to get back to a normal situation in my business."

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

TRIBUTE TO DEWHURST
 Two years ago Colleen Dewhurst was mistress of ceremonies at the Night of Stars fund-raiser for the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts in Goldens Bridge. She served in that capacity every year that she was at home in South Salem during the 12 years of her tenure as honorary board chairman of the organization.
This year the event, to be held next Sunday at 7:30 P.M. in the John Jay High School Auditorium in Cross River, will be dedicated to Ms. Dewhurst, who died last Aug. 22. 
 Many of the stars who will appear are associated with the center as supporters, parents or spouses of students or as teachers of classes at the center. Others knew Ms. Dewhurst as a colleague in theater, film or television. Among the actors are Lucie Arnaz and her husband, Laurence Luckinbill, E. G. Marshall and Jill Clayburgh. Representing music are the flutist and conductor Paul Lustig Dunkel, Rosemary Glyde, violist; Ani Kavafian, violinist, and two composers, Alan Menken and Stephen Schwartz.
"Colleen was a tireless worker for the community and for us," said Bira Rabushka, the center's executive director. The actress, in addition to her busy career and her presidency of Actors' Equity in Manhattan, found time to speak at local high school graduations, coach Little League, participate as a Friend of the South Salem Library and support the Westchester Lighthouse.
She helped negotiate the center's contract with the town for the use of its building, narrated its promotional tape and attended planning meetings for a new facility to be built on a site in Katonah between the Katonah Museum and Caramoor.
Ticket sales will help replace the loss of $25,000 in state and county financing because of the recession and shore up existing programs. For reservations at $50, $75 or $100, call 232-5740.
 
POE SET TO MUSIC
 "The Facts in the Case of M. Valdemar," one of Edgar Allan Poe's chilling short stories, has been set to music by Milton Rosenstock and will be performed today at 2 P.M. in Riverdale by the Bronx Arts Ensemble. Mark Zeller will be the narrator and singer, accompanied by the ensemble's chamber orchestra.
The tale hinges on delaying death by mesmerization, and at the time it was published the medical community mistook it for reportage of an actual case. Physicians were understandably shaken, and the public was horrified.
The 45-minute program will take place in the Russian Mission to the United Nations at Mosholu Avenue and West 255th Street, one of a series of "Glasnost in the Bronx" performances by the ensemble. Each program features works by American and Russian composers. Included today are Stravinsky's "Pastorale" and Tchaikovsky's "Souvenir de Florence."
Poe, whose cottage in the Bronx is preserved as a historic landmark, has been a continuing source of inspiration to the music group, which presented "La Chute de la Maison Usher," an opera fragment by Debussy, in 1978, and a trilogy of chamber operas by Russell Currie based on "The Cask of Amontillado," "Ligeia," and "A Dream Within a Dream" in the 80's.
Mr. Rosenstock has been the music director of more than two dozen major Broadway shows, the American Ballet Theater and the Dance Theater of Harlem.
Tickets are $35, $25 for students and individuals 65 and older. Call (212) 601-7399 for more information.
 
SAVING THE PLANET
 More than 100 heads of state are expected to gather in June in Rio de Janeiro for a United Nations Conference on Environment and Development. Their purpose will be to explore ways in which the deterioration of the planet can be slowed or stopped.
Wainwright House in Rye has scheduled a series of seminars focusing on the various subjects to be considered. The first session, from 2 to 5 P.M. today, will be an introduction to the conference and its agenda. Serving on the panel will be Jeane Sindab of the National Council of Churches, David Miller, Northeast regional vice president of the National Audubon Society, and a member of the United Nations Secretariat assigned to the conference.
On March 8 the religious community will be the focus of the meeting, with Sir Paul Reeves, Anglican observer at the United Nations and former Governor General of New Zealand; Mohammed Mehdi of the National Council on Islamic Affairs, Daniel Martin, director of the conference's coordinating committee on religion, and others.
Speaking on March 15 will be educators, students and environmentalists, including Allison Beall, curator of the Rye Marshlands Conservancy; Patricia Monahan, a Yonkers teacher, and others from Canada and the United States. The final two sessions, on March 29 and April 5, will be concerned with the contributions of women's organizations worldwide and the role of the business community, respectively.
Admission to the series will be $75; individual sessions cost $20. Call 967-6080 to register or obtain more information.
 
FRASCONI WOODCUTS
 Antonio Frasconi's woodcuts, on view through April 12 at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase, range from powerful social statements to intricate depictions of plants and insects to light-hearted illustrations of the fables of Aesop.
The prints, created for more than 50 of his books, are indicative of the depth, style and variety of his work, much of which is in the collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New York Public Library, all in Manhattan; the Library of Congress in Washington and the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris.
Mr. Frasconi, who came to the United States from Uruguay in 1945, has produced a substantial body of work on social injustice and humanistic philosophy. Taking his texts from Richard Wright, Federico Garcia Lorca, Bertolt Brecht, Walt Whitman, Edgar Allan Poe and Henry David Thoreau, he interprets the prose and poetry in drawings, melding literature with art.
The museum is open Tuesday through Friday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is free, but a donation of $3 will be welcome. Call 251-6100 for more information.
 
HISPANIC CONFERENCE
 The Hispanic community, according to recent census figures reviewed by Family Service of Westchester, is the fastest-growing ethnic group in the county. A conference titled "The Hispanic Community: Issues for Professional Practice" has been scheduled by Family Service on Friday from 8:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. in an effort to create broader understanding of cultural diversity among Hispanic residents and friction between them and other Westchester populations.
Josie Palleja, a family therapist specializing in the problems of Hispanic residents, and George Rios, the County Executive's assistant for minority affairs, will be the principal speakers, addressing the effects of changing demographics and the clinical aspects of dealing with Hispanic families.
While the program is aimed at professionals, anyone interested in the subject will be welcome. Registration costs $35, and more information can be got by calling 948-8004. The session will take place at the Andrus Retirement Community, 185 Old Broadway in Hastings-on-Hudson.
 
MAPLE-SUGARING TIME
 The sap is rising at the county's parks and nature preserves, and beginning this weekend sugar maples will be tapped, syrup will be boiled and samples passed out to visitors. The process will get under way today at 2 P.M. at Lenoir Preserve on Dudley Street in Yonkers, at Washington's Headquarters Museum in North White Plains and at the Trailside Nature Museum on the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River.
Using a variety of old-fashioned tools and methods, staff members will take visitors through each step, accompanied by a running commentary on tree biology, the mechanics of harvesting the sap and how the syrup was used in Colonial times as flavoring in cooking.
Another session will take place at Lenoir next Sunday, and programs scheduled on Saturday at Lenoir and next Sunday at Trailside are designed for children to participate in everything from tapping to tasting.
Next Sunday at Muscoot Farm in Somers those who have sugar maples of their own may learn how to produce syrup the modern way. All programs start at 2 P.M. and are free.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Canada's Big Shin-Kicker

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
In accusing the United States of playing "low-level politics" in a series of recent trade actions against Canada, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has promised a "shin kicking" campaign to get them reversed.
His chief shin-kicker is Canada's 15th ambassador to the United States, a 52-year-old career foreign service officer named Derek Burney. 
 The burly Ontarian, born at Thunder Bay, who received Canada's Outstanding Public Service Achievement Award for 1991, says he has been preoccupied with trade issues since his arrival three years ago at the new embassy on Pennsylvania Avenue.
He says the recession has made American industry keen on import protection, but he believes that if there is a healthy recovery, some of the trade pressure will let up. "My job is to see to it that we don't have an accident on the way," he added.
Many Canadians see new walls the United States is building against Canadian-assembled Japanese cars as well as Canadian beer, lumber and magnesium as violations of the three-year-old free trade agreement between the two countries.
Canadians are especially sensitive to protectionism because of their own recession and high joblessness and because 80 percent of their total exports go south. The two countries exchange about $200 billion of goods and services.
Mr. Burney, a former chief of staff of Mr. Mulroney, agrees that the American trade actions are "cumulatively putting a lot of pressure on the trade agreement."
But he sees the accord, and especially the dispute-settlement provisions, which he helped to negotiate, as giving Canada the extra safeguards it needs to preserve its biggest export market.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Staying With the Hong Kong Play

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The Hong Kong stock market is on a roll.
After a spectacular rise of more than 40 percent in 1991, Hong Kong has jumped 11 percent since the beginning of the year. Along the way it has passed 17 new highs for the blue-chip Hang Seng index. 
 Is it time for a correction?
"We'll stick with it awhile longer," said Thomas Robinson, chief international strategist for Merrill Lynch, which sells Hong Kong stocks to retail investors.
Normally, it would be time for a healthy consolidation, a fall of several percentage points that would give the market a breather and a more solid base on which to launch future gains. Many analysts would welcome such a correction because it would provide an opportunity to buy more stocks at lower prices, while anticipating a further rise. But several forces coursing through the market could delay a retrenchment for some time. Thus, many analysts say that getting in now could still provide some nice returns, even with the market, which closed Friday at 4736.47, not far off its all-time high of 4,772.32, at such exalted levels.
Some of these analysts, like Victoria Goodwin of James Capel Inc. in New York and Elizabeth Tran of Prudential Asia in Hong Kong, are cautious but admit difficulty finding reasons not to buy. Ms. Goodwin is looking for second tier-stocks, like Johnson Electric, which makes small electric motors. Ms. Tran is switching from some of the popular bank stocks, like Hang Seng, one of the colony's major banks, to companies that make or sell consumer goods and companies that develop real estate.
"Even we who are very cautious find it hard not to argue that the market is very cheap," Ms. Tran said.
Two forces are propelling the rally. One is market factors, the other the continuing lure of the "China play."
Market factors include Hong Kong's low interest rates and high inflation. With savings account rates around 3.5 percent, the prime interest rate at 8.5 percent and inflation around 11 percent, interest rates are negative. This is driving cash into real estate and the stock market in the quest for returns that will outstrip inflation.
Real estate companies are among the most powerful forces in the Hong Kong market. Property companies in general, including Cheung Kong, Henderson Land and New World Development, outperformed the Hong Kong market by more than 4 percent in January. The reason could be seen last week when a prime residential property was sold for more than 4,000 Hong Kong dollars a square foot. In general, residential prices are up at least 50 percent in the last year.
In addition, said Ms. Goodwin, company earnings across the board are expected to rise 17 percent this year, which would probably drive the Hang Seng index up by the same amount. And while inflation of 11 percent is very high, inflation in China, where more and more of the manufacturing for Hong Kong companies is now located, is lower. This means inflation will have a smaller than expected impact on earnings.
Manufacturers are also getting the benefit of savings from lower interest rates, which have followed the downward path of American interest rates, since the Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the American dollar and the two currencies move in tandem.
Another market factor is known as the safe harbor draw, meaning that because the Hong Kong dollar is pegged, dollar-based investors won't get hurt by an American dollar rally. And earnings and price earnings ratios are especially attractive there because much of the rest of the world does not look so good right now.
The second force is the China play, the conviction that Hong Kong's entree to China makes it the way to play the biggest developing market in the world. This is not a new lure, but it seems it is overcoming long-held fears about what will happen when Hong Kong returns to China's control in 1997.
Barton Biggs, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, is in this school. He switched his position on Hong Kong a week ago in a report from Asia where he is on a tour. Before the trip he had cut back his investment in Hong Kong, saying the market was too high, too popular and too easy to spook. In announcing his change of heart, he wrote that "in the past it had almost invariably been right to buy Hong Kong when everyone was despairing and sell it when shares and speculation were high."
What changed his mind? "The China play aspect of Hong Kong is assuming big-time proportions." he wrote, backing his new sentiment by moving his Hong Kong investment up to 6 percent of his portfolio, three times its normal share. "China, the biggest emerging market story in the world, is beginning to boom, and it should last for years." Among his perferred stocks are Cathay Pacific, the airline; Swire Pacific, which owns Cathy and commercial property, and Hongkong Telecom, the phone company.
So, optimism reigns. "As usual, when things are going quite well in China and the Chinese are making the right noises, people tend to forget about the risks," said Ms. Tran of Prudential Asia.
But this is one of the most volatile markets in the world. The Chinese, who are sending favorable signals now, could stop. There are still some trade tensions with the United States. The Japanese stock market could turn around, which would drain money out of Hong Kong to take advantage of that rally. With any change, the market could fall quickly and sharply.
On the other hand, analysts have been issuing this warning all during the rally.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
As Rates Rise, Stocks May Be Vulnerable

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The collapse of short-term interest rates has been the biggest factor in the changing investment outlook over the past year. With Treasury bill rates below 4 percent, billions have flowed out of banks and into stocks and bonds.
But now there are signs that the fall in short-term rates is ending. The rate on three-month Treasury bills has climbed to 3.92 percent from 3.72 percentin the past two weeks. 
 That move is consistent with the action of the stock market, where cyclical stocks -- the ones that need a healthy economy to prosper -- have been rising and growth stocks -- the ones that can produce profits whatever the economy -- have been slipping.
The trend can be seen in the market for Eurodollar futures. In essence, that market provides a way to bet on the course of short-term rates. Now it is predicting a sharp increase.
Interpreting that market is not always easy. There are lots of hedges that involve Eurodollar contracts, including some related to this coming week'sauction of two-year Treasury notes, and the removal of those hedges, after the notes are issued, could help to stabilize the Eurodollar market a bit.
Still, as Michael H. Sherman, Shearson Lehman's chief equity strategist, points out, the rising trend of Eurodollar futures rates seems to be clear. The rate on March futures -- essentially the market forecast of short-term bank deposit rates next month -- was 4.01 percent two weeks ago. Now it is 4.35 percent. And there are even larger rises in the later months, especially December, after the election.
If the decline in short rates has provided the best news for the stock market over the past year, the relatively small decline in long-term interest rates has proved to be the most troubling for some investors. At the same time that short rates have been edging up, yields on 30-year bonds have also risen, to the point that they flirted with 8 percent last week.
Those rate increases may yet set off warnings that the economic recovery may be aborted, as happened last spring. But it seems clear that such sectors as housing can do quite well at current levels, and some economists see signs of strong growth ahead.
"The facts that short rates have backed up, that economically sensitive stocks are up smartly, and that the dollar and industrial commodity prices have gained, together are at least a collective hint from the marketplace that the first stages of a more traditional economic recovery may be near at hand," said Robert M. Barbera, Shearson Lehman's chief economist. He thinks the economy will begin growing at a 5 percent annual rate by the second quarter of this year.
That would be great news for business and for George Bush. But it also would be likely to push short-term rates up further. Mr. Sherman thinks Treasury bills could get to 5.5 percent by year-end. If that does happen, he added, a stock market correction of at least 10 percent would probably follow.

HEADLINE: Stalking the Next Walkman

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, giving the toast at an annual Sony reception here, Norio Ohga almost sounded like a man who had forsaken electronics for the glitter of Hollywood.
The 62-year-old president of the Sony Corporation talked for 15 minutes without once mentioning the Walkman, the video camcorder, or any of the other gadgetry that propelled his company to huge profitability and tremendous growth in the 1980's. He made only a cursory mention of his pet technological project, Sony's billion-dollar bet on high-definition television. What he did talk about were Sony Pictures Entertainment and Sony Music Entertainment -- once better known as Columbia Pictures and CBS Records. 
 Since Sony dived into Hollywood in 1989, Mr. Ohga told the gathering, it has seized 20 percent of the American box office, "an all-time high for any one movie company in the past 10 years." He waxed on about the success of Steven Spielberg's "Hook" and the critical praise for Barbra Streisand's "Prince of Tides." Michael Jackson's "Dangerous" album, boasted Mr. Ohga, a former opera singer who admits that Mr. Jackson's music was an acquired taste, "has sold over 10 million copies."
Mr. Ohga may be eager to talk about movies and records because, quite frankly, it is easier these days than discussing electronics. Slammed first by the recession in the United States, then by a fast-strengthening yen, profit margins in the business that accounts for more than three-quarters of Sony's estimated $30 billion in sales this year have shrunk to a scant 5 percent.
On Wednesday, Sony issued a dreary financial report, saying that its operating income for the year that ends March 31 will decline 45 percent, to about $1.3 billion. The parent company in Tokyo will run an operating loss, of about $160 million, the first such loss since Masaru Ibuka and Akio Morita founded Sony in 1946. The entertainment business, which burdened Sony with billions in debt to buy and build and only two years ago looked as though it would have to be propped up by the company's electronic wizardry, now seems its healthiest arm, although it accounts for only about 20 percent of sales.
 
A Question of Focus
 Mr. Ohga's "hardware" woes seem particularly startling because throughout the 1980's even the company's biggest Japanese competitors stood in awe of its growth and its speed at rushing new products to market. But for the first time in a long while, Sony has nothing of the proportion of the Walkman or Handycam to give its researchers time to nurse other technologies -- and leeway for a few failures.
Indeed, this recession catches the company at a critical point. Some at Sony say that the attention of senior managers, once focused wholly on the "hardware" of consumer electronics, has been diverted by the new "software" -- the movies and music that, in theory, will fuel sales of its gadgets. That preoccupation has masked a major question: How can a company already competing with giant Japanese rivals, all of Hollywood and the entire record industry take on yet another set of rivals -- the world's computer makers?
It is a fundamental issue for Sony because at their core, its product lines for the 1990's are remarkably sophisticated, single-use computers disguised as easy-to-use consumer electronics. The Data Discman, Sony's 18-month old "electronic book," provides a way to carry around encyclopedias, law books and telephone directories in a Walkman-sized reader. The Palmtop, Sony's ingenious but still struggling entry into the new field of electronic notebooks, allows the use of a pen instead of a keyboard. Coming by the end of the year is Sony's riskiest bet of all: A completely reinvented Walkman that uses a compact disk instead of a tape.
Sony executives argue that the new Walkman, called the M.D., for Mini Disc, will do what the company has always done so brilliantly. That is, invent whole new categories of personal appliances, creating markets where none existed. The underlying technology of the M.D., for instance, could potentially be combined with that of the Data Discman to create a pocket-sized multimedia video player able to store everything from clips of "Gone With the Wind" to music from the latest Mariah Carey album.
But it could take years for these products to yield returns, and until then Sony is in retrenchment mode. Over the past few months, Sony's leadership -- Mr. Ohga; Ken Iwaki, deputy president, and Michael P. Schulhof, the former physicist who spends his days running Sony's huge American operations and negotiating with stars -- has called a halt to factory building and stopped the exponential growth of research and development spending. Capital spending for next year is being cut by $500 million. A giant high-definition television plant is being retooled for conventional TV's, a glaring symbol of Sony's overoptimism about market acceptance of new technology.
"Until last summer, Sony was aggressively preparing for growth," said Mr. Iwaki, who oversaw Sony's expansion in the 1980's, when revenue growth of 20 percent a year was common. "Then we saw the storm clouds growing. Now, it's raining a bit."
Sony's recovery depends largely on the accuracy of its vision of how computers and consumer electronics will mesh. The world, Sony executives think, is moving toward many one-pound "nomadic" computers that each accomplish a specific task -- and must each work with the simplicity of a Walkman. To brace for the day, Sony has entered into a secretive agreement with Apple Computer Inc. to combine Apple's easy-to-use software with Sony's friendly look and feel.
"It is the right approach," said Bill Joy, chief technical officer of Sun Microsystems, a work station maker. "People in the future will not buy computers as computers. But I am not sure the consumer companies like Sony have yet thought through all the software implications."
Indeed, that question is changing Sony today. "We are still debating how to incorporate computer-like attributes into our consumer products," said Mr. Schulhof, who is universally described as Mr. Ohga's American alter ego, with more power in the company than any other non-Japanese. "But the computer industry is moving in our direction, and it will play to our strength."
Mr. Ohga, characteristically, is at once succinct and cryptic about his plans. "If the computer business is a consumer business, we have to be in it. So we will be."
 
So Much for Synergy
 When Norio Ohga began creating the new Sony several years ago -- what Mr. Iwaki once called the "bicultural child" -- the buzzword was synergy. The idea that entertainment "software" could sell Sony "hardware" seemed to explain the purchase of CBS Records and Columbia Pictures. The purchases mean works of hit artists would be available on new, Sony-promoted formats. Sony had learned the importance of this the hard way, when an absence of "software" wiped out its Betamax videocassette player standard in the United States and Europe.
These days the word synergy isn't heard very often around Sony headquarters -- or, for that matter, at Matsushita, the electronics company that followed in Sony's wake and bought MCA Inc., owner of Universal Studios. "Quite frankly," said Mr. Schulhof, "there have not been many software-hardware synergies. Most of them have been software-software," like the early release of music videos drawn from movie soundtracks. One conspicuous exception is a Michael Jackson appearance in ads for Sony's new large, flat-screen television -- but, under Mr. Jackson's contract, only in Japan.
Synergy failed for the digital audio tape (DAT) player that a few years ago promised to be the company's hot product. The record industry worried that such tapes would undercut sales of CD's, and few DAT recordings were forthcoming -- even from Sony-owned CBS Records. Now DAT is reserved for "professionals" and "audiophiles."
Synergy also has not helped much, at least yet, with high-definition television. No sooner had Sony moved onto the Columbia lot than it installed one of the world's most expensive high-definition production facilities, hoping that producers would abandon film to produce programs on video for HDTV broadcast, in turn stimulating demand for the HDTV televisions. They didn't.
The whole HDTV concept has bogged down in international disputes over a broadcast standard. Japan, naturally, is pressing for the system it has spent 20 years developing. America is looking for something non-Japanese -- preferably an all-digital system that will take years to develop and give the nonexistent American television manufacturing industry a chance to rebuild.
"From a technical point of view, HDTV is there," said Mr. Iwaki. But, he added, "Our assumption was that one system would be adopted around the world. That is no longer a good assumption."
Making the humiliation even worse, Matsushita, usually known for eating Sony's dust, raced into the Japanese market with large-, flat- and brilliant-screen televisions. "We had the technology but unfortunately we were not first," said Mr. Iwaki, "Matsushita made a big hit, and we were not first."
At the same time, sales of Sony's 8 millimeter camcorders, the two-pound marvels that generated a fortune in the late 80's, have fallen off dramatically as the recessions in Japan and the United States deepened -- and just as Sony was building new factories.
The end result is what Boris Petersik, the electronics analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd in Tokyo, calls "an electronic void." Video exports for all Japanese manufacturers have dropped considerably. Sony, which sells 62 percent of its goods overseas, suffered the most. In the nine months ended Dec. 31, 1991, sales of Sony's electronics business grew only 5.8 percent, while entertainment revenues jumped 27 percent, though from a low base. On a percentage basis, electronics are far less profitable for Sony these days than music and movies -- if you exclude the cost of Sony's huge borrowings to buy Columbia.
Sony carefully masks the debt payments, leaving analysts to make educated guesses about their effect. But for two years now, Norio Ohga and Mickey Schulhof have heard the same Hollywood sniping: that Sony overspent for the studio, overspent to hire talent like Jon Peters (now, along with many Columbia principals, gone) and Peter Guber and overspent on big projects like "Hook."
"Everyone has accused us of overspending," said Mr. Schulhof. "But our average cost of production is 5 or 10 percent below the industry average."
Mr. Ohga admitted to being "a little bit afraid" of the amounts spent in Hollywood.
"Anticipation is really the right word," Mr. Schulhof interjected, stressing the need for "patience and a long view."
Hollywood, of course, is fascinated by such charges and rebuttals. But in reality, what Sony puts at risk there is relatively minor compared with what's at stake when it rolls the dice on the back streets of Shinagawa, the crowded Tokyo neighborhood that is dotted with Sony laboratories.
 
Mr. Ohsone's Gamble
 These days, Sony's biggest gambler is Kozo Ohsone, father of the Walkman. An amiable man with a broad smile, Mr. Ohsone has one obsession these days and that is to make his famed product obsolete. Quickly.
Over the last 10 years, the Walkman had been refined as far as it physically could be and shrunk to roughly the size of a plastic cassette tape carrying case. "When we realized we couldn't go any further," Mr. Ohsone said, wandering through the fourth-floor maze of desks piled high with prototypes of new models, "we knew the moment had finally arrived for new technology."
Mr. Ohsone reached for a technology bubbling in Sony's central research labs for years -- a compact disk that can be recorded on, erased and recorded on again. Unlike tape, optical disks like CD's provide random access, the ability to scan immediately to a musical selection. And they allow digital sound quality, something a generation of record-rejecting music lovers demand.
The engineers' problem was to design a player that could withstand the jostling a Walkman takes. They solved it, by continuously feeding three seconds of music into computer memory chips, which are impervious to shaking and bashing, creating a buffer so that a skip would never be noticed.
The resulting device is called the Mini Disc, which will use a mini CD. No one knows how quickly consumers will abandon the familiar and be willing to pay a premium price of $400 to $500 for a sophisticated data storage and recording device. "It will take a while," said Mr. Ohga. "But it took a while with the compact disk."
At its simplest, the M.D. is a music machine. But the underlying technology has a huge range of uses -- for mass data storage for portable computers, for video, text and a range of other "multimedia" uses.
Inside Sony's labs, the uses are already merging. It was Mr. Ohsone's audio engineers, not the computer division, who invented the Data Discman. With fewer than 200,000 sold, the $550 device does is not yet a hit. But combining it with the M.D.'s recording capability -- it already plays some audio -- is not a too-distant stretch.
Where Sony still needs the most help, presumably from Apple, is with the pen-operated Palmtop. When it was introduced in Japan, for more than $1,000, it was simply a curiosity. The price has been slashed in half, and the machine made to look more like a pad of paper, with a small printer attached. Combined with the Data Discman, the Palmtop has spurred debate about how computer-like to make Sony.
"The question is do we need computing technology as an internal technological resource, or do we need to be in the computer marketplace," one mid-level Sony employee said recently. "We don't plan to enter the PC market. Instead we meet computers at the appliance level, at the Data Discman."
So far, the idea is still clearer than the execution. Sony's new information and entertainment appliances are still incompatible with each other, meaning that disks that fit the Data Discman will fit none of its other products. Mr. Ohga and Mr. Schulhof express no worry, saying that each format was uniquely suited to a specific application. But many Sony researchers see the compatibility problems as a major obstacle.
The true test for Sony, though, is whether it can sustain its remarkable pace of innovation while management is diverted by Hollywood, by the political tensions between Japan and America and by running an enterprise now half the size of I.B.M.
Sony has always known how to create an aura as sleek as the cool, black metalic designs that have been its trademark. That is why it seemed to be the only Japanese firm capable of learning the strange ways of Hollywoods. "We've always prefered to wear the fashionable suits," said Mr. Iwaki. But for the next few years, it may have to pay less attention to wardrobe and more to production -- especially in Tokyo, where the screenplay needs another rewrite.
