SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1710 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/February 16-21

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
Waiting for the Economic Nitty-Gritty From the Buchanan Campaign 

Even among conservatives, the charge leveled against Patrick J. Buchanan is that though he has support, he doesn't have an economic plan. "I'm not aware of any real economic policy emanating from Buchanan's camp, even on health care," said Edwin S. Rubinstein, a conservative economist at the Manhattan Institute. But on Feb. 9, Mr. Buchanan issued what he calls his seven-point plan. "He has his seven points, but he hasn't had time to write them out into a position paper yet," said John P. Cregan, head of the U.S. Business and Industrial Council and a Buchanan adviser. "They are an economic message for the post-cold war era," he said. The points include getting tough with Japan. "We call it being a 'trade hawk,' " said Mr. Cregan. There are middle-class tax cuts, a Government hiring and spending freeze and foreign-aid cuts. "Pat still has to flush out his health care plan," Mr. Cregan said.

Energy Policy or Energy Bill?
 
The best negotiations, it is said, are those that end with everyone feeling equally bad. The energy bill the Senate passed overwhelmingly last week was the product of that kind of give and take. Liberals wanted a bill favoring conservation. Conservatives pushed for more energy exploration. Environmental groups wanted tougher pollution limits. The White House wanted drilling in the Arctic National Wilderness Refuge. What they got instead was a bill that makes it easier to construct nuclear reactors, does not require increased fuel-efficiency for cars, curbs Arctic drilling and does little to promote domestically produced fuels like methanol. But it does oblige the Government to use alternative fuels in its fleet of vehicles and it allows utilities to sell electricity across state lines. It also sets minimum energy standards for products like air-conditioners and light bulbs. After all the wrangling, Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, said: "We still don't have a national energy strategy." That may be true, but the Senate went ahead and approved the bill 94 to 4.

No Fear of Inflation
 
This economic slump has at least one silver lining. With consumers shunning the malls, the nation's storekeepers have had the good sense to keep their prices flat. According to the Commerce Department, the Consumer Price Index, rose by just one-tenth of 1 percent in January. "This confirms that inflation pressures are abating," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch. "I think that will continue to be the picture for all of this year and probably for a chunk of next year as well."

Seeking One-Armed Economist
 
Harry Truman longed for a one-armed economist. That way he would never have to hear the words "on the other hand." But that's precisely what Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress last week. During testimony before a House subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan said, "We are beginning to see the stirrings" of a recovery. He said it would occur in the second quarter. But then Mr. Greenspan hedged. On the other hand, he said in his testimony about the recovery, "I don't want to overemphasize it. It's a series of weeks and it could just as easily peter out as indeed the much more vigorous recovery of last spring petered out." Mr. Truman would not have been amused.

Survival of the Weakest S.& L.'s
 
Capitalism's strength, the economist Joseph Schumpeter said, is that it lets its weakest institutions wither away, Darwin-style, so strong new ones can be built up. But if the nation's savings and loan regulators have their way, that aspect of capitalism may itself wither. Rather than shutting down ailing thrifts and liquidating their assets, as the Government now does, the regulators want to approach the problem another way. They want to become investors. Which savings and loans will they buy into? The ones that are "heading south," said T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision. That's a contrarian approach, to say the least. But if tax money goes into these institutions, the Government will not only be bailing out the depositors, it will also be protecting the stockholders. That's not very Schumpeterian. The public has 30 days to comment.

Why Housing Helps
 
Housing starts are a leading indicator. Break ground and you must hire workers and buy supplies. And once the house is up, you have to buy all the doodads to fill it. And then there is insurance. So it was good news when the Commerce Department reported last week that housing starts increased by 5.5 percent in January, with most of the increases in the Midwest, and permits for new construction were up by 6 percent. "The trend is definitely positive," said David W. Berson, of the Federal National Mortgage Association.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Toeing the Line at Time Warner
 
It was no secret that Steven J. Ross, chairman of Time Warner Inc., and N. J. Nicholas Jr., co-chief executive and his designated successor, did not see eye to eye. "Their styles and temperaments were quite different and they couldn't agree on what kind of deals to do," said Richard M. Clurman, author of "To the End of Time," about the merger of Time Inc., and Warner Communications Inc. Mr. Nicholas is widely thought to have been against Mr. Ross's plan to take in Japan's C. Itoh and Toshiba as partners in the entertainment business last fall. "What was supposed to be a close, intimate working relationship never developed," Mr. Clurman said. And with Mr. Ross's health in doubt, those differences cast a pall over the direction the heavily indebted company might pursue. Still, it did come as a shock last week when it was announced that Mr. Nicholas had resigned. He will be replaced by Gerald M. Levin, currently vice chairman. With Mr. Levin as No. 2, and with Time Warner's board of directors strongly supporting him, doubts about the company's direction were largely quelled. Wall Street liked the news. Time Warner closed the week at $99.75, up $1.875.

Round-the-Clock Cartoons
 
When Time magazine made Ted Turner, chairman of the Turner Broadcasting System, its Man of the Year, it was because of the vision thing. Mr. Turner's CNN brought breaking news, 24 hours a day, to millions of people around the world. That was lofty. It raised people's consciousness. But last week Mr. Turner announced he was bringing something else into people's homes, and it probably won't do much to increase the world's wisdom. In October Mr. Turner will start a cable-television channel showing nothing but cartoons, 24 hours a day. It will air programs from the Hanna-Barbara and MGM film libraries, which Mr. Turner also owns. Why the new channel? "We're opportunistic," Mr. Turner said, adding that the channel was a "long-term play."
 
Bush's Hotel in Trouble
 
For President Bush, the recession must seem to be closing in from all sides. Not only did it hurt him in New Hampshire, but now it is hampering him where he lives -- or at least where he votes. Last week Houstonian Properties Ltd., which owns the Houstonian Hotel, filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11. The Houstonian is where Mr. Bush maintains a suite that is his official voting address.

Milken to Pay Up
 
Michael R. Milken, the imprisoned former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert's junk-bond desk, made more than $500 million in a single year. Still, the agreement he made last week to settle the more than 9,000 civil suits filed against him was for more than walking-around money. Mr. Milken agreed to pay $900 million in a deal worked out by Federal District Judge Milton Pollack, who is overseeing Drexel's bankruptcy. Mr. Milken's former colleagues will kick in $300 million and Drexel's insurers will add an additional $100 million. If all the claimants agree to the settlement, no more civil charges can be filed against Mr. Milken or Drexel.

Price Cuts, Not Coupons
 
Supermarket aisles are increasingly cluttered with coupon dispensers and displays offering discounts on products. Food companies have to pay premiums to have their goods displayed prominently. It's an expensive way to move the merchandise, especially in a lackluster year. So last week Kraft General Foods Inc., the nation's largest food company, said it would follow the example set last fall by the Procter & Gamble Company, and lower its prices. Procter & Gamble cut some of its prices by as much as 40 percent. Kraft did not say how deep its cuts will be. "We will approach it on a category-by-category basis," said Joseph P. Durret, senior vice president for sales. With the nagging recession, cheaper goods may help Kraft preserve its market share.

The Marriot Corporation expanded vigorously -- just before the recession. Now it is stuck with $2 billion in debt in the midst of a travel recession. So it was no surprise when it announced last week that it would sell six hotels and lease two others to the ITT Sheraton Corporation in a deal worth $160 million.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
The Narrowing Trade Deficit
 
Six years ago, the Plaza Accords went into effect. They brought down the value of the dollar against the world's other major currencies. Proponents said the accords would eradicate the trade deficit in five or six years. The world is still waiting. According to the Commerce Department, the nation's trade gap for 1991 fell to $66.20 billion, its lowest level in eight years. But not because of the cheap dollar. It was because of the slump. Consumers didn't spend much last year, on anything. "At least half, maybe two-thirds, of the year's improvement was due to the recession," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.

Can Korean Cars Buck a Trend?
 
You have to be awfully optimistic to begin selling cars in America this year. Detroit is losing billions of dollars and several foreign manufacturers have gone home in disgust. Still, Kia Motors of South Korea, is making plans to enter the American market, albeit slowly. (It already makes the Festiva, sold here by Ford.) Kia's strategy is to sell Japanese-style cars, but at lower prices.

 Nicholas Jr. The Sportage from Kia Motors (Kia Motors); Michael Milken ; Fred Flintstone

HEADLINE: It's Flash, It's Dash and It's Out of Detroit

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Detroit is once again turning heads with its car designs the striking forms of the Cadillac Seville, Buick Skylark and Chrysler's new family of mid-size sedans. The change has energized the Big Three's studios, where designers still wince at the memory of a 1983 Fortune magazine cover showing four General Motors models, one indistinguishable from the next. That image sent home the point -- "signed, sealed and delivered," as one designer put it: car styling, a traditional American strength, had become a weakness.
In recent years, even while battling the incursions of foreign car makers and retooling to meet ever-stricter Federal standards, they have kept a wistful eye on design. And in recent months, they have rolled out the fruits of their new visions, designed to distance themselves from the drab decades, to return to the days when the whole car -- not just the vanity plate -- made the statement of who you are. It's hardly a return to the be chromed land yachts of the 1950's, but it is a world of "cab forward" design, cat-eye headlights and even plastic cladding around the bottom, an upscale image borrowed from Europe that lends a racy line (as well as protecting the paint job from road debris). 
 The bolder, sometimes overstated shapes signal one of Detroit's strategies to win back market share lost to foreign brands. In contrast to Japanese auto makers, G.M., Chrysler and, to a lesser degree, Ford, say they are designing to inspire strong feelings -- adoration or revulsion, anything but indifference.
"The new production stuff seems to show a pretty confident hand," said David E. Davis, editor of Automobile magazine.
The new direction is particularly evident in three G.M. models derived from the same chassis: the Oldsmobile Achieva, Pontiac Grand Am and Buick Skylark. Despite their common provenance, these cars put on individual displays that send Japanese sedans -- the Toyota Camry, Nissan Maxima and Honda Accord -- into the shade.
These and other Japanese models suffer from a "dreadful sameness," said Thomas Dukes, director of competitive assessment for J. D. Power & Associates, auto industry consultants based in Agoura Hills, Calif.
Industry analysts acknowledge that the move to bolder styling will not, by itself, halt the erosion of the domestic companies' market share. Buying decisions in these economy- and safety-sensitive times are still guided more by perceptions of quality, performance and value. But distinctive exteriors pique consumers' interest and as domestic brands close the value gap, stronger designs may give Americans an edge.
"If the quality were the same, then I would say the Japanese would be at a disadvantage right now," said Jean-Claude Gruet, an analyst with UBS Securities in Manhattan.
The early success of the restyled Cadillac Seville supports the widely held belief that Americans will favor American cars when all else is perceived to be equal.
Unfortunately, auto executives must flirt with disaster before they approve daring designs. Ford, for example, was in deep trouble in 1985 when it introduced the Taurus, a risky, revolutionary form. It had to pull things together, and the Taurus did the trick. But now the company is showing classic unwillingness to tinker with a winner. Ford, flush with cash, spent more than $600 million to revamp the Taurus for 1992, but made few noticeable changes to the exterior. Detroit, in fact, does not always follow its own advice, that the biggest risk is taking no risk at all.
Still, Big Three designers say they are wielding more clout than they have in years. More than a decade ago, new requirements for better fuel economy forced auto makers to downsize their models, causing a head-on collision with the styling trends of the day.
"Longer, lower, wider; that was our creed," said Charles M. Jordan, G.M.'s chief designer. "All of a sudden, cars had to be shorter, narrower and higher."
The myriad engineering changes required to meet Federally set fuel targets forced designers into the back seat. To cut down on manufacturing costs, common body panels were used for models from separate divisions, creating an inevitable cookie-cutter result. Then too, there was overreliance on focus groups, or "clinics," in which consumers are polled for their reactions. To please the greatest number, rakish touches were sacrificed. "If everybody says it's beautiful, it's going to look old by the time it gets to market," said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst with the brokerage firm Furman Selz Inc. in New York.
Today, the Big Three say they are using clinics differently. Chrysler, for example, no longer chooses designs that score the highest average, but rather ones that elicit the highest and lowest scores. The theory is that a bold shape will cut through the clutter of hundreds of available models and grab drivers' imaginations.
"We believe very strongly in a love-hate relationship, something that is very polar," said Thomas Gale, Chrysler's chief designer.
Ford's strategy is focused more on the middle ground. . Fritz C. Mayhew, Ford's chief North America designer, said the auto maker has too few models to risk outlandish styles. Instead, Ford is developing a functional, industrial look, a simple aerodynamic appearance that it is spreading across its product line.
Of course, risky designs that polarize opinion can flop. (Remember Ford's Edsel?) And in G.M.'s line-up of dozens of models, many, like the futuristic minivans with their moonwalker look, have struck off-note chords with consumers. The minivans' sharply raked windshields have also drawn criticism for creating pillars that obstruct the driver's peripheral vision, and drivers have complained that the car's protruding nose makes it difficult to park in tight spaces.
"You could argue that G.M.'s designs are more individual. The question is: Are they better?" said C. Edson Armi, author of "The Art of American Car Design" and an art history professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. He prefers the products of Mr. Jordan's predecessor at G.M., Irv Rybicki, whose models consistently rated a B-plus because of a "Brooks Brothers quality of bland, but well-executed, design."
Today, that description better suits many sedans from Japanese auto makers. To be sure, many of the Japanese companies sought to put themselves in closer touch with their growing base of style-conscious American customers by establishing American-staffed studios in California in the late 1970's and 1980's. And they have turned out some remarkable styles with the help of American teams, from the one led Chuck Jordan's son Mark that put out the Mazda Miata to the one headed by David Doyle of Calty Design Research in Newport Beach, Calif., creators of the Previa minivan.
But what is behind the almost generic look of so many of their models? Designers and industry analysts suggest several things.
Because Japanese brands are lauded for their quality and performance, design is considered a lesser concern to their buyers. This did not stop Honda from displaying an eye-catching concept car, the aggressive-looking, low and wide, designed-in-Japan FS-X sedan at recent auto shows. But given the success of such uninspired exteriors as that of the also designed-in-Japan Honda Accord, there is little reason to toy with the conservative look. Why change the shape of the best-selling sedan in the United States?
A historical focus on perfecting manufacturing and engineering techniques has also overshadowed design. And, as Ms. Keller puts it, the Japanese "take a much more evolutionary approach."
Designers of Japanese brands believe that discerning consumers will appreciate their models' "subtleties," understated variations on a theme of gentle curves. Gerald P. Hirshberg, head of Nissan's studio in La Jolla, Calif., argues that some Big Three designers are making a mistake by focusing so intensely on making their models unlike the competition. It translates, he says, into the difference between "having style, and doing style for style's sake."
Mr. Hirshberg and others say they prefer mass appeal to customer polarization. "Toyota would rather sell its styling to everybody," said Dennis Campbell, senior chief designer of Toyota's Calty studio. Honda executives defend the incremental changes to their Accord model as honoring tradition, a strategy of many staid European brands and of Ford in its latest redesign of the Taurus.
What will be the shape of cars to come? The biggest hits at the recent Detroit Auto Show included Chrysler's mid-sized sedans. Some designers and industry watchers believe they are leading a trend toward so-called cab-forward design, in which the passenger compartment is moved forward in the car's body. The lower and shorter hood lends a wedge shape, and pushing the wheels farther to the corners creates more of a performance-oriented stance.
While many designers believe that cab forward will be a major theme of the 1990's, they also expect diversity to be the watchword. The move toward niche vehicles for specific market segments -- made possible in part by lean production techniques that make small-volume models profitable -- will grow, multiplying designs and further blurring lines among minivans, cars and sport-utility vehicles, for example. The regulatory mandate to build electric vehicles is also expected to force broad changes in design.
As bolder designs become more the rule than the exception, designers admit they will be harder pressed to turn consumers' heads. That will inevitably force them back into borrowing a leaf from the Japanese, trying to win over customers with subtleties. Said Mr. Mayhew of Ford: "It will be much more difficult to do a design that is radically different from what is out there."
 
 
 
WHAT'S GOING ON ON THE INSIDE
 While automotive designers often disagree on how cars should look, they roundly agree that interiors are in for innovation. For decades, by tradition, interiors were modeled by designers who worked on nothing else. The result was foreseeable: Interiors often didn't match the design theme of the exterior. For example, the now-discontinued Buick Reatta was a curvacious two-seat coupe -- with an oddly squarish, angular dashboard. "It was just so jarring," said Maryann N. Keller, an automotive analyst with Furman Selz in Manhattan.
The idea now is to get a better match, and, in some cases, for interior and exterior designers to learn each other's craft. "We want Renaissance designers," said Fritz C. Mayhew, Ford's chief North American designer. Nissan has granted its American studio its own interior design capability, instead of reserving that for Japan.
Car interiors will probably be simpler in the future. Buttons will be eliminated with the help of voice activation technology, for example. But some could be more complex, with more telecommunications technology to help create mobile offices.

HEADLINE: Protect Us From Government Protection

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The theme running through "Deep-Freeze the Regulatory Freeze" (Forum, Feb. 2) was summed up by one phrase indicating that Americans generally "want government to protect them" from the ills of the world. Decades of government "protecting" Americans got the United States into its current mess. Government-subsidized education, health care and housing has encouraged costs to zoom out of control and quality to decline in many areas. The auto industry is an example of how government involvement can turn what was once a bastion of free enterprise into a virtual public utility. For the sake of our great free and democratic society, don't advocate increasing ever-stifling regulation.
 
DOUGLASS C. LYON
Rochester, N.Y., Feb. 4

HEADLINE: The Uses of Anti-Dumping Laws

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read with great interest James Bovard's thesis (Forum, Feb. 9) that United States trade laws "reduce competition and raise prices to protect consumers against the one-in-a-million possibility that foreign companies could corner the market -- and raise prices." Further, he argues that Congress should repeal the country's antidumping laws. 
 The repeal of our antidumping laws could help to maintain lower prices on some imports, at least in the short run. Yet far more is at stake in enforcing the antidumping statues than, as Mr. Bovard suggests, simply raising import prices now to prevent foreign producers from gaining monopoly power and raising their prices later. Rather, the laws seek to remedy the situation where foreign producers, free from significant import competition at home, use their surplus profits from domestic sales to subsidize low-cost export sales that injure American companies and their workers. Dumped imports that undersell United States products even slightly can lead to declines in production and market share, reduced cash flows, cutbacks in R.& D., and disinvestment, not to mention employee layoffs and plant closings.
Mr. Bovard also ignores the fact that foreign firms can substantially increase their production through dumped sales into the United States market and reap significant economies of scale and improvements in technological and manufacturing skills. This makes them stronger competitors in other export markets and in markets for other products.
We can all agree that our lack of competitiveness in certain industries is not just the result of unfair trade practices by others. In fact, it may be that too often our manufacturers fail to use the assistance received under our trade laws to take the steps necessary to improve their competitiveness. United States antidumping laws help to preserve our national manufacturing, technology and tax base, and, in so doing, enable millions of Americans to earn a good living and then reinvest those earnings as consumers. To quote a 1974 Senate Report: "Unemployed persons are not happy consumers."
 
DON E. NEWQUIST
Washington, Feb. 19
 
Mr. Newquist is chairman of the United States International Trade Commission.

HEADLINE: 'Swaps' and the Next Great Banking Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Floyd Norris' column on how the next great banking crisis could result from their dealings in new financial products like interest rate swaps (Market Watch, Feb. 9) was perceptive and timely. Unfortunately, the article gives the impression that it is merely particular products that pose risks for the world financial system. 
 There is a more basic issue, with ramifications far beyond bank capital adequacy and other forms of banking regulation. A distinct process of financial innovation arose in the 1980's. At the vanguard, there has been a shift to institutionalized research and development of the type associated with high-technology companies. Abstruse theory, rocket scientists and powerful computers play major roles. Whether driven by rocket scientists or merely by lawyers relying on the Internal Revenue Code, innovation is now built into the system. There is now a continuous and rapid flow of new financial products throughout the world's major capital markets.
This process, not particular products, poses especially difficult issues for governments, in banking or securities regulation, taxation and corporate law. The process undermines the ability of regulators, legislators and judges to know what is going on.
 
HENRY T. C. HU
Austin, Tex., Feb. 9
 
Mr. Hu is a professor of law and associate dean for academic affairs at the University of Texas.

HEADLINE: Japanese Didn't Invent Military Sex Industry

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Lest your report on karayuki-san, "comfort women," forced into prostitution by the Japanese army in Korea (news article, Jan. 27) be used to fuel the fires of Japan-bashing, let us be clear that the military exploitation of women through rape and prostitution has a long history in every military society, including ours.
A former Navy chaplain who served in Japan during the post-World War II occupation told me that when he protested the American base commander's efforts to set up prostitution centers using Japanese women, he was reassigned stateside. 
 As a Japanese-American woman growing up on United States military bases, I faced the assumption that any woman who looked Asian was sexually available to soldiers. I was often called "geisha-girl" or "Suzy Wong" (soldiers usually couldn't tell Japanese from Chinese). Every base I ever lived on, in the United States, Okinawa and Germany, had a thriving red-light district near it.
The enormous growth in the Thai sex industry occurred with the escalation of the Vietnam War, in which Bangkok was a major rest and recuperation spot for United States troops. When the war ended, the economy was so dependent on the revenues generated by the sex industry that Thais shifted their sales pitch to tourism. Underground best-selling guidebooks give advice about where to find particular kinds of prostitution, including children. Some travel agencies arranged sex tours for Western European, American and Japanese men to Thailand.
The largest users of Korean women for prostitution now are United States soldiers. My Sister's Place, an agency that works with Korean women who marry soldiers or work as prostitutes, estimates that one of every six Korean women 15 to 35 years old works in the sex industry. The women have few other economic options, especially if they have run away from abusive homes or are divorced. The situation was similar around Philippine United States bases and continues on Okinawa, where women from the Philippines and Thailand are illegally imported for the sex industry.
Women in virtually every Asian country are organizing against the economic structures, military bases and social patterns of male dominance that force hundreds of thousands of women and children into the sex industry. If we are shocked by the story of karayuki-san, which ought to shock us for its brutality, we also ought to assist the women of Asia in their struggle against similar abuses now.
 
RITA NAKASHIMA BROCK
St. Paul, Feb. 3, 1992
 
The writer, a professor of humanities at Hamline University, has done field work on the sex industry in Thailand, Japan, the Philippines and Korea.

HEADLINE: Meadowlands No Place For a Large Complex

 BODY:
Re: "Vision of Rail and Office Complex Moves Closer to Reality," Jan. 26: William McCann's vision of a "gleaming oasis of glass and steel," proposed for construction in the Hackensack Meadowlands, is a futile one.
The idea of a major office and hotel complex's being built at a time of office glut and hotel room vacancies is misguided. Other Meadowlands hotels are suffering. 
 We could dismiss or forget that valuable wetland and habitat resources will be lost; that the promised jobs will be short-term and will just as likely go to construction workers from out of the region; that New York City's skyline is now more than ever a symbol of greed gone sour rather than of something to emulate; that Newark and Hoboken are already "intermodal transportation hubs"; that additional car traffic will lead to worsening air quality; that the circle of mobility may be outdated and designed to accommodate a timeworn paradigm, or that the existing rail lines would be better used as trails or light rail -- forget all that, and the Allied Junction project is still doomed to fail.
The concept of a large, citylike paved area in the Meadowland marshes is contrary to every planning fundamental.
The stress this project will cause on the Meadows ecosystem is unconscionable. Runoff, non-point source pollution from the large paved area alone will contaminate large areas of marsh and river. Oil from the cars, rubber, asbestos, antifreeze and grit will form a noxious stew that will run raw every time it rains. This "pointless pollution" will contaminate fishery habitat (the marshes and estuarine streams) critical to the health of the inshore fishery -- the fish we eat.
We must inaugurate a moratorium on development in wetlands, on mud flats, on platforms in rivers and on barrier beaches. It is a small price to pay for healthy food, open space preservation and cleaner air and water.
Large-scale developments like this one benefit only a small group of people while marsh and open space benefit all of us. The short-term monetary gains from wages and taxes do not come close to the cost of servicing the ratable.
We can always build later once we know whether or not mitigation (fake wetlands) techniques work, but we can never restore the open space lost if it is developed now. Urban open space is analogous to an endangered species; it is more valuable, because there is less of it.
Allied Junction is not a "rail project"; it is a private development project with a de facto subsidy because of its location near a rail line. The real rail complex already exists in Newark.
I agree that it makes sense to put economic development around the transit hub, but not with the conclusion that it should be in the Meadowlands. The New Jersey State Plan and common-sense planning say that the older urban areas are the logical place for large-scale development; that farmland and open space are at a premium, and should be spared.
Downtown Newark could be the setting for additional "economic development" and already has the rail, road, sewer, water and electrical infrastructure necessary for a development of this size.
It would be a rare treat if developers, redevelopment-hungry large-city mayors, labor, the State Plan and public policy could all be accommodated in an environmentally benign economic revitalization. Allied Junction in the Meadowlands is not the solution.
 
ANDREW J. WILLNER
Baykeeper
American Littoral Society
Sandy Hook

LENGTH: 1136 words

HEADLINE: In His Various Defining Moments, Has Bush Clearly Defined Himself?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
GEORGE BUSH has been in public life since the 1960's, and he has been President of the United States, scrutinized every day in every way, for more than three years. Yet as he labored last week to recover from a Republican primary in New Hampshire in which he was able to attract only 53 per cent of the vote, his managers were still struggling to find some way to present a clearer impression of the man and his policies.
A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted last week dramatized the depth of the President's problem: the poll showed that more than half of registered voters find it hard to say what Mr. Bush hopes to accomplish in a second term -- although, of course, Mr. Bush still has several months in which to refine his message to the nation. 
 Coming up with an agenda is usually a challenger's problem. But Mr. Bush has never struck most people as a man with a solid core of political beliefs. Personal character and values, yes; he is well known as a family man, a modest and self-effacing man, by the standards of big-time politicians, at least. But deep political roots like Ronald Reagan's or Harry S. Truman's? Not really.
In the battle for the 1980 Presidential nomination, George Bush ran as something of a Rockefeller Republican, dismissing the program of his rival, Mr. Reagan, with the caustic jab, "voodoo economics." When Mr. Reagan chose him as his running mate (which says a lot for Mr. Bush's ability to utter harsh words without making enemies), that sort of talk was quickly shelved.
Mr. Bush quickly took on the ideological coloration of the Reagan Administration; not once during its whole eight years did he distance himself from any of its policies in any significant way. George Bush the Planned Parenthood advocate became George Bush the foe of abortion, for example.
 
Ambiguous Record
 In the 1988 primary and general election campaigns, it was George Bush the Reaganite who showed up, painting Bob Dole as a spineless wonder with a dangerous predilection for big government spending, and Michael S. Dukakis as a softie who let violent criminals out of jail to commit more crimes.
Lately, the record has been ambiguous. As Patrick J. Buchanan kept reminding the voters of New Hampshire, Mr. Bush reneged on his campaign slogan, "no new taxes," and he has a confusing record on civil rights. He signed the Civil Rights Act of 1991 while continuing to appoint judges and make speeches that civil rights leaders could not stomach.
Contradictions abound. The self-proclaimed education and environment President, he habitually takes what experts in those fields deem half measures. A foe of censorship, he dumped the head of the National Endowment for the Arts the moment that Mr. Buchanan threatened to make an issue of arts policy in the culturally conservative Southern states.
The useful aspect of such pragmatism, of course, lies in opening the way to compromise -- always valuable in foreign affairs, long Mr. Bush's prime interest, and increasingly valuable in the new world of domestic affairs, where a Republican President and a Congress controlled by the Democrats has come to be the rule, not the exception.
Less welcome is the harsh political fact that pragmatists have trouble building constituencies, especially in this era of single-issue politics. Mr. Reagan had a band of die-hard supporters who could be counted upon no matter what. Mr. Bush's fans come and go with the changing political weather, which is why he fell so rapidly in the polls when the economy turned sour. And he has never quite convinced conservatives that he is one of them.
It may be that the President's pragmatism derives from his early life, when, as a son of the liberal Eastern Establishment, he found himself in Texas, a land of tough, self-reliant conservatives.
Mr. Buchanan derided Mr. Bush's patrician background in a speech last week, mocking his prep school education, his membership in Skull and Bones, the toniest Yale club, and his wealth. The Mercedes-driving Mr. Buchanan even took a shot at the President's summer house, where, he said, "the Walker's Point G.O.P. salves its social conscience at other people's expense" by backing "reverse discrimination," the challenger's term for affirmative action.
He doesn't mention George Bush the Texan, the horseshoe-tosser, the nibbler of pork rinds. Those are the symbols that the President has used to conjure up the ordinary-guy image he deems politically preferable, to which he adds conservative political language, if not always conservative actions.
 
Indecisive Tactics
 The White House said last week that there would be no change in the President's policies, not even the economic proposals that failed to stir the country in the State of the Union speech. What was needed, it was said, is some limited tactical fine-tuning.
With voters still blaming the Administration, not Congress, for the recession, that is a debatable judgment. But even on tactics, there was indecision; at first it was said Mr. Bush would attack Mr. Buchanan, a vulnerable foe with a long paper trail of contentious and questionable statements. Then the handlers decided that going on the attack would "demean the office," as one said. Snarling-dog duties would be performed by Vice President Dan Quayle and perhaps by some less anodyne television ads.
If Mr. Buchanan can be dispatched without too much self-definition by the President, the ambiguity might prove beneficial in holding the party together in November. Mr. Bush has hoped, and apparently still hopes, that he can avoid offending the right-wingers whose support he will need in the fall.
The Democrats, meanwhile, struggle with their own problems of definition. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and Gov. Bill Clinton have jumped clear of the pack, the Times/CBS poll shows, and Democratic voters, if not Democratic leaders, are starting to get a bit more comfortable with the idea of one of the active contenders as the nominee.
But not one of the five hopefuls has made enough of a splash that even half the voters are willing to rate them in the most general way: Do you approve or disapprove of this guy? In addition, Mr. Clinton has high negative numbers, a legacy, perhaps, of allegations of marital infidelity and draft avoidance.
Unless things change radically in the next few months, those factors could give Mr. Bush and the Republicans a chance to daub the opposing nominee with colors of their own choosing, something they did to the hapless Mr. Dukakis in 1988.
Perhaps slogans and reputation-busting will be less successful this year. But don't count on it. Dwight D. Eisenhower observed hopefully four decades ago that the American people wouldn't buy a President sold like toothpaste; he hasn't been proved right yet.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Plastic Surgery: A Profession In Need of A Facelift?

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
"DOC HOLLYWOOD," a comedy-cum-morality play that appeared in theaters last year, pits the seductions of the big city against the virtues of small-town life. For the prototype of the slick, the soulless and the rich, the scriptwriters picked a plastic surgeon. Will Michael J. Fox amass a fortune in Los Angeles making the beautiful more beautiful, or become a country doctor in South Carolina?
You can guess the outcome, and also the outrage of many of the country's plastic surgeons, who felt they were being stereotyped. Most have spent seven years after medical school learning their specialty. And, they insist, they are not simply catering to vanity. Seeing themselves as inheritors of a medical tradition that goes back to the battlefields of World War I, some plastic surgeons trek regularly to Mexico or the Philippines to heal the burns and the cleft palates of the poor. Others work in inner cities. Still others have pioneered advances in microsurgery or implant technology. 
 But there is also the allure of the fees to be made on procedures that are purely cosmetic -- facelifts, wrinkle removal, eyelid repair, liposuction to vacuum out fat. According to the American Medical Association, the number of plastic surgeons has increased fourfold in the last quarter century while the total number of physicians has little more than doubled. In 1965, the A.M.A. counted 1,133 doctors who called themselves plastic surgeons. In 1990, the number increased to 4,492, although those actually certified by the plastic surgery board numbered only about 3,850.
Attention to the profession has increased with the dispute over the safety of silicone gel breast implants, which are inserted, mostly for cosmetic reasons, more than 100,000 times a year. Thursday, an expert panel recommended that David A. Kessler, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, allow the implants only on a tightly controlled experimental basis, although it found no conclusive evidence to justify suspicions of a link between autoimmune disorders and leaking silicone.
 
$5 Million War Chest
 Dr. Kessler's decision is due in 60 days, and in the meantime, many surgeons are closing ranks. Last year, in response to the implant debate, the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons assessed its members $1,050 to accumulate a $5 million war chest -- $500,000 for research, $4.5 million for lobbying, or "public education." But others within and without the specialty have been troubled in recent years by the direction the specialty has taken. What do the critics say is wrong?
Exhibit A: Advertising. A scantily clad brunette, in a pose that seems lifted from a Victoria's Secret lingerie catalog, looks out proudly from an advertisement in the current issue of New York magazine, next to a text that purrs: "It used to be that if you looked in the mirror and saw something you didn't like, you had to live with it. Thankfully, those days are over." Advertising by lawyers and doctors won Supreme Court approval more than a decade ago, but most doctors still frown on it.
Exhibit B: Income. Plastic surgeons' median pre-tax income was measured at $211,250 in 1989 by the research firm Medical Economics. Though this figure ranks in the middle of all surgical specialties, it is nearly double that of family medicine and pediatrics, and well in excess of psychiatry and obstetrics.
Exhibit C: Absence. In a 1989 survey paid for by the Massachusetts Medical Association and the state's emergency physicians, plastic surgeons led the field of the hard-to-get. Two-thirds of the emergency-room directors who responded said they had trouble getting plastic surgeons to respond to emergencies at some time during the previous six months. About 60 percent had some problems with neurosurgeons, 51 percent with orthopedic surgeons, 46 percent with psychiatrists.
Joseph E. Murray, a 72-year-old plastic surgeon, said he feels that his colleagues have, in some measure, earned a reprimand. Dr. Murray learned his trade in Veterans Administration hospitals during and after World War II, when there were about 100 plastic surgeons nationwide. In 1989, he won the Nobel Prize in medicine for his work in kidney transplants in the 1950's.
"The motivation for plastic surgeons has pretty much been the same throughout the ages -- imagination, perseverance and curiosity," he said. "I found when I got out of the Army that I was much more interested in the reconstructive aspects of surgery than the excisional aspects. We had done tremendous hand surgery, we fixed lost noses and orbits. In the decade after the war, we interested a fine new generation of doctors.
"But somewhere in the 1960's," he said, "a group of plastic surgeons began to concentrate on esthetic or cosmetic surgery. They got out of the mainstream. They were interested in an easy work life. Scheduled patients. No emergencies. Cosmetic surgery is wonderfully rewarding. When you change a patient's nose or help the kid with the jug-handled ears -- that's wonderful. About 15 percent of my practice was cosmetic work. But it bothers me when doctors lose their professionalism and sell their services to the highest bidder."
Boyd R. Burkhardt, a Tuscon-based plastic surgeon who once trained with Dr. Murray, argued that "some things have been forced on plastic surgeons by the way medicine has developed."
"There are only so many head injuries, so many cleft lips and palates," he said. "The one expandable part of the territory is cosmetic surgery."
Since cosmetic surgery rarely qualifies for insurance reimbursement, many patients are likely to be well-to-do. Thus plastic surgeons are also facing competition from ear, nose and throat doctors who do nose jobs, ophthalmologists who fix eyelids, general surgeons who do facelifts and general practitioners who do liposuction.
The number of reconstructive procedures performed was 1,250,000 in 1990, double the approximately 640,000 cosmetic procedures, according to the plastic surgeons society. The amount of hand surgery and laceration repair decreased between 1988 and 1990, while breast augmentation operations increased 25 percent.
"There is no question that the remunerative aspects of our profession sometimes attract a certain type of personality," said James H. Wells, a plastic surgeon in Long Beach, Calif. "That personality gets stereotyped and our profession gets stereotyped."
But, Dr. Murray argued: "There's a fine new generation of doctors coming up. They just need good role models, good leadership."

HEADLINE: The Trains Are Ready, The Parking Isn't

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
ANYONE who's gone near some train stations in the New York area recently, especially during the morning rush, has seen chaos in motion. The trains aren't the problem. It's the scowling commuters circling the packed parking lots, looking -- often in vain -- for a spot.
Two weeks ago, about 80 Long Island Rail Road commuters angrily stormed a makeshift impound lot at the Ronkonkoma station after their illegally parked cars were towed into it. 
 But the outburst there, and the widespread frustration over parking at many stations, is actually a measure of how much the region's railroads have improved. More trains run on time, the heaters and air-conditioners usually work and commuters seem happier, so ridership has grown.
Last week, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, which is used by commuters from Connecticut and north of the city, announced a personal best: 97 percent of its trains have been on time so far this year. In 1983, only 80 percent of its trains ran on time.
The L.I.R.R. went from 83 percent on time in 1980 to 89 percent last year, and trains in New Jersey went from 88 percent on time in 1983 to 93 percent last year.
Ridership on Metro-North rose from 40 million in 1983 to 57 million in 1990, but dipped to 56 million last year because of the recession. In New Jersey, it rose similarly, from 32 million in 1983 to 45 million in 1988 before dropping to 42 million last year. On Long Island, ridership rose from 71 million in 1980 to 75 million in 1989, only to drop back again to 71 million last year.
More people still drive: a one-day survey in October 1990 by the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council estimated that 165,000 people took trains into Manhattan below 60th Street while 221,000 drove.
Among the factors that have pushed more people onto the trains: Outlying diesel lines have been electrified in recent years, and road traffic has become more miserable.
"We're a victim of our own success," said Daniel Brucker, a Metro-North spokesman. "The service is fast. It's efficient. It's comfortable. But now comes the problem of where do people park. If we can't get people on the trains, we're limiting our growth."
Plans to relieve the pressure are under way. New Jersey Transit is scrambling to build new lots or garages and has created more than 3,000 new spaces since 1985. The Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North are each committed to spending $20 million on parking, splitting the costs with the towns they serve. But a lack of vacant land near stations and a resistance to ugly parking garages have made for slow going. Even though Metro-North is adding 2,685 new spaces in Westchester County, it expects to be 3,300 spaces short by the year 2001.
The commuters who want those spots say train service is far better than it was a few years ago. David F. Freeman, a foundation executive in Manhattan, has been riding from the Red Bank station in New Jersey for 40 years. For 36 years, the train had to stop to take on or drop off a diesel engine where the overhead wires ended. When the route was electrified four years ago, almost half an hour was shaved off his daily commute. And, he said, "they've added new cars -- actually new, not rebuilt, like we used to get."
Harry P. Harris, chairman of the Connecticut Metro-North New Haven Rail Commuter Council, an advisory board appointed by the state legislature, said: "We now have the luxury of complaining about little things. You used to have to stand on trains which were frequently late. We even had a stretch when wheels were falling off. You now gripe because a train is a couple of minutes late."
Every day, railroad managers gather at Metro-North's Madison Avenue headquarters to dissect that morning's delays. "Everything that causes a delay is hunted down," Mr. Brucker said. "A few months ago, a squirrel on the New Haven line had crawled up in the overhead wires and got itself electrocuted. That created a short in the system and stopped a large number of trains. That squirrel, as well as the wires, was brought into the second floor, into the meeting."
 
400 on Waiting List
 As complaints about train service have faded, the complaints about parking have gotten louder. In Rye, N.Y., some 400 people languish on a waiting list for 625 parking permits. Before the mid-1980's, there was no list. In West Windsor, N.J., where the Princeton Junction station attracts commuters to both Philadelphia and New York City, 400 residents and 800 non-residents are waiting for spaces. Commuters may have to get up before dawn.
"By 6:45 in the morning, the paid parking is full," said Donald M. Rizzo, chairman of the West Windsor Parking Authority. "If you don't have to get to work that early, you've got a problem."
At some Metro-North stations, people have parked so close to the tracks that their cars have been hit by trains, Mr. Brucker said.
On Long Island, improvements have been less dramatic. "Most commuters would say that while the service they're getting is probably adequate, it's probably not adequate relative to the price of the ticket," said Sheldon Schachter, chairman of the L.I.R.R. Commuters Council.
Because the L.I.R.R. must compete with Amtrak for use of the East River tunnels, its problems scheduling trains are trickier and some experts are not sure it can ever match Metro-North's record.
At Ronkonkoma, the scene of the near-riot this month, a new plan for a larger parking lot is going slowly. Traffic rose from 2,000 riders per morning to 5,000 after electrification. "The capacity of that station was expanded four years ago," Mr. Schachter said, "and yet no one has gotten off their rear end to solve the parking problem."

HEADLINE: Housing Chief Quits Her Post Under Pressure

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Laura D. Blackburne, the chairwoman of New York City's Housing Authority, resigned under pressure yesterday after a week of mounting criticism of her spending practices, including the hundreds of thousands of dollars she spent on office furnishings and business trips.
At a hastily arranged news conference at City Hall yesterday afternoon, Mayor David N. Dinkins said that Ms. Blackburne, 53 years old, submitted a letter of resignation yesterday and that he had accepted it. 
 Mr. Dinkins said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, would immediately step down from her post to succeed Ms. Blackburne as chairwoman of the authority.
 
'Confidence Shaken'
 While citing Ms. Blackburne's accomplishments in improving living conditions in the city's public housing projects, Mr. Dinkins said, "Public confidence in her has been shaken, and her ability to function effectively as chair of the authority is irreparably damaged."
The system she has run since 1990 is the nation's largest housing authority. It shelters more than 600,000 people with a budget of $1.3 billion and staff of more than 15,000 employees.
Ms. Blackburne is the subject of five investigations, by the inspector general of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Manhattan, the State Attorney General, the city Department of Investigations and the Mayor's office.
"The investigations which have been launched limit the time and energies she would otherwise devote to her responsibilities as chair," Mr. Dinkins said.
Ms. Blackburne was not at the news conference yesterday. But she said in a statement issued by her office: "I have appreciated Mayor Dinkins' support, particularly during these last few trying days. Circumstances have forced me to resign in the best interest of the people of public housing."
Mr. Dinkins refused to comment on the investigations or to criticize her actions, other than to say her effectiveness had been undermined.
Beginning with an article in The Daily News on Feb. 12, a string of highly publicized reports have revealed that Ms. Blackburne had redecorated her office lavishly, with a $3,000 couch, among other things, and had used public money to pay for her to accompany the Mayor on his trip to South Africa.
The Mayor had asked all his commissioners to pay for the trip themselves, and earlier last week directed her to pay back the money. The Mayor said yesterday that he did not know if Ms. Blackburne had returned it yet.
Newly released records of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority also revealed that her spending habits as an M.T.A. board member had come under criticism there, and had prompted changes in the agency's rules on reimbursements. She did not resign her M.T.A. seat yesterday, transit officials said.
 
Embarrassments for Dinkins
 Her troubles were the latest in a series of embarrassing revelations about Dinkins aides that began last month with the admission by his former campaign treasurer that he stole $158,000 from its accounts, and continued Friday with a Department of Investigations report concluding that his Commissioner of Youth Services improperly awarded a contract to a foundation he formerly led.
The well-publicized incidents have each raised questions about the Mayor's choice of high-level appointees, and have each put him in the difficult position of choosing between demonstrating loyalty to a supporter and friend or jettisoning a liability.
On Friday, Mr. Dinkins appeared to be standing by Ms. Blackburne, saying he would make no decision on her tenure until all investigations were concluded. But he had actually made up his mind to seek her ouster earlier that day after aides had told him the accusations against Ms. Blackburne were serious and not likely to go away quickly, city officials said.
That evening, the Mayor instructed Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch to meet with Ms. Blackburne and inform her that he no longer had confidence in her ability to do her job because of the investigations and public perceptions.
"What I did was send word to her that I felt she could no longer be effective," the Mayor said yesterday.
Asked if it was difficult to seek Ms. Blackburne's resignation, Mr. Dinkins said: "Yes, because she's a friend. She's someone who's done a good job in the Housing Authority."
 
Mayor Valued Her Services
 Aides to the Mayor said yesterday that he had hesitated to dismiss Ms. Blackburne because she was a close friend and had performed a valuable service when she wrote the report that praised his handling of the Korean grocery boycott in Brooklyn. But at the same time, they said, he grew increasingly angry during the week, and felt betrayed by her spending and unsatisfied with her explanations of it.
The Mayor also valued her as an effective Housing Authority advocate, winning tens of millions of dollars in Federal housing money for New York City and working to rid projects of drug dealers.
Last week, supporters of Ms. Blackburne demonstrated outside City Hall. C. Vernon Mason, a lawyer who took part in the demonstration, said yesterday that she had been held to a different standard from that for officials in previous administrations, as well as the current one, because she is black. Mr. Mason said her actions warranted neither the swirl of publicity nor her resignation.
"The target of all that's been going on is not Laura Blackburne or even other people in the administration," Mr. Mason said. "It's David Dinkins himself."
As head of the Housing Authority, Ms. Blackburne expanded the range of social services offered to housing project residents, whose problems mirror those of the troubled neighborhoods where they are most often situated. Projects, Ms. Blackburne once said, should be "a place of hope and promise, not a holding pen for the poor and damaged."
Her agenda including job training, dropout classes, Scout troops, youth corps, stepping up eviction of drug dealers and the relocation of doubled-up families.
Federal and local housing officials give her high marks for innovative programs that have greatly improved living conditions in public housing projects.
Joseph G. Schiff, Assistant Secretary for Public and Indian Housing at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, had said he was impressed with Ms. Blackburne's work, particularly in monitoring systems for heating-oil deliveries, high school education programs and tenant organizations.
Mr. Schiff said yesterday that Ms. Blackburne's resignation would not affect the department inspector general's inquiry into her handling of Federal housing money.
Investigators are also looking into whether Ms. Blackburne violated any laws by setting up a nonprofit foundation with Housing Authority money and later accepting $3,100 from the foundation to pay for her trip to South Africa with the Mayor in late November.
Late last week, it was revealed that the chairwoman and seven other Housing Authority officials spent $16,000 in Federal money on a weeklong trip earlier this month to Puerto Rico, with excursions to St. Croix and St. John's in the Virgin Islands. The purpose of the trip, the city's Housing Authority said yesterday, was to help the Puerto Rican Housing Authority deal with drug problems and maintain buildings.
Many details of Ms. Blackburne's spending were disclosed to the press by employees of the Housing Authority and the M.T.A., who said they had been annoyed by Ms. Blackburne's brash, arrogant manner.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, 38, is leaving as the administration's chief promoter of economic development even as the city struggles to overcome one of the worst fiscal crisis since the 1970's.
After an initial period in which she was perceived by many in the business community as weak and inexperienced, she gradually earned respect from many of those same critics.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who has told the Mayor that she wanted to shift to a less taxing post to spend more time with her children, said yesterday that her new job would give her more control over her schedule.
Mr. Dinkins declined to name a successor to Ms. Hernandez-Pinero. Barry F. Sullivan, a longtime banker and retired head of First Chicago Corporation, has been reported to be Mr. Dinkins's first choice.

HEADLINE: DELAY BY THE U.S. SAID TO IMPERIL AID TO EX-SOVIET LANDS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
A delay by the United States in approving a large financing increase for the International Monetary Fund -- motivated in part by election-year politics -- is threatening to upset the West's efforts to provide billions of dollars in aid to Russia and other former Soviet republics, I.M.F. officials say.
The United States had promised other I.M.F. members that it would approve a new $12 billion contribution to the lending agency sometime in 1991, but its failure to do so has stalled plans to increase overall financing by $60 billion and thus threatened plans to grant aid to the Soviet Union. 
 Bush Administration officials say they have urged Congress to approve the $12 billion, although members of Congress say the Administration's pleas have been neither loud nor persistent. Democrats in Congress say they are leery of approving the move unless the White House takes the lead on the issue.
 
Electoral Considerations
 Officials of the I.M.F. attribute the delay to a desire by the White House and Congress not to offend the electorate by voting billions of dollars more in foreign aid when the economy is in recession.
Officials of Russia and the other republics have appealed repeatedly for help from international agencies and the industrialized nations for their economy. I.M.F. officials and aid experts say that unless the additional funds are approved soon, the I.M.F. and other agencies could face serious problems in planning a comprehensive aid program and providing the tens of billions of dollars in aid that the republics say they desperately need. Russia and several other republics have already requested membership in the expectation that they will get aid when they become members, which is expected in late April.
The republics are expected to formally request billions of dollars in assistance from the fund after they join it, which officials say they might do in late April at the fund's spring meeting. "There is an undercurrent of distress about America's leadership on this," said one I.M.F. official. "Our resources will be squeezed very seriously by the end of the year when the demand for financing by Russia and the republics hits the system."
I.M.F. officials say they have about $15 billion available for loans to nations in need. Russia alone is seeking about $6 billion for a fund to stabilize the ruble and $12 billion to help it finance crucial imports. Some economists say Ukraine and other republics will be seeking at least $10 billion more in aid. Many Western officials now say the increase in financing, which was planned in 1990, is inadequate because it was planned even before the Soviet Union collapsed and turned to the West for aid.
Some officials and economists fear that with the cold war over, Washington's hesitation on the funds is a step back from America's international commitments even as Washington has sought to portray itself as a leader of the effort to help the former Soviet Union.
"This, by itself, is not a huge signal of that, but combined with other concerns it is causing some nervousness," said Gregory A. Fossedal, a research fellow at the Hoover Institution who heads a study commission analyzing the I.M.F.'s operations.
 
Effect of New Hampshire Vote
 Members of Congress and many economists say that after President Bush's weak victory in the New Hampshire primary, it is less likely that the Administration will push hard for the financing increase, especially since many polls show that Americans believe that the President has paid too much attention to foreign affairs.
"Unless the White House is prepared to put a lot of effort into it, it's not going to sail through Congress," said John Williamson, a senior fellow with the Institute for International Economics, a Washington policy research institute. "I'm worried that New Hampshire will increase the Administration's reluctance to do anything that may displease the Republican right wing. I don't think the Bush Administration is showing much courage on this issue."
Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, noted that Republicans have accused Democrats of favoring foreign aid at the expense of domestic needs, a touchy issue in an election year.
 
'Shooting at Us'
 "The last time that foreign aid authorization was on the floor, the room was filled with Republican rhetoric attacking the Democratic foreign aid bill because it contained aid for the I.M.F.," he said. "If the Republican Party thinks the Democrats in the House are going to carry the Administration's water on this issue while they are shooting at us, they must be smoking something that's illegal."
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, said he told the Administration last year "that they ought to try to move this effort through." He said, "A substantive case can be made for a quota increase, but as a practical matter the Administration squandered or missed the opportunity last year to push it through."
Mr. Sarbanes, chairman of the Senate's subcommittee on international economic policy, said the fund increase was "probably not going to go anywhere" this year. He added that it would not go forward unless there was broad support from Republicans in Congress.
 
Approval Is Doubted
 Two weeks ago, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is chairman the Senate appropriations subcommittee in charge of I.M.F. financing, also said he did not see Congress approving the $12 billion contribution this year.
Testifying before a House subcommittee on Feb. 5, Under Secretary of the Treasury David Mulford said of the I.M.F. financing increase that "at some time, there will have to be a big push to get it done" but he said it was "very difficult" to say when that might be.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has expressed support for the financing increase, and the official said Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will soon also speak on its behalf.
 
'A Lot More Difficult'
 One Administration official said: "The Administration still wants it passed, and wants it passed as soon as it can be. But it is clear that in an election year, this sort of issue is a lot more difficult."
Under I.M.F. rules, the additional $60 billion in funds will not take effect unless countries with 85 percent of the votes approve their contributions. Since the United States has 19 percent of the votes, its failure to approve its one-time $12 billion financing increase has blocked the overall increase. The current American stake in the I.M.F. is almost $24 billion out of a total of $120 billion.
In June 1990, I.M.F. members agreed in principle to raise the group's total financing to $180 billion from $120 billion, but that agreement was contingent upon most members approving their portion of the overall increase. I.M.F. officials say the money nations give to the fund is an investment on which donors receive interest each year.
The I.M.F. could allow the financing increase to take effect after June 30, with Washington's approval but not its participation, so long as members with 70 percent of the votes approve their contributions. According to I.M.F. officials, 110 nations, accounting for more than 70 percent of the votes, have already approved their contributions.
 
Reluctance Among Members
 But I.M.F. officials say that the United States and other I.M.F. members are reluctant to see the financing increase go through without Washington's share.
American officials say they are averse to a capital increase without Washington's joining in because that would reduce Washington's portion of the total financing as well as reducing its voting power at the fund to 14 percent from about 19 percent. This would mean that the United States would lose its veto over I.M.F. policy decisions because I.M.F. rules require 85 percent support for any important actions.
The I.M.F. will not be providing all the financing needed by Russia and the other republics; the World Bank and aid from other nations will also help. But I.M.F. officials say the fund will face a liquidity squeeze without a financing increase, especially since poor African, Asian and Latin American countries are seeking more aid. The I.M.F. grants loans to help the developing world and former Communist countries shape up and rebuild their economies. Loans are granted only to member nations, and are usually made only after the nations agree to a program of economic changes approved by the fund.

HEADLINE: The Path of Andrew Carnegie Leads to the Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Just as aspiring basketball players tack posters of Wilt Chamberlain on their wall, Peter W. Janssen kept a book commissioned by Andrew Carnegie on his nightstand. "Think Rich and Grow," by Napoleon Hill examined the lives of some of the world's richest men in order to provide a blueprint for success.
"The book helped me achieve my goals and financial security," he said. "But now it is time to go on from there, and like Carnegie, put that money to good use." 
 Mr. Janssen, a 32-year-old investment banker, says his goal is simple: "I want to be the world's greatest philanthropist."
Why? After soaring through the roaring 80's, he says, he needs another reason for creating wealth. "When you make enough money where you're comfortable, then you're not striving," he said. "I needed a new goal and this gives me one with the right focus."
Mr. Janssen, a senior vice-president at D.H. Blair in Manhattan, took his first step toward his goal last week when he donated $10,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. He also convinced five co-workers to donate an additional $11,800.
While Mr. Janssen may be modeling himself after Andrew Carnegie, he might also want to learn about Lillian Kent of Manhattan, a model of persistence. Despite tough times, she sent her 30th annual contribution to the Neediest Cases. "Although my income is lower this year than last and will be even lower next year (as a retiree the lowering of interest rates is not a joy to me)," she wrote in a letter attached to her $100 donation, "I am maintaining the level of my 1990 contribution."
And there is the example of Phyllis and Martin Zelkind of Queens Village, a model of flexibility. "For the past 27 years our contributions were equal to the number of years we had participated," they wrote. "Consequently our check this year was to have been for $28. But, the increase in the numbers of needy people and the problems they face compel us to double our contribution. Enclosed is a check for $56."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor, and disabled. So far the 80th annual appeal, which concludes Feb. 29, has raised $4.7 million from more than 15,000 donations.
The Times covers the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed on directly to seven charities. The money provides many forms of relief, including food for the hungry, homes for the homeless, and clothing for those without. The seven charities also use the money to help people pay for operations, to help foster parents care for children with AIDS, and to help emotionally troubled adolescents get their lives back on track.

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Sam Howe Verhovek

 BODY:

 Like Nelson, Like Nephew
While troops of national reporters were camped out in Albany waiting to hear whether Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would make a last-minute entry in the New Hampshire primary late last year, another New Yorker with a famous political name was wrestling with the same decision -- and was finally talked out of it by the White House. 
 The would-be candidate was Laurance Rockefeller, 47 years old, an environmental lawyer and nephew of the late Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, and the primary he wound up forgoing was the Republican vice presidential contest.
Like Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Rockefeller prepared filing papers and agonized up until the end about whether to run. But unlike Mr. Cuomo, he did so privately. Details of the non-campaign have emerged in a somewhat self-deprecating essay about his short-lived political career, "On New Hampshire and CO<2>."
Under a quirk of New Hampshire law, residents are able to vote on a separate line for vice president. Since no other state has the provision, the contest means little. But Mr. Rockefeller and several other Republican environmentalists -- including Theodore (Ted) Roosevelt 4th, a Manhattan investment banker -- seriously explored entering the primary to protest what they said they believed was the Bush Administration's failure to address global warming.
The environmentalists settled on Mr. Rockefeller, he writes, in part because he had "crisscrossed New Hampshire for a month leading up to the 1964 primary, organizing students for my Uncle Nelson and campaigning myself."
As word of the budding campaign filtered to Washington, Mr. Rockefeller was summoned to the White House on the night before the Dec. 20 New Hampshire deadline to meet with the White House chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, and Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter. Among other things, the officials argued that the insurgent campaign "might lead the President to feel he didn't get enough credit from environmentalists and lose interest rather than being encouraged to do better," Mr. Rockefeller wrote.
As the minutes ticked by and Mr. Cuomo was hand-wringing himself out of the race, Mr. Rockefeller was doing much the same. One reason, he said, was that Mr. Skinner was new on the job and deserved a chance to stake out a more concerned position on global warming than his predecessor, John H. Sununu; another was that Dan Quayle was not listed on the ballot so "no real contest was possible."
So Mr. Rockefeller pulled back, although he sent a long note to the President expressing concern about his environmental policies that quickly drew letters from Mr. Bush, Mr. Skinner and Mr. Teeter, all pledging to re-examine the issue. Mr. Teeter's note not only expressed relief that Mr. Rockefeller, who lives in Manhattan, would not be running in the New Hampshire primary, but also added that he was "even more pleased that your Governor has decided to take a pass."
In the end, the vice presidential contest in New Hampshire was won by Herb Clark Jr., a political gadfly from Concord. In one little-noted phenomenon, though, Mr. Quayle actually drew 6,613 write-in votes in the contest, 36 more write-in votes than Mr. Cuomo received in the Democratic Presidential primary.
 
Conservatives Are Hedging
 As if the threat of revolt from the left were not enough for President Bush, the success of Patrick J. Buchanan in New Hampshire has now emboldened the Conservative Party in New York State to threaten to withhold its endorsement for this fall's election.
Mr. Bush drew 243,457 votes on the Conservative line in the 1988 presidential election. While that was only about one-tenth of his vote total as a Republican, the Conservative ballot line could provide a critical margin in a close election.
But Michael R. Long, the party chairman, hedged in an interview on giving Mr. Bush the 1992 line, saying he wanted to see several cabinet members replaced with conservatives and a renewed "no new taxes" pledge from the President first.
Mr. Long said Bush campaign officials had asked him recently whether the "door was closed" to the Conservative nomination. "I said no," he recounted, "but it's not exactly wide open either."
 
Keeping Options Open
 A scramble is under way in the Connecticut General Assembly to fill two legislative auditors' posts that were last vacant when Lyndon Johnson was President. The problem, which threatens to raise tensions among both the majority Democrats and minority Republicans, is that at least half a dozen lawmakers are interested in the jobs, but state law prohibits any of them from even being nominated while serving in the Legislature.
For the would-be applicants, including both Deputy Speakers of the House, the options are sticky. They could resign from their jobs now, to be nominated without guarantee of confirmation. Or they could push the leadership to name temporary auditors, then wait to see how they do in the general election in November, when voter anger about taxes and the recession is expected to sweep many legislators onto the street. Or they could push to scrap the restriction and allow open nominations.
Still another option is to stall until the regular session ends in May, when leaders in the House and Senate could fill the $74,000-a-year jobs on their own from outside the legislature. The wrinkle is that any job filled this summer would have to be ratified next January by the full legislature.
