LENGTH: 1368 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: South;
Support for Clinton Appears Firm in Home Base

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Mildred Bryson, who sells fruit from the back of her truck in the nearby town of Social Circle, is not an expert on politics, but she can sense a politician she likes, and she likes Bill Clinton.
"I don't think his character is a problem," she said. "He seems like a good man to me. He doesn't brag like some of the other candidates." 
 In other words, Mr. Clinton as soft-spoken, Dixie-inflected, yes-ma'am, no-ma'am son of the South counts for more than Bill Clinton as tabloid target.
Interviews with a number of voters and public officials throughout the South suggest that sentiment for Mr. Clinton is holding firm in spite of reports in a supermarket tabloid of marital infidelity and assertions that he had tried to avoid the draft in the Vietnam era. Many analysts had wondered whether the accusations would erode support in his conservative home base.
A strong showing in the Southern primaries culminating on March 10, Super Tuesday, in which he has long been expected to do well, could provide the Arkansas Governor with a significant lift in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
There is no question that some Southern voters have been put off by the reports about Mr. Clinton. At the least, the questions have erased the sense of Mr. Clinton's invincibility in the region.
"I think he's got problems," said Larry James, a painter who works at Newton General Hospital in nearby Covington. "People pick up on that, particularly his marital problems. We're just not like people up North. There are things they don't care about there that make a difference to us."
Mr. James said he was leaning toward President Bush, regardless of what happened with the Democrats.
But among Southern Democratic officials, Mr. Clinton retains the support of the overwhelming majority.
He has resources and an organization that dwarf those of his rivals, and his main opponent seems to be a heretofore little-known former Senator from Massachusetts with no real organization in any Southern state.
Thus, when Paul E. Tsongas, the top vote getter in the New Hampshire primary last week, and Mr. Clinton arrived here on Friday to address the annual gathering of Georgia Democrats, the front page of The Atlanta Journal featured a large color picture of Mr. Clinton with a quote above it from Lieut Gov. Pierre Howard reading: "Tsongas is not Greek for Bubba."
Representative John Lewis, the Georgia Congressman and civil rights pioneer, who endorsed the Arkansan on Friday, said Mr. Clinton would "win the Southern primaries in a sweep and will be the nominee of the party."
 
'Referendum on the Future'
 "The rank-and-file voters here in the South are not going to be concerned with the draft issue," Mr. Lewis said. "They want to get good health care, to send their children to good schools, to get a job. This election is a referendum on the future, not the past."
One of the important Super Tuesday primaries will be in Texas, and a poll there reported in The Houston Chronicle today showed Mr. Clinton with the support of 40 percent of the state's likely Democratic primary voters. Mr. Tsongas was backed by 9 percent, and 42 percent remained undecided. The poll of 400 Democrats had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
In the full poll of 835 likely voters of both parties, conducted Feb. 12-19, two-thirds said the press had paid too much attention to Mr. Clinton's personal life, and more than half said the personal issues would have no effect on their voting. But 3 in 10 said they would be much less or somewhat less likely to vote for Mr. Clinton because of the questions. These figures had a four-point margin of error.
 
'What the Democrats Need'
 Few Southerners seem willing to say Mr. Clinton is home free, and additional damaging publicity could transform the campaign, which includes primaries in Georgia on March 3 and South Carolina on March 7, followed by Super Tuesday balloting on March 10 in Texas, Florida, Mississippi, Tennessee and Louisiana. But for now, Mr. Clinton seems to have weathered the storms that set back his campaign for weeks.
"He's a Southerner, who can get the support of blacks and whites," said John Corbett, pastor of Springfield Baptist Church in Greenville, S.C. "He's what the Democrats need. He's moderate, mainstream, a decent man."
Asked about accusations of infidelity, he said: "I do believe in forgiviness and grace, and I'm just not willing to cut somebody's neck off because they've done something in the past."
Of 14 people interviewed in South Carolina last week, only one cited the marital and draft questions as a reason for voting against Mr. Clinton
 
Many See Problems
 Other Southerners, however, do see fundamental problems.
When Mr. Clinton campaigned Thursday in Savannah, his audience included John Siebert, an unemployed disabled veteran from nearby Hinesville who came with six other disabled veterans to protest the appearance.
"A lot of people served their country, and he ran off to England," said Mr. Siebert, who carried a sign reading, "No draft dodger or playboy for President."
Similarly, the Rev. Joe Lovelady, pastor of the East Edgewater Baptist Church in New Orleans, said he was troubled by both questions and thought Mr. Clinton had been seriously damaged in the South.
"There is a strong streak of Puritanism, in this country," he said, adding that although people talk about a liberal approach, "when we close the curtain to the voting booth, we find the Puritanism creeping in."
But even in Hinesville, Ga., with an economy heavily dependent on the military operations at Fort Stewart, there is sympathy for Mr. Clinton and doubt about the validity or relevance of the accusations against him.
 
'Reached a Saturation Point'
 "Every time, somebody runs for office, whether it's in the White House or here in Hinesville, they're going to dig up dirt, whether it's true or not," said Sheila Bowdle, manager of Leroy's, a pawn shop.
And, even among conservative voters, Mr. Clinton may be benefiting from a kind of scandal fatigue and a backlash against what some see as the constant drumbeat of stories about the private affairs of public people.
"I think people have just reached a saturation point," said Ida Vaughn, a 66-year-old grandmother who owns a feed store in Simpsonville, S.C. "First there was that Supreme Court deal and the Kennedy affair and by the time we got to this, people were sick of it. This was just a lot of stirring."
Still, Mrs. Vaughn, who describes herself as a Democrat who voted in 1988 for George Bush, said she was not overly impressed with any of the Democrats and hoped someone else ran.
In fact, most people interviewed said they had not made up their minds about how they would vote.
But Mr. Clinton's advantages in the region appear enormous. With endorsements from powerful black leaders like Mr. Lewis and Representative Mike Espy of Mississippi and most of the influential Hispanic politicians in Texas, he is the only candidate with a base in the minority populations that are critical in Southern Democratic primaries.
The Rev. Zebadee Bridges, pastor of the Asia Baptist Church in New Orleans and president of the Inter-Denominational Alliance of more than 300 black churches in the New Orleans area, said he and many of his colleagues were praising Mr. Clinton.
"This is politics," he said of the questions about Mr. Clinton. "These are issues that were brought up to destroy this man. We're not concerned about those issues. We're concerned about this country."
Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, a Clinton supporter, said Friday that he did not think the accusations would damage Mr. Clinton unless another candidate made a concerted effort to emphasize them. He conceded that whether or not the other Democrats tried to exploit the issues, the Republicans certainly would. Others agreed.
"I think Clinton will do very well in the Southern primaries," said Hastings Wyman, editor of the Southern Political Report, a newsletter. "I don't think the draft issue will hurt Clinton much in the primaries. I think when it will be an issue is November."

HEADLINE: Haitian Legislators and Aristide Agree on His Return

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Monday, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and leaders of the country's Parliament signed an agreement just before midnight Sunday paving the way for a restoration to democratic government and his return as President.
For the agreement to take effect, it must be ratified by the Haitian Parliament. The accord sets no timetable for ratification or his return. No members of the military were present at the talks, casting doubt about whether the agreement would be carried out. 
 The sudden breakthrough in a five-month political impasse was achieved in part because of Father Aristide's willingness to make crucial concessions on the conciliatory treatment of the military, which overthrew him on Sept. 30.
The agreement, reached after three days of negotiations here at the headquarters of the Organization of American States, accepts Mr. Aristide's choice of Prime Minister, Rene Theodore, and specifies that the two high offices will operate separately under the Haitian Constitution.
 
Assurances to Foes
 This condition is apparently intended to assuage fears of those who thought that Father Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest who gained popularity among the poor, had shown a tendency to accumulate too much government power for himself in a deeply divided society.
The economic embargo imposed on Haiti by the organization and it member states is to be lifted upon ratification of the agreement.
The agreement specifically rules out intervention by foreign forces, which all Haitians oppose. The threat of an international police or peacekeeping force, which regional nations had begun to suggest as a last resort to break the crisis, may have played a role in bringing the Haitians to the table.
The agreement does not mention the fate of the army chief, Gen. Raoul Cedras. But officials at the organization said that it was understood that Father Aristide had conceded that the general could remain in place for the time being. Until this weekend, Father Aristide had demanded the removal and arrest or banishment of General Cedras.
 
General Amnesty
 The agreement goes further to reassure the military by recognizing the need for a general amnesty. There are known to be fears in the military that Father Aristide's populist Lavalas political movement may turn lynch mobs on troops if and when he is restored to the presidency. Under the agreement, however, the army and the police are to be separated, and both institutions reorganized and professionalized.
Military threats to civilian political leaders has not yet ended. Diplomats and American officials here note that Mr. Theodore, who was the focus of two attacks in recent weeks, had to be escorted to the airport by American and Canadian diplomats in Port-au-Prince for his flight to Washington last week. The envoys also had to persuade officials at the airport to let Mr. Theodore, who is the leader of the Communist Party in Haiti and who is viewed a moderate, board the plane.
The agreement, the groundwork for which was negotiated by an O.A.S. team led by a former Colombian Foreign Minister, Augusto Ramirez Ocampo, was signed by Father Aristide, the president of the Haitian Senate, Dejean Belizaire, and the leader of the Chamber of Deputies, Alexandre Medard. Also signing were Mr. Ramirez Ocampo and memebers of his negotiating mission and Joao Clemente Baena Soares, Secretary General of the Organization of American States.
Although the agreement between Father Aristide and leaders of the Parliament came as a major and unexpected advance in the organization's efforts to restore his presidency, many potential stumbling blocks could still delay or prevent his return to power.
Even though Father Aristide had been persuaded to drop repeated vows to see General Cedras punished, it is far from clear whether the Haitian Army is ready to acquiesce in any political settlement.
The ambivalence toward the negotiations of the army, and the provisional government it supports, was underscored in recent days by repeated and angry disavowels of the talks.
For Father Aristide to return, moreover, General Cedras would have to rein in unruly, hard-line segments of the army that have sown terror and created public disturbances every time political efforts to restore the elected government seemed to be advancing.

HEADLINE: United Way Awaits Inquiry On Its President's Practices

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
The United Way of America, the nation's largest charity network, is conducting an internal investigation after its president was accused of lavish spending and free-wheeling management practices.
The accusations have caused a few of the network's larger members to delay a decision on paying dues until the inquiry is completed on April 2. 
 In his 21-year tenure, the president, William Aramony, has been widely credited with creatively building a coast-to-coast network of 2,100 independent United Ways that collectively raised $3.1 billion in its last campaign. The autonomous local units help support 42,000 health and social service agencies.
But this month reports in several publications raised questions about Mr. Aramony's travel habits, salary, possible cronyism in hiring and relations with five spin-off companies he helped create.
 
Vote of Confidence
 In anticipation of the critical reports, Mr. Aramony asked outside investigators to review his work, and based on that preliminary inquiry, a 14-member executive committee of his organization's board gave him a unanimous vote of confidence earlier this month.
A more wide-ranging review is now under way by a Washington law firm, Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand, Mr. Aramony said in an interview Saturday.
He said he welcomed this inquiry and that it would deal more fully with the spinoff companies that were started to help the local members buy goods or services at lower, bulk rates. One company is now headed by his son, Robert Aramony, but he said he had no influence in the selection of his on for the position.
From its headquarters in Alexandria, Va., United Way of America offers training to staff members of local United Ways, provides fund-raising literature, films and kits, and most importantly, has marshaled the support of business leaders to lead local drives.
 
An Outstretched Hand
 United Way has made the logo of an outstretched hand a nationally recognized symbol of charitable giving and has raised millions of dollars through workers' payroll donations and corporate and individual gifts.
The national organization, which has a $28.4 million budget, is supported mainly by voluntary dues from 1,400 member organizations.
Mr. Aramony, 64 years old, receives $463,000 in salary and benefits like health insurance, which makes him the highest-paid executive in the charity field. .
The organization's Executive Committee voted to increase his salary this year but he refused the raise because of the poor economic conditions, Mr. Aramony said during the interview at the offices of United Way of New York City, 99 Park Avenue.
Mr. Aramony said he first became aware of accusations against him about six months ago, when unsigned letters were sent to the 37-member board raising questions about his salary, travel habits and management practices.
In December, reporters for Regardies Magazine, The Washington Post and Jack Anderson, the columnist, also began inquiries about his activities, and have since published articles. United Way sent copies of some articles to its members along with memos that, in effect, aimed to respond to them and probably also to blunt any adverse reaction.
Among the questions raised by the articles was Mr. Aramony's appointment of Thomas J. Merlo as United Way's chief financial officer.
Although Mr. Aramony said he had known Mr. Merlo since 1958 when both were associated with United Way in Miami, he was unaware until reporters began inquiring that Mr. Merlo had personal financial difficulties and had been sued in Florida for unpaid loans. After he learned of the financial troubles, Mr. Aramony said, he told Mr. Merlo he was putting him on paid administrative leave and he would be replaced.
The current investigation is focusing on companies created by United Way. Robert Aramony helped run two of the spin-off companies and now heads a third, Sales Service/America, which sells telephone equipment and mail-order merchandise with the United Way logo.
Partnership Umbrella, another of the spin-off companies, bought and furnished a $430,000 apartment in the Bristol Hotel in Manhattan that is used by the older Mr. Aramony. He described it as a two-room combined office-residence that he uses instead of a hotel, thereby saving money, and said it was used also by company members.
Mr. Aramony said that he traveled often and sometimes in luxury, but he said: "I hate traveling, but I'm on the road 192 days of the year. I've been on the Concorde twice, maybe three times, when my schedule required speed."
Many of the local United Way fund-raising campaigns have ended or are winding down, and Mr. Aramony said he expected the totals to be higher than last year. But a few leaders of local United Ways said they feared the negative reports about Mr. Aramony could dampen future giving, and they underscored that the use of their contributions is decided locally by boards of volunteers, and their operations are independent.
 
Dues Are Delayed
 "We've had a few calls but no tempest brewing," said David A. Paradine, president of United Way in Portland, Ore., which has decided to delay until April a decision on whether to pay national dues. The United Way of King County, Wash., which includes Seattle, also said it would delay paying 1992 dues until its board had examined the issues in early March.
United Way of New York City, one of the largest contributors, is to pay $550,000, said Ralph Dickerson Jr., president. "As a dues payer we want to hear and weigh carefully the results of the investigation," he said. "We are hearing some things for the first time, we are surprised and we want all the facts on the table before we make our decision about future participation."
United Way of Chicago/Crusade of Mercy, which has the largest single campaign and expects increased contributions of $111 million, has not considered withholding dues but expressed its concern to United Way of America's Board, said Martin Nickelbine, a spokesman.
The law firm that is conducting the current inquiry refused to comment on it. But the 14-member Executive Committee was confident it had a substantially complete picture from the inquiries started in December, Dr. LaSalle D. Leffall Jr., committee chairman and professor of surgery at Howard University College of Medicine.
It was on that basis the committee members held a conference call on Feb. 3 and unanimously expressed confidence in Mr. Aramony, he said. The committee and the full 37-member Board of United Way, which is headed by John F. Akers, chairman of I.B.M., are made up of leaders from business, education, minority and civic organizations.
"Some things we knew could have been done better if the system of accounting was better," said Dr. Lefall. "But we also considered Bill Aramony has given 21 years of his life and excellent service and lives and breaths United Way. When our auditors examined the books, we found we actually owed him $1,300."

International
After stuggling through much of the 1980's to survive Japanese competition, Harley-Davidson and hundreds of American companies are challenging Japanese manufacturers at home. [Page A1.] Although they conformed to the rules of what many say is required to succeed in Japan, the Haagen-Dazs and Borden ice cream operations there have widely different histories. [D4.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: South Dakota;
Democrats, in Midwestern Debate, Aggressively Court the Farm Vote

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 23

 BODY:
In a free-wheeling, often chaotic debate that was marked by personal barbs, six Democratic candidates for President virtually tripped over one another tonight trying to assure South Dakotans that they were most sympathetic to the needs of rural America.
While the primary election on Tuesday is viewed as a showdown between two farm state Senators, Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, neither wasted any time in attacking his rivals as insensitive to family farmers. The other Democrats insisted that they understood the importance of agriculture to the nation's economy. 
 At the outset of the televised debate, Mr. Kerrey assailed Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas for having an adviser, Robert Shapiro of the Progressive Policy Institute, who has "made some provocative and negative statements about agriculture."
Mr. Clinton denied that Mr. Shapiro had advised him on such matters, and said he was surprised that Mr. Kerrey would make it an issue in radio advertising here. "It's amazing to me that Senator Kerrey would attack me on the ads," Mr. Clinton said, "since we served on the Agriculture Committee of the National Governors Association together."
Not willing to concede the farm vote to his rivals from the heartland, Mr. Clinton declared: "Senators Harkin and Kerrey know that I've been a farm state Governor for 11 years."
Sponsored by the South Dakota Democratic Party, the 90-minute event was billed as a forum that would offer the candidates no chance for rebuttal. But the audience at the Howard Johnson Hotel here, and the viewers on South Dakota's public television stations and the national C-Span cable television network, were treated to the liveliest of the five national debates held so far.
Mr. Harkin, for one, called on former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who was the top vote-getter in the New Hampshire primary and was a leader in today's caucuses in Maine, to renounce his proposal for a 5-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax.
But Mr. Tsongas challenged Mr. Harkin for interrupting him, saying, "We talk about personal decency; let's practice it." He also said he did not know much about agriculture, but said that did not mean he did not understand rural issues.
"I acknowledge that Bob Kerrey and Tom Harkin know a lot more about agriculture than I do," Mr. Tsongas said. "But I know how to listen, how to learn. I don't compete with you, Bob."
Mr. Kerrey shot back, accusing Mr. Tsongas of knowing more about agriculture than he lets on, and of not being a friend of the heartland. "It's not like you're coming into the state and hearing it all right now," Mr. Kerrey said. Saying, "I'm not trying to be personal," Mr. Kerrey went on to accuse Mr. Tsongas of having a poor record on farm issues in the Senate.
The attacks were punctuated by laughter. At one point, the moderator, Ken Bode, an analyst for Cable News Network and graduate of the University of South Dakota, repeated what he said was a line from Mr. Kerrey that Mr. Tsongas thought "a combine is used to mix a martini."
"Great line, but I did not say that," Mr. Kerrey said.
With comic timing, Mr. Tsongas asked later, "Answer me this: What is a martini?"
Coming off a strong showing today in Maine, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California said the United States should not spend any more money on foreign aid until farmers and small businesses were better taken care of. He devoted most of his time to repeating his themes of overhauling a corrupt political system.
But he did not escape the attacks of Larry Agran, the former Mayor of Irvine, Calif., who is usually excluded from debates of the major candidates but was invited the state party to this event. He accused his fellow Californian of hypocrisy in deriding special-interest donations.
"When I hear Jerry Brown, the grand champion of raising special-interest money in the 70's and 80's," Mr. Agran said angrily, "I'm up to here with it." Turning to Mr. Brown, his voice rising, Mr. Agran said, "You have raised tens of millions of dollars in California and elsewhere."
At the end of the debate, Mr. Agran mimicked Mr. Brown by holding up a sign with his "800" number for contributions. "I want to make Jerry Brown feel more comfortable," he said of Mr. Brown, who often irritates his rivals by giving out his own "800" number at debates.
The candidates also debated American Indian affairs, the environment and health care, but spent far more time than they have in previous encounters outlining the differences among themselves.
Each of the Democrats took a shot at Mr. Tsongas, who, they complained, has not been held responsible for the consequences of his positions.
Mr. Clinton, who accused Mr. Tsongas on Saturday of engaging in "pious rhetoric" on the campaign trail, lashed out.
"It is frustrating for me to be told the only morally appropriate way to wean America off cheap foreign oil is a nickel-a-gallon gasoline tax," Mr. Clinton said. "Your incomes went down and your taxes went up in the 80's and Senator Tsongas wants to feed you more of the same in the 90's. And it's wrong."
 
The Men to Beat
 But some of the candidates seemed at a loss in competing with Mr. Harkin and Mr. Kerrey, both of whom must do well in order to continue credible campaigns for the Democratic nomination.
Mr. Clinton as much as acknowledged in his closing statement that he does not expected to win in the South Dakota contest. "I wish my state bordered South Dakota, but it doesn't," he said.
And Mr. Tsongas boasted that his wife, Niki, and children "have South Dakotan blood in their veins." Mr. Tsongas' father-in-law is from South Dakota.
Mr. Kerrey's campaign is widely viewed as the best organized in South Dakota, and a poll published Sunday by The Argus Leader, the state's largest newspaper, found that he was ahead of the pack. The newspaper also endorsed Mr. Kerrey.

HEADLINE: Modest Goals for an Energy Bill

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
With the elimination of major provisions aimed at oil conservation and production, the energy bill passed by the Senate last week focuses mostly on greater efficiency and competition in the electric utility industry, though experts expect its impact to be modest.
The National Energy Strategy, outlined by President Bush during the Persian Gulf war, originally focused heavily on oil issues. But by the time the bill cleared the Senate, both main oil provisions -- to allow drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and to require cars to use less gasoline -- were stripped because they threatened to sink the whole package. 
 The House version being drawn up takes a similar tack. The measures together, though they may bring modest cuts in electricity use and some reduction in consumers' utility bills, draw little enthusiasm from energy experts, who said the bills would only reinforce a movement that was already under way in many states.
 
'Between a Yawn and a Groan'
 "The right reaction is somewhere between a yawn and a groan," Peter Bradford, the chairman of the New York Public Service Commission and a former member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said of the Senate bill.
He and others said the Senate measure had missed many opportunities for electric efficiency improvements, especially in the Federal Government itself, and that the goals of the package were extremely modest, falling short of those of some states.
Ralph Cavanagh, an energy expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a not-for-profit organization specializing in environmental and health issues, said that under California's current energy plan, three-quarters of all new demand for electricity over the next 20 years would be met with efficiency improvements, even though the population of California was expected to grow at twice the national average.
California's idea was that those energy savings would be cheaper than new energy sources, Mr. Cavanagh said, but "no such commitment underlies the national effort."
Representative Philip R. Sharp, the chairman of the Energy and Commerce subcommittee that put together the bulk of the House package, said in an interview before the Senate passed its bill that with the Senate's dropping of the Arctic drilling and car-mileage issues, the central parts of the energy package would be two provisions that primarily concern electricity generators.
The provisions are in both the House and Senate versions, but differ in their details. The Senate version also includes simplified rules for licensing of new nuclear plants, but the House version does not. Such a provision is expected to face strong opposition in the House.
 
Interstate Utilities
 One provision of the House and Senate measures would repeal parts of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 that make it difficult for utilities to operate in more than one state. A repeal would allow investor-owned utilities to build power plants almost anywhere in the country and sell the power to other utilities in the area.
Currently, only non-utility companies can own such free-standing power plants, and advocates of the repeal said that allowing utilities into the business would stimulate competition and lower costs. Not all utilities agreed that an increase in competition would lower costs, however, and not everyone agreed that such a change would make much difference in cost in this period of relatively slow growth in electricity demand.
A second big provision would open access to the electric transmission system to independent electricity generators and others. The system is now largely controlled in patchwork fashion, depending on who owns the power lines in a particular location. This, too, has deeply divided the electricity industry.
Mr. Sharp, an Indiana Democrat, pointed out that his bill would also encourage public utility commissions to institute rules that put efficiency investments on par with investments in new generators. A utility that needed another 10 megawatts of power, for example, would be encouraged to try to reduce demand by helping its customers use energy more efficiently rather than simply build a small generating station. The technique is known as least-cost energy planning or integrated resources planning.
The idea, critics said, was sound but hardly original. John C. Fox, manager of energy efficiency services at the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, said 41 states had adopted the idea or had "processes under way currently that will lead to its adoption."
But some states might be encouraged to go a step farther, redesigning utility rates so that an electric company that had succeeded in selling fewer kilowatt-hours of power was rewarded with higher revenues. Mr. Bradford of the New York commission said that seven states now had such rates.
The House version also mandates efficiency standards for appliances, lights and motors, which environmentalists called a good start.
 
No Pressure on Oil Policy
 With oil prices currently depressed, there was little impetus for significant changes in oil policy to be included in the energy bill.
Oil prices have fallen to about what they were before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990. On an inflation-adjusted basis, they are near their lowest levels since World War II.
"It continues, from a consumer's point of view, to be a pretty good bargain," said Daniel Yergin, the energy historian and consultant.
One significant oil-related provision remains: the bill the Senate approved still calls for the Federal Government to buy cars that run on something besides gasoline, like natural gas, methanol or electricity. But even with that provision, Washington seems unlikely to be the main force in the evolution of the car; that role, say experts, probably lies with California, which has set progressively stricter air pollution rules that will require alternative fuels.
Another oil provision survived only in the House energy bill. A fee of a penny a gallon would be imposed on oil refiners and importers to pay for faster filling of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, in effect making refiners and importers pay for oil stored in Government-owned underground caverns. The extra cost, however, will probably be passed on to consumers.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS
When Styles Clash: Time Warner's Rupture -- A special report;
A Divorce in the Executive Suite

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
They were corporate America's odd couple. On the one hand, there was the steely, guarded N. J. Nicholas Jr., the epitome of the button-down culture of Henry Luce's Time Inc. A man legendary for his severity, it was said he would turn in his mother if she exaggerated on her expense account.
On the other, there was the suave, garrulous Steven J. Ross, the embodiment of the freewheeling and prodigal style of Warner Communications Inc., the company he built over three decades from a funeral-parlor-cum-rent-a-car business into a global entertainment company. 
 And in the wings was Mr. Nicholas's archrival, Gerald M. Levin, who had been sidelined years ago by Mr. Nicholas's rising career, but who had no intention of playing Mr. Nicholas's No. 2 at Time Warner Inc., the newly formed media conglomerate.
Still, the 1990 merger of Time and Warner had made Mr. Ross and Mr. Nicholas co-chief executives. Mr. Nicholas was there by Mr. Ross's agreement, having been hand-picked by J. Richard Munro, the former Time Inc. chairman who had been mentor to Mr. Levin and Mr. Nicholas.
Then, three months ago, Time Warner disclosed that Mr. Ross, who is 64 years old, was ill with prostate cancer. With Mr. Ross's death suddenly viewed as a stark possibility, it was clear both that his relationship with Mr. Nicholas was floundering and that the company would find it difficult ever to integrate fully under Mr. Nicholas. "He wanted to be sure that the right person was in place, and that person was Jerry," a family friend said.
Working by telephone from his homes in New York and East Hampton, L.I., Mr. Ross, who is undergoing chemotherapy, set in motion a plan to remove Mr. Nicholas, according to a top lieutenant, and install Mr. Levin. Last weekend, Mr. Levin visited Mr. Munro at his home in Connecticut and said he could not continue and was contemplating leaving, a Time Warner executive said.
Mr. Munro, still a Time Warner director, appears to have been sufficiently disenchanted with Mr. Nicholas's management that he reversed his own decision, made several years ago, to annoint Mr. Nicholas. He agreed to support Mr. Levin's promotion. Mr. Munro could not be reached over the weekend. A spokesman for Time Warner said neither Mr. Levin nor Mr. Ross would discuss the move.
A week ago, some Time Warner board members received telephone calls and were told to plan on a special board meeting last Thursday. Then, a day before the board meeting, Mr. Nicholas got a call at his vacation condominium in Vail, Colo., from a director who told him what was about to happen. "He did not know why, he did not have a clue and he felt he had no time to fight it," one longtime associate said.
Mr. Nicholas's wife, who answered the telephone, said he would not comment and she also turned away a reporter who went to Vail to try to interview Mr. Nicholas.
Before the board formally convened, it interrogated Mr. Levin about the company's sinking morale, Then the directors voted -- some by telephone -- to accept Mr. Nicholas's resignation and to name Mr. Levin president, co-chief executive and heir apparent to the chairman. While the change looked abrupt to outsiders, a look back on the two years that the companies have been together -- and their very different styles -- highlights the festering conflicts that led to a clash of personalities and Mr. Nicholas's departure.
 
A Basic Difference
Corporate Cultures Refused to Merge
 "I was caught off guard by the timing, but you might say this was predictable," said Oded Aboodi, Mr. Ross's chief financial aide. "Nick and Steve had different instincts and things were constantly slowed because of that. Steve is more comfortable now, more able to express himself. He likes Jerry and feels that one difficult issue is behind us."
But instead of working together, insiders say, Mr. Ross and Mr. Nicholas grew to mistrust each other to the point of rupturing their relationship. This in turn blocked an effective merging of the companies. Rather than being gradually blended, the separate personalities of Time and Warner were, if anything, reinforced.
"I even feel apprehensive about going over to the Time-Life Building," Mr. Ross, who is based in the former Warner building, said in his last interview before beginning intensive chemotherapy in December.
With Mr. Ross severely ill, and the succession question thus acutely posed, the differences between the executives could no longer be papered over. That is why Mr. Levin, a Time executive who was a major architect of the merger and the man closest to bridging the Time and Warner cultures, was promoted to resolve the impasse, executives said.
As last year progressed, insiders say, it became clear that the Ross-Nicholas setup was not working. "We had HBO and publishing reporting to Nick, movies and music reporting to Steve, and cable to both of them," one board member said. "It was a recipe for not making one company."
 
A Solution
One Executive Bridges the Gap
 The solution adopted last May was to promote Mr. Levin from vice chairman to chief operating officer and have all the businesses report to him. Mr. Levin thus placed himself in the strategic position of being the first executive with a true overview of all the businesses.
He was helped in this promotion by the fact that he had grown steadily closer to the Warner side. In his typically analytical way, Mr. Levin describes this process as one of crossing an emotional line, something that happened gradually but was crystallized for him in a compensation committee meeting some time after the merger.
Some Time people were arguing that they should be treated more generously than Warner executives, who had made a lot in the merger, because Time actually bought Warner at a premium. Mr. Levin suddenly found himself emotionally pointing out that this was history. What mattered was that Time Warner was now one company.
There is no evidence that Mr. Nicholas ever crossed a similar emotional line from the Time side or formed ties with Mr. Ross's entourage that were similar, say, to Mr. Levin's close friendship with Mr. Aboodi.
In the knowledge that his executives at the movie and record companies had still not accepted Mr. Nicholas's destined role as sole chief executive, Mr. Ross increasingly turned to Mr. Levin. "Levin was Ross's weapon against Mr. Nicholas," said Martin S. Davis, the chairman and chief executive of Paramount Communications Corporation, which tried to buy Time Inc. for $200 a share in 1989.
Increasingly, Mr. Levin appeared to act as a buffer within the troika. Mr. Ross became more and more demanding as he was being excoriated for his compensation, which continues to be criticized as overly generous. But Mr. Nicholas was scarcely a responsive shoulder to cry on.
 
Resentments
Cut in Time Jobs Brings Bitterness
 Relations worsened over the company's initially botched stock rights offering last year, whose coercive formula was angrily rejected by shareholders. Company executives said Mr. Nicholas had argued against raising money in this way.
Relations were further undermined when the magazine division decided to cut 605 journalistic jobs -- a decision that provoked indignant comparisons of Mr. Ross's salary and those of the people being laid off. "That killed me," Mr. Ross said a few months ago. "It was the decision of a division, and it's something I've had to do very few times in my life."
Mr. Nicholas, however, took a harsher view. "Employees were bitching and moaning about their jobs and I fully understand that, but it does not relate to Time Warner, Steve Ross's compensation or the stock price," he said in an interview late last year. "We're living through something of a holocaust in employment in journalism and that's it."
Where Mr. Nicholas, who attended the Harvard Business School, tended to approach problems at Time Warner in a meticulously structured way, Mr. Ross, who had no formal business schooling, tended to trust his instincts. Where Mr. Nicholas made points succinctly, talking as if he was reading a memo, Mr. Ross meandered, sometimes maddeningly.
"Ross often comes at things from left field, and that would drive Nick crazy," said a Time Warner board member.
Moreover, Mr. Ross had, over the years, made lavishness a trademark of his business style; he was not about to change to accommodate the more understated Mr. Nicholas.
Mr. Ross defended the much-criticized corporate largesse. He said Time Warner's houses in Aspen and Acapulco and its seven corporate planes were well worth the expense.
Sylvester Stallone, for example, once went down to the Warner villa in Acapulco on the Warner plane and was slipped a script with the message, "If you don't wanna read, just throw it in the trash can," Mr. Ross recounted recently. Mr. Stallone read it. He then made the movie "Cobra" for Warner, which grossed $48 million.
"Nobody understands that sort of thing," Mr. Ross exclaimed. "Nobody."
Among those who had difficulty understanding was Mr. Nicholas.
Moreover, it seems clear that neither Warner's personality-driven movie nor record executives, ever accepted Mr. Nicholas. Indeed, those divisions -- which between them accounted for more than half of Time Warner's $11.5 billion 1991 revenue and generated close to $1 billion in operating profit -- seem to have felt threatened by him.
"At the movie studio, Levin is preferred to Nicholas," Wayne Duband, a Warner vice president, said before last week's announcement.
Thus, over the last two years, Warner and Time divisions kept their former respective loyalties. "Has it meshed as I would have liked?" Mr. Ross asked. "No. Ten million things have hit us." Mr. Nicholas, meanwhile, was fastidious in insisting that Home Box Office and the magazine group, both former Time businesses, report to him. In the end, with cancer threatening Mr. Ross, something had to give.
 
The Last Deal
Complications Plague Merger
 Mr. Levin was ready to make his move. A wry man who once studied theology, he says his favorite novel is Albert Camus's existential classic "The Stranger." An exact contemporary of Mr. Nicholas, his manner is less coolly businesslike and his turn of mind intensely, almost metaphysically, analytical.
Like Mr. Nicholas, he made his way in Time's newer businesses, galvanizing the company's Home Box Office Inc. pay-cable subisidiary into a significant money-spinner during the 1970's. This achievement, which gave Time a vital say in media that were growing faster than its traditional magazine activities, placed him in the running to succeed Mr. Munro as Time's chief executive.
"Levin and Nicholas were my proteges," Mr. Munro, who is now chairman of the executive committee of Time Warner, recalled recently. "Levin is the brighest individual I've ever met, but I thought Nick had more skills as a chief executive, perhaps a stiffer spine, and that is why I picked him. It was not by any means an easy call."
This 1986 decision, which installed Mr. Nicholas as president of Time Inc. and heir to the top job, effectively pushed Mr. Levin into the wilderness. He was even removed from Time's board in 1987.
Thus, when in recent weeks tensions mounted in the boardroom at Time Warner, Mr. Levin had ample reason to feel little compunction in forcing the issue.
 
Mr. Levin's Big Idea
 Left five years ago with the empty-sounding role of "chief strategist," it was Mr. Levin who came up with the notion of a "transforming transaction" to shake Time out of what he saw as a corporate complacency and place it in the vanguard of the fast-growing cable, movie and video businesses. In this way, talks with Warner Communications began.
But the discussions were ill starred from the outset. The original idea of merely putting together the two companies' cable and filmed-entertainment subsidiaries proved too complicated to structure.
Then a plan for a debt-free merger of the entire companies was foiled when Mr. Davis of Paramount bid $200 a share for Time in June 1989. To avoid a shareholders' vote on the Paramount offer, Time's board chose instead to buy Warner for $14 billion, incurring $11 billion of debt in the process.
"Davis lobbed a grenade into our midst," said Mr. Munro, the former Time Inc. chief executive. "And that complicated the hell out of everything. I will go to my grave with $200 a share on my tombstone."
The complications were made worse because, as Felix G. Rohatyn, the senior partner at Lazard Freres put it, "the world changed on Time Warner."
The merger was the last big deal of the 1980's. Debt became anathema. Media stock prices plunged. Publishing went into recession. Executive compensation -- which soared to great heights at the new company largely because Mr. Ross had an enormously lucrative 1987 Warner contract that had to be matched -- came under increasingly critical scrutiny.
All this made a lot of people bitter. Michael J. Fuchs, the chairman of Time Warner's Home Box Office, noted that the difference between the $200-a-share offer and the Time Warner stock price -- now $99 a share -- added up to "an awful lot of anger among Time shareholders and on Wall Street."
The sight of top Time Warner management collecting millions of dollars in compensation and bonuses as a result of the deal further soured things. The fact that Mr. Ross got $196 million for his Warner options and other equity interests tended to make him the target of much of this ire. Used to adulation from his days at Warner, this seemed to hurt him psychologically. "These constant attacks caused him enormous anguish," said Arthur Liman, the prominent New York lawyer.
Thus as Mr. Ross, Mr. Nicholas and their vice chairman, Mr. Levin, took up their plush adjoining offices on the 29th floor of the former Warner building in July 1990, there was a steadily growing strain on them. Mr. Levin, for one, talks of having been physically depressed by the Time Warner share price.
 
The Last Days
A Miscalculation Proves to Be Fatal
 Mr. Nicholas tended to deal with day-to-day operations. This arrangement suited their respective temperaments. Mr. Ross calls himself a dreamer and a strategist, above all; Mr. Nicholas is a very effective manager. In theory, the arrangement might have been complementary.
But Mr. Nicholas apparently did little to ease the mutual suspicions between the Time and Warner sides. "He kept insisting the Time business must report to him," one official said. Sometimes, the situation may have played to Mr. Nicholas's advantage.
Some analysts have suggested that Mr. Nicholas rejected the very notion of looking for partners -- a search which finally led last year to a deal with C. Itoh & Company and the Toshiba Corporation, both of Japan -- and that this was a large source of tension.
But tension between the executives seems to have come from elsewhere: Mr. Nicholas's tenacious defense of his old Time turf; his comparative slowness in moving toward decisions; differences over the increasingly bitter issue of executive compensation; arguments over the stock rights offering last year, and ultimately, a sense in Mr. Ross's close circle of allies that Mr. Nicholas was acting as if the company was already his.
That was a fatal miscalculation on Mr. Nicholas's part. Mr. Ross's influence with the board remained strong. Half the board members were Mr. Ross's allies. And with Mr. Munro, Mr. Nicholas's biggest backer turning against him, the scene was now set for Mr. Nicholas's ousting.
It must have come as a brutal surprise. Just three months ago, Mr. Nicholas felt relaxed enough about the future to muse on who might succeed him as chief executive when his contract expired on July 24, 1999.
"I don't know if my successor would be Jerry Levin," he said in an interview. "I give the question some thought. But I'm only 52, and I don't expect to be hit by a yellow taxi tomorrow."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gerald M. Levin; Steven J. Ross; N. J. Nicholas Jr. (pg. D1); Steven J. Ross, left, chairman of Warner Communications Inc., meeting in 1989 with J. Richard Munro, right, and N. J. Nicholas Jr. of Time Inc. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times) (pg. D9)
 
Chart: "At Time Warner, Three Very Different Managers"
 
 Steven J. Ross, age 64
An intuitive, gut-driven executive who says his favorite occupation is dreaming, by which he means imagining futuristic ways to bring more media to more people. Mr. Ross is a good dealmaker and possesses a great gift for numbers. He chooses talented people to lead businesses and lets them run -- with generally good but occasionally disastrous results. "If you're not a risk-taker," he says, "you should get the hell out of business." He has been ill with prostate cancer, has been undergoing chemotherapy and has been working for the past few months from his homes in New York and East Hampton, L.I.
 
Gerald M. Levin, age 52
A quirky, slightly offbeat, low-key former Time Inc. executive with a very penetrating mind. The only intellectual of the three, he finds Albert Camus's "The Stranger," with its existential angst, to be his favorite novel. Mr. Levin has a gift for cutting through dross and putting things clearly. After his career was sidelined several years ago, and he was removed from the board, he made a steady comeback and was able to forge alliances with new Warner colleagues. He is a passionate believer in cable television, which he helped put on the map. He is said to have a better feel for people than Mr. Nicholas.
 
Nicholas J. Nicholas, age 52
A methodical Harvard-trained manager, who played a vital role in the rapid growth of Time Inc.'s Home Box Office. Mr. Nicholas's strength lies in finance and startegy. His friends say he has a warmth that he reveals to few, but he sometimes gives the impression of a man on automatic pilot. His cost-conscious eye grated on Mr. Rosse's freewheeling ways. He can be meticulous. For example, when commenting a few months ago on his relationship with Mr. Ross, he said: "Yes, it's an unusual arrangement. One reason is the people happen to respect and like each other. No, that's two reasons. They respect each other and they like each other." (pg. D1)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: The House's Tactician of Taxation

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Dan Rostenkowski will be leading the fight for the Democrats' middle-class tax cut in the House this week, but that does not mean he expects it to become law.
Or even that he necessarily thinks it should be. 
 After all, he consistently said for weeks that the economy would probably be helped more by being left alone and that his bill, and President Bush's, too, are responses to political, not economic, needs.
That argument fits the persona the head of the Ways and Means Committee enjoys most, that of the committee chairman who exceeds Washington's expectations, works for a clean tax code and usually seems above partisanship.
His friendship with Mr. Bush, which dates from their service together on Ways and Means two decades ago, produces "Dear Danny" letters and brings occassional golf dates. And he complains that these days, "We never quit politicking in the House of Representatives."
But don't feel sorry about Mr. Rostenkowski's being forced, as he puts it, by circumstances and other Democratic leaders to fight a party fight. He protests too much.
He may not have used his partisan skills much in recent years, but this product of the Chicago organization (Mayor Richard J. Daley decided he would be a Congressman in 1958, and he was) knows the moves instinctively, both in working this tax bill and in dealing with an unexpected and irritating primary challenge back home.
In Chicago, Mr. Rostenkowski is scoring political points with a tale of an arrogant Federal Government that wants to move a Social Security center from one neighborhood in his district to another, even though both neighborhoods oppose the change.
And he is using his prominence on the tax bill -- "the high visibility of theater that takes place in here" -- to campaign with celebrity status and as an acceptable excuse when he must miss an event.
It was his idea to have Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, introduce Mr. Bush's entire tax program with the intention of putting it before the House to show that Republicans would not vote for it. The measure contains some provisions no one in Congress likes, like taxing annuities, and others that even Mr. Bush does not want considered now because of their costs, like a $500 increase in the personal exemption for children.
Mr. Rostenkowski then intended to show that Democrats would support his alternative measure, which he said would define "the difference between the Democrats and the Republicans."
"We're going to see to it that middle-income Americans have a better tax break," he said.
 
Threat of a Veto
 But he was hardly surprised on Friday when President Bush threatened to veto the bill, whose two years of tax credits of up to $400 a couple would be paid for through permanent higher rates for upper-income taxpayers. The day before, Mr. Rostenkowski said that the usual process of first insisting that no compromise was possible and later making a deal was unlikely to be followed this year.
"I think the President has been emphatic enough about raising marginal tax rates that he's not going to sign anything," Mr. Rostenkowski said in an interview on Thursday.
Concerning the bill's appeal, Mr. Rostenkowski discusses that exclusively in terms political rather than substantive. He frequently repeats that the economists his committee heard in December advised inaction, but says: "The one time I agree with the economists, I'm forced to do something other than sit on my fanny and do nothing. The political climate insists that we have something."
He moved this bill through his committee faster than usual, with his customary invitation to Democratic colleagues to change it if they wished and his customary show of muscle to defeat their changes.
The most innovative challenge Mr. Rostenkowski faced was the idea of taking the $46 billion his two-year middle-class tax credit would cost and replacing it with permanent credits for children, at about $180 a year. Two of his proteges on the Ways and Means committee, Representatives Marty Russo of Illinois and Thomas J. Downey of Long Island, tried that idea out. The chairman assembled the votes to beat them soundly.
But when it came to making sure that Democrats would be, if not enthusiastic, at least mollified, Mr. Rostenkowski was ready to give way to the caucus on other points. First, he agreed to add Mr. Bush's accelerated-depreciation provision and another clause to help small businesses buy new equipment and to limit the corporate tax cut to two years. Then, after saying sharply that he would not change anything else, he agreed to drop the corporate cut altogether.
There is one difference between this bill and others Mr. Rostenkowski handled recently, and it may be a measure of how seriously the tax bill should be taken as a potential statute as opposed to the political statement the Representative says he was told to make by leaders like Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley and Mr. Gephardt.
This bill pays no attention to the 1990 budget act's requirement that any losses in revenue be paid for, year by year, by increases in revenue somewhere else. In theory, the Democrats' bill would raise revenues, taking in $14 billion more in six years through tax increases than it would lose in tax cuts, but that does not meet budget-act requirements that it be revenue neutral.
All the defense that Mr. Rostenkowski offers is that Mr. Bush's bills do not balance either, except with slick accounting.
But the budget act problem is not going to cost the measure any Democratic votes to speak of this week, and Mr. Rostenkowski, like the party leaders who urged him to provide a platform of fairness in a tax bill, is confident the bill will pass.
In his office in the Rayburn House Office Building, distinguished by a quizzical stuffed toy snow leopard, a gift from a wildlife organization, the Ways and Means chairman talked about the bill and its politics animatedly for half an hour.
Mr. Rostenkowski kept returning to the question of what was the point of it all if Mr. Bush was simply going to veto the growth package, either in this form or after a House-Senate conference.
Mr. Rostenkowski suggested that those who wanted to do nothing, who "stood in the shadows" as he might have preferred, could then say that the right policy objective had been reached. On the way, they could urge both sides, "get all the mileage you can out of your taking care of the middle class, working on fairness, getting growth packages, putting incentives in." But in the end, leave the tax code unchanged.
That comes later. This week, the chairman and the leaders must pass the bill.
"The worst thing that happens to us is we wind up not passing a bill," Mr. Rostenkowski said. "Then Bush has got free range in his arsenal of criticism. Then he can just throw it at us, and we have no defense: 'They can't get together; they are bickering; they won't see what's in the best interests of the country.' The fact of the matter is I really don't want a bill if I can avoid doing it. But the political climate insists we have something."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, in his Rayburn building office, which is distinguished by a stuffed toy snow leopard, a gift from a wildlife organization. (George Tames for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: ILLINOIS, USA (90%);

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Fell In January

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools fell 36.7 percent in January from the previous month, the industry's trade group said in a report to be released today.
The trade organization, the Association for Manufacturing Technology, said orders totaled $217.2 million last month, compared with $342.9 million in December. But orders were 8.7 percent higher in January than in January a year ago. Orders worth $199.8 million were placed in January 1991, when the Persian Gulf war began. 
 The president of the group, Albert Moore, said he was worried that buyers were delaying purchases of machine tools to see whether President Bush and Congress could agree on incentives for investment as part of an economic growth package.
 
Concerns About Policy
 Mr. Moore said the industry was pleased that the President and Congress were discussing ways to offer investment incentives, "but we are concerned that buyers are delaying making a decision until the specifics are known." He added, "The country needs a decision on this issue without delay."
Purchases of machine tools, which are used to cut and form metal parts in a huge number of manufactured goods ranging from cookware and refrigerators to aircraft, are considered an important indication of the health of the manufacturing sector.
January shipments of machine tools were even more lackluster than orders, skidding 43.4 percent, to $159.6 million, from $282 million in December. Shipments were down 12.5 percent from the $182.5 million of shipments sent in January 1991.
Machine tool makers rely on the auto industry for 30 to 40 percent of their business, and they were hurt last year by cutbacks in production by the big American auto makers.
 
Exports Off as Well
 And while exports of machine tools had been a bright point amid the gloom, slowing economies around the world have hurt this sector of the business as well. The trade group said that January export orders plunged 77.5 percent to $13.1 million from $58.1 million in December, and were off 60 percent from $32.8 million in January 1991.
Export shipments in January were also down, falling 48.9 percent to $24.2 million from $47.4 million in December, and off 14.5 percent from $28.3 million a year ago.
The January backlog of orders was about $1.49 billion, up from $1.44 billion in December. The backlog totaled $1.49 billion in January a year ago.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Tsongas Economic Plan Suggests Few Sacrifices

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas, who won the Democratic primary in New Hampshire with a campaign that emphasized personal sacrifice to revive the economy, is actually quite vague about the ingredients of the bitter medicine he would prescribe.
As he campaigned across New Hampshire, Mr. Tsongas, a former senator from Massachusetts, managed to distinguish himself from the other candidates of both parties, who promised tax cuts for families or popular new public works projects, or both, and who stressed mainly painless solutions to the economic problems in the state and the nation. 
 "I'm not running to be Santa Claus," he said in his standard speech. And he often remarked, "We need to put long-term good ahead of short-term gratification."
But scrutiny of his speeches and position papers discloses few specific proposals that would cause ordinary voters to bite the bullet. For example, while he calls the large Federal budget deficit "one of our most difficult and pressing problems," he says he has no plans for an overall tax increase or reduction in Social Security spending, steps that many economists believe are prerequisites for deficit reduction.
 
Rise in Gasoline Tax
 Asked in a telephone interview Friday to list the sacrifices he would require of middle-income Americans to strengthen the economy, Mr. Tsongas named only one: a 50-cents-a-gallon increase in the Federal gasoline tax, which he would impose in stages over 10 years.
Mainly, Mr. Tsongas said, when he talked about belt-tightening he was referring to his opposition to a tax cut for the middle class, like the one backed by President Bush, Democrats in Congress and two of his competitors for the Presidential nomination, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska.
He said he favored a "flexible freeze," the same words Mr. Bush used four years ago to explain how he would cut spending. As used by Mr. Bush and Mr. Tsongas, the term means that if spending is increased for some programs, it must be reduced for others so the deficit does not rise. "Do I have to reject a good idea and a necessary idea just because someone else used it?" Mr. Tsongas asked.
Under Mr. Bush, the annual deficit has risen to a record high of about $400 billion.
Like Mr. Bush in 1988, Mr. Tsongas names several areas where he intends to spend more money, including the Head Start program for preschoolers, merit pay for teachers, unemployment insurance and job training. He points to few places other than the military where he thinks cuts are in order. The only one he named in the interview was what he called the "populated space station," the word "manned" apparently being politically incorrect.
 
Hints at One Cut
 But unlike Mr. Bush, Mr. Tsongas does not rule out a tax increase or a cut in Social Security benefits. He said he does not intend to carry out either step, but he said a reduction in Social Security payments to wealthy pensioners might be necessary "in three or four years if I don't get a handle on the deficit."
Mr. Tsongas would also use most of the money remaining from cuts in the military budget for deficit reduction rather than for tax cuts or new programs, as would most of his competitors.
Mr. Tsongas's economic philosophy fits no particular school. It is neither Keynesian nor supply side, not liberal or conservative, not completely pro-business or pro-labor.
His main theme is that the United States is losing ground in the world economy. "The cold war is over and the Japanese won," he says at nearly every stop. The solution, he says, is for the American Government to be friendly to business, not hostile the way he says many of his fellow Democrats are.
"You can't have employment and despise employers," he said in his victory speech in Manchester Tuesday night. And then he appended the phrase that he has made his slogan: "No goose, no golden egg."
But he is friendlier to some businesses than he is to others, and the ones he favors most are in manufacturing. In his pamphlet "A Call to Economic Arms," which is the manifesto of his campaign, Mr. Tsongas wrote that the decline of America's manufacturing base was "our collective Kryptonite." He added:
"An ever less competitive manufacturing base inevitably means cataclysmic erosion of our standard of living. If we are reduced to just flipping hamburgers and exploiting our raw materials, we will have an economy, but it will be a diminished economy of decline and defeat."
Many other politicians and economists hold a similar view. But they tend to be the ones like Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, and Jeff Faux, the economist who heads the Economic Policy Institute, who also favor trade restrictions to give American manufacturers a leg up.
Mr. Tsongas, more than any other Democratic Presidential candidate, espouses free trade and vigorously opposes protectionist measures.
His principal step to help manufacturers would be a cut in the capital gains tax for stocks and bonds but not for real estate. The rate would diminish the longer an investment was held, and an even lower rate would be available for venture capital invested in start-up companies. He would offset the cost and diminish the windfall for the wealthy by raising the top income tax rate to 34 percent or 35 percent from 31 percent.
 
Measures for Business
 He also advocates these other measures mainly to help manufacturers: an investment tax credit, a new Government office to coordinate technology, a civilian version of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to generate cutting-edge research, waivers of antitrust laws in many instances so businesses can work together on joint projects and an agency patterned after the Agriculture Extension Service to provide companies around the country access to the latest technology and management strategies.
Mainstream Democratic economists are of two minds about Mr. Tsongas's emphasis on manufacturing.
They agree with the principle that the Government should encourage creation of high value-added jobs, those in which the value of the product depends mostly on the labor and not on the materials. Computer programming, for example, fits the category; computer assembly does not. As a rule, high value-added jobs are also high-paying jobs.
But many economists dispute the idea that manufacturing jobs and high value-added jobs are necessarily one and the same. Charles L. Schultze, who was budget director in the Johnson Administration and chairman of President Jimmy Carter's Council of Economic Advisers, said he admired Mr. Tsongas in most respects but thought that such a strong emphasis on manufacturing would lead the Government to stress low-skilled jobs in failing industries. It is better, he said, to emphasize services like telecommunications and retailing where the United States already excels.
On the other hand, Benjamin M. Friedman, a prominent Harvard economist, said he had come around to the view that Mr. Tsongas might be right. Almost the only high-wage jobs for people without college educations are in manufacturing, he said, and it is important for the country to limit as much as possible the growing disparity in income between those with college degrees and those without them.
While Mr. Tsongas characterizes himself as a pro-business Democrat, he takes many stands that are at odds with business interests. For instance, he favors strong Government health, safety and environmental regulations, and he speaks out often against high executive salaries and poor business management practices.
Mr. Tsongas almost never talks in his campaign appearances about poverty or homelessness, and they are not addressed in his campaign pamphlet. Asked why, he said it was impossible in 83 pages to deal with every issue. He said he had visited a homeless shelter recently and was told by people there that what they really wanted was jobs. With an improved economy, he said, those jobs could become available.
In New Hampshire, Mr. Tsongas's philosophy seemed to sell best with the most affluent voters. A primary day poll showed that among voters with family incomes of more than $75,000 he led Governor Clinton by 45 percent to 28 percent, but among those from households with incomes between $15,000 and $30,000, Mr. Clinton led Mr. Tsongas by 28 percent to 26 percent.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts College Offers Free Classes to Unemployed

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.

 BODY:
Chet Gallup's story begins like many others these days: For 30 years he was an electrical engineer for a General Electric plant in Pittsfield, until the day he was laid off, April 19, 1990.
But instead of polishing his resume and making the rounds of employment agencies, Mr. Gallup has been driving 80 minutes round trip two evenings a week to discuss life according to Plato and health among today's elderly. 
 The classes may not help him land a new job right away, he admits, but they do fulfill credits he needs to earn a teaching certificate. Better yet, the classes are free.
Mr. Gallup, 58 years old, is one of 70 unemployed workers with at least a high school diploma who took empty seats in evening classes this semester at North Adams State College. He showed up after officials there offered to do their part to help ease the area's high unemployment rate, which was 9 percent in December while the national average was 6.8 percent.
 
'Very Nurturing Places'
 The college said that any unemployed person in western Massachusetts could take any of its night classes at no charge as long as there were empty seats, with a maximum of four classes per person. The charge for one class is usually $270.
"Colleges are very nurturing places," said Thomas D. Aceto, president of this small liberal arts school in the Berkshires. "If something changes in their lives as a result of their participation, then we will have felt we've succeeded, even if it's just given them some confidence."
Two unemployed people with graduate business degrees, a dental assistant, a bartender and a number of teachers and other school workers are among those who have signed up for the free classes.
North Adams State Colleges is able to offer free evening classes because those scheduled after 4 P.M. do not receive state funds, which means the offer did not require approval of the Legislature, said Paul G. Marks, chancellor of higher education for the state's nine public colleges.
 
Offer by College Hailed
 Around town, the college's offer was hailed as a much-needed positive sign in the northwestern part of the state, which has yet to recover from three decades of decline in manufacturing jobs.
"It's very easy to come here and find the negatives," said Thom Swift, president of the Northern Berkshire Chamber of Commerce. "You have to live here awhile to appreciate the positives."
The college made a similar offer in 1984, but only 10 people responded. Its officials believe the changes in the economy led to the greater response.
"I think things have really changed," Mr. Aceto said. "I think people realize it isn't a case of waiting to go back to your old job, because your old job isn't going to be there."
This recession, which has been deeply felt in both white- and blue-collar ranks, is also testing the notion that a college degree can improve a person's standing in life, he said. The unemployed are not willing to dip into their savings for college, Mr. Aceto said, adding: "They see all these people out of work with college degrees and say, 'This isn't the ticket anymore.' "
Another man laid off by General Electric, who is taking two free classes toward a master's in business, said, "If you don't have any income, the cost of a credit per hour is pretty expensive."
Other students said they supported the newcomers, to a point. "I don't think it's fair, since we have to pay," said Jill Haynes, 18. "But if it's going to help these people get a job and to help themselves, then it's fine."
Mr. Gallup, the former electrical engineer, said that even if he was able to get a job only as a teacher's aide, the effort would prove worthwhile. Being laid off has, in fact, allowed him to pursue a dream of teaching. "It's a scary opportunity," said Mr. Gallup, "but an opportunity."

HEADLINE: Environmentalists Fear Favors to Builders in Trenton's Pinelands Plan

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
A 10-year policy agenda for governing the million-acre preserve drawn up by the New Jersey Pinelands Commission includes enough nods toward the concerns of builders, farmers and quarry operators to worry some environmentalists that profits may win out over preservation in the state's premiere nature reserve.
It is the first full-scale review of the Pinelands' plan since the rules to limit development and regulate industry inside the preserve were adopted in 1981. Prominent among the public comments on the new agenda were complaints from builders that too few buildings were allowed per acre, from sand and gravel operators that the allowable size and depth of their quarry holes were too limited, and from farmers that wetlands regulations were too severe. 
 The five-point agenda, reached Saturday afternoon after two days of deliberation, seems to take these arguments into account by offering a review of Pinelands regulations to see whether changes are needed to "maintain the viability" of forestry, agriculture and sand and gravel operations, which are lumped together as "resource extraction."
The new policy guidelines also undertake to "evaluate the economic impact" of Pinelands regulations on businesses and localities, a phrasing that conservation advocates read to mean a sensitivity to complaints that development restrictions depress employment and municipal revenues.
 
'Lot of Defensive Work'
 "My first reaction is that we are going to have a lot of defensive work to do," said Don Kirchoffer, a staff member of the Pinelands Preservation Alliance, the principal conservation group involved with the Pinelands. "The things that we proposed to the Commission are not among their top issues."
The Alliance had presented numerous suggestions to the board involving water quality, waste disposal and a call for more scientific evaluation on the condition of the Pinelands. But among its chief concerns was the amount of timber cutting being permitted in even the most tightly managed of the Pinelands' several management zones, the 300,000-acre Preservation Area, where man-made intrusions are most tightly controlled.
Besides deciding to examine economic impacts of regulations, the commission also decided to simplify permit applications, re-examine the way the rules reward developers who build in growth zones on the edge of the Pinelands and review policies on solid-waste disposal in the preserve.
The commission can see the pressure to dig, build, cut and quarry within the Pinelands boundaries in other ways than in the pleas from industry leaders. The number of violations of Pinelands rules has been rising sharply, from 53 recorded in 1956 to 162 in 1990, the last year for which complete figures have been published.
 
Fewer Violations Settled
 As the number of broken rules has increased, so has the difficulty of resolving them: 81 percent of the 1986 violations have been resolved, while just 36 percent of the violations in 1990 have been settled.
The Pinelands Commission has asked the state for more power to enforce its rules, but a measure that would give it injunctive power against violators was lost in the frenzy over tax repeal during the last session of the Legislature. Richard J. Sullivan, a banker from Hamilton Square who is chairman of the commission, said he expected the law to pass in the current session.
In an interview during the meeting, Mr. Sullivan said no interest should regard the agenda as a blueprint, but as a focus for discussion.
"The five areas that we propose are designed to be sufficiently broad to address a range of issues," he said. "We're not trying to get down to the level where we say, 'This distance has to be three and a half feet instead of three.' We think the present plan works quite well, but we think we can do it better."
 
Critics Say 'Closed Shop'
 In deciding to simplify and clarify the often time-consuming business of getting permits to make changes in homes or businesses inside the Pinelands, the commission may be responding to several complaints, published in a volume of public comment, that the current system discouraged outside participation.
The New Jersey Builders Association accused the commission of operating like a "closed shop," impervious to suggestion. An anonymous critic was more blunt. "You are viewed as a supercilious bureaucracy which applies standards in knee-jerk fashion, even when they do not make sense," the critic wrote. "I think compliance with your goals would be more easily achieved if you weren't so highhanded about it."
The New Jersey Pinelands is a state and Federal preserve of inland forests, rivers, cedar swamps and other wetlands. The Pinelands Commission manages 927,000 acres, but when federally protected coastal lands are included, the total protected region, called the Pinelands National Reserve, covers 1.1 million acres.
Less than a third of the state-managed land, or 297,000 acres, is state-owned, however. Balancing the interests of the owners of the rest of the land inside the Pinelands occupies most of the commission's and its staff's time. Simply put, the Pinelands management plan designates areas inside the preserve by the level of protection, from little development and commercial use to so-called Regional Growth Areas, where housing and development are encouraged.
 
Selling Development Rights
 Owners of land in the most protected areas can sell development bonuses to builders in growth areas, which are concentrated in the townships of Medford, Evesham and Hamilton. The bonuses allow builders to put more houses on a piece of land in a growth area than would normally be allowed. They are intended to help compensate landowners in protected areas for the loss of their own development rights.
Such esoterica of land managment may become familiar concepts to the rest of New Jersey this summer, when the new state plan is published. Like a Pinelands system written on a statewide scale, the state plan is expected to classify the whole state into four or five land-use categories, from farmland to high-density urban development areas.
Once the plan is in place, if present thinking holds, the state will then use its power to regulate roads, sewers, utilities and the like to steer development into urban and suburban districts, and away from open space.
