HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Where Government Sits: Leaders and Geography

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
ONE problem with moving the "nerve center" of New York City government to Brooklyn Borough Hall, as Mayor David N. Dinkins is doing today, is that the largely symbolic shift raises an embarrassing question: Where has the nerve center been until now?
Obviously, the center part was never in doubt. What government at all levels often lacks is nerve. 
 That general lack of bravado does not diminish Mr. Dinkins's gesture to disaffected New Yorkers, which he announced in January during his State of the City speech. Peter J. Johnson Jr., a mayoral adviser who conceived the strategy of bringing Mr. Dinkins closer to his constituents, acknowledged that just delivering the speech someplace other than City Hall might have smacked of gimmickry but argued that bivouacking in another borough for a week could be another story. (A predecessor, Fiorello H. La Guardia, regularly summered outside Manhattan and conducted city business on a bluff.)
Merely moving the government, though, is not what advocates of "Reinventing Government" (Addison-Wesley), as the book by consultants David Osborne and Ted Gaebler is called, have in mind. Their goal is to move the public and its representatives to acknowledge the limits of government and to redefine its role. What distinguishes their vision is that it is largely nonpartisan and nonideological. They believe in government but say its value is diminished when it strives to be all things to all voters.
"It is not surprising that Mayor Dinkins and Governor Cuomo find it hard to come to grips with economic reality," said Stephen Berger, former executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, because doing so, he said, would violate two political tenets: that no problem is regarded as outside city government's purview and that the government is less committed to delivering services to citizens than to "dispensing benefits to its service providers."
Mr. Berger elaborates in a provocative article, "Reconstructing New York," in The City Journal, published by the Manhattan Institute, a research group that unabashedly opposes bloated government. He describes Medicaid as a perverse form of city financial aid to the state since the city pays one-fourth of the cost of programs mandated by Albany. He asks whether municipal employees need both collective-bargaining rights and Civil Service guarantees. And he maintains that New Yorkers care more about how services are delivered than by whom.
"New York's elected leaders automatically equate public service with free, or at least massively subsidized, service," Mr. Berger writes. "But a government that would rather let its bridges rot than impose tolls on them, would rather cripple the Staten Island ferry than raise fares, would rather gut New York Technical College than raise tuition for CUNY graduate students, is not demonstrating its commitment to social justice -- only its stupidity."
The government's failure to extract specific productivity improvements from sanitation workers before granting them raises and City Hall's historic reluctance to alter the property-tax formula that subsidizes middle-class homeowners represent other political judgments that may fall into the same category.
If the book by Mr. Osborne and Mr. Gaebler is being embraced by customers of municipal services as a bible of entrepreneurial government, its premises are shared by some converts within the bureaucracy, too.
The book never mentions Mr. Dinkins by name but cites the city's progress in community policing and in sanitation vehicle repair. Also cited are Connecticut's voucher program for child care, Newark's competition to provide public services and New Jersey's policies to prevent homelessness.
If a revised edition is published, Mr. Dinkins's frustrated director of operations, Harvey Robins, deserves at least a footnote for his tireless efforts to make government more efficient. So does the Mayor's Commission on Homelessness, headed by Andrew M. Cuomo, whose report embodies a number of inventive approaches, couched in the jargon of policy reform ("results rather than process should be rewarded," it suggests).
"We will not solve our problems by spending more or spending less, by creating new public bureaucracies or by 'privatizing' existing bureaucracies," warns Mr. Osborne, who is to participate in a forum on Wednesday run by Andrew J. Stein, the New York City Council President, who is managing to privatize the issue of reinventing the government that most other city officials are too busy running or moving.
Mr. Stein said on Friday that he had not yet finished reading the book but shared much of its philosophy, except for Mr. Osborne's preference for strict limits on campaign contributions and spending as one way to endow elected officials with the political independence required for reform.
"Nothing is more important than leadership," Mr. Osborne writes, which means that where the seat of government is situated is less important than where its head is.

HEADLINE: Slump Hits Japanese Electronics

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
With consumer electronics sales in a slump and technological shifts complicating the computer chip industry, several of Japan's electronics giants are predicting sharply lower profits.
The Sony Corporation, which has come to symbolize Japan's ascendance in consumer electronics, said recently that its Japanese operation would suffer its first yearly operating loss ever. 
 The problems largely stem from a weakening of the Japanese economy and economic slumps in Europe and in the United States, where Sony, for example, derives more than a quarter of its sales. Other companies in Japan, ranging from the auto maker Nissan Motor to Nippon Steel, are also feeling the pinch.
 
Special Impact on Electronics
 But some analysts say several deep-seated problems could plague the Japanese electronics companies for years.
Among the problems are the slowing sales of some consumer electronics products, like VCR's and compact disk players, and the lack of new hit products to take their place.
In addition, computer users are now favoring smaller machines like personal computers, posing a threat to Japanese companies that have specialized in larger machines. And the Japanese specialty of producing computer memory chips, which once seemed a brilliant path to dominance in semiconductors, is requiring ever more expensive factories, making profits harder to earn.
 
Long-Term 'Structural Problems'
 "They'll come out of the economic cycle, of course, but they'll still have the structural problems," said Darrel E. Whitten, director of Japanese research for Prudential Securities in Tokyo. "The growth rates they've had in the 80's are not going to be repeatable in the foreseeable future."
With trade tensions between Japan and the United States near a fever pitch, Americans might find an opportunity for gloating in the troubles of the companies that essentially drove United States manufacturers out of televisions and memory chips. But problems in Japan can also hurt Americans.
Toshiba America recently announced layoffs in Southern California, where it makes laptop computers. Hitachi is planning to close a California factory involved in making projection television sets.
Japanese companies still see growth in the electronics business once the slump ends, and say they have lived through downturns before. They suffered a double blow in the mid-1980's, when the electronics industry slowed and the yen was sharply strengthened, making Japanese exports more expensive. But by and large, the companies adjusted and resumed their growth.
"Over the long term, we are not going to change our strategy," said Masaki Mikura, a spokesman in Tokyo for the Toshiba Corporation, which on Thursday sharply revised its earnings forecast for the fiscal year that ends in March. The company now expects worldwide net income to plummet 67 percent, compared with a previous forecast of a 26 percent decline.
A number of factors are contributing to the problems of the electronics companies. The Japanese economy began to weaken in the last two years after a speculative bubble burst and real estate and stock prices dropped. Now the pain is spreading to the manufacturing sector much faster than had been anticipated. In response, makers of chips, computers and automobiles are cutting back their planned capital spending for next year, which in turn will hurt makers of large machinery.
 
Weaknesses in Three Areas
 Some officials and analysts say the Japanese economy will weaken more before it recovers. In announcing its latest earnings, Sony said its business environment "is expected to become more severe" in part because prospects for economic recovery in Japan were "unclear."
For the electronics companies in particular, there have been weaknesses in three areas -- computers, semiconductors and consumer electronics. Usually, executives say, strength in one of these businesses had offset weakness in another. This time, "all are bad," said Manabu Kuwae, an official at Hitachi America in Tarrytown, N.Y.
In semiconductors, Japanese companies have focused heavily on the biggest-selling chip, the dynamic random access memory. They have invested huge amounts in factories to make the latest generation of memory chip, which can hold four million bits of information. But demand has been slow to materialize, making it hard to pay for those factories.
"The price is going down and sales have not grown as we expected," said Yuri Momomoto, a spokeswoman for Fujitsu Ltd. in Tokyo. Largely because of the semiconductor problems, Fujitsu now expects net income for the parent company to decline nearly 60 percent in the current fiscal year.
Demand can pick up, of course. But experts say that each new generation of chips requires a more expensive factory, making it more difficult to make a profit in the memory chip business. Meanwhile, Japanese chip producers have not advanced that rapidly into more profitable areas like microprocessors, the central operating device of computers.
And Japanese companies, which have dominated the memory chip market, are seeing new competition. Samsung, a South Korean company, has emerged from obscurity to become one of the two largest memory-chip producers in the world and is the first to start selling the next-generation 16-million-bit chip.
Japanese companies might also end up on the wrong side of the technology trends in computers.
Joichi Aoi, the president of Toshiba, has been known to say, "Unless Mr. Akers laughs, we can't laugh either." The statement refers to John F. Akers, the chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, and is meant to suggest that Toshiba sees its fate tied to the computer industry.
But it also reflects the high esteem in which I.B.M. has traditionally been held in Japan. For decades, Japanese computer companies, particularly Fujitsu and Hitachi, have been pursuing I.B.M.'s business of selling large mainframe computers.
 
Trend Toward Downsizing
 But now, I.B.M. is suffering from a shift away from mainframes to smaller machines, like personal computers and work stations, which have lower profit margins. In Japan, this trend toward downsizing has been slower to happen. But when it does, it will put more pressure on Japanese computer companies, said Mr. Whitten, the Prudential analyst.
Similarly in supercomputers, Fujitsu, Hitachi and NEC have been avidly pursuing Cray Research Inc. by building machines with a single or a few very powerful processors. But just as the Japanese companies seem to be gaining on Cray, the whole supercomputer business appears on the brink of shifting toward machines based on thousands of less powerful processors.
The Japanese companies do make smaller computers but have not been able to repeat in personal computers or engineering work stations the success they had in televisions or automobiles.
 
No Hits in Consumer Products
 In consumer electronics, a big problem is a lack of new hit products. Through the late 1970's and 80's, growth was fueled by a succession of gadgets -- the video cassette recorder, the Walkman, the compact disk player and, more recently, the camcorder.
Now there is no clear growth leader in sight. High-definition television, once seen as the great hope, now looks as if it will not develop until late in the decade. Digital audio recording, either on tape or recordable compact disk, could catch on, but the market growth could be slowed by the presence of competing formats.
Still, something is likely to emerge eventually. The combination of computers and consumer electronics is opening new possibilities, like devices that allow consumers to control video images by computer.
 
Longer-Term Prospects
 Japanese companies will play a leading role in these areas, although American companies, by dint of their expertise in computers, might be able to jump back into consumer electronics. Apple Computer Inc., for instance, is working with several Japanese companies to develop video computers and "personal digital assistants," which are pocket-size gadgets that store and transmit information.
And Japanese companies have been diversifying, as is most evident in Sony's purchase of an American record company and movie studio in the last few years.
Rodney Harada, an analyst who follows Japanese consumer electronics companies for Merrill Lynch, said the companies had deep pockets and would outlive the slump. "Long term, I'm very positive on these companies," he added.

HEADLINE: Behind Foreclosed Doors;
Troubled Family Strives to Stay Together

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., Feb. 21

 BODY:
Since Theodore Stemberg's death in 1979, the lives of his three emotionally disabled children have gone mostly untended, and, like the trees in the overgrown garden behind their house, now weave inextricably one into the other.
The home Mr. Stemberg built to shelter Rita, 64 years old, Teddy, 59, and Karen, 38, has been seized by Suffolk County for back taxes. Potential buyers wander over the property and through its doors now, terrifying the Stembergs with the prospect that for the first time in their lives, they may be separated. 
 "They're in their own little world behind those doors," said Jimmy Madden, owner of Madden's Auto Body Shop in Hicksville, where Teddy Stemberg has worked cleaning cars since the late 1950's. "If you take any one of them out of there, they would be lost."
Should the home be auctioned and the family forced out, it would cost taxpayers roughly $50,000 a year to shelter the Stembergs -- almost two and a half times the $21,000 they owe in taxes, 12 times what they now pay the county in rent. And likely as not, they would end up living in another foreclosed house, transformed into a county shelter for the homeless.
The tale of the Stembergs' descent from the security their parents tried to assure to desperation involves the failure of Suffolk County agencies to notice the reclusive siblings until 1986, after they had fallen so far behind in their taxes that losing their home became all but certain. It raises questions about a foreclosure process that, once begun, seems almost impossible to halt, despite the best intentions of public officials. It also raises the question of how far helpless adults must fall before the sound echoes through the corridors of welfare agencies.
Had the Social Services Department stepped in sooner, or the Suffolk County Real Estate Department been more flexible later, the money the county provides the Stembergs to enable them to care for themselves could have gone for property taxes of about $4,000 a year to avoid foreclosure. Instead, the home now belongs to the county and the Stembergs pay the county that amount for "reasonable use and occupancy" and live under the threat of homelessness.
 
'Paying More Money'
 "It's not productive for government to be throwing people out on the streets, splitting up a family and then paying more money to put them in shelters," said James F. Gaughran, a Democratic county legislator from Huntington. "The government shouldn't be participating in this recession by making the homeless problem worse than it is."
Each fall for the last two years, Mr. Gaughran has called county officials and managed to rescue the house from the auction block. A lawyer, he once convened a super-meeting about the Stembergs, inviting representatives of public and private agencies and friends of the family, and came away with a dizzying picture of government agencies working at cross purposes.
Margaret O'Regan, deputy commissioner of Suffolk's Social Services Department, said her agency tried unsuccessfully to get the Real Estate Department to reinstate the right to redeem the Stembergs' tax lien, which had expired in December 1986. "We thought maybe the neighbors could get together to pay it off," she said.
Ms. O'Regan said the department feared that separating the siblings could be devastating. "They're emotionally very closely connected," she said. She said the agency did not step in before 1986 because nobody had sought help. "We don't have any ability to go out and find out who's in trouble, unless we have some basis for making an inquiry into somebody's private life," she said.
 
A Promise to a Mother
 At the meeting arranged by Mr. Gaughran, Jimmy Madden offered to pay the back taxes, but the Real Estate Department said it was too late for that.
Mr. Madden and his brother Mickey were driven to help in part by their feelings for Teddy Stemberg, who has been a faithful employee, and in part by a promise their father made to the Stembergs' mother, Muriel, he said. Before she died of cancer in 1973, she asked Mr. Madden's father to take care of Teddy. "That was her last request, and we've been trying to honor it ever since," Mr. Madden said.
Roy Dragotta, acting director of the County Real Estate Department, said the department did not have much leeway to reinstate the right of redemption under state law.
Doing so "would open the floodgates to a lot of problems," he said, adding that his department had "bent over backwards to do the right thing" by postponing the auction each year.
"We don't want to displace anybody," he said. "At the same time we have an obligation to follow the law and put the property back on the tax rolls."
When the property was first put up for auction in 1990, the minimum price was $65,000. Similar houses for sale on the block now, but in better repair, are priced between $120,000 to $180,000.
With the election of a new County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, who has pledged to speed up the return of properties to the tax rolls, friends of the Stembergs have been told the house may have won its last reprieve.
 
On Her Knees for a Job
 Neighbors have been unusually helpful, seeing beyond the eyesore to the people struggling inside. Some apologize for not being able to buy the property for the Stembergs.
"I would not want to uproot these people," explained Rochelle Maucher, an advertising copywriter and next-door neighbor. "I would rather have them there, harmless, good people, than a multiple-family dwelling of transients."
Mrs. Maucher knows only Karen Stemberg, the youngest and most lucid sister, who strains to hold the family together.
Karen Stemberg daily checks the windows of the fast-food restaurants near her home for work. Last December, she said, she was hired by the assistant manager of one, and then later turned down by the top manager. She is a proud, independent woman, but is thinking of returning to ask again for the job.
"Maybe that lady will reconsider," she said. "I'll get down on my knees."
 
A Day at a Time
 Once the county put the property up for auction, it ordered repairs to the house, paid for by the Real Estate Department. Still, the house has many problems. The roof leaks, spreading black stains. When it rained here last week, Karen Stemberg lay unable to sleep, listening to the water drip in yet another new corner. "It was going kerplunk, kerplunk. If I was a nervous person, I would have been screaming," she said.
Together, the siblings just make it through life's daily demands. Rita Stemberg, who believes she narrowly escapes assassination each time she walks to the corner, seldom ventures outside, but cooks for the family. Karen goes to the grocery each day, since there is no electricity to run the refrigerator. Teddy works part time and pays for the groceries. They pool their earnings and stipends to pay the rent and expenses.
Inside the house, darkness and disarray obscure the knotty pine paneling and scalloped cornices, along with other touches their father, a carpenter, built into the house. "He was a lovely man, very gifted with his hands," Rita recalled.
As she spoke, a family of squirrels darted across the eaves, the sudden rumble of their stampede through the ceiling filling the kitchen. The sisters shouted at them to go away, as Rita struck the ceiling with a broomstick.
Because there is no electricity in most of the rooms, the family uses candles and flashlights to see at night, but mostly, they turn in early.
Rita Stemberg hears her private demons then, strangers outside whispering about burning down the house. And Karen Stemberg wonders how long and how else the three of them can hang on.

HEADLINE: V.A. Raising Mortgage Rate

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Higher interest rates on home mortgages from the Department of Veterans Affairs take effect Monday.
The department raised the rate to 8.5 percent from 8 percent on Friday because of what it said were recent increases in interest rates in the credit markets. 
 V.A. rates on loans for home improvements and manufactured homes, like mobile homes, will also rise by half of a percentage point, the department said.
V.A. loan guarantees help veterans buy homes with little or no down payment. The V.A. rate is considered a reliable gauge of the home mortgage market.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Businesses Are Aiding Academy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
While arts organizations throughout the country struggle to find ways to replace revenues lost in government cutbacks, a group of corporations in Brooklyn will announce today the establishment of a fund to contribute a total of $1.5 million over three years to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
The announcement of the Metrotech Downtown Fund is to be made by Robert B. Catell, the president of Brooklyn Union Gas, at a lunch attended by Brooklyn community leaders and Mayor David N. Dinkins on the first day of his temporary moving of City Hall to Brooklyn. 
 All the corporations in the group are located in Metrotech, a campus-like office center on a 16-acre site adjoining Polytechnic University that is one of the largest such projects in New York. Four office buildings in the complex are now complete, a fifth is in an advanced state of construction and two or three more buildings are planned.
 
Specialness of the Support
 "What is new and different about the fund, and what may set a precedent in arts fund-raising," said Karen Brooks Hopkins, executive vice president of the academy, "is that it combines sponsorship such as you can get on TV, direct philanthropy like extending complimentary tickets to needy children and families in the community, and employee benefits like discount tickets, shuttle bus service, restaurant packages and on-site performances."
"Many types of business support for the arts provide one or another of these incentives, but not necessarily all three together," she continued.
Speaking in an interview over the weekend, Mr. Catell said that his company had joined the consortium because the academy "is good for the quality of life in Brooklyn."
"For us," he continued, "it's a matter of enlightened self-interest to help provide the amenities that will attract businesses and people to this community. The payoff of community development is more customers."
 
Reasons for Involvement
 Asked if he had any regrets about losing the spotlight his company enjoyed when individually sponsoring events at the Brooklyn Academy in previous years, Mr. Catell said he had none. "Our corporate philosophy has been to have business collaborate on efforts like this," he said. "We try to be a catalyst."
Bruce Ratner, president of the Forest City Ratner Company, which developed the project and is also a tenant, said: "Just as Manhattan has been a magnet for the arts, and that led to its economic development, so goes the economic development of Brooklyn."
Sponsors of the Metrotech Downtown Fund also include Chase Manhattan Bank, the Consolidated Edison Company, Morgan Stanley & Company, the New York Telephone Company and the Securities Industries Automation Corporation.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Is Seattle Major League? Film at 11

BYLINE: By Claire Smith

 BODY:
It is major league baseball's owners who must decide whether or not to approve Nintendo's $100 million-plus offer to purchase the Seattle Mariners. But it is Seattle that really must make the ultimate decision: whether it has the wherewithal and the will to save the franchise for the Pacific Northwest.
Guaranteed, the first is the more intriguing drama for Americans. Should baseball let Japanese interests, or any other non-North American interests, for that matter, buy a part of the American pastime? It is an emotional question being played out against a larger, more volatile issue as baseball remains an unwitting and unwilling player in the current United States-Japan trade imbroglio. 
 But just because baseball is still digging out from that fallout and ruing the timing of what started out as a simple franchise transfer, it does not mean it has lost sight of the other dilemma: Can and will Seattle prove once and for all that it can support a major league franchise?
It won't make any sense to throw good money after bad -- whether it's dollars or yen -- if the root problems that have helped doom the current Seattle ownership are not fixed, not just for this season, but for the next 3, 5, 10 or 20 seasons.
That community is trying mightily to insure that the problems can be fixed for the long term because of other, more immediate threats from the East. As Washington Gov. Booth Gardner recently said: "The only foreign investor I'm concerned about is Tampa Bay."
Proving Seattle's worth will be difficult; the Mariners are situated in one of the game's smallest markets, with one of the game's smallest sources of revenue. Two months away from a new season, the Mariners remain the only major league team without a local television deal.
So, even in light of Seattle's best intentions, baseball owners cannot be faulted if they remain skeptical. They cannot be faulted if they remind observers that not one, but two Seattle franchises have ended up on the rocks, that first the owners of the Pilots and now the Mariners arrived at the same conclusion: There is no financial windfall for them in the city.
The major league owners cannot want the next owners of the Mariners, whether American, Japanese or whatever, sitting in Seattle a few years lamenting -- in much the way the team's current owner, Jeff Smulyan, is -- that their economic survival now may hinge on either getting out of the game or getting the Mariners out of Seattle.
Washington State knows those sentiments and knows that it has a finite amount of time to provide the evidence that a team can make it in Seattle. For even though Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, has guaranteed that the Mariners will play in Seattle in 1992, no promises have been made beyond that, something Vincent reiterated last Wednesday when asked if he believed the team would stay indefinitely.
"I'd rather speak in terms of what our objective is, and our objective is to keep the Seattle team in Seattle," Vincent said. "But we need help from the community, support from the business community. That is very important because the community ultimately decides whether baseball goes or whether baseball stays."
That was precisely the message that Vincent carried to Capitol Hill last week, when he met with Washington State's congressional delegation. They talked about the $100 million offer by Nintendo, but also about economic realities. The same realities that communities from Cleveland to Montreal have heard from Vincent as he states and restates the three requirements to justify a team's relocation: lack of community support, inability to turn the situation around financially or lack of a major league caliber stadium.
So Vincent and Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner, talked about what is needed from the Seattle business community, about the efforts of Herman Sarkowsky, a former owner of the National Football League's Seattle Seahawks and a co-founder of the National Basketball Association's Portland Trail Blazers, to have the community increase the Mariners' advertising, television and ticket revenue by a total of $13 million a year for the next three years.
Sarkowsky and Seattle officials forwarded details of such a plan to major league baseball the first week of February. But Vincent said Wednesday that "we told the members of Congress that we felt the $13 million commitment is not as firm as we would like."
So, the ball is definitely back in the hands of those business people and civic leaders. They have to prove they can win at this major league game, either with or without the financial infusion from Nintendo. Even the politicians acknowledge that.
"They want to keep the team in Seattle. We know that," Brock Adams, a Democrat and the state's senior United States Senator, said of Vincent and Greenberg. "That's where they start from. Then, whether an offer can be structured that will keep it there, that's the question."

HEADLINE: The Human Peace Dividend

 BODY:
Large cuts in the defense budget threaten to dump hundreds of thousands of demobilized veterans on a soft job market, raising fears of social and economic distress. But creative ideas now circulating in Washington could turn that potential problem into a rewarding opportunity.
Defense Department officials recently predicted the discharge of one million military and civilian personnel by 1996. Yet the United States has produced only 20,000 new jobs in the last three years. Even a recovering economy may find it hard to absorb the human military surplus. 
 Adam Walinsky, a New York attorney, therefore proposed recently in a Times Op-Ed article that Washington keep the military men and women on Federal payrolls but assign them to meet urgent needs of American cities.
With only minimal additional training, he pointed out, many could effectively augment police departments struggling to control violent neighborhoods. Those with medical corps training could put their skills to work in beleaguered city hospital emergency rooms.
Noncommissioned officers and training specialists could bring discipline as well as teaching skills to chaotic city high schools. And former military instructors have the math and science expertise necessary for a competitive work force. The large proportion of blacks and Hispanics now in the ranks constitutes an invaluable pool of role models.
Senator Sam Nunn also sees the potential. He believes those with the most to offer may now be approaching the end of 20-year military careers. He suggests an early retirement program that would offer partial pension payments after 15 years of service, with an increase earned for post-military employment in education, health care, law enforcement and other "critical" work. Washington would also provide retraining for such employment.
In a recent speech, Senator Nunn pointed out that defense downsizing results directly from victory in the cold war. "These people are not losing their jobs because they failed -- they are losing their jobs because they won. The nation owes all of them . . . more than just a simple 'thank you' for a job well done."
Now more than ever the nation needs their help at home. However Washington works out the details, it dare not squander so useful a resource.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
BLACKBURNE RESIGNS FROM M.T.A. BOARD
Laura D. Blackburne, who resigned under fire as chairwoman of New York City's Housing Authority on Saturday, has also quit as a member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board, where her spending habits had also come under criticism. Ms. Blackburne's lawyer declined to give her client's reasons for leaving the 17-member board she has served since 1985. Her proposed successor has been waiting in the wings for over a year. B3.
 
SCANDALS THAT HIT MAYOR'S SORE POINTS
Any mayor might have been duped by the financial behavior that culminated in a guilty plea by David N. Dinkins's campaign finance chairman two weeks ago and in the resignation under fire of his Housing Authority chairwoman over the weekend. But the scandals transcend the inevitable human failings that torment every administration because they revive two issues from which Mr. Dinkins seems unable to escape: lapses in personal finances and questions of race. News analysis, B3.
 
YES, HE'S BROOKLYN'S MAYOR, TOO
Mayor Dinkins is set to move into his transplanted office at in Brooklyn Borough Hall, in a week-long attempt to get closer to a borough that sometimes feels far from the city's halls of power in Manhattan. It was probably inevitable that the move has presented his aides with some logistical problems -- along with skepticism from the people he hopes to meet. B3.
 
FINDING THE MUNICIPAL NERVE CENTER
With the Dinkins administration moving the "nerve center" of city government to Brooklyn this week, the question arises: Where has the nerve center been up to now? Metro Matters, B2.
 
TWO HOUSE PARTIES END IN GUNFIRE
The host at a Brooklyn party turned away a group of teen-age boys after frisking them for guns. The boys retaliated by firing through the door, wounding two girls at the Canarsie apartment. And in Flatbush, a 15-year-old boy was killed and another grazed when gunfire erupted outside a birthday party as 100 young people spilled out on the streets to go home. B2.
 
CARDINAL DENOUNCES RACISM IN CHURCH
Speaking on the last full weekend of Black History Month, John Cardinal O'Connor delivered a homily that amounted to a chastisement of all white Roman Catholics, including himself. He told an almost entirely white congregation at St. Patrick's Cathedral that he was disappointed to see empty pews "on the one Sunday I'd like to have the greatest attendance," and then delivered a bitter message about racism among churchgoers, black and white. B3.
 Rocks are thrown at bus carrying yeshiva students in Brooklyn. B2.
 
REGION
 
GOVERNING THE PINELANDS
A 10-year policy agenda for governing the million-acre preserve drawn up by the New Jersey Pinelands Commission includes enough nods toward the concerns of builders, farmers and quarry operators to worry some environmentalists that profits may win out over preservation in the state's premiere nature reserve. It is the first full-scale review of the Pinelands' plan since rules to limit development and regulate industry in the preserve were adopted in 1981. B5.
 
D'AMATO SEEKS TO PAY LEGAL BILLS
Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato plans to begin a fund-raising drive to pay off more than $400,000 in legal bills for his defense in the Senate on charges of ethical misconduct. He said he cannot afford the bill himself, and cannot spare his regular campaign money because he faces a tough fight for re-election. "I can't afford to personally pay it, so I have to depend on the generosity of others," he said. The Senator has already sold more than 200 tickets to a $1,000-a-plate fund-raiser tonight in New York City. B5.
 
NO COMMUTER TRAIN IS A MODEL TRAIN
There were no tiny commuter cars at the 18th Annual Spring Train Meet in Old Greenwich (51 mintutes by express from Grand Central, 59 on the local). People there already spend enough time on the way to and from work. "I don't think of these trains as commuter trains," said one man who spends 500 hours each year commuting, "and if I did, I probably wouldn't collect them." Old Greenwich Journal, B5.

HEADLINE: The G.M. Cutbacks;
G.M. Picks 12 Plants to Be Shut As It Reports a Record U.S. Loss

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation announced today the first stage of its plan to close 21 plants over several years, identifying 12 plants to be closed in the United States and Canada within three years, affecting 16,300 workers. It also detailed a sweeping reorganization of its troubled North American operations.
The company, the world's largest auto maker, had announced in December that it would begin to overhaul its operations to restore its profitability. Its reorganization plan represents an attempt to unscramble a previous restructuring in the 1980's, which had sought to increase efficiency and reduce costs, with mixed success. 
 G.M. also said today that it posted a $4.45 billion loss for 1991 -- the largest loss for any American company ever. The loss reflected a one-time $2.8 billion charge against its income to cover the expense of the plant closings. The company, the nation's largest manufacturer, is trying to adjust to its declining share of the United States car market, a corporate structure too big for its sales and a miasma of costly labor contracts and supplier agreements.
Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, cited current events worldwide and the unusually deep automotive slump in the United States as important reasons for G.M.'s woes. "The rate of change during the past year was unprecedented," he said. "And no one was immune to the extraordinary events which affected our lives and the way in which we do business."
Mr. Stempel's speech was broadcast live over closed-circuit television to most of G.M.'s 780,000 workers worldwide, many of whom feared for their jobs. More than 3,400 workers at G.M.'s North Tarrytown, N.Y., assembly plant, which makes mini-vans, and more than 4,000 workers at the Willow Run assembly plant in Ypsilanti Township, Mich., near Ann Arbor, learned that they would be among those looking for work by 1995.
But 3,800 workers at an assembly plant in Arlington, Tex., near Fort Worth, sighed with relief when Mr. Stempel said their jobs were safe.
Among the bigger closings will be an engine-assembly plant in Flint, Mich. It employs 4,036 workers who make eight-cylinder engines.
The closings in Michigan, Ohio and Indiana underscore the disproportionate impact the auto industry has on the economy and social fabric of the Midwest. And one of the G.M. closings highlights a trend that has been particularly irksome for the United Automobile Workers union: diesel engine production will be transferred from a plant in Moraine, Ohio, which will be closed, to Toluca, Mexico. The move will eliminate the jobs of 549 union members.
Mr. Stempel, noting that union workers under the current contract are paid whether they work or not through the fall of 1993, declined to say specifically why Willow Run was chosen for closing and Arlington was saved. Both plants make full-sized rear-wheel-drive cars like the Chevrolet Caprice.
"The timing of our actions and the income-security provisions provided for employees will lessen the immediate impact on families and communities," Mr. Stempel said. In answer to a question, he said he had notified President Bush in advance of G.M.'s actions.
By 1995, when the current wave of consolidations is complete, G.M. is likely to employ 71,000 white-collar and about 250,000 union workers, or roughly half the number employed in 1985, Mr. Stempel said. Mr. Stempel did not specify how many white-collar jobs would be affected by the actions announced today; of the 74,000 people that G.M. expects to lay off as it closes all 21 plants, about 20,000 will be white-collar workers.
G.M. said it would try to eliminate jobs through retirements and attrition, but it did not rule out dismissals.
 
Spreading the Pain
 G.M. is taking some important symbolic steps to show that it is trying to spread the pain to executives. For example, the auto maker confirmed today that it had trimmed a special executive pension that pays Roger B. Smith, its former chairman, more than $1.1 million a year.
The revised pension plan, which also affects 100 G.M. executives who have retired since 1990, would mean an annual payment to Mr. Smith of slightly less than $1 million. G.M. said it would save $14 million annually from the revisions.
Not all G.M. hourly workers affected by the latest shutdown announcements will lose their jobs. Some may move to other plants as part of consolidated operations, others will be able to "bump" less senior workers from their jobs under union seniority rules.
 
Earlier Reorganization
 G.M.'s cutbacks have clearly been shaped by recent worldwide economic events, including President Bush's trip to Japan in early January. The automotive industry's efforts to reduce Japanese competition through Mr. Bush's intervention has yielded no more than token results. "We're not getting help from the Government and we're not getting restrictions" on imports, Mr. Stempel said.
With more cuts to come, Mr. Stempel's program promises to continue a climate of anticipation and suspense among G.M.'s white-collar and union workers. Since December, when he first disclosed that G.M. would be closing plants and shedding jobs, employees have been waiting for more specifics.
But other questions were raised as he identified a new management for North American auto-making that essentially replaces the structure announced in 1984 by Mr. Smith. The earlier restructuring, which created three "supergroups," was designed to reshape G.M. so it could take on all comers by the 21st century. Clearly, G.M. has experienced deep pain and dislocation in recent years as it has struggled to stanch losses and market-share erosion and to live up to Mr. Smith's vision. Mr. Smith retired in 1990.
The new structure will be organized around "platform teams," Mr. Stempel said, focused on the manufacturing of similar-sized vehicles. One platform team, for example, will represent all small front-wheel-drive cars, like the Pontiac Sunbird, Chevrolet Corsica, Oldsmobile Achieva and others. The G.M. brand names -- Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Chevrolet, Buick, Cadillac, GMC Truck and Saturn -- will remain as sales and marketing divisions.
 
'List Is Endless'
 Supervising all the platform teams, which encompass engineering, manufacturing and component plants, will be a group of executives called the North American Operations Strategy Board. This group will comprise the manufacturing executives who once ran the supergroups. Staffs and engineering groups deemed redundant will be merged with one another. That is likely to mean the elimination of thousands of white-collar jobs.
Lloyd E. Reuss, G.M.'s president, will run the North American operations. "Lloyd's my man," Mr. Stempel told reporters. Mr. Reuss's job had been rumored to be in jeopardy in recent months, but Mr. Stempel has taken pains to emphasize that he supports the G.M. president.
Mr. Stempel said G.M., in deliberating whether to close the plants in Arlington, Tex., or Ypsilanti, Mich., took into account their overall efficiency, the flexibility of local union work rules, the number of defects in the cars and other cost factors. "The list is endless," he said. He denied accusations by the U.A.W. that G.M. was trying to "whipsaw" plants -- that is, to pit one against another, threatening to close factories that do not lower their costs enough. He also denied playing communities against one another in an attempt to receive tax breaks, although communities including Arlington, whose plant was saved, offered abatements.
G.M. workers at Arlington also voted recently for three-shift production, with output continuing nearly around the clock, which could raise the plant's efficiency when G.M. consolidates production of Caprices and Buick Roadmasters there. Workers at the Willow Run plant studied three-shift production but concluded that it was inefficient.
As expected, the union blasted G.M., as it has each time since 1986 when the auto maker announced layoffs and shutdowns. Owen Bieber, the U.A.W. president, portrayed G.M.'s action as "obedience to Wall Street priorities and Reagan-Bush trade and economic policies."
Mr. Bieber specifically accused Mr. Stempel of whipsawing. As proof, he accused G.M. of forcing a contract on workers at its Moraine truck assembly plant that included concessions on wages, health care, overtime and vacations. The Moraine workers belong to the International Union of Electrical workers, and their plant is one that is in danger of being closed in further consolidations.
In December, G.M. identified two engine plants in Lansing, Mich., that would close. The other plants announced today include a Saginaw, Mich., foundry with 600 workers, scheduled to close in 1994; a V-6 engine line in St. Catharines, Ontario, with 165 workers, to be closed in 1992, although other engines will continue in production, and two Detroit gear and axle plants with a total of 435 workers, one to close in 1992, the second in 1993.
In addition, the closings include a chassis plant in Dayton, Ohio, with 249 workers, to be shut in 1992; a G.M. horn plant in Anderson, Ind., 375 workers, to close in 1992; a casting plant in St. Catharines, Ontario, with 2,150 workers, to close in 1995, and a Lordstown, Ohio, die plant, with 279 workers, to close in 1992.
G.M. also said it was "pursing the sale of operations at the Danville, Ill., foundry" that makes brakes, exhaust manifolds and other parts, employing 1,449 workers.
Five assembly plants that build midsize cars will be reduced to four or fewer, G.M. said. One or more assembly plants among those in Doraville, Ga.; Fairfax, Kan.; Oklahoma City, and two in Oshawa, Ontario, will be shut.


GRAPHIC: The plant closings announced yesterday by General Motors. The shutdowns, which affect more than 16,000 workers, are part of General Motors plan to eliminate 74,000 jobs by 1995. In December, Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, said 21 plants would be idled, including two plants in Lansing, Mich., that make V-6 engines. Seven additional plant closings will be announced by the first quarter of next year, a company spokesman said yesterday.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1541 words

HEADLINE: U.S. DETAILS TERMS ISRAEL MUST MEET FOR DEAL ON LOANS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today laid out the Bush Administration's conditions for granting loan guarantees to Israel.
In his first public description of the terms, he said Washington would back $10 billion in loans over five years only if Israel agreed to freeze all construction of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. 
 He testified before the House Foreign Operations subcommittee today, on the same day that peace talks resumed here between Israelis and Arabs.
Mr. Baker said that if the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir felt that it could not accept a total freeze on settlement construction, the Administration was prepared to offer an option: a far smaller amount in American loan guarantees, for only a year at a time -- on the conditions that only those settlement units now under way are completed and that all new construction in the territories is frozen.
 
Stronger Link Than Before
 The Administration's approach marks the first time in American-Israeli relations that the United States has chosen to use economic aid as a tool to try to change Israeli political actions in the occupied territories.
Every American administration since the territory was captured in 1967 has opposed the construction of housing and settlements for Jews in the West Bank and Gaza as an obstacle to peace that might hamper chances for a territorial compromise with the Arabs. But none has attempted to link American assistance to such a curb.
Mr. Shamir was quoted by Israeli newspapers today as saying that he would not stop settlement building in the West Bank and Gaza "even for a day." He says settlements are necessary both for security reasons and to drive home Israel's philosophical and biblical claim to the territories.
 
Nonconfrontational Tone
 Secretary Baker, in laying out the Bush Administration's conditions, adopted a nonconfrontational tone, indicating that he was still negotiating the issue with Israel's Ambassador, Zalman Shoval, and wanted the deal to go through -- but on his terms.
Both sides would prefer the matter to be resolved in the coming weeks while Congress is considering the foreign aid bill.
With the exception of Representative Larry Smith, Democrat of Florida, who complained that Mr. Baker was being too harsh on Israel, the members of the committee in general reacted favorably to Mr. Baker's presentation.
Senior Administration officials are convinced that many Israelis and the vast majority of Americans, including many American Jews, support using aid to change the actions of the hard-line Shamir Government.
The Administration apparently wanted to make its position known now in order to galvanize support. Its approach is intended to cast Mr. Shamir -- and not the conditions -- as the obstacle to the guarantees.
"The choice is Israel's," said Mr. Baker. "She can determine whether she wants to take action which would permit the strong support of both the legislative and executive branches for these loan guarantees, or not."
 
Talks Resume, Bilaterally
 At the Mideast peace talks here, Palestinian negotiators and those from Lebanon, Syria and Jordan held separate sessions with their Israeli counterparts, picking up where they left off last month: arguing over interpretations of United Nations resolutions, over agendas, over recent clashes between Israeli soldiers and Arab guerrillas in Lebanon -- over everything but peace agreements.
Israeli officials said that they would not be presenting a plan for Palestinian self-rule in the occupied territories, as the Palestinians have, because there is no consensus in Mr. Shamir's Likud party for such a plan, so the Israeli negotiators have apparently been instructed simply to stall.
Both the Israeli and Arab delegates today seemed to be preoccupied with Mr. Baker's testimony. Hanan Ashrawi, spokeswoman for the Palestinian delegation, said: "We think it is important that Secretary Baker has clearly indicated the end and the halt to all settlement activities. I think it certainly adjusts this peace process to place it back on the right track."
The Israeli request for loan guarantees was first presented last fall, but the Administration insisted that discussion be postponed until now so that it would not complicate efforts to put together the peace talks, which began in Madrid in October.
Since the fall, there have been repeated reports that the Administration intended to impose some sort of freeze on settlement building as a condition of support, but Administration officials always declined to discuss their terms in public.
Support for the Administration on Capitol Hill appears to be wide, among both Democrats and Republicans, with the members of neither party very eager to vote for foreign aid in an election year. Both Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Operations Subcommittee, and Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, his Senate counterpart, have made clear that they want to see a halt to Israeli settlement activity as a condition for loan guarantees.
 
Jewish Groups' Lower Profile
 Given this political mood, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker have apparently concluded that there is little political cost in this election year in taking a tough line with the Shamir Government. Jewish organizations that traditionally give strong support to Israel all back the request for loan guarantees in order to help Israel absorb the great number of Jewish emigrants from the former Soviet Union.
But in contrast with a year ago, they are seeking to avoid a confrontation with the President on this issue. This is in part because they are divided over the question of Israeli settlement practices -- with some supporting a freeze and others in favor of continued settlement.
In addition, the Jewish groups do not feel comfortable pressing aggressively for further aid to Israel in the current recession, when foreign aid in general has lost further popularity.
With Israeli general elections planned June 23, the Bush Administration evidently has no incentive to make the conditions for the loan guarantees easy; rather, it appears to be tightening the conditions.
 
Must Not Be Seen to 'Lean'
 As its nominee to oppose Mr. Shamir in the vote, the opposition Labor Party has chosen former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, a politician well regarded in Washington, in constrast with Mr. Shamir.
While Administration officials say they are doing all they can not to get embroiled in Israeli politics -- which they believe would only strengthen Mr. Shamir's hand -- the logic of their strategy is to put Mr. Shamir in a position of either accepting Washington's conditions or being held responsible by the Israeli public for not getting the guarantees.
Mr. Rabin has said that he is opposed to "political" settlements in the occupied territories, such as those placed in the midst of densely populated Arab areas, but he insists that Israel has a right to build settlements for security reasons.
Israel would use the guarantees to borrow money from private banks at lower interest rates.
Although Mr. Shamir has taken a hard-line public stance, both Israeli and American officials insist that the negotiations between Mr. Baker and Ambassador Shoval are continuing and that there is more leeway in the Israeli position than is evident.
Mr. Shoval, American officials said, suggested to Mr. Baker that Israel might be prepared to accept a deal that would allow it to complete those settlements already in progress and to limit new housing units to 1,000 a year.
But as the Secretary made clear in his Congressional testimony today, that was still unacceptable.
"We will support loan guarantees of up to $2 billion for five years if there is a halt or an end to settlement activity," he said.
If Israel chooses this alternative, Mr. Baker said, it acknowledges that the United States would deduct a dollar from the guarantees for each dollar being spent to complete the settlements under way as of Jan. 1. This would insure that no American money went into such building.
 
No Sauce for Gander
 Mr. Baker acknowledged that the Administration was imposing conditions on Israeli policy that it was not imposing its Arab allies, but he said this was justified since the Israeli request came on top of $3 billion a year in economic aid that the United States is already providing.
"Nobody else is asking us for $10 billion in additional assistance over and above the $3 billion to $4 billion that we give every year with no strings attached," he said, putting special emphasis on each dollar number.
That drew the ire of Mr. Smith, a strong supporter of Israel, who called the Secretary of State's remarks "extremely offensive," apparently because they suggested that Israel would be getting $10 billion in cash, rather than loan guarantees that, he said, would not cost the American taxpayer much, provided Israel repaid the loans on schedule.
When Mr. Baker refused to be drawn into an argument with Mr. Smith and said he was finished elaborating, the Congressman shot back: "I hope some day the American public is going to determine whether you finish the answers or not. Disgraceful!"

HEADLINE: Jury Foreman in 1987 Gotti Trial Is Indicted in Plot to Sell His Vote

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
The foreman of the anonymous jury that acquitted the reputed Mafia leader John Gotti in his 1987 Federal racketeering trial was indicted yesterday on charges that he conspired with the mob to sell his vote and influence the jury for $60,000.
The indictment held no new formal charges against Mr. Gotti, the flamboyant, 51-year-old reputed leader of the Gambino crime family, the largest underworld group in the nation. Mr. Gotti has been acquitted in repeated state and Federal cases in recent years and is now on trial in Brooklyn on murder, loan sharking, tax fraud and other Federal racketeering charges. 
 But the indictment painted a stark portrait of jury-tampering and behind-the-scenes machinations that prosecutors had complained about -- but not proved -- in three previous Gotti trials. Its allegations appeared to buttress the need for extraordinary security precautions a judge has taken in the latest case, which could send Mr. Gotti to prison for life.
The indictment by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn charged that the juror, George H. Pape, told a friend with ties to the Gambino family that he would take a bribe to engineer an acquittal. It said that Mr. Gotti authorized the payment, and that his top lieutenant, Salvatore Gravano, gave $60,000 to the intermediary to be passed on to Mr. Pape, known then only as Juror No. 11.
 
Unclear if Money Was Paid
 It was unclear if Mr. Pape got the money. The intermediary, Bosko Radonjich, fled to Yugoslavia last year and is a fugitive, prosecutors said. The indictment charged Mr. Pape and Mr. Radonjich with conspiracy and obstruction of justice, but did not say Mr. Pape got the money or that the 1987 acquittal was fixed; at the time lawyers said the case against Mr. Gotti was weak.
The 53-year-old Mr. Pape, who was arrested by Federal agents at his home in East Norwich, L.I., on Sunday, pleaded not guilty yesterday at an arraignment before Judge I. Leo Glasser in Federal Court in Brooklyn, and was held without bail for a hearing on Thursday. His lawyer, Barbara Hartung, said he was married, had two children and had been unemployed except for odd jobs since 1987.
If convicted of both counts, Mr. Pape would face up to 10 years in prison and fines of $500,000. But prosecutors noted yesterday that a conviction of Mr. Pape would not invalidate Mr. Gotti's 1987 acquittal; they said that under the constitutional protections against double jeopardy, he could not be retried.
Beyond announcing yesterday's indictment, United States Attorney Andrew J. Maloney, who leads the prosecution in the current trial, had no comment. Judge Glasser, who is presiding, has ordered both sides to refrain from public remarks.
Mr. Gotti's lawyer, Albert J. Krieger, said only that he was surprised by the charges. "I didn't know about the indictment until it was first mentioned in court today," Mr. Krieger told The Associated Press after yesterday's proceedings, in which more tapes of Mr. Gotti and his associates, clandestinely recorded by Federal investigators, were played.
There were sharp differences in the way jurors were handled in the 1987 and present cases against Mr. Gotti. In the 1987 case, which took place in the same courthouse, Federal Judge Eugene H. Nickerson numbered the jurors, but did not restrict their movements or contacts.
In the current case, Judge Glasser has ordered the tightest secrecy and security measures in recent memory to guard against jury tampering. The jurors are referred to in court only by their numbers, and the court has promised to preserve their anonymity permanently.
 
Sequestered in a Hotel
 Also the jurors have been sequestered in a hotel for the duration of the trial, which began in January and is expected to last two more months. While they are allowed occasional visits with relatives, they see no one else unless accompanied by a Federal marshal.
The marshals escort them to and from court. They also monitor all mail and telephone calls to the jurors, and strictly regulate their radio and television to bar exposure to broadcasts touching on Mr. Gotti, organized crime or the trial.
Judge Glasser ordered the precautions after prosecutors furnished evidence that there might have been tampering at previous trials. "The Gambino family's history of interfering with the judicial process is extensive and replete with instances of a variety of tampering schemes," prosecutors said in court documents.
They cited a 1984 case in State Supreme Court in Queens, in which Mr. Gotti was accused of assaulting and robbing Romual Piecyk. At the trial, Mr. Piecyk refused to identify Mr. Gotti, who was acquitted. Prosecutors said the witness had been intimidated by Gotti emissaries.
Mr. Gotti was also acquitted in state court in Manhattan in 1990 of assault charges involving a carpenters' union official and, while the jury was sequestered, prosecutors contended that the underworld had intimidated witnesses.
While prosecutors refused to say so, it was widely believed that the charges in yesterday's indictment came from Mr. Gravano, Mr. Gotti's former top aide, who became a Government informer last fall and is expected to testify against Mr. Gotti.
The indictment said that during the 1987 trial, Mr. Pape, who had sworn as a prospective juror that he had never had any contact with anyone connected to organized crime, approached Mr. Radonjich, a friend of many years who was a close associate of Mr. Gravano, and said that "in exchange for money," he would "be willing to vote 'not guilty' in the Gotti case and persuade other jurors to vote 'not guilty.' "

HEADLINE: New Housing Chief Plans Stricter Rules on Spending

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The newly appointed chairwoman of New York City's Housing Authority, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, said yesterday that she planned to adopt strict new spending guidelines at the agency -- which has come under sharp criticism for lavish spending in the last week -- and to focus on improving the city's deteriorating housing projects.
"I am a fiscal conservative," Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said in an inteview yesterday. "These are the most austere times we have seen, and I plan to make sure that every agency dollar is spent wisely on public housing tenants and not bureaucrats." She said she would devise the new guidelines in the coming weeks. 
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who stepped down as Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, replaced Laura D. Blackburne, who resigned under pressure on Saturday, after questions were raised over about her spending practices.
Ms. Blackburne spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on office renovations and business trips, including $1,500 to charter a helicopter to a housing conference in Atlantic City and $16,000 to take city housing officials to Puerto Rico to give advice to the housing authority there.
In a symbolic first step, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said that she had removed a pink leather office couch -- which has come to epitomize the lavish spending of her predecessor -- and that she planned to donate it to a center for the elderly in Brooklyn.
But Ms. Hernandez-Pinero did not openly criticize Ms. Blackburne, who is credited with winning tens of millions of dollars in Federal housing money for New York City and helping to rid city housing projects of drug dealers. Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said that she hoped to continue many of Ms. Blackburne's social service and housing development programs, but that repairing the physical condition of public housing was her top priority.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said she was concerned that the number of managers at the authority had increased sharply under Ms. Blackburne, at a time when other agencies have been scaling back, and that she would seek to shrink management.
Housing advocates and experts yesterday praised Ms. Hernandez-Pinero's appointment. "I can't think of anyone who would be better able to take this job," said Kathryn Wylde, president of the nonprofit New York City Housing Partnership.
Barry Feinstein, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 236, which represents municipal housing workers, said: "Sally is a tough, smart lady who knows a lot about housing. I think she will take a firm grip of this agency and move forward."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The G.M. Cutbacks
General Motors listed the 12 plants it will close in its sweeping reorganization of its troubled North American operations. It also reported a $4.45 billion loss for 1991 -- the largest in American corporate history. [Page A1.]
Without $2.8 billion in one-time pretax charges for plant closings, G.M.'s fourth-quarter loss represents a significant improvement from the fourth quarter of 1990. [D6.] 
 Workers at G.M.'s Willow Run plant disputed the assertion that the factory would be closed solely for economic reasons. [D6.]
The closing of the 90-year-old G.M. assembly plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., surprised workers and local officials. [D7.]
 
 Companies
Barry Diller, the Hollywood executive who challenged the television networks, resigned as chairman of Fox Inc. [A1.] No other executive in Hollywood has left so strong a mark on a company in the last decade. [D18.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Incumbent;
Bush Sounds Patriotic Theme in Maryland

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 24

 BODY:
President Bush drove seven miles to a financially comfortable suburb of Washington today to open his Maryland re-election campaign, declaring that "the fight for the future has just begun and it will continue for four more years."
To a crowd of 2,500 people in a high school gymnasium, Mr. Bush offered what is becoming a stock campaign address. It is an upbeat melange of allusions to last year's military victory over Iraq, attacks on Democrats in Congress, calls for passage of his legislation to boost the economy and scornful comments on "professional pessimists" who fear America's claim on world leadership is ebbing. 
 Drawing on a vein of tub-thumping patriotism that spurs applause even from tepid crowds, the President urged his audience at Bethesda-Chevy Chase High School "to send a message to those doomsayers and those pessimists": that "we are the United States of America, and we can compete with anybody."
 
Attacks Isolationists
 Tonight, the line appeared to be directed at Mr. Bush's Republican rival, the conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan, who was reared in the Chevy Chase section of Northwest Washington, a stone's throw from where Mr. Bush spoke. Mr. Buchanan favors erecting trade barriers to shield American companies from foreign competition and has opposed Mr. Bush's more activist foreign policy.
Without naming Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Bush attacked those who would "lock the doors and pull down the blinds and hope the world goes away."
"America is not that kind of country," the President said. "Never before in this nation's history have we turned our back on a challenge and we are not going to start now by becoming an isolationist nation.
"Think back a year ago this very day," the first anniversary of the allied ground attack in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Bush said. "What did we hear of those professional pessimists? They spoke of defeat and humiliation. Well, they were wrong then, and they are wrong now."

HEADLINE: Dow Struggles to Advance 2.23, to 3,282.42

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as trading eased with investors expressing concern over a weak bond market and rising interest rates. Still, blue chips drew some interest, nudging the Dow Jones industrial average to another high, 3,282.42, up 2.23 points.
The bellwether average of 30 industrials was the only index to reach a closing high yesterday -- its 12th record this year. 
 Paul J. Kronlokken, a technical analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis, was surprised by the resiliency in the market as it came back late in the session. "However, the story was the broader market, which was not able to bounce back" from earlier lows, he added.
As interest rates tick higher, investors become increasingly concerned about the impact on corporate profits and look to the more attractive bond yields that would begin to compete with the equities for investors' money. Yesterday, the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond was up 2 basis points, or two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.96 percent.
"There's nothing wrong with locking your cash at 8 percent and being able to get a good night's sleep," Mr. Kronlokken said.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 181.3 million shares, down from 261.7 million on Friday.
The Big Board composite gained 0.16 point to finish at 227.62, as losing issues outpaced gainers by 1,013 to 726.
Investors' interest in blue-chip stocks also helped the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks to gain 0.81 point, 412.27, while the American Stock Exchange index dropped 1.05, to 411.80. In Nasdaq trading, the composite fell 4.82, to 624.93, while the Russell 2,000 dropped 1.51, to 208.89.
General Motors announced a 1991 fourth-quarter loss of $4.25 a share, a record for the industry, including a one-time charge of $2.8 billion relating to its previously announced plans to close 21 plants and cut 74,000 jobs by 1995. The announcement had little impact on the market because most analysts expected it. The stock fell 5/8, to 37 3/4.
Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm, pointed to Merck, up 3 1/4, to 149 1/2, on expectations of a 3-for-1 stock split; Walt Disney, up 1 1/2, to 154 3/8; Texaco, up 1 3/8, to 58 3/4, and J. P. Morgan, up 1 1/4, to 59 3/4, as the big movers on the Dow.
In other market activity, Home Depot closed at 61 3/4, up 1/8, but not before rising 1 1/4 after the chain of building materials and home improvement stores reported fourth-quarter earnings of 31 cents a share, better than most Wall Street expectations of 26 cents to 28 cents a share.
Shares of Du Pont fell 1 1/8, to 47 1/8, after the publication of reports that one of its fungicides, Benlate, was responsible for contaminating farms in Florida. The fungicide, which was taken off the market a year ago, has cost the manufacturer more than $205 million in damage claims.
A breakthrough that would enable users of Macintosh personal computers to make commands by voice, without the use of a keyboard or mouse, sent Apple Computer stock up 1 1/8, to 66 1/8. Analysts said the event was significant in the race to develop computers that respond to voice commands, but a company spokesman said, "It's not ready for prime time yet."
Zenith Laboratories, a manufacturer of generic pharmaceuticals based in Northvale, N.J., jumped 3 5/8 yesterday, to 23 3/4, after a court in New Jersey ruled on Friday that its Cefadroxil drug did not infringe Bristol-Myers Squibb's patent for Duricef. Bristol-Myers rose 1/4, to 78 7/8.

HEADLINE: Sign on Capitalist Road: --> Recessionary Bumps

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBNICA, Czechoslovakia

 BODY:
Ever since the 1930's, towns like this one in the soft valleys of the White Carpathian mountains have housed Czechoslovakia's biggest arms forges, hidden deep from enemies in east and west. Now, two years after the collapse of Communism and the resulting wave of disarmament, the Slovak workers who once turned out many of the heavy weapons for Warsaw Pact armies are still awaiting their peace dividend.
"We once sent 75 percent of our production to the old Soviet Union,," said Ivan Juttner, personnel director at the huge Heavy Machinery Works. "Now it is about 8 percent. This is our reality, and it is having a tremendous effect on employment." 
 The problems at the factory, which employs 80 percent of the work force in this town of 25,000 people, are typical. As Americans experience dismay over military spending cuts that are costing jobs in the midst of a recession, the cutbacks here are threatening to undermine industrialization itself and push this town back into a pattern of farming, a bit of tourism and waves of emigration.
 
Bitterness Breeds Sarcasm
 The bitterness here over the arms industry is only reinforced when the news reaches the valley that the United States has shipped billions of dollars worth of arms to the Persian Gulf region, while the Government of President Vaclav Havel in distant Prague has ordered Dubnica's arms industry closed down.
"My compliments to America's arms industry," said Stanislav Hajas, an adviser to the management of the Heavy Machinery Works, adding that roughly 5,500 of 16,400 workers have been laid off since 1988. At Dubnica's steel mill, whose 98,000 tons of annual capacity once barely met the needs of assembly lines that turned out heavy armored personnel carriers, workers may soon go on four-day weeks as furnaces shut down.
Juraj Cervinka, the 52-year old mayor, said some people opened small businesses after 90 percent of Dubnica's stores were privatized. "Others are leaving, seeking work in Germany," he said, "and an arrangement with the Dutch enables 300 workers to go to Holland."
Until now, most of those laid off were women whose husbands remain the family breadwinners, he said. Consequently, the impact has not yet been severe on social services like nursery schools and vacation homes, where budgets have been cut by a quarter in two years.
 
Deja Vu
 Fifty miles to the northeast, at the big arms factories in Martin, management spurned the warnings of Prague policy makers and the objections of Washington and Israel and agreed last September to sell 250 big Soviet-designed T-72 tanks to Syria. In Dubnica, there is no feeling of censure for Martin's rebelliousness, but rather of regret that Dubnica's arms makers lack Middle East contacts from former communist days.
"When the order came to stop arms production, we had 2 billion crowns in inventory tied up," Mr. Hajas noted, adding that all the aid provided this year by cash-strapped Prague totaled only 1.2 billion crowns (about $40 million).
This is not Dubnica's first conversion. Under the Soviet Government of Nikita S. Khrushchev in the 1950's, assembly lines that were built under Stalin after World War II to make heavy artillery were converted to make construction equipment. But the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 reintroduced arms manufacturing, and brought a prosperity that was intended to wean Czechs and Slovaks from a yearning for freedom.
 
Problems of Scale
 Mr. Hajas says potential investors are often frightened away by Dubnica's sheer size. "To be frank, our factory is a colossus," he says, "It is fair to say that since the revolution, we've had 2,000 representatives of firms worldwide come through here. But when they see how huge the plants are, and hear that for the conversion of our former products about $500 million would be needed in a short time, nearly everyone has a short discussion and leaves."
One that did not is the Reda Corporation, an Oklahoma-based maker of petroleum pumps. In what at first sight appears to be an ideal triangular deal involving Western technology, skilled Slovak labor and customers in the oil fields of western Siberia, Reda has agreed to transfer technology to Dubnica to employ about 1,200 people making drilling pumps that will go to Russia in barter for crude oil.

HEADLINE: Further Cuts at GE Aircraft

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: EVENDALE, Ohio, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The General Electric Company said today that it would make further cuts in its aviation jet engine business to save $150 million a year and meet stiff market competition.
GE Aircraft Engines said it would cut 2,800 salaried and hourly jobs throughout its North American operations this year, with most of the reductions coming by the middle of the year. 
 The company said it also planned improved production and inventory management, organizational restructuring, tightened use of business travel expenses, decreased overtime spending and less use of outside personnel to perform work from clerical tasks to consulting.
General Electric said it was putting on hold plans for the start-up of an engine overhaul plant in Suffolk, Va. G.E. imposed a similar cost-cutting delay last year for an engine blades plant in Durham, N.C.
The newest round of cost-cutting is necessary because of reductions in Government military programs and the effect of a stalled economy on the commercial airline industry, G.E. said. It makes and sells engines for military and commercial jets.
The company cut 2,900 jobs last year in its American operations, mostly at its headquarters plant in Evendale, a suburb of Cincinnati. The division employs about 33,500 people around the country, including 17,000 in Evendale.
