HEADLINE: The G.M. Cutbacks;
Michigan Workers See Politics in Closing

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Workers at General Motors' Willow Run plant in Ypsilanti Township, Mich., today disputed the assertion by the company that its decision to shut their plant in 1993 was made solely on economic grounds.
Officials of Local 1776 of the United Automobile Workers, which represents workers at Willow Run, said their plant had several economic advantages over its sister plant in Arlington, Tex., which will remain open and will be refurbished to handle increased output of large rear-wheel-drive cars. 
 Because of its proximity to suppliers, the union officials said, Willow Run could produce each car for $400 less than in Texas.
 
 
Suspicions of Politics
 Officials of the Willow Run local asserted that an internal G.M. study had also found that upgrading Willow Run would be less expensive than making the required investments in Arlington. A G.M. spokesman said the company would not discuss its internal reports.
"Show me how they made the decision based on numbers, and you can't," said Jerry Clifton, shop chairman of Local 1776.
He said workers felt that President Bush had swayed G.M.'s decision in favor of Arlington because Texas was his home state. In return, Mr. Clifton says, G.M. stands to benefit from the President's effort to obtain speedy approval of a free-trade agreement with Mexico.
 G.M.'s chairman, Robert C. Stempel, insisted at a news conference today, when he announced the company's fourth-quarter and 1991 losses and its factory-closing plans, that the Willow Run closing was strictly a business judgment.
"The plant decisions were based on internal factors and the economic realities of the world automotive market," he said. "Political considerations were not part of our decision process."
City, county and state officials in Texas had scrambled in the weeks after Mr. Stempel's Dec. 18 announcement to prepare an assortment of tax abatements tied to a planned enterprise zone surrounding the Arlington plant. Gov. Ann Richards promised that Texas would buy more than 1,000 natural-gas-powered vehicles from G.M. if the Arlington plant remained open.
The survival struggle between Arlington and Willow Run -- and among politicians and union and company officials -- was the most closely followed example of how G.M.'s restructuring announcement stood to affect various communities.
 
 
Worker Concessions
 The tug-of-war was also seen as a test of whether the competing plants would be goaded into "whipsawing," or making competing concessions, to win G.M.'s favor. Workers in Arlington reportedly expressed willingness to work 10-hour shifts with no overtime pay, but national U.A.W. officials said that would undercut the national contract.
Union officials at Willow Run said that they had made no such offer, adding that extraordinary shift agreements would ultimately hurt productivity.
Workers on the morning shift at G.M.'s Arlington plant, near Fort Worth, erupted into cheers and applause when they learned that their plant, with 3,800 employees, would remain open.
"I'm glad the news is here and I'm glad the news is good," said Mike Seiler, chairman of U.A.W. Local 276. "We've got a good work force. But I hate to see anyone lose their job anywhere in this company."
 
Corvairs and X-Cars
 While the 36-year-old Willow Run plant has never before faced the threat of closing, it has seen its share of troubles.
The products it built through the years have included the Chevrolet Corvair, the rear-engine, air-cooled car attacked by Ralph Nader in his 1965 book "Unsafe at Any Speed." In 1979, it also started building the ill-fated series of so-called X-cars: front-wheel-drive compacts sold with nameplates that included the Chevrolet Citation, Buick Skylark and Oldsmobile Omega. The series was discontinued because of quality problems.
Willow Run has also seen many corporate reorganizations. The plant has been assigned to Chevrolet-Fisher Body, the General Motors Assembly division, the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group and the Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada Group. With each change, the plant had to adjust to new management philosophies.
In 1989, the plant started building the restyled Chevrolet Caprice. Its sales also flagged, in part because of its unusually rounded styling and lukewarm reviews.

GRAPHIC: Photo: G.M. workers in Ypsilanti, Mich., learned yesterday that the Willow Run plant would be closed in 1993, while a sister plant in Arlington, Tex., would be spared. Officials of U.A.W. Local 1776, which represents Willow Run workers, heard the news on a live broadcast by G.M.'s chairman, Robert C. Stempel. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ex-Soviet Nations May Join I.M.F. Soon

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Russia and at least half a dozen other former Soviet republics will most likely join the International Monetary Fund at the group's spring meeting in Washington on April 27, executives at the fund and foreign officials said today.
The officials said the Group of Seven nations and the I.M.F.'s 156 members were still debating how large a share of the bank's capital the republics should supply. 
 These officials said that Russia, Armenia, Belarus, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Moldova, plus the three Baltic states, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, would likely join the international lending organzation. But they said it might take longer for other republics to join because of delays in obtaining sufficient data on their economies.
"The feeling is it's a very high priority to get on with these applications," an American official said.
The officials said Russia and the other republics would probably take a stake of 4 percent to 4.5 percent of the I.M.F.'s current capital, which is slightly more than $120 billion. According to some officials, Russia alone would supply about 2.5 percent.
After the United States called for shrinking the I.M.F. board, the Group of Seven agreed to give Russia a seat and expand the board by one, to 23, Western officials said.
The republics are eager to join in order to increase their ties with the West and to qualify for I.M.F. assistance. The group's aid is usually conditioned upon a country's adopting strict economic reforms.
The I.M.F. board plans to finish paperwork for admitting Russia and several other republics by April 15. At that time, it hopes to send out a mail ballot to the members in the hope they will approve the admissions before April 27.
If the former Soviet republics take a 4.25 percent stake in the I.M.F., they will be asked to put up about $5.1 billion. They would have to put up a quarter of this in hard currency; the rest could be in their own currencies.
 
Where Money May Come From
 Because the republics are so short of hard currency, foreign officials said there was a good chance that the republics would get that money from grants or loans from wealthy nations.
Member countries can qualify for aid from the I.M.F. equal to three to four times their capital stake.
Some I.M.F. officials fear their efforts to aid the republics will be thrown off track by delays in increasing the fund's overall capital to $180 billion, from $120 billion. The main reason for that delay, they say, is that the United States, the largest shareholder, has not yet approved its $12 billion share of the increased capital.
An I.M.F. delegation returned today from a trip to Moscow, where it worked with Russian economics officials to develop a reform program that would be tied to I.M.F. aid.

HEADLINE: Shanghai vs. Mah-Jongg: What Odds?

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
In the evening, after folks here have emptied their rice bowls and put down their chopsticks, the criminal instincts overwhelm the most unlikely people -- high-school students, white-haired old women, even longtime Communist Party members. As if by compulsion, someone locks the door and they prepare for an evening of law-breaking.
It is mah-jongg time. 
 The Communist Party has tackled tough assignments before, like the 1949 Revolution. But these days, the leadership of Shanghai, China's largest city, has set itself a truly daunting task: to eradicate mah-jongg, the game that is a national craze.
The crackdown conducted over the last few weeks has been about as effective as a campaign against office football pools would be in the United States.
 
Nothing Better to Do
 The campaign seems to illustrate two fundamental truths about Communist Party rule in China.
The first is that the party seems so remote these days that it has an unerring talent for annoying ordinary people without really meaning to. Probably more Chinese peasants care passionately about mah-jongg than about freedom of the press, and the result is that even those unconcerned about persecution of dissidents profess irritation at endless political study sessions, at requirements that they "volunteer" to buy Government bonds, and at denunciations of mah-jongg when there are no better entertainment options.
The second fundamental truth is that the party has lost much of its ability either to inspire or to terrorize, and so its edicts are frequently ignored.
"It's no use to try to regulate mah-jongg," said a young woman here. "Nobody pays attention to the campaign. The Government babbles, and the people play."
"The Government has no authority anymore," she said, pointing to a group of bicyclists careering across the street through traffic. "Look at those people -- that's illegal too. But the law doesn't matter."
 
Gambling Is the Target
 The authorities are trying to stamp out mah-jongg because play is usually accompanied by gambling. Most mah-jongg enthusiasts bet only small amounts, often the equivalent of just a few cents. But some people become hard-core gamblers and fritter away all their savings, occasionally even staking their wives on a game.
Consequently, many Chinese regard mah-jongg as a dangerous vice -- but an exceedingly fun one -- with much the same ambivalence that some Americans might feel for alcohol or blackjack or double helpings of chocolate cake.
The United States and other countries also control gambling, and sometimes even office pools, but Shanghai is one of the few places that tries to change social habits and ban small-scale betting in the privacy of the home. In Hong Kong, in contrast, mah-jongg is legal at social gatherings or in the abundant parlors that have licenses from the Government, which has sought to keep the game out of the hands of Chinese gangs.
The Taiwan authorities allow social mah-jongg betting in the home, while Macao offers all kinds of gambling, including casinos, and consequently attracts large-stakes gamblers from all over Asia.
One reason for the authorities' zeal in Shanghai may be that privacy is not a well-known concept in China. Even the Chinese expression for privacy is usually used in a pejorative sense to hint at selfishness or secretiveness. Still, even if they don't always value privacy, many ordinary Chinese treasure their small-stakes mah-jongg.
"There's no way you can succeed in banning mah-jongg," said a college-educated woman who supports the Government. "You might as well try to ban knives because they can sometimes be used to kill people."
Mah-jongg, which had its origins in the Song Dynasty more than 700 years ago, is played with 144 domino-like tiles with names like West Wind and Red Dragon. In the 1920's the game became popular in the United States and Britain, and Chinese who saw the movie "Driving Miss Daisy" were astonished to see a scene in the film in which Americans were playing mah-jongg.
Whether in America or China -- or in other countries like Japan and Korea where mah-jongg is popular -- the rules are essentially the same. Four people normally play at a time, each player keeping a "hand" of tiles and leaving the rest in the center of the table. The players take turns putting some down and taking up others, with the aim of building up a set of matching tiles. The rules are something like gin rummy, but played with tiles rather than cards.
 
Shanghai Gets Tough
 China banned mah-jongg during the Cultural Revolution from 1966 to 1976, but there was a resurgence in the 1980's and now it is normally tolerated, even though it is frowned on. Mah-jongg sets are available in stores -- Beijing Department Store has 10 kinds on sale, at prices ranging from $5 to $156 -- but mah-jongg gambling dens are strictly banned and the game is normally forbidden in the workplace and in schools.
While in most of China the Government does not bother people who play in their homes, Shanghai for some reason has been particularly determined to uproot mah-jongg.
"Playing mah-jongg is an ugly social trend," Wenhui Bao, a Shanghai newspaper, declared several months ago. "People wallow in it so that it saps the energy and seriously affects production, work and studies. Gambling over mah-jongg causes crime and considerable social harm. We must absolutely eradicate this mah-jongg craze."
In the latest campaign against mah-jongg, which began around the turn of the year and was timed for the Chinese New Year celebrations, when people have time on their hands and are prone to gamble, the authorities created 5,000 "anti-gambling squads" to prowl the suburbs.
In addition, 270,000 rural Communist Party members in Shanghai were summoned to meetings to watch as 4,300 party members publicly gave self-criticisms and renounced mah-jongg.
One county head in the Shanghai suburbs called a mass meeting and started a bonfire of 400 mah-jongg sets. Shops in the outskirts were told to stop selling mah-jongg games, according to official newspaper reports. But in central Shanghai, stores continue to sell mah-jongg sets and the police have been restrained.
"If you're just playing at home with the old lady and the kids, then the cops will just give you a warning," said a middle-aged mah-jongg enthusiast.
"But if you've got some friends over, then they'll probably figure you're gambling and confiscate all the money in your pockets."
Shanghai residents said that while the police might enter a house if they heard the sound of tiles from the street, most police officers were too lazy to bother and would hurry on. But if a neighbor reported that mah-jongg was being played, the police would almost certainly raid a private house, they said.
Many mah-jongg players said that the real problem in Shanghai was that there was nothing else to do in leisure time that was fun and affordable.
"We need more ways of having fun," said Zhang Weiguo, a Shanghai journalist and dissident. "On TV we see these things from the West -- skiing, water slides, hang gliding and so on -- but the only thing that people here have to turn to is traditional old mah-jongg. So it's gotten to the point that out of 1.1 billion Chinese, maybe 900 million play. Only a melon-head doesn't play."
"The problem is the Communist Party management," Mr. Zhang said. "It's true that more people are playing mah-jongg and that this is hurting the economy and harming the society. But the reason people play is that they don't have alternatives."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Challenger;
In Georgia, Buchanan Plays Up His Role as a Republican Outsider

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ELLIJAY, Ga., Feb. 24

 BODY:
In his most extensive day of campaigning in Georgia since his strong showing last week in the New Hampshire primary, Patrick J. Buchanan said today that President Bush and the "Republican establishment" were seeking to shut him out of the race for the party's Presidential nomination.
Mr. Buchanan, the conservative commentator who received 37 percent of the vote in the New Hampshire Republican primary last Tuesday, complained that he was being kept off the ballot in several states by Mr. Bush's supporters and that he was being denied opportunities to speak to Republican gatherings like the Southern Republican Leadership Conference meeting last week in Charleston, S.C. 
 The candidate's comments came as he undertook an energetic day of campaigning in Georgia, a state he and his aides have called "crucial" to his chances of maintaining his challenge to Mr. Bush.
 
A Populist Theme
 Mr. Buchanan traveled to this town in northwest Georgia, to be interviewed by a local radio commentator, address students and parents at a Ellijay High School and wolf down barbeque at a roadside stop. He also attended a reception and spoke at a rally in Atlanta.
With his comments today, Mr. Buchanan appears to be shifting to a populist stance, playing up an image of an outsider fighting the Washington establishment. In doing so, he seems to be placing less emphasis on voter anger over tough economic times, an issue that may be less effective in a state like Georgia where unemployment is not the problem it is in New Hampshire.
In playing the role of an outsider, Mr. Buchanan also hopes to be able to tap into Democratic as well as Republican votes. In the Georgia primary, members of one party can cross over to vote in the other party's primary.
Mr. Buchanan and campaign officials say they are concerned that they might not have enough time before next Tuesday's primary for the message to sink in with enough voters. Mr. Buchanan has campaigned in Georgia for portions of two days.
Frank I. Luntz, who serves as Mr. Buchanan's poll taker, said his surveys show that many voters in Georgia are not aware of the results of the New Hampshire primary or of Mr. Buchanan's campaign, which has just started broadcasting radio and television commercials.

HEADLINE: Students as Leaders

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
"What's the catch?" 16-year-old Francis Clement asked when told that his Bronx high school, James Monroe in Hunts Point, had been chosen. Students at George Washington High School in Harlem asked, "Why us?" And disbelief blended with pride at Brooklyn's Automotive High School, where students complain that outsiders often stereotype them as grease monkeys.
Now, three weeks into the program, skepticism has faded over the unexpected windfall -- grants from the wealthy Surdna Foundation to create student-run foundations to improve neighborhood life. In its place, students are discovering an almost heady sense of power. 
 The Surdna grants of $7,500 a year for three years to each school dovetail with the frequently expressed goal of Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez to get students more involved in community service. If the experiment works, the Chancellor wants to extend it citywide -- assuming the money comes from philanthropies or corporations.
 
Ambitious Programs
 The three schools each initially enrolled about 25 students in the new Student Service and Philanthropy Project, but all students are invited to propose projects. Some want to clear vacant lots for playgrounds, while others discuss working with the elderly and patients with AIDS, or searching for ways to promote racial harmony. Students are expected to identify local problems, decide how to use their money for grants, develop a budget and run and monitor projects.
Recent racial incidents in Brooklyn made promoting harmony a priority for Austin Smith, 17, the president of the student government at Automotive High. He dreams of creating a community center in his Brooklyn neighborhood, Canarsie, to induce isolated ethnic minorities to get together at least for sports. "This might be too ambitious," he conceded, saying, "We'll have to be realistic about what we can accomplish."
Chancellor Fernandez is encouraging the students to let their imaginations soar. "At a time when too many adults in our city and country have thrown up their hands in despair over the problems of unemployment, homelessness, AIDS and the crumbling infrastructure," he said, "we need practical ways to show our young people that each of us can play a role in turning things around."
Surdna, one of the country's wealthiest family foundations with assets of $325 million, was created in 1917 by John E. Andrus, an investor in pharmaceuticals and real estate. Surdna -- the family name spelled backwards -- has always operated quietly in supporting traditional philanthropies. Two years ago, its director, Edward Skloot, decided to concentrate on environmental issues and community revitalization, and it now gives away $17 million yearly.
"At Surdna, we wanted to show we take kids seriously and don't regard them as grunt laborers but as active planners who can take on responsibilities for their own communities," said Mr. Skloot. The foundation is providing $292,000 for the undertaking.
In making their selections, organizers looked for those schools offering leadership training and where students demonstrated an interest in the community. At Monroe, students accompanied the elderly to shops and clinics. At Washington High, they cleared litter and made a garden.
Unlike the other two schools, most of Automotive High's students are not residents of the surrounding community, and must commute to their school in Greenpoint, a working-class Brooklyn neighborhood of small factories, modest houses and a largely Polish population. Steven Gilbert, the principal, acknowledged his students are often regarded by some residents and shopkeepers with distrust.
Mr. Gilbert said students have made overtures to the community in an effort to improve the school's image. They cleaned two nearby subway stations, swept the platforms and replaced graffiti with a mural.
Automotive students, meeting with their adviser, James Mulqueen, decided to focus on helping children.
"Kids need our help to keep away from drugs," said Danny Ortiz, a 17-year-old who commutes daily from Washington Heights.
Mr. Mulqueen and his students tried but failed two years ago to raise money for students to work in a nearby day-care center, the John Oradecz Center. Automotive's students occasionally help out at the center, but it lacked money for a formal training program. That could change now because of the windfall to Automotive High.
The center cares for more than 170 youngsters. "We're always looking for extra hands," said Diana Sito, who now directs the center. "We need help in the classrooms. We need help in the after-school program. And we could certainly use some help in the kitchen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Automotive High School in Brooklyn is one of the schools that received grants from the wealthy Surdna Foundation to create student-run foundations to improve neighborhood life. Automotive students, meeting with their adviser, James Mulqueen, center, voted to name their philanthropy the "Automotive Leadership Foundation" and to focus on helping young children. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Disconcerted, Kerrey Changes Course

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RAPID CITY, S.D., Feb. 24

 BODY:
As he struggles for survival, hoping that a victory in South Dakota will give him the lift he needs to remain in the Democratic race for President, Senator Bob Kerrey seems to have cast off some of his skepticism about conventional political behavior.
The candidate who entered the campaign late, acting on impulse, and who often seemed as much at war with himself as with any of his Democratic rivals, has shed some of his quizzical detachment from the contest. 
 The Nebraska Senator attacks the two leading contenders, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, with vigor. His standard speech has grown broader and better organized. Known for his off-the-cuff, self-deprecating wit, Mr. Kerrey is now careful to leaven his remarks on planning the post-cold-war era and the need for national health insurance with prepared jokes -- at someone else's expense. "George Bush's contact with working people," he told college students in Aberdeen, S.D., "is bumping into the hired help."
His advisers explain that in the last week of New Hampshire, once his prospects had dimmed, Mr. Kerrey was "liberated." He has said that after a "pretty clunky" debut he has found his stride. What Mr. Kerrey seems to have discovered is that common motivation for politicians: a dread of losing. "I have to fight my way back to the perception that I can compete," is how Mr. Kerrey describes his plight.
 
Charmed Political Existence
 Senator Kerrey, who lost part of a leg in Vietnam, has known extraordinary personal adversity in his life, but he has never in the course of a charmed political existence confronted as directly the prospect of public failure.
When Mr. Kerrey was a popular Governor of Nebraska, he surprised virtually everyone in his state by deciding not to seek a second term that was all but assured. He told a reporter, rather airily, that he wanted "more danger" in his life. Walking out on defeat, however, is an entirely different prospect.
At a child care center in Sioux Falls today, Mr. Kerrey, echoing the theme of one of his advertisements, attacked Governor Clinton for seeking economic advice from a Washington consultant whom Mr. Kerrey said was "negative" about farm subsidies. Mr. Clinton insisted in the debate Sunday night that the consultant helped him only on tax issues. Today, Mr. Kerrey said sharply, "Not only does it not have the ring of truth, it's not true at all."
In Colorado on Saturday, Mr. Kerrey described Mr. Tsongas as "a corporate lawyer and registered lobbyist in Washington." Mr. Tsongas's economic plans, he added, included "elements of the trickle-down economics that failed in the 1980's."
And like any seasoned politician, he denied in an interview today that there was ego attached to his competitive spurt. "I'm not in this to drive up my name identification," he said, "If I am President, this country will be different from the one of Paul Tsongas or Bill Clinton. I'd be the better President."
 
No 'Baptism by Fire'
 A supporter in Sioux Falls, Arnold Snortland, said he and others had wondered what was keeping Mr. Kerrey from catching fire. "I think he is finding himself," said Mr. Snortland, an insurance company executive. "That's been the big problem."
Mr. Kerrey, he said, has "had it pretty easy until now, from Governor to the Senate. He hasn't had a baptism by fire."
Mr. Kerrey has complained about reporters' depictions of him as "quirky" and "diffident." But Mr. Snortland said he was not bothered by psychological examinations of Mr. Kerrey. "I have advice from that great philospher, Mae West," he said. "It's better to be looked over than overlooked."'
Mr. Kerrey had said of New Hampshire, where he finished behind Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton, that his efforts there had not been wasted because "I learned something about myself." He now says he wishes he had not said that. "I'm not on a mission of self-discovery," he said. "I am running because I am concerned about the future of the country."
 
A Crucial Contest
 Most analysts say the South Dakota contest is crucial for Senator Kerrey as well as for his rival, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, because their states both share borders with this state and, as the only Midwesterners in the race, they must prove they can show strength in their home region if they are to be taken seriously elsewhere.
Saying that he expected to win in South Dakota, Mr. Kerrey described his strategy for survival after Tuesday as "just stay in the boat." (One Kerrey adviser, Tad Devine, adopted the motto from a line in the Vietnam film "Apocalyse Now.") But with sparse national press coverage of the campaign here, and a depleted campaign treasury, the complications for Mr. Kerrey are mounting.
Still, he is seeking a second chance to be discovered, and that hope mainly rests on something's causing Mr. Clinton or Mr. Tsongas to stumble. "The best hope for Bob Kerrey is that voters take a look and say, 'These two guys aren't good enough,' " said William Carrick, a Kerrey adviser.
The competitive zeal that has infected Mr. Kerrey has not entirely transformed him. In the debate in Sioux Falls on Sunday, he was at turns good-humored and aggressive, but his performance lacked the fire he showed in previous debates. He was not as "electrifying," as he sarcastically said the day before that he needed to be.
Nor are all his Presidential-sounding comments on the global economy as direct and forceful as he intends. Talking about world trade in Sioux Falls, Mr. Kerrey discussed about the importance of making payments to the International Monetary Fund, which, he said, helped world prosperity. A reporter asked him to name a few countries that have been helped by the I.M.F. Mr. Kerrey was caught off guard. "Oh God, you've stumped the band," he said, with an embarrassed smile.
And in still other ways, he remains an unconventional politician. Flying from Sioux Falls to Aberdeen, surrounded by aides inspecting scheduling sheets and newspaper clippings, Mr. Kerry sat quietly by himself, reading the Thomas Hardy novel "Jude the Obscure." He insisted that neither the title nor the book's themes, about fate being determined by character, held any special meaning for his campaign. "I just like good writing," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
It's Time to Get Tough, Bush's Advisers Declare

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
For weeks, White House strategists put out bullying talk about "going negative" on Patrick J. Buchanan. After New Hampshire, the President's strategists concluded they had talked too hard and hit too softly. This week, they say, they really mean it.
They are ready to spend whatever they have to on commercials, including attack ads, and to accuse Mr. Buchanan of "cheating" and question his patriotism to show how tough they can be. 
 The first blast against the conservative commentator came from a fellow fire-eater, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the state singled out by the Bush team as their killing ground. Working on President Bush's behalf, Mr. Gingrich denounced Mr. Buchanan for running a campaign commercial accusing Mr. Bush of abandoning a promised tax break.
The advertisement was "dishonest" and "hit below the belt," said Mr. Gingrich, whose sudden affection for a President he has derided for three years as a sell-out on taxes is one sign of how topsy-turvy the Republican campaign has become.
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas has undertaken the task of portraying the tough-talking Mr. Buchanan as a wimp by reminding Southerners that the commentator opposed the war against Iraq. "Let him drop by Fort Benning and explain to the people there why when they were in the desert, he was opposing the President," Mr. Gramm said today.
And Charles Black, senior adviser to the Bush campaign, said that after holding its fire in New Hampshire, the campaign was almost certain to run commercials criticizing Mr. Buchanan in the South.
The motivation for this sudden toughness is simple: The stakes are high in the South. By March 10, eight Southern or border states will have held nominating primaries or caucuses, beginning with Georgia and Maryland next Tuesday, and the Bush campaign hopes to accomplish no less than eliminating Mr. Buchanan as a candidate.
Southern poll takers, political scientists and politicians say the ingredients are there for Mr. Bush to do that. The region has well-heeled and well-organized Republicans who have been a minority so long that they cling loyally to a Republican White House, and it has a better economy than the Northeast. And Mr. Bush has millions to spend on advertising.
"If the President does not do substantially better in the South than in New Hampshire, he better buy him a real house in Texas, because he's going to need it," said Claiborne Darden, a poll taker in Atlanta.
Mr. Bush's supporters, who frantically tried to play down the importance of New Hampshire, acknowledge that the next two weeks are a clear test of the President's ability to drag his campaign out of its current state of confusion, reassert control over his own party and prepare for the fall campaign against the Democratic nominee.
So, the Bush camp is angry. Are the other guys scared?
Even though his decision to pull his punches in New Hampshire clearly cost Mr. Bush votes, no one doubts his ability to get nasty. He did that in 1988 against Michael S. Dukakis.
But Mr. Dukakis did not fight back. This time, Mr. Bush is calling a proven street fighter outside.
Mr. Buchanan has shown no hesitation to attack Mr. Bush, and in the fall, Mr. Bush could be running against someone like Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who likes to remind everyone that he has already shown he can take a punch.
Mr. Buchanan's strategy in the South is clear. He has nowhere near as much money as Mr. Bush and has been concentrating on Georgia. Mr. Bush seems secure in South Carolina, thanks to the efforts of Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr., who delivered the state to him in 1988 and to Ronald Reagan in 1984, and Mr. Buchanan will have a difficult time getting enough money to compete in large states like Florida and Texas.
In his Southern campaigning, Mr. Buchanan will go on hitting hard on racial tensions, which he has been doing by accusing Mr. Bush of signing a bill that would create quotas in hiring. He will also remind Southern voters that Mr. Bush broke his 1988 "no new taxes pledge."
In Georgia, Mr. Buchanan is running a commercial that proved effective in New Hampshire. It accuses Mr. Bush of reneging on a promise to push for a $500 increase in the tax exemption for children. The proposal was included in Mr. Bush's economic plan, but not in a list of the seven most urgent measures that the President wants passed by March 20. Today, Mr. Bush wrote to Representative Robert H. Michel, the House minority leader, saying that the proposal was a "major part" of his policy that he wants passed this year.
But Merle Black, professor of political science at Emory University in Atlanta, criticized Mr. Bush, saying "The business with the $500 is classic stupid politics and stupid politics doesn't play well anywhere."
Mr. Black and others said Mr. Buchanan's task in the days ahead is to focus on the 40 percent of Georgia Republicans who, according to state polls, are not firmly committed to Mr. Bush. Also, he must pull in some conservative Democrats, a possibility since Georgia voters do not have to decide which primary they will vote in until they enter the polling place.
"These are the white swing voters, who could have voted for Reagan, could have voted for George Wallace, might even have voted for David Duke, but Buchanan's blown Duke out of the water by talking about quotas," Mr. Black said.

HEADLINE: The G.M. Cutbacks;
Auto Maker Posts Deficit Of $2.5 Billion

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Closing the books on its worst year in history, the General Motors Corporation today reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $2.5 billion, a record quarterly loss for the company. The deficit reflected a one-time pretax charge to income of $2.8 billion to close 21 plants over the next several years.
Excluding all extraordinary charges, the auto maker's loss for the fourth quarter was $519.8 million, on revenues of $33.6 billion. That represents a significant improvement from the fourth quarter of 1990, when G.M. posted a $1.62 billion loss on revenues of $29.9 billion after war in the Persian Gulf shattered consumer confidence and dried up auto sales. 
 G.M.'s profits have improved since the fourth quarter of 1990, one-time charges aside, in part because of cost-cutting and strong performances by the company's subsidiaries.
G.M. was the last of the Big Three auto makers to report its fourth-quarter and 1991 earnings. The Chrysler Corporation showed a $97 million profit in the final quarter and a loss for the year of $795 million. The Ford Motor Company posted a fourth-quarter loss of $475.7 million and a yearly loss of $2.25 billion.
Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, said he expected quarterly earnings to improve. "We are committed to substantially re-sizing G.M.'s North American operations in order to achieve full competitiveness as quickly as possible," he said.
 
Biggest Corporate Loss
 The fourth-quarter loss brought G.M.'s 1991 loss to $4.45 billion -- the biggest in American corporate history -- compared with $1.98 billion in 1990. Revenues fell to $123.05 billion, from $124.7 billion in 1990.
Mr. Stempel said that G.M.'s North American automotive operations were responsible for all the losses, though he did not break out a separate figure. Analysts estimated the North American losses at roughly $7.5 billion, excluding one-time charges.
"There are no major surprises here," said Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst with Merrill Lynch in New York.
G.M.'s stock fell 62.5 cents in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $37.75.
Auto sales remained at recessionary levels throughout most of the year, weighed down by weak consumer confidence. Costly customer rebates and other incentives also drained G.M. cash, averaging about $1,000 a car, according to many analysts. Mr. Stempel also cited costly labor expenses as a burden on its finances.
Sales of G.M. cars internationally earned $2.1 billion in 1991, helped by strong sales in Europe and Mexico.
G.M.'s three major subsidiary operations, Electronic Data Systems. GM Hughes and G.M.A.C., posted strong financial results.
 
Data Systems
 E.D.S., a computer services company based in Dallas, posted the best quarter in its history, with net income rising to $155.9 million, or 33 cents a share, from $133.4 million a year ago, or 28 cents a share. Revenues rose 24 percent, to $2.09 billion from $1.68 billion.
The company registered a rise in annual revenues of $7.1 billion for 1991 compared with $6.1 billion for 1990. Net income last year rose 10 percent, to $547.5 million, or $1.14 a share, from $496.9 million, or $1.04 a share, in 1990. A change resulting from a new accounting standard lowered net income from $563 million for the year.
Last year was also the first since G.M. acquired E.D.S. in 1984 that revenues from sources outside the auto maker exceeded revenues derived from business with the parent.
G.M.'s class E shares on the New York Stock Exchange closed at $56.75, unchanged.
 
GM Hughes
 GM Hughes, which includes Hughes Aircraft and Delco Electronics, also posted record revenues and earnings in the final quarter. It earned $224.6 million, or 64 cents a share, on revenues of $3.1 billion, compared with earnings of $158.4 million, or 49 cents a share, on revenues of $2.9 billion in 1990.
For the year, GM Hughes earned $435.5 million, or $1.39 a share, on revenues of $11.5 billion, down from earnings of $577.2 million, or $1.82 a share, on revenues of $11.7 billion in 1990.
The company attributed the declines to an 8 percent drop in General Motors' North American vehicle production and a decline in the worldwide aircraft flight simulator market.
G.M.'s class H stock rose $1.125, to $19.375.
 
G.M.A.C.
 Net earnings of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation for the fourth quarter were $102 million, down from $259 million for the period a year earlier, but net income for all of 1991 was $1.37 billion, a 15 percent increase over 1990 earnings of $1.19 billion.
The 1991 earnings, showing the results of G.M.A.C.'s financing, insurance and mortgage operations, reflect the addition of $332 million that resulted from a change in accounting standards. A special wholesale loss provision recorded in the fourth quarter also amounted to $171 million after taxes. Excluding these provisions, net income totaled $1.21 billion, the second-highest earnings in G.M.A.C. history.
The total cost of borrowed funds in the United States averaged 7.66 percent in 1991 compared with 8.57 percent in 1990.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Record in Congress;
In House and Senate, Tsongas Went His Own Way

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
As a member of Congress, Paul E. Tsongas described the Federal budget deficit as the nation's "No. 1 economic problem," criticized labor unions as an obstacle to increased industrial productivity and led efforts to help the guerrillas who were resisting the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan.
He consistently sided with liberals when they sought to protect the environment and the civil rights of women and homosexuals. But he often sided with moderates and conservatives when they moved to curb the growth of Federal spending. 
 In other words, as a member of the House of Representatives from 1975 through 1978 and as a Senator from 1979 through 1984, Mr. Tsongas displayed the same unorthodox mix of ideas that he espouses as a Presidential candidate.
 
An Atari Democrat
 He described himself in those years as an Atari Democrat, a member of the young generation of politicians and economists who looked to high technology as a source of jobs and economic growth.
He was a decade ahead of most lawmakers in identifying Japan as both an economic threat and a model for cooperation between government and private industry. In the early 1980's, he introduced several bills that would have authorized the Government to subsidize certain new technologies.
At a time when many Democrats and labor leaders were lambasting President Ronald Reagan's fiscal policies as an assault on poor people, Mr. Tsongas complained instead that the Reagan Administration was not investing enough in science, research and technology.
Mr. Tsongas's voting record indicates that he was among the most liberal members of the House. As a Senator, he continued to vote with liberal Democrats. But in 1979 and 1980 he re-examined his political assumptions and began to suggest that to help create jobs the Government should adopt tax and economic policies to assist businesses.
As a Senator, Mr. Tsongas was more effective than most other freshman members. He played a major role in shaping two laws of lasting significance. One protects more than 100 million acres of pristine land in Alaska from commercial development. The other authorized a $3.5 billion aid package for the Chrysler Corporation.
 
Peace Corps Volunteeer
 Having served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Ethiopia and the West Indies in the 1960's, Mr. Tsongas often complained about the "foolishness" of American policy toward third-world nations. By spurning their pleas for economic aid, he said, the United States drove such nations toward Moscow.
Mr. Tsongas urged Presidents Jimmy Carter and Reagan to establish diplomatic relations with the Marxist Government of Angola. He supported legislation to cut off military aid to El Salvador and deplored that country's human rights record.
Through all this, Mr. Tsongas had a touch of whimsy rarely found in the Senate. Mocking politicians and oil executives who sought maximum oil production, he suggested breeding dinosaurs in the hope they would increase future supplies of fossil fuels.
As a Senator, Mr. Tsongas served on the committees on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, Foreign Relations and Energy and Natural Resources. In an interview, James A. McClure, a conservative Idaho Republican who was chairman of the Energy Committee from 1981 through 1986, said: "Paul Tsongas was intelligent, listened well and contributed to our discussions in a thoughtful way. There was no knee-jerk reaction from him that told you his mind was committed before he got into a subject."
What follows is a survey of Mr. Tsongas's record in Congress, as reflected in his remarks, votes and actions.
 
Energy
 Energy was the topic of Mr. Tsongas's first speech in the Senate, in 1979. He described the energy crisis of fuel shortages and high oil prices as "the greatest threat to America's future." Calling for a new definition of national security, he said: "Any rational strategic military planner would have to conclude that our major vulnerability today is not, as many would argue, a first strike by the Soviet Union on our I.C.B.M. installations, or a Warsaw Pact attack upon NATO, but rather our vulnerability to the crude oil supply" from the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Tsongas was a tireless advocate of energy conservation, which he called "the best weapon we have" against the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. He supported greater use of solar energy, windmills and synthetic fuels. He boasted that he voted for increases in the Federal excise tax on gasoline whenever they were proposed.
But unlike many liberals, Mr. Tsongas refrained from attacks on the oil companies, saying such criticism, while emotionally satisfying, did nothing to reduce the excessive consumption of oil. "If Mother Teresa were put at the head of Exxon, the energy crisis would not go away," he said in 1981.
 
The Environment
 Mr. Tsongas made his mark in the Senate as a champion of environmentalists in the fight to restrict development of Federal land in Alaska. The state "represents the greatest conservation challenge of the 20th century," he said.
Donald J. Barry, who worked on the bill as an Interior Department lawyer, said last week: "A lot of people like to claim credit for the Alaska Lands Act. Senator Tsongas is one of the few members of Congress who truly deserve it."
Mr. Tsongas was more willing than most liberals to accept nuclear power. "No nuclear power means one certain result: large-scale reliance on coal," he said in 1980.
 
Chrysler and the Economy
 Though initially skeptical about loan guarantees for Chrysler, Mr. Tsongas supported them after labor unions agreed to wage reductions. He helped develop what he described as a Federal bailout for the auto maker in 1979. He worked closely with a Republican, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, and was sometimes criticized by the unions.
Howard G. Paster, chief lobbyist for the United Automobile Workers at the time, said last week: "Senator Tsongas initially demanded wage givebacks that were out of the question. In the end, he was clearly committed to saving Chrysler. But he could not be taken for granted by organized labor. The Chrysler loan guarantee showed his willingness to think unconventional thoughts and his impatience with the ritual dance of the legislative process."
Mr. Tsongas got high ratings from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. During his 10 years in Congress, his scores averaged 89 on a scale of 100. He presents himself now as aggressively pro-business. But his ratings from the Chamber of Commerce of the United States averaged only 23, also on a scale of 100.
As a member of the House in 1978, Mr. Tsongas voted against a proposal to lower the capital gains tax, but a few years later he said he had made a mistake because that bill "did more for the economy of my state than anything I did as a Congressman."
In 1982, Mr. Tsongas warned that Japan was outstripping the United States in world trade. If the United States is to compete with Japan, he said, "business and government must adopt a new cooperative spirit."
 
Civil Rights
 Mr. Tsongas repeatedly introduced bills to prohibit employers from discriminating against homosexual workers. "The use of an irrelevant factor, such as sexual orientation, in evaluating an applicant or employee is a blatant invasion of that person's privacy," he said.
He was also a leading supporter of a proposed constitutional amendment to guarantee equal rights for women.
In 1979, Mr. Tsongas said, "I personally support busing as a constitutionally acceptable remedy of last resort to achieve desegregation." But to strike a compromise with lawmakers opposed to busing, Mr. Tsongas supported restrictions on its use. He was an early supporter of legislation to strengthen the Voting Rights Act..
 
Foreign Affairs
 Mr. Tsongas supported President Carter's decision to protest the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979 by embargoing shipments of grain and high technology products to Moscow.
In 1982, he introduced a resolution calling on the Reagan Administration to step up the supply of "material assistance," including weapons, to Afghan guerrillas trying to expel Soviet forces.
Through his years in Congress, Mr. Tsongas often highlighted human rights abuses, from East Timor in Indonesia to South Africa to El Salvador. As early as 1979 he was urging colleges to show their opposition to apartheid by selling their stock in companies doing business in South Africa.
Mr. Tsongas consistently supported military and economic aid for Israel. But in 1982, he criticized Israel for carrying its war in Lebanon all the way to Beirut. He voiced concern at "the magnitude of human suffering and physical destruction in Lebanon."
After a trip to Lebanon and Israel in that year, he said Prime Minister Menachem Begin's approach to the Palestinian question was "nothing more than a charade."

HEADLINE: Rutgers's Quote-a-Matic Keeps Professors Talking

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 24

 BODY:
Obscene corporate salaries in the news? Prof. Charles Fay is a Rutgers University expert on the history of executive pay.
How about the legend of the New Jersey Devil around Halloween, or the shifting social rules of dating on Valentine's Day? Dr. Angus Kress Gillespie is the resident sage in the American Studies Department on campus. 
 And no sooner was Anita Hill behind the witness table at Clarence Thomas's Supreme Court confirmation hearing than the names of Rutgers academic experts on sexual harassment began chirping their way out of newsroom fax machines along the Atlantic Coast.
Using the advanced facsimile machine's ability to send the same message to dozens of other machines automatically, the Rutgers University News Service has developed a state-of-the-art, on-top-of-the-news supply of quotable experts ready to meet a reporter's most urgent need, an authority to quote, and to soothe a skeptical editor's doubts.
Since the service began on a regular basis in the summer of 1990 with an offer of interviews with experts on the law and politics of abortion, the six-member Rutgers News Service staff has worked in specialized areas like reporters on beats. They have culled the state's flagship campus here for experts on New Jerey's deer population during recent protests about hunting them and for a zoologist, an ornithologist and a biologist to discuss the onset of spring.
For the rare conjunction of Jupiter, Venus, Mars and the moon last June 14, there was Prof. Ted Williams, astronomer. For President Bush's trade talks in Japan, Norman J. Glickman, an economist at Rutgers; for Santa Claus and "the impact of mass communications on the spread of the legend," back to Professor Gillespie.
 
'Communications Revolution'
 All colleges and universities like to see their faculty members quoted as experts, and most send out annual lists of specialists in various areas. But Roz Hiebert, a spokeswoman for the National Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges, and herself a 20-year veteran of the University of Maryland's news service, said she knew of no other campus that could match Rutgers's efforts to tailor its list of sources to breaking news events.
"It's all part of the communications revolution," Ms. Hiebert said, "and although I'm sure that many other universities would like to be doing the same thing, at this point most have not been able to set up such a quick response system."
Ruth Scott, director of the Rutgers News Service, said her staff members thought up the plan. "For many years, the News Service responded to requests for interviews," she added, "but this was an attempt to get ahead of the requests, to anticipate what the media would need."
 
Response to Earthquake
 "The first time we faxed them was in 1989, right after the San Francisco earthquake," she went on. "We put out the name Dr. Young Chae, the chairman of the department of civil engineering, who was also a member of the University Council for Earthquake Research. And the response was very good."
Between August 1990 and the end of December 1991, the university sent out 239 news advisories, more than three a week, offering the expertise of 454 faculty members. The faxes produced 1,031 interviews with newspapers and radio and television stations on the university's roster of 71 newsrooms.
Douglas Frank, a Rutgers News Service staff member who runs the facsimile service, said most faculty members welcomed a chance to comment on news events in their fields, and some even provide home telephone numbers.
As a public institution, Ms. Scott remarked, Rutgers has something of a duty to advance its role as a shaper of, or at least commentator on, public events. The faxed advisories also help keep the university's name before the taxpayers who support it. But the service is not, Ms. Scott said in response to a question, intended to help Rutgers compete for attention with the world-renowned Ivy League university about 18 miles down U.S. Route 1 in Princeton.
"I think that Rutgers University is recognized in its own right," she said.
As it happens, Princeton does not usually solicit interviews with its faculty, said Justin Harmon, head of the university's news office. It relies instead on the mails to distribute releases that stress Princeton's extensive resarch efforts and uses faxes only occasionally.
But Mr. Harmon rose like any good publicist to a sly question about being one-upped by another campus:
"The answer to your question," he said, "is that our faculty are such heavy-hitters that their names are already in everybody's Rolodexes."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Post of Vice Chairman Is Filled by Dayton Hudson

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The Dayton Hudson Corporation, which operates the Target, Mervyn's and Marshall Field's store chains among others, yesterday named Henry T. DeNero to the newly created position of vice chairman.
Mr. DeNero, who will join the Minneapolis-based retail company from McKinsey & Company Inc., the management consulting firm, will also serve as Dayton Hudson's chief financial officer, a position that has been vacant since September. 
 "Mr. DeNero brings a set of skills and experiences to this position that will enable him to make important contributions to the leadership of our corporation," said Kenneth A. Macke, the company's chairman and chief executive.
While Mr. DeNero, 45, has worked with retail clients during his tenure at McKinsey, he said he had been hired for his skills as a strategic and operational planner. He headed the consulting firm's Operating Company Strategy Practice for five years.
Mr. DeNero has been with McKinsey since 1973, most recently as a senior partner in its Los Angeles office. He will move to Minneapolis with his wife, Nancy, and 11-year-old son, John, while his daughter, Karen, 17, will head to Duke University.
Before joining McKinsey, Mr. DeNero was an officer in the Navy and worked with another consulting firm. He is a graduate of Amherst College and received a master's degree in business administration from Stanford University.
McKinsey has not done any work for Dayton Hudson.
Mr. DeNero said he would act as a member of the senior management, "deciding on and implementing and accomplishing strategies and operations to address the issues the company is facing."
He said it was too early for him to comment on what some of those issues were. The company has been hit by the weak economy in California, which accounts for more than 50 percent of sales at Mervyn's, a purveyor of moderately priced clothing.
Profit margins at the company's Target division, the discount store chain that has driven Dayton Hudson's business recently, are under pressure because prices in Target stores have been deliberately lowered to compete with Wal-Mart and K Mart.
The purchase of Marshall Field's, a department store company, for $1.1 billion in 1990 also added high-yield debt to the company's balance sheet.
During 1991, several key Dayton Hudson executives left the company. Target's president, Warren Feldberg, joined Marshall's as chief executive, while George Jones, executive vice preesident, left to become president and chief executive at Rose's Stores. Two senior vice presidents at Target also left last year.
"While Target has always been good at developing backup management, these losses come at a time when the company is embarking on a fast-track expansion plan," wrote Wayne Hood and Diana Pilotis, retail analysts at Prudential Securities, in a report on the company issued in January.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Light Day And Gold Drops Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed on world currency markets yesterday in extremely light, uneventful dealings.
Gold prices declined worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $349.80 a troy ounce, off $1.40 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold slid $1.45 an ounce to a late bid price of $349.75. 
 Analysts said currency trading was dull. "It appeared as if there was virtually no business taking place," said Richard Levine, a foreign exchange broker at Merrill Lynch Futures Inc.
The dollar advanced against the Japanese yen. Mr. Levine said the "only thing worth noting about the session was the absence of further intervention by the Bank of Japan."
Last week the Bank of Japan stepped in and sold dollars for yen in an attempt to prop up the Japanese currency.
But with the dollar piercing the 128.50-yen level without touching off central bank action, traders said it appeared the United States currency would soon move even higher against the yen.
Mr. Levine cited structural changes in the Japanese economy that point to a "growth recession" there as factors weighing on the yen. "All their economic numbers that were so wildly positive in the 1980's are coming into line" as Japan catches up with a global economic downturn, he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.61 yen, to a closing 129.26 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 129.10 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 129.20 yen, up from 128.95 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7473, from $1.7470 late Friday. In New York, it cost $1.7467 to buy one pound, more expensive than Friday's $1.7400.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.6528 German marks, down from 1.6590; 1.4935 Swiss francs, down from 1.5020; 5.6185 French francs, down from 5.6390; 1,240.00 Italian lire, down from 1.243.75, and 1.1892 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1868.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $349.65 a troy ounce, from $351.85 late Friday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $349.80 an ounce from $351.75. In Hong Kong, gold fell $3.59 an ounce to close at $350.80.
Silver prices were mixed. On the Comex in New York, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.090 a troy ounce, down from $4.093 on Friday. But in London it rose to a late bid of $4.11 from $4.10.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Odd Economics Of Russian Cars

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

DATELINE: TOGLIATTI, Russia

 BODY:
ZHUGULIS and Ladas, Russian cars that look like Fiats, roll off the assembly line at the Vaz Auto Works every few minutes. Despite huge public demand for new cars, this steady, unhurried pace has not risen in years and does not seem likely to now. The workday remains two shifts, not three. And twice a day, the lights dim, the mile-long assembly line stops cold and thousands of workers take 45 minutes to eat.
But underachieving at the commonwealth's largest auto maker has its payoff. If a General Motors or a Ford were to increase car prices by 750 percent in a single day, as Vaz did on Jan. 2, they would undoubtedly suffer a severe drop in sales. Vaz cars are selling as well as ever -- the difference being that while American auto companies make more cars than Americans buy, the Russians don't begin to meet the demand within the Commonwealth of Independent States. 
 "Ten million people want new cars, and among these people, more than enough can afford to pay the higher prices," said Nikolai A. Glushkov, deputy general director of Vaz, which makes 700,000 of the 1.2 million cars manufactured annually in the old Soviet Union.
The upshot is that people fight to buy each new car. Never mind that Vaz models now cost from 140,000 to 220,000 rubles - roughly $1,400 to $2,200 - up from less than 20,000 rubles, or $200, on Jan. 1. A few even travel to the huge Vaz works in this Volga River city 700 miles east of Moscow in hopes of somehow snagging cars before they are shipped to customers who signed up for them years ago.
Still others go to Russia's new commodity exchanges, where Vaz now offers nearly 14,000 cars a year at whatever price the market will bear. Lately, a four-door compact has been auctioned for 700,000 rubles, or $7,000, an indication of what car prices would be if Vaz's management and the Russian Government had not agreed to limit the price increase to only 750 percent.
So why not let the price shoot up to 700,000 rubles, and then float down as buyers at that level make their purchases and disappear? Mr. Glushkov's firm answer is that Vaz has a social goal: to provide cars for the average Russian. Letting the price float freely would compromise that goal.
Why not, then, raise output so that the 10 million potential customers can buy vehicles without having to wait so long? Satisfying demand by increasing production, as would occur in a free market, would make buyers less willing to pay high prices. The rationale, as offered by Mr. Glushkov, a 42-year-old former physicist, and other executives, is revealing.
Using the computer system installed by Fiat, when the Italian company built Vaz for the Soviet Union in the late 1960's, they find that the current average car price of 150,000 rubles yields a profit of about 30,000 rubles a car, after subtracting the cost of materials, parts, labor and taxes. Higher production might threaten this profit by chipping away at the price. Even though they could produce many more cars and still not begin to satisfy demand, they fear that more production would somehow mean lower prices per car, forcing Vaz to cut costs, which would mean shrinking its labor force of more than 200,000 people. That, Vaz's managers are not yet ready to do.
"While we still have the opportunity, we choose the easier way," said Sergei V. Zhiltov, the chief financial officer. "We maintain profits by raising prices rather than reducing costs."
There is another obstacle to higher production: parts shortages. Since late summer, cars have come off the assembly line without a bumper or a front grille or some other part. Across a street from the main plant, a huge lot is nearly filled with several thousand snow-covered cars awaiting some missing item before they can be shipped.
Most of the shortages result from the political turmoil, an obstacle that Vaz's managers say they are solving by going around politicians. "We are establishing direct relations with the companies that supply us in Russia and in other republics, and no longer operating through ministries," Vladimir I. Tikhonov, a production chief, said.
But Mr. Glushkov acknowledges that even with enough supplies, and the reinvestment of profits in labor-saving robots, a step now being taken, there is still not much incentive to raise production. That prod would come only if Vaz and the smaller Russian car makers lost their monopoly, said Rair Simonyan, a Russian economist.
One way to dismantle the monopoly would be through more imports. Foreign cars can be legally imported, but their cost in dollars is prohibitive. The more likely next step would be foreign investment -- for a Fiat or a Honda to build an auto factory. But no foreign company has yet found the Russian market worth the huge investment. Even Fiat's plan to buy an ownership stake in Vaz has been put on hold.
So Vaz's managers have a free hand, for now. Until you get foreign competition or other competitive pressures, Mr. Simonyan said, "you won't get an increase in production here."

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
Welcome Glimpse Of Summer

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS

 BODY:
Hooray for summer!
After the fizz of spring fashions, summer clothes look positively wholesome. These are the styles that will be in the stores in May and June, when vacations and long weekends loom ahead, when attention is divided between surviving in the heat of the city and playing at the beach or in the country. 
 Designers' solutions are eminently simple. Two of them are offering clothes that are uncomplicated, easy and cool. Isaac Mizrahi concentrates on cotton. Donna Karan alternates between silk and linen.
Colors are quiet, not distracting. At Isaac Mizrahi, there are groups of beige, blue, red and black. Donna Karan likes yellow, white, navy and green.
In the all-American spirit of sportswear, pieces are interchangeable. A white linen tailored jacket by Ms. Karan is quite sober in itself -- or with matching linen pants. It develops a little snap when worn with a short wrap skirt embroidered in white soutache and combined with a cotton blouse knotted at the middle to show the midriff.
 
Short or Long
 Mr. Mizrahi is serious about offering "something for everybody."
Do you prefer short skirts? He has them -- albeit a smidgen longer than they were last summer.
Want to try out some long ones? He has them with plenty of fullness or cigarette slim.
"There's no way we can tell women who have just found out how mobile they can be in short skirts to switch to long ones," he said, reflecting the non-dictatorial understanding mood of designers at the moment. "But women who want a chance to try something new will have an opportunity."
So he has suits with familiar tiny skirts, and suits with skirts that cover the knees. Every designer has pants, narrow or wide, signaling further emphasis on trousers for the next season, the most important of the fashion year, fall and winter. The reasoning here is that women who don't have a big conviction about which hem length they prefer will turn to pants, a safe solution. Comfortable and convenient, too.
The Karan approach to warm-weather dressing includes loose, easy shapes, like a big shirt that descends almost to the floor, or a poncho embellished with gold hand-painted motifs to wear at home or at the beach. Both are presented over stretch pants.
 
Sundress for Day or Night

The shoulder-baring sundress that can also be dazzling at dinner is another possible component of summer wardrobes. In the spirit of diversity, this is offered in long and short versions, with either slender or full skirts.
The backbone of summer wardrobes is still the suit. To make it look fresh, Mr. Mizrahi offers it with full puffed sleeves or a cool scooped neck. The Karan innovation is a zipper down the back of a jacket with a diagonal fold across the front; other zippers are concealed in the side seam. The new closures are all in the interest of clarity and smoothness, Ms. Karan said. They also give the jacket the uncluttered look the designer considers so desirable.
"The perfect summer wardrobe is about simplification," she said. "It's about looking pulled together in an effortless, comfortable way."
The versatility of the suit is welcome at a time of recession. Not only can the jacket be worn with skirts or pants, it can also accompany dresses and, depending on its accessories, can move from office to dinner. For these reasons, designers see no waning of its popularity as a key wardrobe component.

HEADLINE: ON TENNIS;
Court Technology Goes On-Line

BYLINE: By Robin Finn

 BODY:
After a querulous semifinal outing recently in Chicago, where she later made history by securing her 158th career title, Martina Navratilova mused on the outbursts tennis professionals often direct at the linesmen who pass judgment on their shots. "Until you have robots instead of players, these arguments are going to happen," she said, and shrugged.
Actually, there's a more realistic technological innovation at hand, one that could cause linesmen to go the way of the white tennis ball, and it's already pitting tennis traditionalists against the computer-programmed perfectionists. 
 The alternate solution to player-
linesman piques is one in which robot surrogates don't hit the balls but do call the lines. The system made its debut in semi-secrecy last week at the U.S. Pro Indoor in Philadelphia.
There, unbeknownst to most players and linesmen because it was buried beneath the Supreme court surface, the Sensor Courts system was tested by the ATP Tour. It was the first time that the invention, which uses a digital pattern recognition system to track the bounce of a tennis ball, had been activated under tournament conditions.
The dubious charms of Nintendo-style tennis, where the computer won't make a peep in the umpire's ear unless the player's shot is out of bounds, has arrived at a projected cost of approximately $35,000 per court per event. According to the Sensor Courts brochure, it even has the unofficial blessing of the game's renowned expert on the foibles of linesmen, John McEnroe.
That doesn't mean it will be seen again soon. The technology may be ready, but as yet no other tournament has agreed to use it, the ATP's board of directors has not approved use of the system, and the women's tour has yet to even agree to test it. One of the system's developers estimates it is two years away from regular usage.
In Philadelphia, linesmen and chair umpires made the calls, but behind the scenes, a computer was doing the same job. According to the computer, which supposedly is 99.9 percent correct, its human counterparts were on the money with 92 to 93 percent of their calls, not bad for the naked eye.
According to one of the system's developers, Russ Kussack, as well as several umpires and the honorary tournament chairman, Marilyn Fernberger, Sensor Courts performed like a pro. Unlike an Israeli system that's applying the technique of Scud missile tracking to tennis but isn't ready for the courts, this Florida-based version is installation-compatible with any hard court. Unlike an Australian competitor that traces the lines of the court with an electromagnetic field and responds only to specially designed tennis balls, Sensor Courts uses normal balls.
"Just pop open a can and flip the switch," said Kussack. "Not one of the umpires has objected to it. They come down from the chair after a match and ask us how they did."
Kussack was allowed to chat his product up to the media, but players were forbidden by ATP Tour officials in Philadelphia to observe the system. The courtside monitoring of the line-calling device was carried out with such discretion that, said semifinalist Brad Gilbert, "I thought the person with the headphones in the front row was listening to tunes or something."
Gilbert was in favor of a switch to computerized courts, so long as it can be done consistently and economically. But Pete Sampras, apparently a classicist in tennis philosophy as well as form, said replacing linesmen represents too great a sacrifice.
"I don't want to hurt anyone's feelings," said Sampras, who did little more than raise his eyebrows over suspect calls in the course of winning the Philadelphia event, "but I think you'd be giving up a human part of the game for accuracy that isn't really so much better than what we've already got. I don't mind that every call isn't perfect. And I don't know what it would be like to watch John McEnroe on a court with no linespeople. You can't argue with a machine."
Too, you can't yet install any computerized system of this ilk on anything other than hard courts and Supreme. Clay and grass aren't conducive to being pinned down by computer technology. That means players might be asked to play the futuristic way one week, treading a network of computer signals, and the old-fashioned way the next, with linesmen hollering "fault" and "out." Gilbert said that makes for perhaps too great an adjustment.
Dana Loconto, an ATP Tour umpire, is no stranger to computer innovations. His hand-held computer scorecard, a creation that allows umpires to get rid of their pencils and erasers, will be de riguer on the tour after its formal introduction next month in Key Biscayne, Fla. Loconto liked Sensor Courts, but he envisioned an obvious drawback: with no linesmen to berate, players will vent their spleen on the umpire.
"It's accurate, but it ain't human," said Loconto, "and we've got to assess what it will do to the game as we've known it. And how expensive is it, and how will it affect the linespeople if they only work the grass and clay circuit -- will they be less sharp because they have less work?"
Kussack admitted that, "Maybe I'm optimistic," but added, "I would say the reality of eliminating linespeople is just two to three years away."
The next test of Sensor Courts, and its peers, will be whether the game of tennis is so broken that it takes a computer to fix it. Ninety-three percent accuracy is no glitch.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
$1 Million Men a Dime a Dozen

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Continuing to forge stunning new economic ground, major league baseball clubs will pay more than 40 percent of their players $1 million or more this year. Barring trades, the Yankees will have the greatest number of those players on any one team, 16.
With the salary-arbitration season completed and only lower-paid players left to be signed, 273 players are set to earn $1 million or more in 1992, a 21 percent increase over the 226 who were in that position at the close of salary arbitration a year ago. 
 Based on a total of 650 players on the 26 opening-day rosters (although a few of the millionaires will open on the disabled list), 42 percent will earn $1 million or more.
 
A $4 Million First
 This will be the first season that any player earns $4 million or more, and 22 are scheduled to soar to that plateau, including Danny Tartabull of the Yankees and Ruben Sierra of Texas at $5 million or more and Bobby Bonilla of the Mets beyond $6 million. The figures include salary and the pro-rated share of a signing bonus and any other guaranteed payment.
Except for third base, the Yankees could field a starting lineup of million-dollar players, complete with a five-man starting pitching rotation and a three-man relief corps. A year ago, the Yankees had 11 players at or over the $1 million level.
Gene Michael, the Yankees' general manager, chose not to dwell on the number of million-dollar players.
"That's coincidental," said the former shortstop, whose highest salary as a player was $62,000. "We're not No. 1 on the payroll. That's the way I look at it. We're in the upper third, but we're not No. 1."
By comparison, the Mets, with the year's highest-paid player, Bonilla at $6.1 million, have 11 million-dollar players but are in position to have the highest payroll at more than $44 million. They have a major-league-high seven players who will earn more than $3 million; the Yankees have only two such players.
Boston, Toronto and Los Angeles all have 15 players at $1 million or more; Oakland and Cincinnati have 14 apiece. In all, nine National League teams and eight American League teams are in double digits in the category.
 
Cleveland's Frugality
 Cleveland, whose winter activity seemed geared to emerging with the lowest major league payroll, is the only team with no millionaires. The Indians' highest-paid player is Felix Fermin at $950,000. The teams closest to the Indians in this regard are the Houston Astros and the Montreal Expos, each with four.
For the second consecutive year, the number of players with salaries between $1 million and $2 million decreased, dropping from 125 in 1990 to 102 last year to 95 this year. The higher levels, however, continued to escalate, reflecting the rapid rise that has club owners reeling.
The biggest leap in players who earn between $1 million and $2 million came in 1990, the total rising from 86 to 125. Last year, the most dramatic escalation occurred in the $2 million to $3 million group (27 to 93) and the $3 million to $4 million group (1 to 31).
This year, the $2 million to $3 million group rose modestly to 109, and the $3 million to $4 million group to 47, but the most significant change came from $4 million up, where 22 players suddenly soared. Thirteen of those 22 players are hitters, 9 pitchers. Last year, Darryl Strawberry of Los Angeles was the highest paid at $3.8 million. This year, 23 players have higher salaries.
The Mets have four players at $4 million or more (Bonilla, Dwight Gooden, David Cone, Eddie Murray), followed by the Pittsburgh Pirates with three (Barry Bonds, Doug Drabek, Andy Van Slyke). Two teams have two apiece: the Boston Red Sox (Frank Viola, Roger Clemens) and the Texas Rangers (Sierra, Nolan Ryan).
