HEADLINE: End of Plant Predictable, But Closing Still Hurts

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 26

 BODY:
Two days after General Motors shocked Westchester County with news that it would close its huge plant here in 1995, the fallout seems certain to be painful, but limited, across a suburban landscape where welding metal, stamping plastic and other manufacturing has long been a relic of the industrial past.
In this Hudson River village, 18 miles north of Manhattan, as elsewhere in New York State, a chorus of angry charges is being directed at General Motors, which received rich subsidies in the mid-1980's to keep the plant open. 
 It is now leaving a legacy of lost jobs, business failures and reduced tax revenues.
"They leave us holding the bag, and it's empty," Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, said at a news conference today.
 
More Campus, Less Flint
 But while the decision has come as a harsh blow during the worst recession in decades, experts say it also comes at the end of a long period of economic change that has made the towns around the plant far more reliant on lush corporate campuses and high-technology research.
"This is not Flint," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. In contrast to Flint, Mich., and most other areas where the American automobile industry operates, Westchester has for decades been without parts fabricators, machine shops and other small companies that serve as direct suppliers to the assembly line.
"The Westchester economy is in a better position to survive this blow than a lot of places would be," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Even some of the strongest advocates of business here say that shutting down the North Tarrytown plant has been inevitable for years and that the only question was when. The plant, which has been producing cars since 1900, ranks as General Motors' oldest and Westchester County's largest remaining manufacturer.
"It is a stand-alone operation, and the last great manufacturer in Westchester," said Sy Schulman, president of the Westchester County Association, a business group. "It represents the tail end of the American revolution."
 
Effects Beyond Plant Gate
 Almost 3,500 people now work at the plant, which produces mini-vans and which General Motors said it will close permanently in the summer of 1995. As in other communities where large factories have closed, the financial hardship is certain to flow beyond the plant gate.
"It's going to change everything," said Herbert Kammerman, owner of Lemac Drugs, a small pharmacy and children's clothing store here.
"There are a lot of mom-and-pop retail outlets that rely on the business of G.M. workers," he added. "This is going to drive some out."
Fully 20 percent of the budget of North Tarrytown is paid for by taxes from General Motors, and officials of the school district here said that more than 8 percent of what is spent on public education is paid by the automaker.
And the announcement by General Motors comes at a time when other industries in Westchester, as throughout the New York region, are struggling.
 
Long Manufacturing Decline
 Mr. Ehrenhalt said overall employment in the county had risen by 23 percent during the 1980's to 415,000, and plummeted 7 percent since 1990, falling by 29,000 jobs. Among manufacturers, he said the recession has only accelerated a long and steep decline in employment, which has fallen by more than 25 percent since 1980, to 53,000.
But while the experts hold out little hope for a renaissance of manufacturing, they say the main engines of future growth in Westchester, as in Fairfield County, Conn., Morris County, N.J., and other suburban enclaves around New York City, will be in the offices of corporate headquarters and research parks that moved in droves from Manhattan to the suburbs during the same two decades that manufacturing was in steep decline.
Within a 30-mile radius of North Tarrytown is the nation's second-highest concentration of headquarters for companies on the Fortune 500 list, after Manhattan.
 
Few Job Alternatives
 Companies that have headquarters in Westchester, but manufacture little or nothing here, include the I.B.M. Corporation, based in Armonk; Pepsico Inc., in Purchase, and General Foods U.S.A., in White Plains.
In the midst of such corporate giants, experts say alternatives for the thousands who will lose their jobs at the North Tarrytown plant will be limited. Unless other manufacturers can be attracted to Westchester, "This county will simply not be able to absorb these workers," said Renee Guy, the county's director of employment and training.
Only a small minority of the workers are likely to be offered jobs at other General Motors plants, the company said.
Officials say they were surprised and angered by General Motors' announcement because of the inducements the company had accepted to remain in North Tarrytown.
In 1985, faced with the prospect that the plant might close, New York State, Westchester County and the Village of North Tarrytown approved a 10-year package in which General Motors received reduced property taxes, state-financed job training and subsidized electric power. The Metro-North Railroad rebuilt bridges to allow easier transportation of automobiles from the plant.
At his news conference today, Mr. O'Rourke said the subsidies had cost the village, county and state $140 million. He proposed that any company receiving similar inducements in the future be required to pay them back if they leave Westchester County in anything less than 10 years. If they leave in less than 20 years, he suggested that they be required to reimburse taxpayers on a sliding scale.
One question only beginning to be addressed by General Motors and government is the fate of the plant and its 97 acres of riverfront property. William Regan, North Tarrytown's Administrator, said one option would be to subdivide the site for smaller companies, including those with more direct ties to the corporate and research offices nearby.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Voters;
Warnings for Winners In South Dakota Results

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 26

 BODY:
There was bad news all around after Tuesday's South Dakota Presidential primary, even for the winners.
While Democrats here handed Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska his first victory, with 40 percent of the vote, the main reason people said they voted for him was because he "knows my state." 
 President Bush, who received 69 percent of the Republican vote, could hardly be reassured, considering that 31 percent voted for an uncommitted slate. And many disgruntled with the President vowed to desert their party and vote for a Democrat in the fall.
A nagging minority of Democrats also voiced doubts about the character and honesty of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, and about the health of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, issues that could haunt them as the race turns south.
 
Warnings From the People
 These warning signals came from a survey of voters leaving polling stations in South Dakota on Tuesday. While turnout was light in this sparsely-populated state of just under 700,000 -- only 58,608 Democrats and 44,664 Republicans actually went to the polls -- the findings underscore the political land mines faced by the Democratic field and an incumbent President.
Mr. Kerrey scored a victory over Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who finished second and with whom he was vying for pre-eminence as the farm belt favorite. One-third of the Kerrey backers cited his regional ties, while 25 percent pointed to his ideas, and another 25 percent said that he "cares about people like me."
While he was the clear favorite of the state's dwindling farm population, Mr. Harkin came in second over all, a showing that could cripple his money-hungry campaign. Only 21 percent of Mr. Harkin's supporters mentioned the regional factor, while the largest proportion, one-third, credited him with caring about their issues.
And though Mr. Harkin is considered closest to labor, Mr. Kerrey did equally well among those with a union member in their household. Both men each got about a third of the union vote. Although both candidates are veterans, Mr. Kerrey had made much of his Vietnam War experience, and he won half of the veterans' vote.
 
Mixed Outcome for Clinton
 Mr. Clinton's third-place showing was repsectable for an outsider who had little presence here until the final days of the campaign. But he might have done better, perhaps overtaking Mr. Harkin, had voters not had misgivings about accusations of marital infidelities and disclosures that he tried to avoid the draft.
Asked if they were satisfied that Mr. Clinton had the "honesty and integrity to serve effectively as President," 32 percent said no and 61 percent said yes. Of the Democrats who voted for Mr. Tsongas, 49 percent said they had qualms about Mr. Clinton's integrity; 38 percent of the Kerrey and Harkin voters also were concerned.
Mr. Tsongas, the winner of the New Hampshire primary, received 10 percent of the vote here, a sign that his strength in New England may not resonate in other regions. Although Mr. Tsongas said he has been cured of cancer, some voters are worried.
Twenty-six percent of the Democratic voters said they were concerned that his health "will interfere with his ability to serve effectively as President." Nearly one-third of the Kerrey and Clinton supporters said they were concerned about Mr. Tsongas's health, as were 24 percent of the Harkin backers.
 
Health Care the Issue
 Karen Schreier, chairman of the South Dakota Democratic Party, said Mr. Kerrey won for more reasons than his local ties. "Kerrey campaigned here more than Harkin, and organization was a big part of it," she said.
As for health care, the polling by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created by the four major television networks in 1990, found that more than any other issue, health care mattered most to Mr. Kerrey's supporters. Perhaps that was because the largest pool of Democratic voters, 43 percent, were over the age of 60.
Mr. Kerrey has made national health insurance the centerpiece of his campaign, and 35 percent of his supporters said the issue was critical to them, closely followed by 33 percent who cited the economy and jobs. Among Mr. Harkin's backers, the biggest concern, among 39 percent, was farm policy, while 47 percent of Mr. Clinton's and Mr. Tsongas's backers said the economy and jobs.
The vote against Mr. Bush was also largely a protest over the sour state of the economy. Fifty-four percent of those who rated the national economy as poor backed the uncommitted slate.
 
'Still a Danger Sign'
 While Mr. Bush retained the overwhelming loyalty of voters identifying themselves as Republicans, the uncommitted slate got its biggest vote, 60 percent, among independents.
Bob Burns, head of the political science department at South Dakota State University at Brookings, said the protest vote against Mr. Bush should not be underestimated: "When an incumbent President cannot hold 70 percent or more in a primary against an uncommitted slate, it says there's real discontent in the ranks."
Although they were answering the poll in the heat of casting a primary ballot, more than 4 of 10 of those who voted uncommitted said they would vote for Mr. Tsongas or Mr. Clinton if either was the Democratic nominee against Mr. Bush.
The findings also showed that men were less supportive of Mr. Bush than women -- a pattern that was apparent in the New Hampshire primary. By 14 percentage points women were more supportive than men of Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bush's conservative opponent, Patrick J. Buchanan, did not file in time to get his name on the ballot here. Today, Mr. Buchanan, a conservative columnist, said the President's performance showed he was "politically as weak as a kitten."
But Don Peterson, chairman of the South Dakota Republican Party, said many Bush supporters stayed home.

(Based on a poll conducted by Voter Research & Surveys of 628 Republican primary voters leaving 38 polling places throughout South Dakota on Tuesday.)
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
The Election Day exit poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout South Dakota on Tuesday.
The poll was conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN and NBC News.
The results are based on 1,248 voters in the Democratic primary and 628 voters in the Republican primary in 38 randomly selected precincts around the state.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results from such polls should differ by no more than a few percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all primary election voters in South Dakota on Tuesday. For Democrats, the difference should be no more than four percentage points in either direction; for Republicans, it should be no more than five percentage points.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day may introduce other sources of error into the poll. For example, refusal rates by voters leaving voting stations can be higher than those for other types of polls.

HEADLINE: Abrams Takes On Senator Pothole;
Attorney General Charges D'Amato Doesn't Serve Constituents

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
No one goes on at greater length about bucking politics as usual than State Attorney General Robert Abrams. So it can be jarring to watch him run for the Democratic nomination for the Senate, attacking Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican Senator known for old-style pork-barrel politics. Mr. Abrams is proposing to out-D'Amato Mr. D'Amato.
Senator D'Amato "has cut and hurt and punished New York," Mr. Abrams told reporters he summoned in late January to the modest Nassau County home of Ken and Betty Koch -- "middle-class people," he said -- to shift his year-old campaign into high gear. Partly because of Mr. D'Amato, he said, New York receives fewer dollars back than it sends to Washington in taxes. "And Al D'Amato has the gall to say that he has delivered for New York," Mr. Abrams said. 
 Mr. Abrams is engaged in a close race for the nomination. He is opposed by four other Democrats: Geraldine A. Ferraro, Elizabeth Holtzman, Robert J. Mrazek and the Rev. Al Sharpton.
As he has contended in campaigns since he was 27 years old, Mr. Abrams said he would deliver. "It's time that New York had a senator who is more interested in putting money in your pocket than money in the pockets of his cousins and his cronies," he said. Six months ago the Senate Select Committee on Ethics rebuked Mr. D'Amato for his conduct, but declined to censure him. Mr. D'Amato has been called Senator Pothole for his service to constituents.
In interviews and before groups, Mr. Abrams repeatedly promised to bring in more Federal money and criticized Mr. D'Amato for not doing so. Mr. D'Amato, he said, "has tried to create the image that he has brought home the bacon for New York, but that's a sham, it's a lie, it's a fraud."
Then Mr. Abrams would turn around and tout himself as an idealistic, independent force. "My agenda has always been one of change, of progressive social values and political reform," he said. That Mr. Abrams is running as both a crusading independent and a committed pork-barreler, as both "the only candidate who has not served in Congress" and the candidate best qualified to win dollars playing "the big game in town," is one of several apparent contradictions in his campaign. Despite his changed circumstances, Mr. Abrams, at 54, appears to be running an updated version of every race he has run since he was a young man.
Mr. Abrams is a career politician running as an outsider.
He is an innovative official pushing proposals that seem warmed over from other campaigns.
To his opponents, these contradictions reek of opportunism. "Bob Abrams will say just about anything," Mr. D'Amato said through a spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, who said that Mr. D'Amato would comment directly on Mr. Abrams only if he won the nomination.
 
A Dissonant Message?
 Advisers to Mr. Abrams's opponents say that his dissonant message has made him vulnerable. "There's not a big impression in people's minds of who Bob Abrams is," said Frank Wilkinson, a spokesman for Ms. Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice Presidential candidate. Polls conducted by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in spring 1991 showed Mr. Abrams comfortably in front, but a survey by the institute a month ago put him and Ms. Ferraro in a virtual tie. He had the support of 27.4 percent of respondents, compared with 27.1 percent for her.
Ms. Holtzman, the New York City Comptroller, received 20.2 percent in the poll; Mr. Mrazek, a United States Representative from Long Island, got 3.1 percent, and Mr. Sharpton got 2.3 percent. Twenty percent of respondents were undecided.
To Mr. Abrams, the contradictions are more evidence of his independence. While they may seem stark, they begin to blur on closer examination. Mr. Abrams does seem to be something of all things to all Democrats: an inside player who has retained certain ideals and an advocate of abstract principles who believes in doing the gritty work of making government meet individual needs.
The son of a Bronx candy store owner, Mr. Abrams said that he "came up the hard way," working four jobs a day during college at Columbia. After graduating from New York University Law School, he won election as a state assemblyman in 1965, then as Bronx borough president in 1970. Both victories were upsets against an entrenched Democratic organization.
But what Mr. Abrams's Reform Democrat slate offered was not no machine, but a clean machine; not no pork, but more pork. "It's going to be up to me to persuade the Board of Estimate to make its proper and appropriate investment in Bronx County," he said during his run for borough president.
Mr. Abrams won the Attorney General's office in 1978. Since then, he has taken three elections easily, though at first blush he lacks the basic tools for survival in the blow-dried age. The balding Mr. Abrams, who wears glasses, is no backslapper.
Even in private Mr. Abrams rarely relaxes his theatrical voice and his formal, elaborate sentences. Asked over lunch about his wife, Diane, he pronounced her "a fabulous asset to me in rearing our family, and being a partner in my life and a partner in my career."
Despite his starched persona, Mr. Abrams invariably comes across as a nice guy. "Bob is the only high-ranking politician in the state who is well liked," said Mark Green, New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner and Mr. D'Amato's last opponent. "He's an utterly decent family man in a totally rapacious business."
Mr. Abrams attributes his political success to his ability to deliver. Wherever he travels in New York, Mr. Abrams said, people "tell me, 'Hey, Mr. Abrams, I got a check from you today!' " He has fought dozens of suits on behalf of New Yorkers, forcing insurers, brewers and others to mail them checks totaling more than $800 million, said his spokesman, Timothy Gilles.
 
Expanding Office's Mission
 Those checks represent dividends from Mr. Abrams's efforts to expand his office's capacity and mission. As the Department of Justice retreated under Ronald Reagan from antitrust and environmental prosecutions, aggressive state attorneys general, including Mr. Abrams and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, stepped into the breach. Mr. Abrams intensified his office's efforts against tax cheats and consumer frauds and tackled new areas, prosecuting polluters, such as the company that poisoned Love Canal.
"He really over the years has set a standard for state attorneys general around the country," said Mr. Lieberman, now a Democratic senator.
But Mr. Abrams's high-profile prosecutions have also spawned the most persistent criticism of him: that he picks his battles for their publicity value.
Mr. Abrams's supporters point out that even if the criticism were true, a desire for good press would hardly distinguish Mr. Abrams from other politicians. Two lobbyists for liberal causes, who insisted on anonymity, cited recent instances when Mr. Abrams agreed not to sponsor legislation he favored. They said that Republican legislators would fight any measure that might help Mr. Abrams beat Mr. D'Amato, and getting the bills passed meant more to Mr. Abrams than receiving credit.
 
'Hindsight' on Gulf War
 But critics say Mr. Abrams is not always so inner-directed, and a tendency to skirt tough confrontations has popped up during his campaign. When he declared his candidacy, Mr. Abrams was asked whether he would have voted to authorize war against Iraq. He dodged, saying he did not have as much information as sitting senators. The war won, Mr. Abrams said that with "hindsight" he supported the decision to fight it.
Like his opponents, Mr. Abrams has put forward few specifics for his campaign's central proposals, which include a universal health care system and a tax cut for the middle class. Mr. Abrams's freshest plank appears to be his claim that Mr. D'Amato has not served constituents well. The reason, he said, is that Mr. D'Amato voted for policies of President Bush and Ronald Reagan that resulted in less money for New Yorkers.
But economists are not convinced by the evidence he cites. "For 1990," Mr. Abrams said, offering his chief piece of data, "there was a $21 billion shortfall of what we as New Yorkers sent to the Federal Government and of what came back."
That number was plucked from a study by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. As the study noted, the chief reason for the Federal Government's deficit with New York is that New Yorkers are wealthier than most Americans and so pay more taxes.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Plan to Ease Rule on Buying Radio Stations

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
In a move likely to raise hackles in Congress, a staff report by the Federal Communications Commission recommended that a single company be allowed to acquire as many radio stations in a city as it wanted until it had 25 percent of the audience.
In a highly fragmented market like New York City, for example, a company could own four of the largest stations, or many more smaller stations, without exceeding the 25 percent limit. 
 In small markets with fewer than eight radio stations, the proposal specifies that a company could acquire as many as half of the licenses.
Under current law, one owner is limited to an AM station and an FM station in a single market.
Under the proposal, if the company subsequently increased its audience share to more than 25 percent, it would not have to sell any stations.
The commission's staff report, prepared by Roy J. Stewart, chief of the commission's mass media bureau, also calls for raising the limit on the number of radio stations one owner can have to as many as 200 stations from the current 12 AM and 12 FM.
The commission's chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, supports the proposals, but it is uncertain whether he can persuade his fellow commissioners to go along. The proposals, particularly the one on multiple ownership in a single market, are certain to provoke anger on Capitol Hill and may well be amended by the commission itself.
In effect, the staff report sides with the bigger-is-better camp in the troubled radio industry, which argues that companies holding many stations have the best chance of remaining profitable and serving the public. The other camp believes that such an approach seriously jeopardizes diversity of ownership, forcing out smaller broadcasters, including family companies and those owned by members of minorities, that cannot compete with the broadcasting giants.
"Diversity isn't necessarily served by how many separately owned voices there are," Mr. Sikes said today. "Frequently, diversity is served by people who have the assets. To have rules that cause radio stations to go bankrupt isn't in the public interest."
Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which oversees the F.C.C.'s budget, said, "There is the outside chance that these things could do some good, but there is an enormous opportunity here to create mischief and a major threat to diversity,"
 
Hearings Set in Senate
 The proposals are expected to come up for a commission vote on March 12, but are likely to be discussed before then. The Senate Commerce subcommittee with jurisdiction over the F.C.C. has scheduled a hearing for next week on the state of the radio industry.
Owners are currently limited to 12 television stations as well, and that ceiling would be retained under the proposal. Nor do the proposals seek any change in rules that bar newspapers from owning broadcast stations in the city where they publish or broadcasters from owning local newspapers. (That rule, adopted in 1975, left intact more than 100 existing ownership arrangements.)
The proposal is likely to be of greatest benefit to large broadcasters that are bumping into the current limits. Among these are CBS Inc., Group W-Westinghouse Broadcasting, Capital Cities/ABC and the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation. Each owns AM and FM stations in 10 top markets, including New York City, and is eager for the chance to pick up an additional station in some of those cities.
"We would love to have another station in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago," said Mel Karmazin, president and chief executive of Infinity. "A change in the ownership rules would be very favorable to us. It would certainly give us many opportunities."
Market share is generally measured in ratings compiled by the Arbitron Company in New York. The staff proposal did not specify how audience share would be measured.
To shore up support for the proposal, the F.C.C. released a report today that argues that the commercial radio industry is in deep financial trouble and would greatly benefit from greater concentration of ownership.
The radio industry has been battered in recent years as cable television and other new forms of mass media have competed for advertising. Adding to the industry's woes, the Government awarded hundreds of new AM and FM licenses during the 1980's and increased competition within the industry.
The report says that most radio stations are losing money and that hundreds of broadcasters unable either to turn a profit or sell their stations have simply shut down. The report said 287 stations around the country had closed, 153 in the last 12 months.
If financial data are adjusted for inflation, the report said, profits of the average AM station have plunged by 50 percent since 1988 and by 36 percent for the average FM station.
"The magnitude of potential economies from consolidation appear to be significant," the staff study said. "Consolidated radio operations will permit increased expenditures on informational programming, may allow some previously marginal stations to remain on the air and may provide for activation of unused channels."
But minority broadcasters and some media experts fear that the rules will end diversity and leave many cities with only a few radio voices.
"This doesn't help competition in any way, shape or form," said Andrew Jay Schwartsman, executive director of the Media Access Project, a public interest group.
"Lifting ownership restrictions in the 1980's was a disaster and brought in people who wanted to make money as speculators and not as broadcasters," he said. "The solution that Sikes is proposing to deregulation is more deregulation."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Northwest;
Caucuses in Idaho and Washington Offer New Challenges for the Democratic Field

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Feb. 26

 BODY:
With a chance to show that their campaigns are more than contests of regional loyalties, Democratic Presidential candidates are planning to arrive in the Pacific Northwest this weekend in advance of next Tuesday's caucuses in Washington and Idaho.
Washington, the second-most-populous state in the West, has 80 Democratic delegates up for grabs, and it presents a bit of a puzzle to candidates who have tailored their message toward economically depressed areas. It was one of only two states in the West -- Oregon was the other -- to vote Democratic in the last Presidential race. 
 Idaho, enjoying its best economic climate in decades, has 25 delegates and has long been a sort of black hole for Democrats. But while voters have overwhelmingly voted for Republican Presidential candidates, Democrats have made big gains in the last three years, and polls show that President Bush is extremely unpopular in Idaho.
The caucuses are binding for Democrats only; Republicans in the two states will choose their delegates in primaries in May.
As the first test of the Presidential campaign in the Far West, Tuesday's caucuses are likely to focus on such issues of regional interest as free trade and environmental quality, political leaders say.
"There are some very difficult issues that are near and dear to every Westerner, but none of the candidates are talking about them," said Gov. Cecil Andrus of Idaho, a popular Democrat who is in his fourth term. Governor Andrus said the chief issues were water rights, environmental concerns, range-land management and dumping of nuclear waste.
Idaho is particularly sensitive to being ignored by national politicians. "We are sick and tired of candidates who rise out of the East Coast of the United States and don't see anything in the West except Seattle, San Francisco and Los Angeles," Mr. Andrus said. The Governor said he is withholding an endorsement until he has a chance to sit down with each of the candidates.
Mr. Andrus has been a leader in an effort to restore dwindling salmon runs in his state. The sockeye salmon in Idaho and the spotted owl in Washington have become symbols of a larger struggle in the Northwest over quality of life versus economic stability. The Endangered Species Act, which mandates restrictions of industries that are causing fish and wildlife to decline in numbers, has driven a wedge between rural and urban communities here. The act is up for renewal this year.
 
Focus on Health Care
 Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington, a two-term Democrat, is trying to make the Presidential contest a litmus test on health care. He would seem to be a likely supporter of Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who has campaigned strongly on a plan to provide national health insurance for every American. But the Governor is a long and close friend of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. Governor Gardner has not formally endorsed a candidate.
Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, has visited Seattle many times in recent months but has limited his appearances to small gatherings of supporters. The other two Democrats are Edmund G. Brown Jr., former Governor of California, and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, neither of whom has a strong organization in Washington. Karen Marchioro, chairwoman of the Washington State Democratic Party, said her own small polls show that a tremendous number of Democrats remain undecided.
Health care is a concern among thousands of machinists at Boeing Company plants in the Seattle area. Although the workers have health insurance, Boeing has raised the possibility that the machinists will have to pay more of the burden every time they visit a doctor.
"This sort of talk has made a lot of our members very nervous," said Connie Young, a spokeswoman for the International Association of Machinists, which represents 37,000 Boeing workers.
Although Boeing recently announced a plan to lay off 6,500 workers in the next year, most of the jobs will be lost through attrition, company officials say. The recession has not hit Washington nearly as hard as it has hit most states.
 
Don't Bash Japan
 But trade, which drives the Northwest economy, is a big issue here. Washington, which has trade surplus with Japan, has generally not been receptive to calls for protectionism. The fear is that fewer Northwest products would be sold overseas if the United States were to curtail foreign imports. Japan-bashing will haunt some candidates, say this state's political leaders.
"Because of television, we know who's been saying what," Ms. Marchioro said, "so I don't think a candidate can say one thing in New Hampshire about trade and another thing here."
Ms. Marchioro, a veteran leader of Western Democrats, has been feuding with Mr. Brown since he campaigned on behalf of a proposal to limit officials' terms. The measure failed here in November.
After listening to Mr. Brown talk last December, Ms. Marchioro said, "He's nuts." When Mr. Brown confronted her a month later at a meeting in Chicago, complaining that she had called him "crazy," Ms. Marchioro said: "I did not say you were crazy, I said you were nuts."
With no published polls, it is hard to predict the outcome of Tuesday's caucuses. Governor Clinton is well organized, with a full staff and phone volunteers. In the past, the best-organized candidates have fared well on caucus night, when Democrats gather in homes and halls to debate the issues and vote for delegates pledged to certain candidates.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Slide; Taxable Funds Are Steady

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt funds continued to drop in the week ended Monday, while short-term taxable funds held virtually steady in the week ended Tuesday for the first time in many weeks, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
"The yields on the short-term taxables appear to have bottomed finally," said Walter Frank, economist for Donoghue's. "They have felt the full impact of the decline that was triggered by the Federal Reserve's lowering of the discount rate in late December. It takes time for the initial decline in open market yields, such as Treasury bills and commercial paper, to work its way through money fund yields." 
 The seven-day compounded average yield for the tax-exempt funds was 2.66 percent, down from 2.73 the previous week; the seven-day simple yield dropped to 2.62, from 2.69.
In the same period, the 30-day compounded yield was 2.78 percent, off 2 basis points from last week, and the 30-day simple yield also dropped 2 basis points, to 2.74. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The top Connecticut fund again was Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, which reported a seven-day compounded yield of 3.13, down from 3.24 percent.
In New Jersey, the top fund once again was Fidelity Spartan N.J. Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with a yield that dropped to 3.24, from 3.32 percent.
In New York, the top fund again was Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market fund. It had a seven-day compounded yield of 3.49, compared with 3.64, percent the previous week.
Assets of the tax-exempt funds rose by $767 million, to a record of almost $99.6 billion.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios moved down by two days, to 49.
Of the funds monitored by Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund of Milwaukee, led the way once again with a seven-day compounded yield of 3.59, off 7 basis points from the previous week.
 
Taxable Funds
 The assets of the taxable funds, which had declined two weeks ago by $13.1 billion, to $496.6 billion, increased by $11.0 billion, to a total of $507.6 billion, last week. About $8.3 billion of the increase came from institutions, and Mr. Frank noted that the public accounted for a substantial part of the increase -- $2.7 billion.
Mr. Frank said the average days to maturity of holdings in the taxable funds declined to 57 days, from 58.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield was 3.85, down a basis point, while the seven-day simple yield was unchanged at 3.78 percent.
The 30-day compounded yield declined to 3.91 percent, down 7 basis points, and the 30-day simple yield dropped 6 basis points, to 3.84.
The taxable fund with the highest seven-day compounded yield for the week was Fidelity Spartan Money Market fund, with a yield of 4.57 percent, off a basis point.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.72 percent, off 3 basis points, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Panel Proposes Tough Rules to Maintain Delaware River's Quality

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 26

 BODY:
Four states and the Federal Government proposed unusually tough rules today to preserve the high quality of the upper Delaware River.
The plan would prohibit new pollutants that would be legally permissible elsewhere but would damage the nearly pristine water of the northernmost 121 miles of the river, between Hancock, N.Y., on the southwestern edge of the Catskills and Delaware Water Gap, near Stroudsburg, Pa. 
 Officials said they believed that the proposal was the first of its kind in the country.
 
Over 13,000 Square Miles
 Under the Federal Clean Water Act, if social and economic needs are shown, high-quality rivers and lakes are allowed to deteriorate to levels that would protect fishing and swimming. The quality of the upper Delaware is rated 30 to 170 percent higher than the fishing-and-swimming standard.
The Delaware River Basin Commission issued the plan at its headquarters here after nearly five years of study, hearings and negotiations among its members. Congress created the commission, made up of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware and the Federal Interior Department, in 1961 to regulate water quality and use, as well as flood control, in a 13,000-square-mile region along the river and Delaware Bay.
"There may be some states on specific rivers that have adopted water-quality standards this rigid," the executive director of the commission, Gerald M. Hansler, said. "But to my knowledge, this goes further than any other stream with the Delaware's mix of agriculture, new development, cities and park land."
The upper Delaware flows through two Federal parks maintained by the National Park Service, the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area and the Upper Delaware National Scenic and Recreation River. The clear waters attract hundreds of thousands of canoeists, anglers, swimmers and rafters annually.
The commission says river-based recreation pumps as much as $60 million into scores of riverfront and other communities in Sullivan and Orange Counties in New York and Monroe, Pike and Wayne Counties in Pennsylvania.
 
To Strike a Balance
 Development has been increasing in the region and is expected to continue into the next century. Because of such pressures, the commission is moving to protect the quality of the river, the primary magnet for tourists, hunters, hikers and new settlers.
Officials of the commission said the plan would balance development and conservation, adding that growth could continue in the rural counties and the the quality of the river could be maintained. The plan is intended to insure that there would be "no measurable change" in several categories of contaminants and biological benchmarks of the river's health.
The major elements in the plan include tougher standards on effluent from new or expanded sewage plants, measuring an increased number of water criteria in the upper Delaware and its 70 tributaries where they flow into Federal parks and controls on nonpoint pollution, primarily storm-water runoff from roads, parking lots, building sites and farms. Nonpoint sources account for 65 percent of the pollution in a river, the commission estimated.
If the proposal is adopted, developers along the upper Delaware would be required to submit to their plans to the commission.
 
Bacteria and Nutrient Limits
 Under the sewage rules allowable measures of fecal coliform bacteria would be cut, from 200 to 50 colonies per 100 milliliters of water. Limits would be imposed for the first time on nitrogen, phosphorus and ammonia-nitrogen, nutrients that spur plant growth and algae, in effluent discharged into the river or its tributaries. The commission could also review proposed waste-water discharges exceeding 10,000 gallons a day. Now just discharges of more than 50,000 gallons a day are examined.
The commission would also begin to measure, in the river and near the mouths of the tributaries, phosphorus, ammonia and nitrogen, as well as the microorganisms and insect larvae that trout, shad and other fish eat.
For a critical indicator of the health of the river, dissolved oxygen, which fish need to breathe, the plan sets a standard of 9 milligrams a liter of water. The Federal Clean Water Act requires at least 4 milligrams a liter. The limit for fecal coliform is 24 colonies per 100 milliliters of water, as opposed to 200 colonies under the Clean Water Act.
Under the plan's requirement that there be "no measurable change" in the water criteria, the acceptable levels of dissolved oxygen could range from 8.9 to 9.2 milligrams. The permissible amount of fecal coliform colonies could range from 21 to 28.
Environmentalists seemed a bit uneasy about the "no measurable change" rule. "We still aren't quite sure how big measurable is," said Mary Ellen Noble, director of the Watershed Association of the Delaware River, an environmental group that urged the drafting of the plan. "We need to be clearer on that."
Hearings on the plan are scheduled for May 5 in Matamoras, Pa., and May 6 in Narrowsburg, N.Y.

HEADLINE: BRIDGEPORT JOURNAL;
For the Few Who Visit, One Less Place to Stay

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
BAD news is no news in this beleaguered Connecticut city, which has teetered on the verge of bankruptcy, watched its university struggle to survive and seen two of its banks go under. So it was just another blow to Bridgeport's image and economy when its Days Hotel abruptly closed last week.
The eight-story hotel's sunny yellow-orange logo has been removed, the curtains are drawn in its 240 rooms and its restaurant, Otto's Lounge, is boarded shut. As security guards prowl the property, near Interstate 95, prospective guests are further deterred by a mysterious yellow ribbon saying "crime scene," blocking the parking lot entrance. 
 The closing, which left Connecticut's largest city with only one hotel, also makes it more difficult for Bridgeport's No. 1 booster to get the message out that her hometown is really a great place to visit.
"This is a mid-sized city with more attractions than any other in the country," said Lucie A. Farrel, executive director of the Bridgeport Convention and Visitors Commission. "The city has ongoing problems, and the hotel's closing certainly doesn't help, but people aren't aware of the urban treasures we are blessed with."
Saying that much of Bridgeport's image problem is a result of the relative prosperity of neighboring towns in Fairfield County, she added: "We're the brown-eyed child in a blue-eyed family."
"I've seen a lot of frustrations," Ms. Farrel acknowledged. "But I've never brought visitors here who haven't been impressed with what they found."
Among the 24 Bridgeport attractions that she enumerates are the P. T. Barnum Museum; a jai alai fronton; the Polka Dot Playhouse, a summer theater; the H.M.S. Rose ("the largest operational wooden sailing ship in the world"), and "the only zoo between New York and Boston."
Because state funds for promoting tourism are allocated to towns on the basis of hotel-tax revenue, the Days Hotel's closing means that support for Ms. Farrel's office is likely to drop precipitously from the current $125,000 a year. As Ms. Farrel points out, neighboring areas with "few or no real attractions get enormous amounts of money because they have hotels."
"Stamford, with two major visitor attractions, receives $1.5 million annually," she noted in a recent essay-cum-news release titled "A Remarkable Tale from Barnum Country, U.S.A." Hartford, she added, receives $1.3 million. Adding to her woes are proposals to cut state aid for tourism and to streamline Connecticut's tourism-promotion network from 19 to 7 offices. Under the plans, the Bridgeport, Norwalk and Stamford tourism districts would be consolidated into one called the "Fairfield Coast."
Ms. Farrel said she did not know whether her four-person office or one of the others would be eliminated. But the silver lining in the proposals, she said, would be that "with regional marketing, we would get access to more funds."
With or without additional public financing, the Bridgeport tourism industry faces a daunting battle.
Even with the Days Hotel's closing and a recent 50-percent rate cut to $49 a night, the Bridgeport Hilton's occupancy rate of just over 40 percent is likely to edge upward only slightly, said William McGarry, the hotel's general manager. The 229-room hotel needs an occupancy rate of about 65 percent to break even, he said.
"There will be no windfall for us," he said of the closing of the nearby Days Hotel. "We hope to get some of their loss. But their closing is not something to be happy about."
Asked who stays in his hotel or stayed in the Days Hotel, Mr. McGarry said that a sizable proportion of the guests are just "people driving through on I-95 between New York and Boston." He said that Bridgeport's principal tourist draw is the jai alai fronton, which has attracted gamblers and is being converted into a greyhound racing track.
The Days Hotel, which charged $39 a night, only filled about one-third of its rooms, Mr. McGarry said. It owes $680,000 in taxes to Bridgeport, which wants to foreclose on the property but has been blocked because the hotel's franchiser, Days Inns of America, filed for bankruptcy protection in September, said John Blank, a lawyer for the city.
Further complicating the story is the tangle of players involved with the hotel. The building is owned by Route 347 Realty, a company based in Port Jefferson, L.I., which bought it from Days Inns of America, and the hotel was managed by a company called Buckhead Inc., said Timothy Shea, a lawyer for Route 347.
In the hotel's desolate parking lot, two Owl Security guards who refused to be identified or to tell who retained their company, said: "We're only here to secure the business."
As for who closed the hotel, putting 31 employees out of work, Mr. Shea said it was not Route 347. Nor was it Days Inns, said a company spokeswoman.
Even Ms. Farrel said the closing was "a bit of a puzzlement to me." But ever the optimist, she added: "It's an extraordinarily appealing property."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Solid Rally Raises Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Government securities market turned in its strongest performance in weeks yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds posted solid gains and interest rates fell.
Dealers said a highly successful auction of new five-year Treasury notes was the main catalyst for the rally. 
 The securities were sold at an average yield of 6.75 percent, up from the 6.28 percent average at the last five-year note sale on Jan. 23. At the higher yield levels, demand for the new notes was strong.
 
Termed Best Auction
 "It was the best auction we have had this year," one bond trader said.
The securities traded well after the results of the auction were announced, and by late yesterday the notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.66 percent.
The auction was the last in a stretch of note and bond sales that began early this month with the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.
Coping with the huge inflow of new Treasury issues has put downward pressure on prices, as dealers have been forced to offer securities at higher yields in order to drum up demand.
But for the next month supply should not be a problem, dealers said, because the Treasury is not expected to sell anything other than short-term bills until the next two-year and five-year note sales in late March.
In addition to the good auction results, market participants said an article in The Washington Post yesterday also helped prices.
The article said that a deadlock in Congress over a fiscal stimulus package seemed increasingly likely.
"The possibility that the tax package will fall apart is one the market will embrace very strongly," the trader said. "Fear of what might come out of Washington has been a big reason why rates have been backing up for the last six weeks or so."
 
Market Called Cheap
 Analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, noted in their daily market commentary that "without the threat of a potentially inflationary, deficit-ballooning fiscal plan to worry about, this market looks very cheap at current levels."
Traders said that demand was strong for all types of fixed-income securities. But analysts cautioned against reading too much into the market's performance.
"There has been a two-month downtrend, and we are clearly not out of the woods yet," said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago.
"But it strikes me that with the inflation outlook as good as it is, a long-term investor can still take a shot in owning bonds."
Bond prices posted the biggest advance in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
By late in the session, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10125/32 , up more than 1 1/8 points, to yield 7.84 percent, compared with 7.94 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues outstanding, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 1/4, up 7/8 point, to yield 7.31 percent. The 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 9623/32 , up 17/32, to yield 6.98 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes auctioned on Tuesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.34 percent.
 
Rates Move Lower
 Short-term Treasury bill rates moved sharply lower.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.92 percent, down 10 basis points, or 10 one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by eight basis points, to a late offered rate of 4 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 10 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.15 percent.
Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a number of utility company financings.
Among the issuers was Duke Power, which sold a total of $275 million worth of first mortgage bonds at three maturities through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
Thirty-year bonds offered as part of the package were priced to yield 8.66 percent. Twelve-year securities were priced to yield 8.082 percent and seven-year bonds were priced to yield 7.533 percent.
All parts of the issue are noncallable for life. The securities are rated AA-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
New York City Offer
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Metropolitan Transporation Authority in New York City offered $250.58 million worth of securities through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.
Serial bonds offered in the financing carry yields from 4.85 percent on securities maturing in 1996 to 6.45 percent on bonds maturing in 2007.
Term bonds with maturities of 2010, 2018 and 2022 were also sold with yields of 6.55 percent, 6.62 percent and 6.58 percent, respectively.
The issue is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, and is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
The big rally in the Treasury securities market helped prices of outstanding investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt bonds.
Corporate traders said that prices of most issues rose by 1/2 point to 3/4 point in very active trading.
Participants in the municipal bond market said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/2 point.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Backed for Another Term

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Despite the complaints of many senators that the Federal Reserve had moved too slowly to end the recession, the Senate Banking Committee voted overwhelmingly today to confirm Alan Greenspan to a second four-year term as chairman of the central bank.
The vote was 20 to 1, with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, casting the vote against. 
 "I have been continually asking the Fed to lower rates," Mr. D'Amato told reporters as senators entered the committee's hearing room to cast their votes. "They should have been lowered long ago. There has been a lot of unnecessary pain."
Mr. D'Amato said that while the Fed had cut interest rates, though less aggressively than he would have liked, the central bank had failed to end the tight credit situation in which banks have been reluctant to lend.
"The intended result, to make credit available, has not happened," Mr. D'Amato said. "That has been failure by the regulators and the Federal Reserve. This is my way of sending a message."
The full Senate still has to vote on reconfirming Mr. Greenspan, and committee officials said no date had yet been set for the vote.
Today's Senate Banking Committee vote was also to confirm the Fed chairman to his first full 14-year term on the Federal Reserve Board.
On Tuesday, Mr. Greenspan told the committee that the Fed's interest rate cuts were starting to work and that a recovery should begin in the second quarter.
The Banking Committee's chairman, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, voted to confirm Mr. Greenspan. When the Fed chairman testified before the committee Tuesday, Mr. Riegle said regarding Mr. Greenspan's reconfirmation: "If there were a public referendum," the people "might well vote you out, deservedly or not, and the Fed out because they don't see the policies working. Our obligation is to have policies that work, not policies that might work or policies that, you know, given enough time and patience, have the chance of working."

HEADLINE: Wal-Mart Has Record Year; Neiman Marcus Profit Slips

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Defying the recessionary downturn that has plagued most other retailers, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the discount giant that is now the nation's largest retailer, yesterday posted record sales and profits for the 1991 fiscal year after ending the year with a quarterly earnings gain of 25 percent.
Profits for the year that ended Jan. 31 were up nearly 25 percent on a 35 percent sales gain. Much of the sales increase came as a natural result of the rapid growth of the chain, which added 207 stores in the year. But even considering only stores that had been open a year or more, Wal-Mart sales rose 10 percent for the year and 9 percent for the crucial fourth quarter. 
 At the other end of the retailing spectrum, the Neiman Marcus Group, the specialty retailer, posted slightly higher sales but lower profits for its second fiscal quarter, indicating a lackluster holiday season.
 
Wal-Mart
 For the fiscal year, Wal-Mart earned $1.61 billion, or $1.40 a share, compared with $1.29 billion, or $1.14 a share, in the 1990 fiscal year. Sales rose to $43.9 billion from $32.6 billion.
Profits for the year's final quarter, which included the holiday selling season, were $602.4 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $481.8 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 30.8 percent, to $13.6 billion from $10.4 billion.
The strong results came as little surprise to industry analysts, because Wal-Mart's sales have increased an average of 32 percent a year since 1985.
"It's a company that continues to be on the go," said Walter Loeb of Loeb Associates. He predicted Wal-Mart would have "a very strong year in 1992."
He pointed out that Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., was just beginning to move into the heavily populated New York metropolitan region with stores in New Jersey and Connecticut.
In addition, the retailer has turned its attention to the high-volume, low-margin grocery business with the introduction of Supercenter stores.
Wal-Mart "will gain share of market from other retailers," Mr. Loeb said. "That's, of course, very exciting for the company but very disturbing for the rest of the industry."
Wal-Mart stock rose $2.375 a share yesterday, to $53.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
While the billionaire founder Sam Walton, 73 years old, is battling a form of bone cancer, Wal-Mart executives have no plans to slow the pace of growth. The company plans to open another 160 Wal-Mart stores, adding Idaho, Washington and Oregon to the 42 states where the chain already operates, a spokeswoman said.
 
Neiman Marcus
 At Neiman Marcus, earnings fell 20.8 percent, to $11.4 million, or 12 cents a share, in the quarter that ended Feb. 1, compared with $14.4 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose slightly, to $541.2 million from $539.4 million.
The company's president and chief executive officer, Robert Tarr, said that mail-order operations showed some strength, but he was cautious about prospects for a spring upturn.

HEADLINE: In the House, Taxes and Posturing

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The election campaign came to the floor of the House of Representatives today as both parties used their tax bills to argue about who cared most about the middle class and who wanted to stimulate economic growth.
Republicans argued for President Bush's short-term agenda, featuring a reduction of taxes on capital gains to 15.4 percent from 28, as a measure that would produce more jobs. "It will put Americans back to work and preserve the jobs of Americans already working," said Representative Bill Archer of Texas. 
 Democrats maintained that their bill, with a tax credit of up to $400 a year for working couples, was essential to make the tax code fairer and help the middle class. "Vote for the working men and women of this country," maintained Representative Butler Derrick of South Carolina.
 
Back and Forth
 Each side spent at least as much energy attacking the other proposal as defending its own.
Republicans said the tax increases in the Democratic bill would retard or prevent economic recovery.
"Democrats destroy jobs," said Representative Robert S. Walker, Republican of Pennsylvania. The second- ranking House Republican, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said Democrats were hoping the recession could be prolonged so their candidates could prosper.
Democrats argued that the Republicans only wanted to help the rich and were foolish to think that cutting their taxes would lead them to create jobs.
"The President tells the middle class to wait for the trickle-down to start," said Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee. But, he said, "after a full decade of waiting, they're not even damp."
 
Senate Action Tuesday
 Today was the day for debate, largely political and only incidentally economic, and no important votes were scheduled to be held before Thursday. Mr. Bush's plan is sure to be defeated and the Democratic alternative is very likely to be adopted.
The Senate Finance Committee is scheduled to begin trying to write a bill of its own next Tuesday. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Denmocrat who heads that committee, said today that he would seek to raise individual income taxes, though not as much as the House bill does, to pay for a tax credit for children.
Because President Bush has insisted he will veto any bill that includes an increase in tax rates, and the Democrats have made that a price for a change in capital gains taxes, there is doubt on Capitol Hill that any new tax provisions will become law this year.
But before the question of whether a bill will become law is joined, the House has to finish with the measure. Democrats expect to pass it, although they have to contend with attacks from their own ranks that their capital gains proposal goes too far in helping the rich, and by others who say both bills are political stunts.
"Either one is certain to make things worse in the long run," contended Representative Anthony C. Beilenson, Democrat of California. And Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, commented, "Pollsters wrote these bills, not businessmen or economists."
 
A Gephardt Proposal
 The only vote taken today came on a political stunt, a version of President Bush's overall tax proposal introduced by the Democratic floor leader, Reprsentative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.
The Gephardt bill omitted the spending cuts in areas like Medicare and tax increases on such difficult areas as annuities, which Mr. Bush had proposed to pay for changes like an increase in tax exemptions for children. He introduced it to show that hardly anyone would back the sum of Mr. Bush's proposals, and the House made his point today, voting the bill down 427 to 1.
The political point of the Democratic measure was underscored today when the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee announced that it was going to start running television ads advocating its middle class tax cut in states with Presidential primaries coming up in the next few weeks.
The ads show men in tuxedos, more or less passed out, while a voice proclaims: "In the 1980's, Republicans threw a big party. Only the rich were invited."

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Rose by 1.5% in January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Orders to factories for durable goods rose 1.5 percent in January, the Government said today. The report was seen as a fresh evidence that the once-stalled economic recovery may be starting to pick up.
Analysts also pointed to the recent increases in retail sales, including automobiles, and growing housing activity as other signs of an improving economy. 
 "We're now starting to see the resumption of the recovery, which may have started in the spring a year ago and stalled out in the fall," said Lynn Reaser, an economist with the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
"We're seeing the first glimmers of a revival in January," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. "It's another tentative sign of an improved economic outlook in 1992."
 
'Robins on the Lawn'
 The Bush Administration also hailed the January increase as one of several indicators pointing to an economic rebound.
"I see robins on the lawn in the economy now," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in a speech to the National Association of Business Economists.
Mr. Brady cited increased purchases of tires and light bulbs as signs that spending was picking up.
"I went out last weekend and bought two new tires," he said, adding that many Americans likely would do the same because they had put off such purchases and now, "this country's tires are bald."
But many analysts caution that economic growth will be below average and will not result in any substantive improvement in employment for months.
Orders for durable goods -- usually expensive items like cars and computers expected to last more than three years -- totaled a seasonally adjusted $119.6 billion in January, according to the Commerce Department.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve board, Alan Greenspan, told Congress last week that the Fed had seen signs that orders continued to rise in early February.
They had plunged 5.1 percent in December after gains of six-tenths of 1 percent in November and 2.7 percent in October.
Ms. Reaser of First Interstate said the new gains in orders should "prompt a bit of a turnaround on the production front in the next several months." She added, "It's the kind of ammunition we need for a recovery in the spring."
 
Looking to Consumers
 But Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley said he placed "a lot more credence" in automobile and other retail sales because they measure what consumers are doing rather than what they are saying. Consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and is considered necessary to sustain any recovery.
The January orders advance was led by gains of 6.3 percent for industrial machinery and equipment and 1.2 percent for transportation equipment. Excluding the transportation sector, orders were up 1.6 percent.
Analysts were particularly impressed by a 4.3 percent gain in non-military capital goods orders excluding aircraft. With aircraft included, the gain was 9.1 percent.
"This indicates an emerging recovery in equipment investment," contended Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers.
Often-volatile military orders plummeted 21 percent. Excluding this category, which represents about 7 percent of the total, orders rose 3.6 percent.
Shipments of durable goods, a measure of current production, increased 1.1 percent. It was the ninth increase in the last 10 months. But unfilled orders slipped three-tenths of 1 percent, the fifth consecutive decline. These orders measure whether plants and manpower are able to keep up with demand.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Wells Fargo Debt Rating Cut

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Moody's has downgraded nearly all the debt of Wells Fargo & Company, voicing concerns about the bank's commercial real estate loan portfolio.
The action by Moody's Investor Services Inc. on Tuesday came only weeks after San Francisco-based Wells Fargo added $700 million to its reserves for losses against bad loans. 
 It was also the latest in a series of downgrades for California's third-largest bank since the spring of 1990. Wells Fargo has a higher proportion of real estate and construction loans than many leading institutions and has been hit hard by the recession.
Moody's reduced its rating of Wells Fargo's long-term senior debt to Baa-1, a mediocre rating, from single A-2, an investment grade rating. Moody's highest bond rating is Aaa; the lowest is C. The agency also downgraded the bank's commercial paper, or short-term debt, to prime-2, the middle of three grades, from prime-1.
The action affects about $4 billion of the bank's $4.2 billion in debt and could make it more expensive for the bank to borrow.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Tambrands Official Promoted to President

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
Tambrands Inc. announced yesterday that Charles J. Chapman had been promoted to president and chief operating officer of the company, which specializes in personal-care products like Tampax tampons.
Mr. Chapman, who was also elected to the board, will be responsible for Tambrands' worldwide operations. The company, based in White Plains, does business in 135 countries. Previously he had been executive vice president, in charge of Tambrands' business in North and South America. 
 "Charlie Chapman is a strong, hands-on operating executive," said Martin F. C. Emmett, chairman and chief executive. "He has proven his ability to increase profits in our established markets and to establish sound businesses in our developing markets."
Tambrands, the leading producer of feminine-hygiene products, holds 60 percent of the domestic market for tampons. Sales last year were $660.7 million, compared with $631.5 million in 1990. In recent years the company has sold two of its businesses -- the First Response brand of home pregnancy tests and Physicians' Formula, a hypo-allergenic makeup line -- in the company's efforts to concentrate on its core business. Aside from tampons, Tambrands also sells disposable diapers and other infant-care products in a limited number of markets.
Mr. Chapman, who is 53 years old, has extensive experience in consumer products. Before joining Tambrands in 1989 he spent most of his career as a marketing and general-management executive at Chesebrough-Pond's, and at RJR Nabisco, where he was president of Nabisco Brands North America.
He received a bachelor of arts degree in economics from Dartmouth College and an M.B.A. in marketing from the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration.
Mr. Chapman lives in Weston, Conn., with his wife, Kristin.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines in the U.S.; Gold Prices Mostly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined on profit taking in domestic trading yesterday after posting gains overseas.
Gold prices were mostly lower worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $349.60 an ounce, off 20 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold was unchanged at a late bid price of $349.50 an ounce. 
 The dollar advanced in foreign trading overnight, building on its impressive move upward in the previous session. But analysts said it had begun to falter slightly when the Malaysian central bank stepped in and sold dollars for German marks.
The move was considered speculative rather than an attempt to influence the direction of trading, said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
When activity shifted to domestic markets, the dollar was initially supported by a Commerce Department report showing orders to United States factories for durable goods rose 1.5 percent in January. The report represented a rebound from the biggest drop in more than a year just a month earlier.
But the dollar failed to sustain any advance, and traders quickly stepped in to take profits.
"There might be a slight change of sentiment that the dollar can't go higher, and traders might be looking to test the downside," said Bob Morrissey, a senior dealer at the Bank of Boston.
Trading was moderate.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.73 yen, up 0.41 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 129.70 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 129.20 yen, down from 129.90 yen on Tuesday..
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7460, from $1.7560 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.7550 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.7380.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, include: 1.6453 German marks, down from 1.6595; 1.4935 Swiss francs, down from 1.5065; 5.5920 French francs, down from 5.6410; 1,234.75 Italian lire, down from 1,245.25, and 1.1789 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1860.

HEADLINE: GlenFed Uncertain on Profit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 26

 BODY:
GlenFed Inc. said today that it might fail to post a third-quarter profit and likely would not be able to meet Federal standards for financial soundness.
GlenFed, which lost $232 million last year, blamed the same factors battering many other California savings and loans for its problems: the recession and the lingering slump in the real estate market. 
 Despite help from accounting changes, the parent of the Glendale Federal Bank said in a statement that profitability for the quarter ending March 31 is "in question."
Further, the company said it was "unlikely" the bank would be able to meet the new, more stringent Federal requirements for capital reserve, which is the cash cushion against losses.
If GlenFed fails to meet the new standard, it could be required to submit a capital plan to regulators or consent to other regulatory action.
GlenFed, however, took advantage of newly approved accounting techniques, allowing it to meet Federal capital requirements as of the end of 1991. The new rules also allowed GlenFed to restate its second-quarter earnings from $20.5 million to $27.6 million.
GlenFed has 214 bank offices in California, Florida and Washington state. Its shares lost $1.875 each on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $7.125

HEADLINE: Newark Unveils Arts Center Design

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The architectural design for the first phase of a proposed $200 million arts complex near Newark's central business district was made public today by the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
The first building of the complex, an ambitious Lincoln Center-like arts plaza that is intended to stimulate growth in Newark's downtown area, includes a 2,700-seat multi-purpose theater, a 500-seat hall for repertory, concerts and lectures, two restaurants, banquet rooms and a gift shop. At the center of the complex will be a new public plaza called Theater Square. The comprehensive master plan for the arts complex, in preparation for more than a year, was designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and James Stewart Polshek & Partners. 
 The design represents the first major East Coast performance hall to be built in more than 30 years. Lawrence P. Goldman, president of the arts center, said at a press conference at the Newark Museum that the objective behind the project was to "take New Jersey and the City of Newark and stand them shoulder to shoulder with Kennedy Center in Washington and Lincoln Center in New York and say we are equal partners in this cultural mission on the East Coast."
Barton Myers, the Los Angeles architect appointed in 1990 to create the design, said that his mandate had been to create a facility that was an elegant and beautiful "beacon on the city." The design's focal point is a brightly lighted grand rotunda that dominates the intersection of Center Street and Park Place. Its terra cotta and glass facade will rise 85 feet above the street, with an extended canopy to protect theatergoers in bad weather. The architect describes the concept as a "small village of separate structures in keeping with the scale of the 18th- and 19th-century fabric of Newark."
The design is also intended to convey a feeling of festiveness and drama, with banners hanging from the facade and a warm glow of interior lights shining through expanses of glass. Stone and patterned brick were chosen to lend the building a sense of permanence amid the surrounding cityscape.
"We were looking for a building that was really about excitement, coming together, festivity in the performance arts, a building that expressed that," said Mr. Myers, as he showed slides of his design in the art museum's auditorium.
 
Two Deadlines
 For the first phase of development, which is scheduled for completion in 1995, $140 million will be needed. Half of that sum is for the multi-use hall; the other half is for site work, including the construction of the plaza and the refurbishing of an existing 1,100-space parking garage. The second phase of the plan, construction of the concert hall, is budgeted at $60 million and scheduled for completion in 1998.
Corporate and other donors have pledged $45 million so far. The Federal Government has committed $1.2 million for the planning and design of Theater Square, and the State of New Jersey has sold $21.5 million in bonds through the Economic Development Authority to pay for the acquisition of the 12-acre tract in downtown Newark between Military Park and Route 21 and adjacent to the Passaic River, and for work on the site. Gov. Jim Florio, who attended the press conference along with Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, said he had proposed an additional state commitment of $40 million in his State of the State message last month. He focused on the arts center as a potential stimulus for growth in the state's largest city, which suffered major losses in employment and population over the last several decades but which is undergoing something of a revival.
"People know there are no easy answers for restoring economic opportunity to our state or nation," Governor Florio said. "It takes hard work and it takes something else equally important. It takes common sense and a common purpose. That's what this project is about."
